SECTION: Section 4; Page 19, Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Peace With Japan, Before It's Too Late

BYLINE: By Cyrus R. Vance and William H. Gleysteen Jr.; Cyrus R. Vance, Secretary of State in the Carter Administration, and William H. Gleysteen Jr. are chairman and president, respectively, of the Japan Society.

 BODY:
Are we going to risk letting resentment and emotion, rather than a commonsense understanding of our national interest, govern our critically important relationship with Japan?
The key to combatting this dangerous tide of opinion is the White House, which has the necessary authority to explain a complicated situation to a confused American people. And the need for public understanding remains urgent, despite the recent, welcome agreements to reduce Japanese trade barriers. 
For most of the postwar period, American appreciation of the economic and security benefits of our Japan ties offset the inescapable strains of a major alliance. These strains included our complaints that Japan was taking unfair advantage of the international trading system. This view prevailed even as Japan rose to great power status.
Now, however, that pragmatism is being undermined by ignorance and emotional recrimination. Japan's economic prowess, combined with a fading Soviet threat, has generated a new sense of rivalry and anxiety.
Too many politicians, publicists and others have exacerbated this situation by playing on popular anxieties, arousing fear and anger. The Japanese have reacted with mounting nationalism and frustration. And, most unfortunately, American leaders have done little to counteract these growing tensions and explain the stakes to the American people.
If the world's two greatest economic powers allow this emotional infection to lead to real hostility, both will be the poorer and far less secure.
If Japan adopts a more independent ''Gaullist'' course, it could destablize the regional equilibrium only recently achieved in East Asia. Other countries would become far more uncomfortable about Japanese power and would, more than ever, want us as a buffering force in the Pacific. We, however, would find it difficult, if not impossible, to maintain a forward presence in the Pacific without easy access to Japanese bases.
If naked rivalries suppressed cooperation, the economic consequences would jeopardize the prosperity of both nations. If Americans clearly recognized these dangers, few would want to start down the slippery slope of protectionism and open antagonism in our dealings with Japan.
It is foolish to criticize the Japanese for not being more like ourselves. But one can properly fault them for failing to change policies adopted in earlier years for survival and development. These policies are now as unfair to Japanese consumers as they are to other nations.
Obviously, Japan could help check the growing antagonism by accelerating its movement toward a less regulated society, and taking on substantially greater global responsibilities. Presumably, progress in this direction will require some pressure from abroad. But the decisive factor must be Japanese awareness that the change is in their national interest. And, as we can see from Japanese reaction to the new trade pact, this awareness is developing.
What must be done on this side of the Pacific? First, we must blunt our anti-Japanese rhetoric. Second, Americans need to be told in the most authoritative - and attention-grabbing - way about the full range of interests that are at stake.
Third, we have to put our own house in order. This would include steps to radically reduce our Federal budget deficit, increase our savings rate and lengthen the time horizon against which we measure business success.
There will be occasions when we should use well-timed, well-aimed pressure to accelerate Japan's progress toward liberalization. But in no instance should we resort to the protectionism we wish Japan and others to shed.
If we manage our relations with foresight and restraint, we will find a new glue for the U.S.-Japan alliance. In an era in which economic ties will define the common fate, this relationship must be made to work.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); JAPAN (95%); EASTERN ASIA (79%); ASIA (79%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: ;JAPAN

SUBJECT: UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (77%); PROTECTIONISM (76%); INTERNATIONAL TRADE (74%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (71%); 

PERSON: VANCE, CYRUS R; GLYSTEEN, WILLIAM H JR

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4629 words

HEADLINE: Is It True What He Says About Dixie?

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome: Peter Applebome is chief of The Times's Atlanta bureau.

 BODY:
''GOOD GOD,'' SAID LEWIS GRIZZARD AS HIS 225-pound co-star waddled into a television studio near downtown Atlanta. ''It's a real hog. This is the most bizarre thing I've ever seen. Where'd y'all get that hog? Do hogs bite?'' No answer, certainly none from the year-old sow, which apparently found a pile of graham crackers on a desk where Grizzard is typing more interesting than one of the South's best-read writers. Grizzard watched the hog dine for a moment and then asked in a deep Rhett Butler baritone: ''Didn't we meet recently in a Holiday Inn lounge in Tupelo?''
Grizzard's public image may be the quintessential good old boy, but in real life this is about as country as he gets. A half hour earlier he had snuffed out the last of his Marlboros and climbed into a white stretch limousine donated to the Atlanta Chapter of the American Heart Association for the seven-minute ride from his home in the trendy Ansley Park section to the studio owned by Georgia Power. There he knocked out a quick public-service commercial for the heart association - ''Seven years ago, I had major heart surgery replacing one of my heart valves with one from the first cousin of my good old buddy Porky here'' - left the hog with its keeper and climbed back into the limousine in plenty of time for his daily golf game at the Ansley Golf Club. 
Such is life for Grizzard, most celebrated for his best-selling books of folksy humor and nostalgia, with trademark Grizzardian titles like ''Elvis Is Dead and I Don't Feel So Good Myself'' and ''Don't Bend Over in the Garden, Granny, You Know Them Taters Got Eyes.'' Grizzard, a columnist for The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, may not be a superstar in the Boston-Washington corridor, but he's his own conglomerate elsewhere, with syndication in 450 cities, a hectic round of speaking engagements at $20,000 a pop, and a best-selling book a year (with a total of almost five million copies now in print). To manage it all, he has his own company, Grizzard Enterprises Inc.
In a region where everyone has rural roots, Grizzard (it rhymes with lard, not wizard) may be the South's most conspicuous throwback. He has made a career out of standing up for God and country, Momma and Daddy and biscuits and gravy while at the same time ruminating over his own life, which has been something of a country music cliche of hurtin', hangovers and heartbreak. Still, if Grizzard sings the song of the South, he lives the life of the Sun Belt, a place that knows where it was better than it knows where it is, where issues of race and sex roles are still shadowed by ancient archetypes and where a poor, self-proclaimed ''smart-assed white boy'' in Gucci loafers with no socks from Moreland, Ga., can get everything he dreamed of in life and still end up confused, alienated and alone. Rather than the stories he tells or the columns he writes, the best window on the South may be his own life story - the sad ballad of Lewis Grizzard.
''I THINK I'VE GOT MY PEOPLE HERE,'' Grizzard invariably says when speaking to groups in the South. On the previous evening at a Holiday Inn near the banks of the Chattahoochee River in Atlanta his people were the Homebuilders Association of Memphis in town for the National Homebuilders Association meeting. Grizzard's syndication is increasingly outside the South and he has given speeches in places as alien as the ritzy hotel Pierre in New York. But most of his audiences are like this one, all-white Southern conventions or business groups. They're people who live in cities but remember growing up in small towns or cities that felt like them. They're people who share the same icons of college football coaches and country music stars, who roar when Grizzard talks about being held prisoner of war in Chicago for three years, who figure the joke's benign if he asks, ''How many Baptists we got here? How many Methodists? How many gays?''
Sometimes, rarely, the humor touches on race, the omnipresent dividing line in the new South as much as the old. No one in the room needs to ask whom he's referring to, for instance, when he talks about muggers and the Atlanta subway system.
''We've got lots of people from the North in Atlanta,'' he says. ''We didn't need a subway, but we built one anyway to make them feel at home. The other problem was that the muggers kind of all got stuck downtown, but we put in this subway so the muggers could go all over the metropolitan area and rob people. I really miss Andy Young, our Mayor who just went out of office. Andy ran Atlanta not from a municipal approach but a global approach. The big one he never, pulled off: get this, he was trying to get nonstop air service from Hartsfield Airport to Lagos, Nigeria, so those of us who buzzed off to Lagos for a weekend wouldn't have to change planes at Chattanooga.''
But more often, the subject is the fading culture of the South. At 43, Grizzard has the lanky look of a high-school athlete settling into middle age, who dresses each day like a golfer on his way to the first tee, in knit shirts reading ''The Crosby'' or ''Melrose,'' a country club and resort. But his thick glasses and bushy mustache give him a more serious appearance than his public persona might suggest. In private, he can be awkward and insular. He usually avoids a questioner's gaze, and he times his public appearances to minimize encounters with his fans.
But on stage, he seems blissfully at ease and in control. Grizzard is a marvelous storyteller, who knows how to use every second of silence and every twist and turn of his Georgia drawl to perfect effect.
''Yankees think we talk funny,'' he says. ''God talks like we do. Yankees don't understand that the Southern way of talking is a language of nuance. What we can do in the South is we can take a word and change it just a little bit and make it mean something altogether different. Take the word 'naked.' It means you ain't got no clothes on. Sometimes 'naked' just won't do. You need something a little bit stronger. So we change the word just a little bit. We say 'nekkid.' 'Naked' means you ain't got no clothes on. 'Nekkid' means you ain't got no clothes on and you're up to something. 'Darlene was nekkid.' [Laughter.] Sounds like you know Darlene.''
Most of the listeners know the stories by heart - Grizzard has been using much of the same material since he began appearing before audiences in the late 70's. They've heard about the service station offering free sex with a fill-up. They've heard about his heart surgery and read about it in his book ''They Tore Out My Heart and Stomped That Sucker Flat.'' And enough people have heard his most famous story, the tale of Bubba and Earl and Uga, the beloved but indiscreet white English bulldog mascot of the University of Georgia, that it's hard for Grizzard to go out in public whether in Atlanta or Eretria, Greece, without some voice booming out in the most exaggerated South Georgia drawl, ''That dog would biiiiiite youuuuuuuuu.'' That line is to Lewis Grizzard what ''Whole Lotta Love'' is to Led Zeppelin.
Like a Borscht Belt comedian's, Grizzard's stories serve as more than entertainment - they evoke a shared culture. To his admirers, Grizzard is one of the last, great unvarnished voices of the South, harking back to simpler values and easier times. ''I have all his books,'' says Bobbi Gillis, who is married to a Memphis home builder. ''I love the story he tells about people who come to the South. He says, 'They eat our food, they marry our women, and then they want to tell us how they did things back in Cleveland.' One of his greatest lines ever is, 'Tell you what folks, Delta's ready when you are.' ''
To his detractors, Grizzard is something quite different. Pat Conroy, the Southern novelist who wrote ''The Great Santini,'' lambastes Grizzard mercilessly. Conroy once wrote him saying, ''Your South is the one I loathe, Lewis.'' Dudley Clendinen, the former features editor of The Journal and Constitution, while acknowledging Grizzard's popularity, says: ''I find him odious. I resent the narrow lens Lewis puts on being Southern. The South has both a more interesting past and a more interesting future than you could guess by reading Lewis Grizzard. I think he's racist, sexist, homophobic and xenophobic, suspicious of anything that's different from himself.''
IF LEWIS GRIZZARD has any secrets left, it's hard to imagine what they could be. Local newspaper columnists end up being ravenous scavengers, scrounging for any morsel from their life to turn into column fodder, then needing another one a day later. ''Someone once said writing a daily column is like being married to a nymphomaniac,'' Grizzard says. ''The first two weeks is fun.''
But Grizzard has taken confessional literature as far as it can go. His readers know everything about his alcoholic father, who died in 1970, and his long-suffering mother, who died last year. They know the gory details of his two heart operations and his three divorces. In fact, Grizzard's whole career has become a marvel of recycling. He reuses most of the material in his column, in his books - 11 so far - and then recycles most of the same stuff in his audiotapes (four) and videotapes (two) of his concerts, so dedicated Grizzardologists can come upon the same joke in at least four media. If they want a second opinion, there's always his third wife Kathy Grizzard Schmook's book, ''How to Tame a Wild Bore & Other Facts of Life With Lewis - The Semi-True Confessions of the Third Mrs. Grizzard.'' The Grizzard soap opera is so well known that for a while Atlanta's freeways were dotted with bumper stickers reading: ''Honk if You've Been Married to Lewis Grizzard.''
Grizzard was born in Fort Benning, Ga., in 1946, the only child of Army Lieut. Lewis Grizzard Sr. and Christine Grizzard. His father, who was decorated in World War II and Korea, was an alcoholic who left his family when his son was 6. A great storyteller and wit, who like his son had three unsuccessful marriages, Lewis Sr. spent his life going from job to job, amiably conning people out of money. Until his death, his relationship with his son was a heartbreaking tease in which he periodically popped into his life, raised his hopes and then had to be rescued by him from a drunken stupor in one or another seedy motel.
Grizzard is the kind of writer who scores better with readers than critics, and most of his books are so fluffy and ephemeral as to float away. But his book on his father, ''My Daddy Was a Pistol and I'm a Son of a Gun,'' despite the cheery title is a harrowing account of the ties that choke as well as bind, a George Jones crying song elevated to art. ''Don't hate me'' his father invariably said, upon blinking into consciousness after a long drunk, and Grizzard can neither hate him nor fully come to grips with what the relationship did to him. Most of his best friends voice fears that Grizzard's life is defined by a self-destructive need to emulate his father's virtues and vices.
He was raised by his mother and her relatives in Moreland, Ga., a small town about 45 miles southwest of Atlanta, which also gave the world the novelist Erskine Caldwell, best known for Depression-era novels about the South, like ''Tobacco Road.'' Smart, industrious and ambitious, Grizzard worked as sports editor of the local newspaper while attending the University of Georgia. The Atlanta Journal hired him right out of college, and he was made executive sports editor at the age of 23. He later became sports editor of The Chicago Sun-Times before returning to Atlanta to write a column.
The timing was perfect. Grizzard hated Chicago - ''It has two seasons. Winter and the Fourth of July.'' He was coming off divorce No. 2 and was burnt out by assorted unpleasantnesses there, including a successful discrimination suit against the paper filed by a black sportswriter who had been dismissed after being demoted by Grizzard. At the same time, Jimmy Carter had come to the White House and the mood of the times was ripe for a new Southern voice. Nothing if not a shrewd marketer, Grizzard churned out odes to beer joints, Georgia football, Southern women and his hometown, excoriated feminists and homosexuals and became an instant sensation.
Before long came books, records, wife No. 3, two heart surgeries, divorce No. 3 and more money than Grizzard ever expected to make in his life. He became, quite unconsciously, the dividing line between the mythic South of old and a more inclusive New South made possible by the economic and social gains of the past three decades - an icon to legions of dedicated fans, an embarrassment to some corporate types tired of the South's good-old-boy image, a reactionary mossback to blacks, feminists and liberals.
It all came to a boil when old and new collided during the tenure of Bill Kovach as editor of The Journal and Constitution; the former New York Times editor came to Atlanta in 1986 intent on turning The Journal and Constitution upside down and making it ''a world-class newspaper.'' Grizzard's buddies, including the paper's former editor, Jim Minter, who hired Grizzard three times and was as close to a father figure as he's had, were soon gone. Grizzard quit too, then quickly came back, but he always figured the new regime would have been just as happy to see him go, too. Kovach says he never tried to run Grizzard off, but when asked about Grizzard's column says: ''I don't like it. I don't believe in using the space in a newspaper to belittle people, especially those least able to represent their own interests.''
When Kovach himself was forced out, Grizzard reacted to the wailing of the Kovach partisans with an advertisement he considered running, saying: ''I think I can assure all our readers that The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution can survive the recent resignation of the tempestuous Mr. Kovach. In fact, we might even benefit from his departure, with apologies to those who enjoy reading exhaustive series on what's doing in Africa.''
The ad never ran, but copies circulated anyway, and there are those who have never forgiven him for it. In a widely published open letter to Grizzard, Pat Conroy wrote: ''Because I am too a redneck, I want to translate for all your readers and for the Cox chains what you meant by the line 'with apologies to those who enjoy reading exhaustive series on what's doing in Africa.' Let me translate this in our shared Southern vernacular. You wrote it in code but the translation is this: Atlanta doesn't care if niggers starve. It is the word, 'nigger,' Lewis, that subliminally disfigures your work and cheapens your worth as a man.''
Conroy has hacked away at Grizzard ever since like a fighter pumping hard, straight jabs at the head of an opponent sprawled on the ropes. A screenplay he's writing on the Kovach affair features a buffoonish good-old-boy character whose identity will be clear to anyone in Atlanta.
Grizzard, for whatever reason, has never hit back. ''I don't know why the guy hates me, I really don't,'' he says. ''To tell you the truth, I think he's a great writer. I love his fiction. I love 'The Great Santini.' I've read 'The Lords of Discipline.' But I'll tell you what. When a major American novelist has any sort of opinion about me it's pretty impressive. A lot of people go their whole lives without a brilliant American novelist even thinking about them.''
In a region where manners still mean at least as much as substance, Grizzard's aw-shucks, slightly sarcastic nonresponse probably plays better than Conroy's tirades. And Conroy is regarded as such a passionate, hyperbolic character that perhaps Grizzard doesn't worry about his salvos. But, for someone who's worked so hard to achieve so much, there's something sad in Grizzard's all-purpose response to criticism: I get paid to turn 'em out and get a reaction, folks. Don't take it too seriously. ''Hey, I never said I was any good,'' he says. ''I just write the books and people buy 'em.''
MY MOTHER MADE no real distinction in being Southern and her belief in life after death. There was a seamlessness to her life and she appeared to be a woman of absolutes. She thought that being Southern was a state of unearned grace and proof of a loving God in the universe.''
The sentences sound like something Lewis Grizzard could have written, but he didn't. Pat Conroy did. They speak to the ferocious pull that the South has on those who call it home. For Conroy it plays out in raging torrents of pain, love and conflict, pitting old attitudes on race, sex and class against changing times. It's the conflict that has made the South the source of so much of the nation's great literature. Grizzard is selling something much simpler but perhaps even more popular - the South as nostalgia, a modern version of the mythology as old as the Civil War, about the South as God's happy, homogeneous chosen land. His fans often sound like Conroy's mother. ''I know God blessed me by allowing me to be born in the South,'' a fan wrote him in January. ''When I was exiled from the South, your books and tapes kept me close to the land that I love.''
Grizzard does not write solely about the South. In fact, as his column has become more widely circulated, it has lost much of its regional character. But the South symbolizes the small-town values he champions, and the South still defines who he is and how he's perceived. In truth, Grizzard is not nearly so simple as either his fans or detractors would like. If he's conservative on most things, he's harder to typecast on others: he's adamantly for abortion rights and gun control, for instance. But, for the most part he enjoys playing professional throwback, inhabiting a world where homosexuals are ''fruit flies,'' women are either goddesses or ''sweathogs,'' and blacks are, for the most part, invisible.
One of his columns last year found Grizzard at a University of Mississippi-University of Georgia football game in Oxford, Miss. The band played ''Dixie.'' The Mississippi partisans waved Confederate flags. The people in front of him were drinking Jim Beam. Grizzard was in heaven: ''All of this prompted my friend Bugar Seely, a veteran Georgia fan, to say, 'They still wave the flag, still sing ''Dixie,'' they can still pray and they can still bring liquor into the game. No wonder they beat us.''
GRIZZARD'S SHTICK IS that he's the ultimate confused man, trying to live by old values in a changing world. In fact, his life and values have little to do with the life he pines for. But the confusion he represents taps into something powerful and pervasive, particularly in the South, and it puts Grizzard atop a cultural fault line.
In the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture, Charles Reagan Wilson, a University of Mississippi professor, wrote: ''Grizzard embodies the traditional Southern white male's confrontation with modern America.'' In an interview Wilson added: ''The South is in a transition period in terms of culture where the older values and symbols are still around in conflict with new symbols and new ways. There's a struggle going on for the South's public culture and Grizzard is right at the center of it.''
To Grizzard and his partisans, there's something dispiriting in the degree to which the turf he inhabits is charged territory. In some ways, it's a fair gripe. At a time when any stray comment deemed racially insensitive can cost someone a career, that sensitivity can be magnified when the writer is a white Southerner extolling the South.
''What I want to know is what is it about the goddamn South?'' Grizzard asks. ''No one says, so and so, a famous Iowa writer. But it's always 'The South.' Hey, we got paved roads. In Atlanta, it so happens, a lot of the politicians are black. But if I write a negative column, it's so easy to say, here's a white guy writing ugly about the black mayor. Must be the white guy's a racist.'' Grizzard's former editor Jim Minter adds: ''Unless any Southerner in the newspaper business is willing to be totally contrite about being a Southerner, many people are going to find traces of racism in what he writes, and what he does and perhaps what he is.''
Others might say Grizzard draws so much flak not because he writes about the South, but because his vision of the South seems to exclude so much. Kovach, for example, said he found it galling that a paper that once spoke to the best instincts of the South through the columns of former editor Ralph McGill, now has Grizzard as its dominant voice. But whatever the case, the South Grizzard celebrates is easier to find in his books than his life.
GRIZZARD AND I ARE in Moreland, his hometown, driving around in my car like two invisible spies. Grizzard's tour is mostly more recycling of stories from his books - the baseball field where he unsuccessfully tried to woo wife No. 1 back one depressing Christmas Eve after she left him, the barn where he and Mike Murphy shot rats with .22's, the vacant lot where Steve Smith's truck stop used to be.
Except for the Delta Air Lines pilots buying up surrounding land for rambling new brick houses, Moreland is now pretty much what it was then - a patch of red clay and simple frame buildings from which the fortunate escaped as soon as they got the chance. The only thing new in town is the cameo picture of his mother on her grave. He sees the picture for the first time when we visit the town cemetery. It brings to mind his Christmas column last year, which recounted memorable Christmases, many of them depressing, and concluded: ''This Christmas all I could give her was a new headstone for her grave. Hers is the sweetest memory I will ever know.''
Nostalgia for the rural South is a grand Southern tradition. The intellectuals who made up the Vanderbilt Agrarians in the 30's promulgated their famous manifesto, ''I'll Take My Stand,'' in defense of the South's rural traditions. But the country folks have been steadily migrating to the city ever since. Similarly, Grizzard is no more likely to move back to Moreland than he is to Moscow.
''I used to have to drag him down there,'' says Kathy Schmook, his third wife. ''Going to Moreland was like going to his death.'' In fact, one of the odd things about Southern nostalgia is that despite its pull, it is nostalgia for a time few people really want to go back to. Jimmy Breslin may yearn for a simpler, safer, less yuppified, more democratic New York. Mike Royko would prefer an earlier Chicago of vibrant Polish and Italian ethnic enclaves. The homogeneity that so many Southerners pine for is gone, but in most way these are the good old days.
Grizzard may write about the old days in Moreland, but he lives like the quintessential arriviste. He resides in Atlanta's trendiest in-town neighborhood and hangs out at one of its oldest all-white country clubs. He may say on one of his tapes that he's a patriot who wouldn't buy a car from any country we've fought a war against or write in ''Elvis Is Dead'' that ''the only materials we really need to import from foreign countries, in my way of thinking, are porno movies.'' But, in fact, the car in his driveway is a Mercedes, he wears Italian shoes and drinks Stolichnaya vodka.
He may rhapsodize about the old churchgoing South of stable families and simple values but, as he says, he doesn't darken the doors of churches very often. After three bad marriages he seems disinclined to try a fourth, and everyone who knows him worries that he's smoking and drinking himself into a slow death. With no family left, Grizzard's biggest passion is University of Georgia football and the tailgate parties and camaraderie that go along with it. Even his column over time has become flattened out, far less likely to offend than it once did.
''Lewis is the loneliest man in the world,'' says Kathy Schmook. ''He has always felt he would die like his father, young and penniless. Lewis is now constant shtick, and there's very little of the man I knew left. I don't know what Lewis represents anymore. He's like a great big plastic fast-food box that sells really well, but I don't know what's inside it anymore.''
IT DIDN'T BREAK AN inch. It stayed dead straight,'' Grizzard grimaces as he watches his putt sail past the hole at the Cotton Creek Golf Club in Gulf Shores, Ala. His columns may dwell on the mythical Holiday Inn in Fort Deposit, Ala., but this is Grizzard's South, the bleached-out new South of beachfront condominiums and pine-studded suburbs, where the woman setting up his speech proudly announces to his manager, Tony Privett, ''There is not one black resident of Gulf Shores, Ala.'' In many ways, life in places like this or Hilton Head Island or the white suburbs ringing Atlanta or Birmingham is a new and improved version of the mythical South of old, richer, just as friendly, just as laid back and just as segregated by custom and economics as it once was by law.
Every day the weather permits, whether in Atlanta or on the road, you can find Grizzard on the golf course, with his black and red Georgia Bulldogs golf bag with the matching Bulldog head covers. After today's round, it's back to the pink stucco Perdido Beach Hilton, and then on to his night's speaking engagement.
It is only after he finishes at around 9:30 P.M. that the real fun starts. Grizzard hates to fly, and he can get home to Atlanta from most places in the South on an overnight drive, so he likes to travel by bus - specifically, the 40-foot long, customized Silver Eagle with the 318 Detroit engine, the humongous steer horns above the driver's seat, the televisions and VCR's and tape decks, the shag carpet, and the mirror with the two big-eyed cocker spaniels that he rents from Sonny Williams of Fairview, Tenn. Sonny, who owns a truckstop there, has driven country music stars like Alabama and rock stars like Bon Jovi. With Sonny's buddy Elvis, also known as Danny Ramm, today acting as copilot, Grizzard gets the same treatment.
Like a lot of people who are paid to be funny, Grizzard seldom seems to be having much fun. But on the bus, he comes to life. He starts chain smoking Marlboros and knocking back screwdrivers, one after another from a half-gallon bottle of Stolichnaya. Soon Ricky Van Shelton is belting out Merle Haggard's ''Workin' Man Blues'' over the tape deck, and suddenly the gritty South Grizzard evokes in his columns beckons. There's talk of getting off the damn interstates and going to one-stop-light towns and country stores or canoeing in middle-of-nowhere mountain streams. ''If this ain't better than flying, there's something wrong with the world,'' Grizzard says.
By 1:30 A.M., the bus has become the spirit of the South - not the antiseptic country club South Grizzard lives in but the rough-edged real thing. Sonny's smiling as he bounces up and down in the driver's seat. Grizzard has taken the co-pilot's seat from Elvis. ''Goddam! We're at Montgomery? This is great! You just tell Sonny when you want to get there, and he'll get you there. Take it on down the road, Sonny! Take it on down the road! At this rate, we'll be home by 4:30.'' That's as far as the fantasy goes. Grizzard is asleep in the back an hour later when the blower shaft that gets air to the engine cuts off and the bus breaks down on I-85 outside Auburn, Ala., about 120 miles from home. At about 6:30, a bleary-eyed, Grizzard and associates stumble into a cab his manager has rounded up. They stop for breakfast at McDonald's and with Grizzard sitting in the front seat next to the driver, they head silently back to the comforts of Ansley Park. From the front seat comes a final comment.
''Show business is my life,'' says Lewis Grizzard.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2477 words

HEADLINE: The Death of a Child

BYLINE: By ROBERT COLES; Robert Coles is a child psychiatrist who teaches at Harvard University. His next book, ''The Spiritual Life of Children,'' will appear this fall.

 BODY:

WHAT LISA KNEW
The Truth and Lies of the Steinberg Case.
By Joyce Johnson.
303 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.
In early November 1987, a 6-year-old girl, Lisa Steinberg, brought to a New York City hospital comatose, was pronounced dead - a victim of severe and repeated beatings. In the melancholy and wrenching ''What Lisa Knew,'' Joyce Johnson, a novelist and a contributing editor to Vanity Fair, has tried hard and long to understand what such a brief life was like - those few years of agony that culminated in the violent death of a child of supposed privilege: the ostensible mother, Hedda Nussbaum, a one-time editor of children's books at Random House, the ostensible father, Joel Steinberg, a well-off lawyer. 
Not that Lisa's death was unique. Ms. Johnson has given much time and energy in an effort to understand what happened to this one child, but reminds us, right off, that ''in 1987, an estimated four thousand children died in America as a direct result of abuse.'' A number of these children, born to humble and impoverished parents, go to their graves with no attendant notice or outcry from the news media. In comparison, we are reminded, ''Lisa was one of those children to whom we assign high value.'' Such ''value'' prompted close and extended journalistic attention when the story broke, and later, when the father stood trial as responsible for the death. (He was ultimately convicted of first-degree manslaughter and is now in jail.) Not much detective work was necessary at the hospital before Lisa's experience could be surmised: ''Elizabeth Steinberg's small body was a map of pain,'' Ms. Johnson writes. ''The marks were different colors, different vintages. Red, purple, yellowish-brown. It seemed as if she had been hit just about everywhere - on her arms and the calves of her legs, on her chest, her buttocks. One of the biggest bruises was in the center of her lower back - not a place where a child would be likely to injure herself. There were fresh scratches on her elbows, as if someone had grabbed her there. Her parents had just let her go dirty - her feet and ankles had a crust of black grime. The hair and the feet shocked everyone almost as much as the bruises.'' As for the mother, she had ''two black eyes, a split lip, a nose that no longer had a bridge.''
Understandably, the world (and later, the criminal justice system) turned on Joel Steinberg. He became known, soon enough, for what he was - a crook, a liar, an accomplice of underworld figures, a spiteful, tricky, brutish man whose professional life is yet another reminder that virtue is not by any means a prerequisite for financial success. Many began to call him a monster, someone whose life in one way or another warrants setting him apart. Yet Ms. Johnson keeps reminding us that this man lived gregariously in a comfortable Manhattan world, had many business associates and friends, who had plenty of opportunities to take his moral measure - and see what he was doing to the woman with whom he was living, to his daughter - but who raised no voice of concern, let alone alarm.
The author does her best to try to understand this man, as well as the woman he kept beating for years, even as she refused to leave him -remained stubbornly, even fiercely, attached to him. If Mr. Steinberg inhabited a legal and business demimonde, Ms. Nussbaum achieved a substantial professional respectability. Mr. Steinberg's mean, manipulative, manic manner, his crude personality, his upstart ways and half-crazy palaver came as no surprise to his shyster companions and associates and earned him no reprimands or warnings. But Ms. Nussbaum's fellow workers at Random House became increasingly worried and then horrified by her bruised and battered appearance. The more her women friends tried to advise or warn or help her, the more she angrily detached herself from them and the cultured, refined world in which they had all, as colleagues, hitherto worked. Eventually, Ms. Nussbaum lost her job, became Mr. Steinberg's full-time, constant object of derision and assault. She also became a drug addict - a sometime zombie, people began to notice. Cocaine was her obsession, and she had no trouble stashing away large amounts of it for her daily consumption.
These two not very attractive or stable unmarried individuals refused to settle for their own harsh, coarse madness. They had no problem in illegally procuring two children - Lisa, whose death made her so-called parents all too well known, and Mitchell, who was 17 months old in 1987 when the public side of this tragedy first began to unfold. Mr. Steinberg was a criminal lawyer in several senses of that phrase. He defended many a lowlife, and he knew how to cut corners, to put it mildly. He and Ms. Nussbaum manipulated the New York State adoption laws to secure a girl and a boy from two frightened young single women. Of help, in that regard, was a network of unscrupulous doctor friends - another riffraff professional world Mr. Steinberg knew well. In the months that preceded Lisa's death, she and her baby brother - living in New York City's Greenwich Village, on West 10th Street, in the very building Mark Twain once claimed as a residence - had become part of what was supposed to be an upper-middle class family, but was in fact a living arrangement run amok: a man jabbing and punching at a woman; she, in turn, all drugged up day and night; a little girl increasingly knocked about; a baby boy ignored, left to lie for hours in a urine-soaked crib.
Inevitably, a substantial part of this book is given over to exercises in speculative psychology. The author does her best with that discipline's overwrought, portentous phrases (a secular lingua franca of our time) as she introduces us to Mr. Steinberg's family and Ms. Nussbaum's. But the most careful psychiatric scrutiny doesn't quite explain how these two college-educated, well-to-do, late-20th-century Americans turned into such a debased, callous, utterly self-preoccupied couple, to whom the lives of two young children meant next to nothing.
No question, Mr. Steinberg's mother comes across as shallow, egotistical, stingy; Ms. Nussbaum's parents as no paragons of emotional strength. But so what? The world is full of vulnerable people who have had difficult childhoods, who have known all sorts of psychological strain and pain - and who have not turned into malign emotional partners or parents. The author, a sensitive and skilled novelist whose work has received quite favorable critical attention, knows to call it quits at a certain point. ''In a way,'' she points out, ''it would be a relief to learn that Hedda Nussbaum had been beaten by her parents, that her relationship with her father had been incestuous. That would both explain her and distance her from those of us who consider ourselves more normal than she is. In fact, it appears she was not an abused child at all, that her upbringing was truly as average and uneventful as she said it was.'' Not that child abuse or family violence are exclusively a matter of ''upbringing'' come home to roost. Social and economic upheaval or vulnerability prompt an increase in such violence, as emergency ward physicians and pediatricians living in certain neighborhoods or entire cities that have been hit hard by rising unemployment well know. Family violence also increases in response to alcohol and drug abuse - and those problems also rise in frequency among jobless people.
Needless to say, partisans of psychological determinism will insist on some formulation that accounts for the behavior of Mr. Steinberg and Ms. Nussbaum, both individually and together. The author tries her best to address this issue: quotes at length, for example, from Rollo May's ''Love and Will,'' even imagines Ms. Nussbaum, ''with her appetite for literature on sex and psychology,'' reading that 1969 book, and offers us such startling and original cultural profundities from it as this: ''It is always true that love and will become more difficult in a transitional age, and ours is an era of radical transition. The old myths and symbols by which we oriented ourselves are gone, anxiety is rampant; we cling to each other and try to persuade ourselves that what we feel is love.'' As for Ms. Nussbaum's way of getting on with her so-called lover, Rollo May has this dramatic pronouncement for his readers: ''When inward life dries up, when feeling decreases and apathy increases, when one cannot affect or even genuinely touch another person, violence flares up as a daimonic necessity for contact, a mad drive forcing touch in the most direct way possible. This is one aspect of the well-known relationship between sexual feelings and crimes of violence: to inflict pain and torture at least proves that one can affect somebody.''
Such a way of seeing things was quite familiar to Ms. Nussbaum, whether she had read Rollo May's book or not. She knew phrases such as ''sadomasochistic relationship,'' or ''folie a deux'' - phrases that one day would fill the air as people tried to put a fast fix on her psychological life. She had been in and out of ''treatment'' for years before she took up with Mr. Steinberg, was seeing a therapist three times a week as she cemented that fateful friendship. She had visited doctors alone and in ''group sessions.'' She had ''tried Biofeedback.'' She had been ''Rolfed for a few months.'' She had gone to ''Dr. Albert Ellis, a best-selling authority on sexual responsiveness.'' The author dryly observes that ''none of these therapies succeeded in liberating the real Hedda.'' Meanwhile, naturally, Mr. Steinberg talked with no one about himself - only looked for people whom (at work or at play) he might con.
As this patient, shrewd storyteller worked her way through what she calls the ''blanks and blind alleys'' of an attempted biographical study, the weight of psychological banality obviously became oppressive and stifling to her. One by one certain words start making a credible appearance in her text - ''choice,'' ''will,'' ''evil,'' ''responsibility.'' At such moments, as with George Eliot's authorial voice in ''Middlemarch,'' Ms. Johnson becomes the aroused chronicler of a moral tale. At what point is any of us responsible for our actions - no matter the trials and tribulations (evident or hidden) of our early or later years? (Hitler was a victim of what we now call child abuse - he and his mother constantly tyrannized by an alcoholic man whose raging fists surely marked a stepson for life.) Put differently, when ought psychological analysis to give way to moral judgment? The author makes clear, finally, her own position.
It is not hard, Ms. Johnson knows, for many of us to condemn Mr. Steinberg, his putatively unhappy childhood notwithstanding. Ms. Nussbaum, in contrast, received from many enormous sympathy. She was quickly wrapped in a thick psychiatric cloak, was flanked by her lawyer and doctor, neither of them especially camera-shy, and was not put on trial, even though many of the jurors felt that she was partially responsible for Lisa Steinberg's death (she testified that after the child was severely injured, she smoked cocaine with Mr. Steinberg for hours before calling 911). By the end of the book, the author is also quite willing to emphasize the significant ''role'' that Ms. Nussbaum ''played in Lisa Steinberg's life and death.'' In an interesting afterthought, Ms. Johnson declares: ''Clearly she has no understanding of what she did that was so wrong - of how she sinned, if one dares to use such an old-fashioned term.''
Some will charge the author with blaming the victim, but she argues, in her own way, for a kind of old-fashioned respect for Hedda Nussbaum that is moral rather than psychological - her right to be judged ethically rather than exculpated through the dreary, trite phrases of contemporary psychology, a dubious ally, anyway, because what can be given (the masochist as a one-time hurt child) can also be taken away (the masochist as a sly, insistent, clinging aggressor, feeding off and provoking constantly a tormentor's rage.) Ms. Johnson is neither a Diana Trilling nor an Elizabeth Hardwick, either of whom, I suspect, would have written with more sardonic bite and would have risked a grander impatience with the cast of seedy, self-absorbed, nasty characters who populate this story - their actions, finally, the essence of ''what Lisa knew'' in her all too brief life. But Ms. Johnson, constrained by factuality as Henry James was not when he gave us ''What Maisie Knew,'' does eventually develop a fine narrative momentum. Her novelist's eye for detail and character portrayal serve her and us well - nowhere better than during those moments when she reminds us that some New Yorkers possessed both moral intuition and moral energy in response to their fleeting encounters with young Lisa. Even though the girl's teachers apparently (and incredibly) noticed nothing alarming in their day-to-day work with her, hours and hours of presumably close contact, a frightened neighbor repeatedly contacted city agencies and warned of the violence she suspected was taking place in the Steinberg apartment. And a New York State Thruway toll collector (unlike those teachers, she had no fancy university degrees, had taken no courses in something called educational psychology), on the basis of a second's look at Lisa and her father in a car, immediately suspected that the child was in grave jeopardy and got the highway police called - in vain, though. The lawyer Joel Steinberg, ever the wily, truculent blabbermouth, knew well how to keep secure guard over his particular realm - until death carried off one of its young inhabitants.
 
THE WOMAN WASN'T CRYING
 [Officer] Botte . . . went back to the apartment . . . to pick up a sample of the food the child was said to have choked on. The woman didn't want to let them in. . . . Botte had never seen a woman who looked as bad as she did. Hedda Nussbaum resembled a pugilist who had just lost the last of a long series of fights. . . . She limped away . . . hunched over like an old person. She wasn't crying. Botte had evidently had the sentimental expectation that she would be crying over the little girl. It was like Steinberg all over again: the emotions didn't match up with the situation.
Hedda Nussbaum took a plastic container out of the refrigerator and handed it to Botte. There were soggy vegetables inside. They're rotten, Botte thought to himself. The woman asked . . . a weird thing. ''Do you have to take all the vegetables?'' Botte went to check out the baby. . . . He was tethered to [a playpen] by a rope. . . . The baby, the mat he was sitting on, the dirty sweatshirt he was wearing, had an awful stench of urine.
 
From ''What Lisa Knew.''

HEADLINE: DOES THE CREDIT GO TO THE KREMLIN?

BYLINE: By ADAM B. ULAM; Adam B. Ulam is a professor of history and political science at Harvard University and director of Harvard's Russian Research Center.

 BODY:

THE AWAKENING OF THE SOVIET UNION
By Geoffrey Hosking.
182 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $19.95.
A student of contemporary affairs might understandably groan at the appearance of yet another volume on perestroika. The pace of change in the Soviet Union has been so rapid that most books on the subject are liable to be outdated by the time they get into print. Moreover, the majority of them are quite repetitive, with the writers belaboring the question of whether Mikhail S. Gorbachev will survive politically. (It is somewhat ironic that while the Soviet people are learning to view their leaders soberly, there has emerged in the West a cult of personality around the man whose name is usually assumed to be synonymous with the Kremlin's ''new thinking.'') ''The Awakening of the Soviet Union'' by Geoffrey Hosking, a professor of Russian history at the University of London, is a welcome departure from these excessively Gorbachev-dominated discussions. All in all, this thin volume is among the most enlightening and informative accounts of what has already been one of the most amazing peaceful revolutions in modern times. 
Perestroika, in Mr. Hosking's opinion, was not invented by one man. Nor has it been triggered exclusively by the economic and political crisis of the Soviet state in the mid-1980's. In many ways, Mr. Hosking argues, the impulse to reform sprang from forces generated by the growing maturity of Soviet society. Just as that society had thrown off the shackles of despotism imposed by Stalin, so it is now struggling to free itself from the bureaucratic oligarchy preserved by his successors. But to assess realistically the chances of the present reforms, Mr. Hosking says, we ought to look beyond the day-to-day political games in the Kremlin and examine the country's past.
The author is quite hopeful on this point: ''Russians do not have a heritage of democracy as we understand that term. All the same, I do not believe they are condemned to eternal civic passivity. On the contrary, I believe that they have derived, from their past, traditions of political participation and mutual solidarity under pressure which are proving to be decisive elements in the new situation, and which are creating the makings of a civil society.''
More specifically Mr. Hosking invokes the example of the pre-Revolution peasant community (the mir) as a source of what he calls ''habits of community.'' These, he says, survived into the modern Russian and Soviet period, providing the people with a modicum of autonomy and privacy even under the autocratic and totalitarian regimes. The traditions of community manifested themselves in the workers' soviets (the grass-roots organs of self-government that erupted spontaneously during the revolutions of 1905 and 1917), as well as in the ''tightly knit circles'' of intelligentsia, which provided small havens of opposition, both in pre-World War I Russia and under Khrushchev and Brezhnev, to the omnipotent state.
Thus, even before the onset of perestroika ''a dim sense of loss of community was reawakening. . . . The preoccupation with human rights was the first sign of recovery.'' It is the strength of this tradition of communality, Mr. Hosking believes, that will largely determine whether Mr. Gorbachev and his colleagues will succeed in their grandiose task of razing what remains of the autocratic structure.
There is no doubt that the pace of what might be called the self-emancipation of Soviet society has far outdistanced not only what Mr. Gorbachev intended, but even what more radical would-be reformers expected as late as 1987-88. And the sources of that explosion of self-assertion, which has astounded (and in many cases frightened) the original proponents of perestroika, must indeed be sought in Russian history as well as in the events of the last five years. But as Mr. Hosking himself admits (though rather obliquely), force, not ''habits of community,'' is likely to be the decisive factor with regard to the explosive problem of ethnic nationalism. While the nationalism question has broken other empires of the 20th century, he says, ''the strength of the armed forces and the security police gives [the Soviet Union] quite a good chance of being an exception for the foreseeable future.'' But as recent events have shown, force may not prove the solution to the Soviet Union's nationalities problems; and with ethnic Russians constituting only 50 percent of the population of the Soviet Union, one might well ask, can the Soviet system don new democratic clothes largely on the strength of Russian traditions?
Some historians might also take issue with Mr. Hosking's view of the soviets of 1905 and 1917 being harbingers of democracy and organs of self-government. They were essentially revolutionary (and chaotic) organizations. The 1917 Petrograd soviet, rather than attempting to govern, construed its function as that of obstructing the Provisional Government of the post-February 1917 infant Russian democracy, and so contributed to its collapse. Indeed, the lessons of the February Revolution ought to be kept in mind both by Mr. Gorbachev's people and by those who believe that he is not moving fast enough.
Such questions aside, ''The Awakening of the Soviet Union'' has great merit in distinguishing the various phases and elements of the process of reform. Mr. Hosking is especially perceptive in attributing great importance to the reverberations of Chernobyl: after first trying to conceal and then to minimize the repercussions of that catastrophe, the Kremlin realized the imperative need for glasnost. That realization and Mr. Gorbachev's call to Andrei Sakharov marked a decisive phase in the evolution of perestroika.
By placing perestroika in a historical perspective, Mr. Hosking provides an extremely useful corrective to those who see its success or failure solely in terms of the balance of power between the reformers and the conservatives on the Central Committee. The regime's readiness to bite the bullet on the economy and other issues makes up the daily headlines of the Western press. But the ultimate fate of Mr. Gorbachev's efforts, as this fine study suggests, rests on matters far deeper than what the newspapers are able to tell us.

HEADLINE: SCIENCE BOOKS;
LOVE AMONG THE INSECTS

BYLINE: By DAVID QUAMMEN; David Quammen, the author of ''The Flight of the Iguana,'' is working on a book about worldwide patterns of evolution and extinction of species.

 BODY:

SONORAN DESERT SUMMER
By John Alcock.
Illustrated by Marilyn Hoff Stewart.
187 pp. Tucson:
The University of Arizona Press. $19.95.
Two years ago the sociobiologist and entomologist Edward O. Wilson published an essay titled ''The Little Things That Run the World,'' making a good case for the transcendent significance of insects. Actually, he was speaking up not just for insects but also for mites, worms, copepods, spiders, corals, mollusks and all those other spineless (and, for the most part, tiny) animals that science lumps in the category of invertebrates. Mr. Wilson's point was that these creatures, despised and inconspicuous as they generally are, represent a sort of interstitial glue holding all of nature together, and that we ignore such species, we extinguish such species, at our peril. 
It's helpful to keep Mr. Wilson's argument in mind while reading ''Sonoran Desert Summer'' by John Alcock. Otherwise we might mistake it for merely a sweet book of observations by a man who studies wasps and butterflies in the desert of central Arizona. It is that, but not merely that. John Alcock is an ecologist with a patient eye, a broad curiosity and a head full of well-honed questions, and this is his rumination about the way the world works.
The Sonoran Desert between May and September is a zone of ferocious extremes - of heat and drought and famine - extremes that enforce the laws of biological economy remorselessly. It's a good place, therefore, to study how living creatures meet their most basic needs. Mr. Alcock, a professor of zoology at Arizona State University, focuses on the seemingly small subject of how male insects solve the problem of finding females. At the same time, he stays alert to such tangential but intriguing ecological matters as how a Gila monster budgets its energy, why the poorwill doesn't lay camouflaged eggs and what caused the mysterious disappearance of the Hohokam culture of desert Indians.
He also narrows his focus along another dimension, concentrating on just one piece of landscape, Usery Mountain, an hour outside of Phoenix. After years of fieldwork there, Mr. Alcock seems to know his chosen mountain - with all its peccaries and lizards and coyotes and vultures, all its saguaros and paloverdes and hackberries, all its mutualisms and predator-prey interactions - as intimately as the 19th-century French entomologist Jean Henri Fabre knew his two acres of stony meadow at Serignan.
''Sonoran Desert Summer'' is a sequel in some sense to his earlier ''Sonoran Desert Spring,'' but because of the drama inherent to Sonoran summer it doesn't read like an afterthought. It's a mixed record of pure nature observation and conceptual ecology. And it's a more subtle mix than it first appears. Some of the short sections are laconic and visual, innocent of thought, like a Japanese landscape screen. But in longer pieces, such as ''Altruism Among Ground Squirrels'' and ''How to Win Mates and Influence Enemies,'' Mr. Alcock wrestles with hard-edged biological questions and competing hypotheses, citing his own research alongside the work of other scientists. He shifts back and forth between these two modes, the cognitive and the moody, so any reader expecting a succession of self-contained nature essays may be disappointed. ''Sonoran Desert Summer'' is not a collection of essays but a book shaped to be a book. The panels of landscape and the bursts of scientific explication give way to one another in a nicely irregular rhythm.
For instance, in a piece called ''May Twilight'' Mr. Alcock writes, ''In a patch of creosote bush between the two peaks of Usery Mountain an orange bee hovers, a huge bee whose wings blur in flight as the insect drifts up, then to one side, loops out, then back.'' He has no point to make about this huge orange bee; it is simply there, a mantra for desert meditators. But the orange bee also serves as a restful counterpoint to his analytical explanation of social behavior among Centris pallida (the digger bee, which happens to be huge also, though not orange), in which he shows why male diggers are obliged by evolution to excavate virgin females from their pupal burrows.
Elsewhere, Mr. Alcock describes two kestrels and two Cooper's hawks riding thermals near a ridge: ''The four hawks curl around the flank of Usery Mountain and continue on their migration, heading south across a remnant of lowland desert that yields to a patchwork of houses, trailer parks, and alfalfa fields.'' The birds cruise toward Mexico, though in a narrative sense they go nowhere; they are part of a purely descriptive interlude titled ''Hawk Morning,'' which falls between two analyses of intricate adaptations among other species. This surging and coasting intellectual rhythm, this alternation of offerings to the mind, to the eye and to the heart, serves Mr. Alcock well. His book seems to get stronger and more assured as we notice the pattern and adjust our expectations.
''One of the great insights that has come from rigorously thinking about the costs and benefits of traits to individuals, as measured by their impact on individual reproductive success,'' he writes, ''has been to escape from the notion that there is some sort of absolute scale of characteristics in the animal kingdom, running from primitive, inferior, and second rate to advanced, superior, and first rate.'' That's a valuable piece of wisdom, and behind it lies the awareness that, ironically, even the rigorous thinking that brings us such an insight has its limits. The real charm of Mr. Alcock's book is that, while he tells us such cerebral things, he also shows us that scientific cognition isn't the only way to experience a glorious ecosystem.

TYPE: Review

TITLE: SONORAN DESERT SUMMER (BOOK)

HEADLINE: Outdoors;
A Debate on Atlantic Salmon

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant

 BODY:
Should game-fish status be sought for the Atlantic salmon in Canada, which, if achieved, would protect that highly prized species from commercial netters?
In the spring issue of the ''Atlantic Salmon Journal,'' the quarterly publication of the Atlantic Salmon Federation, Lee Wulff argues for that proposal, and Wilfred Carter, who was for many years the chief executive officer of the federation and now serves as president emeritus, opposes it.
Wulff, a world-famous angler and author who is also an officer of the federation, observes that a recent federation study of the salmon's economic value to Canada shows that a salmon caught by an angler is worth 40 times more to the general economy than one taken in a commercial fisherman's net. The entire commercial catch of salmon in Canada is worth about $7 million, he writes, while the angler take, usually about 15 percent of the total harvest, is worth $43 million. 
While admitting that commercial netting has been eliminated in some provinces, Wulff notes that it still continues in Newfoundland, which has, he observes, ''traditionally taken the lion's share of our fish.''
''Why is this allowed?'' he continues. ''Consensus is that the people of Newfoundland are poor and need all the money and food they can get. That is a kind and sentimental excuse but not a very good one, since, having depleted its own rivers, Newfoundland's major take is of salmon created by conservation measures that were carried out and paid for by other provinces.''
The Newfoundland fishery also intercepts salmon bound for their home streams in New England, where a multimillion-dollar salmon restoration effort has been under way for years.
''It would be far better to subsidize the people who will suffer if the Newfoundland fishery closed than it would be to continue allowing them to diminish the salmon resource at great cost to the nation,'' Wulff adds.
It is Wulff's contention that the influential Canadian-American federation should have as its rallying cry ''Make the Atlantic salmon a game fish.'' This would, he believes, unite Canadian anglers from coast to coast.
Carter admits that the emotional appeal of such a campaign would be compelling, but adds that ''in practical terms the losses (by alienation of civil servants, politicians and citizens) might easily outweigh the gains.''
Wulff also notes that the increasing production of Atlantic salmon farms (Norway pioneered this and there are now such farms in Canada and Maine) insures - even if the salmon were given game-fish status - that those who like to eat salmon but don't angle for them would not be deprived of their pleasure.
Although game-fish status for the fish he so deeply admires is his dream, Wulff nonetheless makes some less drastic suggestions for controlling and limiting the commercial catch. He would have the commercial netters use gear that allows the large breeders to escape. He would also limit netting to the mouths of rivers and their estuaries. Carter would be the first to agree with the last.
River-by-river harvesting of Atlantic salmon has long been regarded as the ideal management approach. Hatched out in fresh water, young salmon eventually descend to the sea, where they attain growth and maturity, returning, in one to three years, to their natal streams to spawn. River keepers know how many salmon should make their way upstream to spawning beds to insure a given stream's optimum production. If sufficient numbers didn't appear, the commercial and sport fisheries on it could be closed.
In his argument, Carter notes that Canada has already reduced the numbers of its commercial fishermen by half, and adds that ''further cutbacks are planned.''
''It really doesn't matter to a resource manager,'' Carter writes, ''how a renewable resource like salmon is cropped. What does matter is the number of fish that are taken, and the number that are left for spawning.''
Noting that as a member of the North Atlantic Salmon Conservation Organization, Canada ''has accepted the fact that nonproducing countries (countries with no salmon rivers) such as Greenland and the Faeroes, in whose waters Atlantic salmon from North America feed and grow, are entitled to catch some fish.''
''This catch is not now, and won't ever be done by recreational fishermen,'' he adds. Carter then observes that action by Canada making the salmon a game fish wouldn't apply to those high seas fisheries.
Although the Canadian Government has spent millions in buying up commercial fishermen's salmon netting rights, some 3,700 more are still entitled to take salmon.
And even if, Carter continues, a total buyout of commercial licenses did take place, Canada would have to allow ''its native populations of Indians and Inuit to fish salmon for food.'' Carter doubts that those natives could be persuaded to ''harvest their catch with rod and fly.''
Carter observes that remote coastal villages in Newfoundland that are now getting much of their income from salmon netting, could not, were the salmon to become a game fish tomorrow, immediately woo anglers to their streams. Guides would have to be trained, roads improved, hostelries built. And one should also remember that commercial fishing is a way of life in many parts of Newfoundland.
Whenever a fish is avidly sought by both sport and commercial interests, there is inevitably disagreement over how to allocate the resource. In the United States, the striped bass is the subject of such contention. Some of the Atlantic coastal states allow commercial fishing for them, some do not. Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, has introduced a bill to make the striper a game fish. The chances of its becoming law are exceedingly remote. Federal game-fish status isn't likely for any species that is the target of a longstanding or substantial commercial fishery. And if a state decides to bestow game-fish status on a species - which has been done with the snook in Florida and the red fish in Texas -one may rest assured that a thriving sport-fishing industry that includes those species already exists.

HEADLINE: Wave of Conversions Slows to a Ripple

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
THE wave of conversions that moved across New York City in the 1980's and transformed some 300,000 rental apartments into cooperatives and condominiums has slowed dramatically.
After being nearly overwhelmed by a rising tide of conversion plans, the Real Estate Financing Bureau of the State Attorney General's office saw more than a 50 percent drop in the number of plans submitted for review from 1987 through 1989. Submissions declined from 584 in 1987 to 444 in 1988 and then to 280 last year. The figures include eviction and noneviction plans for both co-ops and condominiums.
''The drop in 1989 was most significant in the last quarter of the year,'' said Frederick K. Mehlman, an assistant attorney general in charge of the bureau, ''and the numbers for 1990 so far are even slower.'' 
Slow sales and tumbling prices have so weakenened the positions of some sponsors that they are abandoning their conversion plans. At the same time, many tenants have gained the upper hand in bargaining and are negotiating substantial reductions in the prices they have to pay for their apartments.
The braking action on conversions came from several directions. It started in 1986 with a change in the Federal tax code that limited the deductibility of passive losses on real estate investments. That drove away nearly all investor buyers of converted units, many of whom had until then been snapping up blocks of occupied apartments.
The city's residential building boom, which brought to the market a huge number of both renovated and newly built co-op and condominium residences, pushed down prices and narrowed profits for converters. Then a downturn in the region's economy dealt another blow to the weakening residential real estate market.
Another factor in the slowdown was that by the late 80's sponsors were faced with a dwindling supply of top quality rental buildings appropriate for co-op or condominium conversions.
''We are far from the point where there is an end to cooperative and condominium conversions,'' said Nancy Kramer, a lawyer in the bureau who serves as the office's deputy director, ''but activity has slowed considerably.''
Declines in conversions were recorded by the bureau for all of the city's boroughs. Brooklyn had the most substantial drop, with the number of plans accepted by the bureau dropping from 179 in 1988 to 126 last year. In Manhattan, which has long been at the front of the conversion trend, the number sank from 220 in 1988 to 184 last year.
In Queens, 94 plans were accepted in 1988 and 63 in 1989. In the Bronx the fall was from 59 in 1988 to 48 last year. Staten Island had only one residential conversion during 1989, whereas four went through the previous year.
Even though New York remains overwhelmingly a city of renters - 82.7 percent of apartment-dwellers at last count in 1987 - when the pace of conversions hit its peak in the mid-80's it seemed to many that the trend was moving with the speed and force of a steamroller out of control. One primary catalyst for the conversion movement, housing experts say, was the establishment of rent stabilization in 1969. The new rules greatly expanded the number of apartments with regulated rents.
''AFTER that some owners felt they could not justify holding their properties as rentals any longer,'' said Lee Fasio, divisional director of investment finance and development at New York University's Real Estate Institute. ''One way to get out from under the burden of carrying buildings where operating costs outpaced rents or where owners were not satisfied with profit margins was to sell to tenants through conversion plans.''
But rising interest rates, which reached the double digits by the late 70's, coupled with the city's financial woes, limited the pace of conversions until the early 80's.
Once mortgage interest rates retreated, the floodgates opened. Suddenly converters found scores of eager buyers in middle-income families and the growing population of high-earning young professionals as well as in investors looking for a ride up with the city's soaring property values.
This surge in demand attracted speculators who bought rental properties with the specific purpose of conversion. It was not uncommon for them to see profits triple on the original investment even if extensive renovations and improvements had to be made.
But one sign of the conversion market's failing health today is that speculators have all but vanished.
''We are basically out of the conversion business,'' said Robert Stang, a vice president with M. J. Raynes, a real estate investment and management company that was among the most active converters in the last two decades. ''With the exception of one or two projects in Westchester, the sales we are handling now are in projects we converted two or three years ago.''
Mr. Stang estimated that between 1979 and 1986, M. J. Raynes was responsible for converting 20,000 rental units. In 1986, the company was a partner in one of the largest and most valuable conversions the city had seen. In partnership with Bernard Mendik, it offered for sale the 3,800 units in the eight buildings of Lincoln Towers, a complex that sprawls along West End Avenue from 66th to 70th Street. They were put up for sale 18 months after the Mendik-Raynes partnership acquired the complex as part of the MacArthur Foundation real estate portfolio.
But the Lincoln Towers conversion project was one of the last for M. J. Raynes. Mr. Stang said that since 1986 the company has not bought a single rental property in New York City for the purpose of converting it.
''The alteration in the tax laws made it clear to us that the atmosphere was going to change substantially,'' said Mr. Stang. ''Then in 1987 there was a move in the State Legislature to change the rules for co-op conversions, which we felt would further erode the market. So even before prices started to fall, we were easing off on this aspect of our real estate business.''
One real estate company that seems to be swimming against the tide, however, is Rose Associates. In the last few months the family-owned, Manhattan real estate investment and development company has submitted plans for the conversion of nine apartment buildings in Manhattan. Taken together, the plans, which are for both co-ops and condominiums, hold the potential for converting more than 3,000 rental units.
Among the Rose buildings for which plans are pending are the Sheffield, an 843-unit building at 322 West 57th Street near Eighth Avenue; a building at 45 East 89th Street with 157 units, and the Park Gramercy, at 7 Lexington Avenue at 22d Street, with 97 units.
Adam Rose, a company principal in charge of the residential management division, refused to answer questions about the conversion projects.
''It would serve no worthwhile purpose for us to discuss any aspect of our plans at this time,'' said Mr. Rose. The company is in varying stages of negotiations with the tenants of the buildings where conversion plans have been proposed.
Although prices for co-ops and condominiums have fallen in the last two years, real estate industry observers say the Roses are not as vulnerable to the market's drop as other converters might be. This is because the Roses have owned all of the buildings undergoing conversions for at least 10 years.
''The people who are hurting now are the sponsors who bought buildings in 1986 and 1987, when prices were really high,'' said Michael Finder, a lawyer who has represented tenants in several converted buildings. ''Most of them are not getting anywhere near the prices they expected to get.''
BUT instead of being a magnet for buyers kept on the sidelines by the rapidly rising housing costs in the 80's, the down market has been characterized by some striking contradictions.
''The conversion business is much less predictable today than it was just a year or so ago,'' said Arthur Weinstein, a lawyer who serves both tenant groups and sponsors. ''On one hand, the soft market has made the tenants' money more attractive to sponsors. This has given them the upper hand in the bargaining process and some have been able to get very good deals from their sponsors.''
''But on the other hand,'' he continued, ''the weak residental market has made other tenants very nervous and even more skeptical of the entire conversion process. They are afraid that prices will drop even further. Apartment ownership, which at one time seemed like a great chance for equity and huge profits, now is viewed by some as not worth the risk.''
Moreover, news reports about the recent financial problems of some buildings converted to co-ops or condominiums have also made outside buyers wary.
''They are much less willing to invest in buildings where the number of inside buyers is low,'' said Mr. Finder. ''They now take low tenant involvement as a sign that the deal may not be so good or that there may be problems that are not apparent in the prospectus.''
Although Ms. Kramer of the Financing Bureau says the agency has not documented or observed a noticeable rise in the number of conversion plans withdrawn by their sponsors, others contend that an increasing number of conversion plans do not make it to the finish line.
Under the bureau's procedures, a sponsor first submits a detailed proposal for converting a building. The proposal is examined by the bureau to make sure it includes all the information a tenant or an outsider needs to make an intelligent decision on whether to buy. Once that is determined, the plan is circulated and a period of negotiation usually follows, resulting in amendments to the plan.
Then sales begin, and when the minimum number of units is sold - 15 percent in a noneviction plan and 51 percent in an eviction plan - the bureau accepts the plan and the co-op is established.
MR. FINDER said that in the last few months tenants groups in two buildings he has represented have seen sponsors abandon plans.
In other cases sponsors are making concessions to make their deals work. That was the case for a building on Ocean Parkway between Avenue C and Beverly Road in the Kensington section of Brooklyn.
It came as a surprise to both tenants and the sponsor of the conversion plan for the building that after more than two years of negotiations occupants of only nine of the 112 units in the building agreed to buy their apartments. The sponsor first told tenants that there would be no conversion unless at least 10 tenants committed to buy their apartments.
''There was a lot of excitement when the plan was first presented,'' said Risa Kriegal Coscia, a tenant in the building who was active in the negotiations. ''Even though we have many older people who would not have bought, most who could afford to said they probably would. Other buildings on Ocean Parkway were being converted and real estate was doing so well back then.''
But as the negotiations dragged on, prices for apartments in nearby buildings fell and there was a turnaround in the mood among tenants. Some began to worry about the market for resale and others, Mrs. Coscia said, others grew tired of waiting to buy and moved on.
''After we got only nine buyers,''said Mrs. Coscia, ''the sponsor said he was not sure he was going to go through with the conversion.''
But last month after meeting the 15 percent sales requirement through commitments from outside buyers, he decided to relent on the 10 inside-buyers requirement.
''The process took a long time - probably too long,'' said Mrs. Coscia. ''But we did manage to get nearly everything we wanted in terms of building improvements, prices and the reserve fund.''
