HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Transitional Housing;
The New Shelters for Homeless Families

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE problem of homelessness in American cities has given birth to new housing forms, mainly in New York City. The latest, on Powers Avenue in the South Bronx, is a structure built for permanent use as temporary housing for families, usually mothers with young children. It is as solidly designed and built as a public school or a small hospital. People started moving into it in December.
The Koch administration originally planned 20 of these, for close to 2,000 apartments in all boroughs on city-owned land. They were a key element in former Mayor Edward I. Koch's plan to phase out hotels, and such buildings as old schools or hospitals, as first-stop transitional housing for homeless families and singles.
But communities and their elected representatives objected to many of the chosen sites. It now appears that at most 11 buildings - the number approved by the Board of Estimate - will be built. Only the Powers Avenue building is complete and occupied. 
A second will be occupied in late spring, and five others are in construction. All are designed for families, with private baths and kitchen facilities. The remaining four, each for singles, should be finished by the end of next year, city officials say.
There are two basic designs, one for 100 families and the other for 200 singles. The firm of Skidmore Owings & Merrill designed both.
Mayor David N. Dinkins hopes to complete these projects, said Nancy Wackstein, director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness, and also to provide other facilities - in some mix of rehabilitation, acquired existing buildings and new construction - for about 5,000 single adults. These would replace the armories now used as temporary shelters for single adults. No sites have been picked.
''We need three or four years to deal with the people in the armories,'' Ms. Wackstein said.
The 100-unit Powers Avenue shelter was one of three awarded to the construction firm of Kreisler Borg Florman of Scarsdale, N.Y., in the first round of contract awards in April 1988. It makes a good starting point for considering how the new permanent family shelters will fit into their environment and into a total policy for dealing with the needs for both housing and social services by families on their way to independent living.
Will the buildings and their use stigmatize the communities in which they are situated, or blend smoothly in? How ''transitional'' will the housing be? Will lengths of stay grow?
One outcome that may already be emerging is that this quality housing will become the shelter of choice for dependent families hoping to make their way into independent living in publicly assisted apartments. Housing relocation assistance is one of the key social services provided at the new shelters, and with it families in shelters may be able to compete more successfully with the still-housed poor for scarce vacancies in government-assisted housing.
''The city's success in emptying the welfare hotels and providing an alternate system of transitional housing has brought a new way for people to prioritize themselves for permanent housing,'' said William Grinker, former Commissioner of Social Services and now a consultant to the Twentieth Century Fund, a public-policy research foundation.
A ruling by the state's Court of Appeals last week in the case of Barbara Jiggers, a single mother who was evicted in 1987 from an apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, may point the way to higher housing allowances for welfare recipients, which the court said must be ''reasonable.'' This will give courts a role in deciding whether state shelter allowances are adequate.
ACCORDING to some city officials, eviction for lack of adequate rent has not been a significant cause of family homelessness. Others say that providing households with public assistance to pay rent is bound to avert their splitting into components in need of separate housing.
In any event, the Powers Family Residence - at 346 Powers Avenue, near 141st Street - is an attractive and unobtrusive three-level addition to a low-income community that was a pocket of subsidized rehabilitation efforts in the 70's and 80's. Shaped like an H, it has a landscaped front entrance and a play area in the rear. Cupola-like elements on the pitched roof bring daylight through glass-enclosed spaces to the long corridors on all floors.
The rooms are spare, with cooking facilities near the entrance, and a private bath. There are 100 rooms in all, 70 single rooms of 275 square feet, normally for a single adult with one or two children, and 30 suites of 550 square feet for larger families.
There are also offices, consulting rooms, four day-care rooms, two common living rooms on each floor of each wing and a 1,600-square-foot common room for meetings and large gatherings. In the front there is a landscaped area leading to the entrance, which is intended to create a friendly, noninstitutional appearance, said Thomas Killian, the Skidmore Owings and Merrill design architect.
''There is nothing temporary about that facility,'' said John V. Cricco, vice president of Kreisler Borg Florman, which built the Powers Street residence. The 70,000-square-foot structure is built of reinforced concrete. Between the sheetrock walls stands wire mesh that will provide extra security. Bathroom mirrors are made of polished stainless steel to prevent breakage. Shower stalls are also stainless steel. Security doors and metal window guards protect openings. Inside, bright colors and daylight make the appearance cheerful. Strangers are carefully signed in by guards.
THE average length of stay of the families is expected to be about six months, but by some accounts the average is already falling. Interestingly, the farther it falls, the stronger will grow the evidence that transitional housing is any low-income family's best bet for rapid relocation to scarce, desirable permanent housing.
Already, competition is reported to have developed between homeless families in the transitional system and other families on public assistance who are not homeless for the rehabilitated housing being created from the city's tax-foreclosed housing stock.
Permanence as a transitional facility is what distinguishes these city buildings from the HELP (Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged) buildings that Andrew Cuomo, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's son, has been developing in New York City and elsewhere for homeless families and singles.
Mr. Cuomo's first project was a 200-unit building for families in the East New York section of Brooklyn that opened in 1987. He said that his concept is that the buildings will eventually be transformed into permanent housing, perhaps when they transfer to city ownership after 10 years. It is owned by a nonprofit corporation in which Mr. Cuomo is a principal and was financed by 10-year state bonds.
The rooms in this building are 400 square feet, which can be combined into one 800-square-foot room to make larger permanent apartments for families of four or five. The typical current occupant is a young mother with a child. The average length of stay is six months but the range is wide - from three months to a year - Mr. Cuomo said.
To officials of the city's Department of Social Services, the new buildings are part of the long-term need to provide emergency rooms for 3,100 families by fiscal 1992, which starts July 1, 1991. Typically, these families are a young mother with one or two children, the mother unemployed and never having lived independently.
These family units are to replace the so-called welfare hotels entirely, which at peak use were housing more than 3,600 such families a night citywide. Currently, the department is down to about 1,100 families in hotels.
The Powers Residence, from the Department of Social Services' standpoint, is merely one of a variety of family shelters, most of them in older but renovated buildings. Together, all these shelters are providing 1,900 family units.
But building permanent new structures custom-designed for a transient occupancy gives a special dimension to the homelessness issue. It demonstrates plainly that the contemporary issue is as much more preparation for independent living and day care for youngsters as it is housing creation.
Separate buildings that offer all necessary conditions for these services and are built to institutional standards under city auspices are a great if expensive convenience. Family shelters' costs, when the city develops them, are typically above $200 a square foot in pure construction costs, or at least $14 million for a 70,000-square-foot structure.
Nobody can judge how many people will need that help. What is suspected is that there are 50,000 to 100,000 ''doubled up'' families. The ones most in need of help may be the first into the shelter system. But many may see the shelters as an essential way station on the road to desirable permanent housing.
Community resistance to them, or at least to the sites picked by the Koch administration, was so intense that permanent new shelters will probably never become more than demonstration projects. The few that are created will make a contribution to finding a humane and constructive way of temporarily housing people in distress.

HEADLINE: A Sweet Deal and a Sponsor Dropout

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
THE downturn in the co-op and condominium market in recent months has given tenants in some buildings going through the conversion process the sort of leverage that has resulted in some pretty sweet deals. But in other proposed conversions, the soft market has been a spoiler.
The paradox can be seen in the conversion efforts in two buildings in Manhattan.
After nearly 18 months of bargaining, the tenants in the 12-story building at 780 West End Avenue at 98th Street were able to negotiate an average 45 percent reduction in the original asking prices for their apartments. 
The negotiations with the sponsor also resulted in significant building improvements and a $1 million reserve fund.
''The timing of the conversion really put us in a good position for two reasons,'' said Richard Bellman, a tenant who served on the negotiating committee. ''While we were negotiating our deal, apartment prices in the neighborhood really started dropping. When we saw what was happening we felt we could be hard on the price issue.''
Another factor working in the tenants' favor, Mr. Bellman said, was that Alvin Dworman, a principal in the company sponsoring the condominium conversion plan for the building, was a new owner. He had bought the building in 1986 for $6.1 million, when real estate prices were at their highest.
''The rents in this building are stabilized,'' said Mr. Bellman. ''We didn't see how from a financial standpoint he could justify keeping the building a rental. We took advantage of that, too.''
Mr. Bellman said that in the initial offering plan, the six-room apartment he lives in was priced at $580,000 for outside buyers and $400,000 for existing tenants. By the end of negotiations the price for an insider had come down to $180,000. In addition to the price cuts, the sponsor agreed to install new windows and replace the roof and renovate the lobby and corridors.
Of the 61 units in the building, 25 were sold to existing tenants and, so far, six have been sold to outside buyers.
By contrast, the tough negotiating posture of tenants derailed a conversion plan for 228-330 Eighth Avenue near 26th Street.
''We had a core group of about five or six who were very interested in buying,'' said Hugh McLoughlin. ''With only 28 apartments in the building, that would have been enough to satisfy the 15 percent needed by the Attorney General's requirements.''
The first offering put the price of a one-bedroom apartments at $130,000 to $145,000. The tenants rejected it immediately. But Mr. McLoughlin said that the sponsors, Edward and Joan Cohen, agreed fairly early to come down. At one point the sponsors put a proposal on the table that gave insiders a 70 percent break on prices.
''Their strategy was to sell very low to a few of us just to meet the requirement,''' said Mr. McLoughlin. ''They hoped to make up the difference with sale of units at market rate to outsiders.''
ANOTHER reason the Cohens could justify giving very low prices to insiders was that the building's lucrative retail spaces would not be part of the residential conversion plan. They would stay in the sponsor's hands.
But the market did not cooperate. When co-op and condominium prices started on their downward course, Chelsea was one of the neighbohoods that led the way.
Another issue in the negotiations concerned the building's condition. An engineer's report the tenants had commissioned, Mr. McLoughlin said, revealed serious problems with the building's electrical and plumbing systems and boiler. The tenants negotiating to buy their apartments, Mr. McLoughlin said, insisted that any deal include renovations and repairs.
But when presented with that demand, the sponsors decided to drop the plan.
''Once the market fell apart,'' said Goldie Rotenberg, who served as the sponsor's attorney, ''the numbers did not work. The improvements the tenants were asking for would have taken too much money out of the deal. The bottom line was that it just did not make economic sense.''

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
Skirting the Potholes on Renovation Road

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN spring, many a homeowner's thoughts turn to remodeling the kitchen, enlarging the deck or adding a great room. And so it was in 1987, when Peter and Mary Gilman hired Lawrence Williams, a home-improvement contractor, to build an addition to their Wilton home and make some repairs to the house itself. ''We chose him because he was the lowest bidder,'' said Mrs. Gilman.
More than two years later they were some $57,000 poorer and living through a nightmare of mud and debris, of wind whistling through tarpaulins, of arguments over payments, of unanswered phone calls. The job was incomplete and a contractor's lien was placed on their home. 
Last October, after they and other customers of Mr. Williams complained to the Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection, he was arrested and tried, and on Dec. 13 in Superior Court in Bridgeport he was sentenced to two years in jail. He was convicted of having renovated 10 homes without first registering his business with the state - a criminal offense in Connecticut.
Because of prison overcrowding he was released 49 days later. Joseph Rubin, an assistant attorney general, said it is doubtful, but not impossible, that he could register and start working again.
Three other remodeling contractors were jailed for the same violation last year, and the court ordered $222,113 to be returned to clients by contractors, double the amount of the previous year. Home remodeling complaints referred by the State Department of Consumer Protection to the State Attorney General for criminal prosecution rose from 63 in the previous year to 120 last year, and 112 resulted in convictions.
But most of the state's 16,000 registered home remodelers appear to operate without major problems. Among them is Robert Hanbury, president of the House of Hanbury in Newington, who is completing a $65,000 job for Michael Kehoe in West Hartford.
''We called him back because we were so pleased with a $15,000 job he did for us two years ago,'' said Mr. Kehoe. ''He's expensive, but his work is very good, he finishes on time, and he understands the style of our 60-year-old house.'' Mr. Hanbury is co-chairman with Paul St. Onge of the newly formed Connecticut Remodelers Council, a division of the Connecticut Homebuilders Association.
Shoddy remodelers are a particular embarrassment to their reputable counterparts at a time when the home-improvement business is going through what Mr. St. Onge, president of the All Seasons Construction Company in West Hartford, calls ''as tight a time as I've known in 10 years.''
''Homes are going down in value,'' he said. ''Combine that with uncertainty about job security and people are holding off on that big addition or even a new bathroom.''
For those who do renovate, the watchword is caveat emptor. ''We're talking about a tremendous impact economically on the consumer,'' said June Neal, spokeswoman for the Department of Consumer Protection in Hartford.
Of the 1,800 remodeling complaints filed last year - the department's No. 1 problem - several represent losses of more than $100,000 each.
To help consumers, the state implemented a Guarantee Fund this past Jan. 1. Contractors and their salespeople must pay into it an annual fee ranging from $60 to $430. Victims of registered contractors can be reimbursed from the pool for losses up to $5,000 a job.
''It's scary for the public going into the marketplace,'' said Mr. St. Onge. ''We formed the council to provide a reliable referral service, to share ideas and experiences with our peers and upgrade the industry by holding educational seminars and dealing more effectively with legislative matters.''
SINCE registration does not constitute endorsement, proposals for more control through licensing of contractors crop up periodically. But the General Assembly consistently rejects them because of the diversity of skills involved and the expense of setting up a bureau. Carpenters, electricians and many other professionals are already licensed.
The council has 40 members in Connecticut, while the National Remodelers' Council in Washington has 4,000 members nationwide. Bryan Patchan, the national director, noted that ''in the Northeast, remodeling grew at a phenomenal rate from 1984 to 1988, but the industry has turned flat'' and that ''typically, people remodel an existing house when they move in, or a new house after about five years.''
Another trade organization - the 25-year-old International Remodeling Contractors Association in West Hartford, with 1,000 members nationwide, covers much the same ground, offering contractors and suppliers referrals, low-cost insurance and seminars about the industry and the law. The two organizations charge annual dues ranging from $150 to $450 a year.
''Both groups work with us,'' said Ms. Neal at the Consumer Protection office, ''but most contractors are not members of any trade association. They tend to be loners.''
For several years her department tried to reach consumers through a booklet outlining the do's and don'ts of hiring contractors. ''The trouble is that by the time you get your hands on one - usually when you get your building permit, you've already hired somebody,'' said Mrs. Gilman.
She learned too late that she should not have made that $5,000 down payment until material was delivered or work had begun. A written contract should have detailed all work and materials and a starting and completion date enforceable by law.
A waiver against liens placed by unpaid subcontractors should have been required, and the contractor's registration number should have been on the contract and on his truck, on his business cards and on his advertisements.
Consumers have three days in which to cancel and they are not obliged to pay for work done during that period. If the contractor arranges financing for the customer, he must comply with all Federal truth-in-lending and state banking laws.
''We have been unable to educate the consumer, so now we are trying to educate the contractor,'' said Ms. Neal. On April 27 her department will start a campaign touting the publication of its booklet called ''The Connecticut Contractor.''
''They will be mailed to registered contractors and available to the public on request,'' she said.
As for the Gilmans, ''I wish we had accepted another contractor's estimate for $85,000,'' said Mrs. Gilman. ''That's what it's going to cost by the time we pay somebody else to finish.''

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: 55 Wall Street;
Foreign Buyers Get a Costly Piece of Americana

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
AS the central meeting place of New York's business leaders, as the United States Custom House and as headquarters of the National City Bank (forerunner of Citibank), 55 Wall Street has always commanded attention. Today is no different. It has just been sold to foreign investors, including the Japanese, for $69.1 million.
In effect, they have bought two buildings in one that fills the block bounded by Hanover and William Streets and Exchange Place. The bottom building is the 150-year-old Merchants' Exchange, whose tremendous Ionic colonnade - brooding, deep and as enduring as the granite from which it was carved - gives Wall Street a classically noble air.
Atop that is a five-story addition by McKim, Mead & White, the centerpiece of which is an equally colossal Corinthian colonnade. Within the base is one of the grandest interiors in lower Manhattan, a banking room framed by 30-foot marble columns, under a coffered ceiling and a 72-foot-high dome. 
What the new owners paid is almost as remarkable as what they got. And it comes at a time when, as the Julien J. Studley brokerage has noted, ''the Japanese are becoming gun shy about trophy deals.''
The price for the 241,000-square-foot building works out to $287 a square foot. In one of the few vaguely comparable sales downtown - that is, a low-rise, turn-of-the-century, designated landmark - the former Chamber of Commerce building at 65 Liberty Street was sold to the International Commercial Bank of China last year for $5.6 million, or about $147 a square foot.
But Jeffrey R. Gural, one of the sellers of 55 Wall, said that its tremendous rotunda alone put it in a category by itself. ''You can't duplicate that space,'' he said. ''It is such a unique, valuable space. It offsets the price per square foot.'' Mr. Gural, together with Barry Gosin and Philip Pilevsky, paid $49 million for the building in December 1987. Mr. Gural said that the recent sale did not represent a $20 million windfall, given the ''substantial amount'' of money spent renovating the building, as well as transfer taxes and carrying costs.
Little is known about the new owners, who do business under the name of the 55 Wall Company, other than that Japanese purchasers are involved and that the group may also include Australian and Thai interests. Neither the sellers, the brokers nor the lawyer will identify them.
''I don't believe anyone is privy to the ultimate ownership of the company,'' said Robert Bell, a lawyer for the buyers, who included himself among those who do not have a complete picture of the company's composition. He did, however, stress that the building had not been bought by the Kajima Corporation of Tokyo, as had been reported in some accounts of the transaction, although he said there ''may be a link in some form or other'' between the buyers and Kajima.
About the owners' regard for 55 Wall Street, Mr. Bell was more explicit. ''They're in love with the building,'' he said. ''They think it's a fine structure, a fine piece of Americana. They intend to maintain it. They certainly have no intention of demolishing it or in any way altering it. And they have no intention of selling it.''
''It was bought more for the magnificence of the structure than for anything else,'' Mr. Bell said, although he added that the economics of the transaction were ''better than most of the deals that are being done now,'' given what the building will yield in income.
''THE Japanese have paid very, very high prices for properties in New York and other American cities in the recent past,'' said Irwin Shapiro of McDonagh Real Estate and Development, who, with Thomas McDonagh, brokered the 55 Wall Street deal. ''To the American real estate community, some of the deals they've made look ridiculous. But only time will tell. Maybe they know something we don't. Any company with that kind of buying power is not stupid. Maybe it behooves us to wait and see.''
Any contemplation of 55 Wall Street certainly invites the long view. ''If the walls could talk in this building,'' said Mark Sullivan, the chief engineer, ''they would have some stories to tell.''
Construction of the Merchants' Exchange was completed in 1842, to designs by Isaiah Rogers. In the 1860's, the structure was pressed into service as the Custom House and then purchased outright by the Federal Government for $1 million.
With the prospect of a new Custom House on Bowling Green, the Government sold the building to the National City Bank in 1899, for $3.3 million, although it did not move out for another eight years.
In December 1908, after McKim, Mead & White's addition was completed, 55 Wall Street reopened, with the grand Exchange Hall remodeled as an even more ornate Banking Room. Upstairs were City Bank headquarters and the offices of its longtime law firm, Shearman & Sterling.
The bank, which evolved into the First National City Bank of New York, kept its headquarters at 55 Wall until 1961, when it moved to 399 Park Avenue, between 53d and 54th Streets. It held on to 55 Wall, however, and still has a branch operation there, now under the Citibank name.
The building's air rights were sold in 1983 to George Klein, who was developing the 60 Wall Street tower across the street. Four years later, Shearman & Sterling moved out of 55 Wall Street and Citibank sold it.
Mr. Gural said he and his partners intended to flip 55 Wall Street. ''During the period we had the building under contract,'' he said, ''the Wall Street crash occurred. After that, we felt that the market was too unsettled to flip it. So we elected to buy it and lease it up and then decide what to do.''
They managed to lure several tenants, by far the largest of which is the law firm of Milgrim Thomajan & Lee, which was then in the Chrysler Building and looking for new offices in mid-Manhattan, without much luck.
''SPACE was inhospitable,'' said Roger M. Milgrim, a member of the firm. ''Modern office buildings often lack charm and character. The rents were staggering and we felt that we'd rather send our children and grandchildren to college than the landlord's.''
At 55 Wall Street, the lawyers found space for $23 a square foot, as opposed to $50 or $55 elsewhere. They kept some of the cherry doors and oak wainscoting from Shearman & Sterling days, as well as a sweeping oak staircase between the sixth and seventh floors. But the design firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox Conway also opened up the space.
Mr. Milgrim said that ''several partners were very concerned about the move downtown'' but that the firm had doubled in size since its move to Wall Street in May 1989. ''Our clients love coming here,'' he said. There are now about 125 lawyers in the firm, which built dining rooms, exercise rooms and child-care space.
''When I began practicing law in 1963,'' Mr. Milgrim recalled, ''it was considered extremely bad show for a so-called Wall Street firm to move to midtown. The earliest firms that did it - Kaye Scholer and Debevoise Plimpton - were genuinely viewed as having gone astray. Why would anyone move to midtown, since it was such a soulless, boring, sterile and arid area, compared to Wall Street?
''The answer then was very simple: They saved a fortune doing it. They were willing to go to a less satisfactory part of town to make themselves more competitive.
''Curious how the urban landscape changes, isn't it?''

HEADLINE: POSTING: Higher Limits;
Mortgage Pool

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Some New Yorkers shopping for their first home who have been unable to buy because they could not meet the qualifications for mortgages may benefit from significant relaxations in income and purchase-price limits put into effect this month by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, which issues bonds to generate a pool of money for mortgages. The agency has raised the old purchase-price limits on single-family houses by as much at $47,000 and increased some family-income limits by almost $9,000. 
A pool of $200 million is currently available for home loans carrying interest rates of 8.5 percent for fixed mortgages of 20, 25 and 30 years. The pool is sufficient to provide mortgages to 3,000 households for the purchase of a house or a cooperative or condominium apartment.
With the changes, annual income limits for single individuals and two-member families in New York City, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties increased from $45,400 to $48,650 and limits for families of three or more members rose from $53,000 to $56,760. For Nassau and Suffolk Counties the yearly income limits went from $53,000 to $59,520 for one- and two-person households and from $61,000 to $69,440 for households of three or more.
As for the maximum prices of houses, the limits for one-family houses in New York City, Westchester, Rockland and Putnum Counties rose from $158,000 to $193,600 and those in Nassau and Suffolk Counties rose from $156,000 to $185,700. Further details are available by telephoning the agency's toll-free information number, (800) 382-HOME.

HEADLINE: Dairy Farmers Face A 'Roller Coaster' Year

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER

 BODY:
AFTER reaching record high levels, the price of milk received by dairy farmers in Connecticut is falling sharply. But that decline has not yet been reflected in prices to consumers.
''It's a nerve-racking situation,'' said Robert Jacquier, a dairy farmer in East Canaan, in Litchfield County, who is also a board member of Agri-Mark, one of the largest dairy cooperatives in the Northeast.
Mr. Jacquier said he was concerned about the future of dairy farming in Connecticut and the entire Northeast because of a squeeze between rising costs of production and falling prices for milk. 
Because of the declining milk prices at the farm, Mr. Jacquier and the other 630 dairy farmers in Connecticut are facing an uncertain 1990 after coming though a good year in 1989.
 
Surge in Prices
Although figures for 1989 are not yet in, farmers and farm economists agree that dairy income rose, largely because of a surge in milk prices in the second half of the year, after four consecutive years of decline.
''Our conclusion is that 1989 will be significantly better than 1988,'' said Donald G. Stitts, professor of agricultural economics at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.
Even though prices at the farm are now declining and will continue to fall through June, Professor Stitts said they would start to rise again in the second half of the year. ''On the average, 1990 should be about the same as last year,'' he said.
 
Falling Cash Receipts
In 1988, the last year for which complete figures are available, cash receipts for the state's dairy farms fell to $73 million, down from $78 million in 1987, $81 million in 1986 and $86 million in 1985, according to the New England Agricultural Statistics Service in Concord, N.H.
''The dairy industry had a good year in 1989 but is being battered again so far in 1990,'' said the State Commissioner of Agriculture, Kenneth B. Andersen.
He compared dairy-farm income to a roller-coaster ride, with sharp ups and downs, largely beyond the control of the dairy farmers.
The farm price of milk in Connecticut and other states is determined by national market forces, basically by the price of cheese at auction in Wisconsin, the nation's leading milk state.
 
Distance From Boston
In Connecticut, the price is adjusted slightly by the distance a farm is from Boston, the headquarters of the New England Milk Marketing Order, a Federal agency that regulates the sale of milk to processors in the area, and by milk's butterfat content. The agency sets a minimum price for milk monthly; but in recent months, many processors in the Northeast have been paying a premium over the minimum because of a shortage of milk.
Another factor, a strong demand for cheese nationally, caused the price paid in December and January to northwestern Connecticut farmers to rise to $16.34 for 100 pounds of milk with 3.5 percent butterfat (or 33.8 cents a quart).
But when the demand for cheese dropped early this year, the price fell to $15.64 in March and is expected to drop to $12.68 by June, dairy economists said.
''I would say that 1990 is going to be a very difficult year for dairy farmers,'' said Norma O'Leary, president of the Connecticut Farm Bureau. Mrs. O'Leary and her husband, Ernest, are dairy farmers in Thompson.
''With prices going down and costs continuing to go up, it becomes harder and harder for farmers to survive in the dairy industry in this state,'' she said.
 
Record Retail Price
For consumers, the decline in farm prices has not yet shown up on the retail level, with prices last week even higher than last year. In December, the State Department of Agriculture reported a record retail price of a gallon of milk with 4 percent butterfat at between $2.25 and $2.59.
Since then, the price to consumers has continued to rise. Following a market survey on Monday, the market reporter for the Department of Agriculture, Jane Murdock, said she found gallons of milk ranging from $2.53 to $2.74 and half-gallons from $1.43 to $1.49.
But some convenience stores are advertising a gallon of milk with 1 percent butterfat as low as $1.99.
Milk is one of Connecticut's major products, with dairy farms forming a large component of the state's agriculture, ranking behind greenhouse and nursery products and eggs in annual sales. In 1988, greenhouse products accounted for 30 percent of all agricultural sales in the state, eggs 22 percent and milk 19 percent.
 
$478 Million Income
In its latest survey, the Regional Statistics Service reported a gross income of $478 million for all Connecticut farms in 1988, up from $463 millon the year before; expenses of $299 million, up from $292 million, and a net income of $179 million, up from $171 million.
Among Connecticut's major crops, it listed cash receipts from farm marketing: nursery and greenhouse, $116 million; eggs, $82 million; milk, $73 million; tobacco, $20 million; cattle and calves, $13 millon; vegetables, $12 millon; apples, $10 million; hay, $8 million, and sweet corn, $5 millon.
It put the number of farms in Connecticut at 4,000, but most of those were hobby and or part-time farms, with afarm income of less than $10,000 a year. The commercial farms, those that have a cash income of $10,000 or more from their crops each year, numbered 1,487.
 
500 Cows
In East Canaan, Mr. Jacquier and his family operate a large commercial farm, milking 500 cows. His home farm covers 120 acres, but he rents 600 acres more to grow crops to feed the cows.
''Over the last few years, dairy farmers have been squeezed by low prices and rising costs,'' he said. ''As a result, many have not replaced or repaired their buildings and equipment. And taxes have increased; there has been a tremendous increase in insurance, and fuel and fertilizer costs are going up, too. I see many more dairy farms going out of business.''
But he is optimistic about the future of his farm. ''We are fortunate,'' he said. ''We have grandsons to carry on.''

HEADLINE: A Campaign to Attract New Business

BYLINE: By Tessa Melvin

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
FOUR prominent developers are asking the county to contribute funds to their $1 million marketing campaign to attract new businesses to Westchester.
Hoping to fill a growing number of empty office buildings in the county, each developer has contributed $50,000 and has promised to help raise another $600,000. H. Guy Leibler, president of the Schulman Realty Group, called their campaign ''an opportunity to keep the glass full; to do that, you have to bring in new business.''
The other three developers are Lee Neibart, executive vice president of the Robert Martin Company; Jon Halpern, vice president of development for Halpern Enterprises, and Louis R. Cappelli, general partner of Saturn Construction Company. 
 
O'Rourke Asks for $200,000
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has asked the Board of Legislators to approve a $200,000 contribution to the development campaign. Citing the economic slowdown, Mr. O'Rourke said it was ''critical for Westchester to market itself aggressively.''
Unless the county can stimulate its economy, Mr. O'Rourke told the legislators, ''the domino effect of a collapsing region will affect us.''
The request is being considered by the Board's Budget and Appropriations Committee. It has asked Margaret S. Soter, the county's Director of Commerce and Constituent Affairs, to explain the county's request to the committee at its meeting on Thursday.
''Our economy is closely tied to New York City,'' said Katherine S. Carsky, the committee's chairwoman. ''What makes us think that if a business is leaving the city because of high taxes and a manpower shortage, they will stop in Westchester? These questions must be addressed.''
The money would be drawn from a special reserve fund dedicated to settling tax claims, Mrs. Carsky said. ''We intend to look at this proposal very closely,'' she added.
 
A List of the Indicators
If approved, the appropriation would be the largest contribution of county tax money ever offered to market Westchester business, according to county officials.
''We have to be realistic,'' Mr. O'Rourke said last week. ''The whole Northeast is in a downtrend. In Westchester, the sales-tax revenue is down. There is increased vacancy in our offices, business travel is down and new construction has slowed. Those are all indicators that the time to do something about it is here.''
Office-vacancy rates in the county over the last year reached 20 percent, the 17th highest rate in the country. That figure does not truly measure the amount of ''quality space'' available, Mr. Leibler suggested. Noting that his company's buildings have an 11 percent vacancy rate, he said, ''Five years ago that figure stood at 2 percent, so the current situation is clearly unsatisfactory.''
S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association, said the county's economy was ''the victim of uncontrolled regional, state and national factors.'' He cited cutbacks at companies with headquarters in Westchester, as well as a downturn in construction work, as examples of the current economic climate.
 
Cuts in Staff Are Noted
A survey released by the Westchester County Association last fall said that in the last three years, six of the county's 10 biggest corporations have reduced their work forces, including International Business Machines, General Motors, Reader's Digest, Kraft, Con Edison and Pepsico.
Despite these reductions, total employment has remained steady and unemployment - at 3.5 percent - remains low.
''There really isn't a crisis here in Westchester,'' said Connie Freid, director of the county's Office of Economic Development, whose office will help direct the marketing campaign. ''We are saying, let's get our act together before there is a crisis. The office buildings are there. Let's fill them up.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12, Column 5; Education Life

LENGTH: 129 words

HEADLINE: FLASHCARD

 BODY:
A RECENT report from the Economic Policy Institute says the United States spends less on primary and secondary education than most other industrialized nations. The institute, a research organization in Washington, D.C., compared the percentage of national income spent during 1985 on education from preprimary through high school in 16 nations, including most of Western Europe, Japan, Australia, Canada and the United States. The figure for the United States was 4 percent, less than the spending levels for 11 other countries. If the spending figures are adjusted for the size of the school-age population in each country, only Australia and Ireland spent less than the United States on education from preprimary to 12th grade. - Economic Policy Institute

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 29, Column 1; Education Life

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: A SPECIAL REPORT: Numbers Please!;
Body Heat

BYLINE: By Calvin Sims

 BODY:
PUBLIC SCHOOLS in Buffalo are so overcrowded that until the city gets the money to build additional space, teachers must conduct classes in auditoriums, cafeterias, gymansiums, storage spaces and rooms leased from nearby Roman Catholic schools.
In Los Angeles, about 24,000 students are being bused each day, not because of a mandate to desegregate but because there is no room for them at their home schools. And the number of older and part-time students, especially women over 25, is growing so rapidly at the California State University at Northridge that demand for child-care services increased 20 percent last year.
Public school districts and universities nationwide are both witnessing a demographic explosion in their student populations, fueled by a rising number of annual births, a huge wave of immigration and an influx of older and part-time college students.
The deluge of new students - many of whom need special language classes, child-care services and financial aid - is creating a critical shortage of classroom space, qualified instructors and resources that education officials are trying to supply through a variety of new programs and services. 
But many experts in the demographics of education say such programs must ultimately fail. The nation's education system, they argue, is not equipped to accommodate the diverse needs of a student population that is expected to increase 10 percent by the year 2000 at the elementary, secondary and university levels.
''There's going to be a great flood of students at all grade levels throughout this decade and unless we build bigger schools, hire more teachers and get more money, I don't think we will be able to educate them properly,'' said Vance Grant, a specialist at the National Center for Education Statistics, a division of the Education Department.
 
10 Percent Increase in 10 Years
The numbers speak for themselves. The total enrollment in public and private elementary and secondary schools is expected to reach 49.7 million in 1998, a 10 percent increase from 45.4 million in 1988, according to a report by the Education Statistics Center. By the year 2000, the number of students from kindergarten through the 12th grade will be 49.5 million. Total enrollment decreased steadily from 1975 to 1984, reaching a low of 45 million, a reflection of the decline in the school-age population. But as the children of the baby-boom generation entered school, enrollment shot up.
The changing demographics pose new challenges for districts that contended with declining enrollments in the 1970's and must now prepare for a boom in elementary- and secondary-school students in the 1990's. To accommodate new students, officials are reopening schools closed several years ago, switching to year-round school schedules, squeezing more pupils into classrooms, busing students to less-crowded schools, setting up portable classrooms in playground space and recruiting teachers, especially those who are bilingual. Hit hardest by the growth in student populations will be the Southern and Western portions of the nation, which have expanding immigrant populations and expanding economies. Western states, like California, Nevada and New Mexico, will witness a 12 percent rise in total enrollment of elementary and secondary students. In the South, where enrollment is expected to rise 6 percent, states like Florida, Georgia and Maryland will grow the fastest.
 
Los Angeles Feeling the Crunch
No city is feeling the effects of the student body boom like Los Angeles, which last year enrolled 15,000 new public school students, 11,000 of whom were at the elementary level. With many of its 600 elementary, junior and senior high schools at more than 100 percent capacity, the Los Angeles School District recently adopted a year-round schedule at more than 100 schools; the remainder are expected to switch to some type of year-round program by next year.
Still, Los Angeles schools remain overcrowded, and the district has been forced to try a more controversial solution - busing. Every day about 24,000 of the district's 610,000 students are bused throughout the vast Los Angeles region because there is no space for them at their community schools.
Most of these students are immigrants who need help with English. But they often find there are too few bilingual instructors to teach them when they arrive at their destination. About 61 percent of the district's students are Hispanic, 16 percent are black, 15 percent are white, and the remainder are Asian or Pacific Islanders.
''We are coping the best way we know how, but you have to realize that much of the busing is only a temporary solution until we build more schools and hire more teachers,'' said Joyce Peyton, an administrator in the district's priority-housing department, which is responsible for providing each student with a seat.
The school district plans to build 24 new schools by 1995, through a $571 million bond issue that comes up in June. It recently began a recruitment program for bilingual teachers, who are paid as much as $5,000 a year above the starting salary of $27,300.
 
Nationwide Enrollment Increases
Many of Los Angeles's problems are being faced by school districts nationwide, where enrollment from kindergarten through eighth grade is projected to rise to 35.2 million by 1996, from 32.4 million in 1988, and to end the decade slightly lower, at 34.7 million. At grades 9 through 12, enrollment peaked at 15.7 million in 1976, declining 16 percent, to 13 million, by 1988. It is expected to decline 3 percent more by the end of this year, to 12.6 million. But enrollment in grades 9 through 12 will rise to 14.8 million by the year 2000, an 18 percent increase from 1990, reflecting a significant increase in the number of 14-to-17-year-olds.
Schools in Buffalo have seen a 7.8 percent increase in students in the last year because of the growing number of baby-boomer children and an influx of Puerto Rican students whose parents migrated to the area after Hurricane Hugo laid waste to part of the island last fall.
School officials say it will cost about $700 million to build an estimated 380 additional classrooms to provide for these youngsters. ''Our local community does not have the the capital dollars to meet our needs,'' said Joseph T. Murray, Buffalo's associate superintendent for instructional services. ''The only hope would be a bond issue or help from the Federal Government by having it direct some of the savings from the defense cuts to education.''
The Federal education report, titled ''Projections of Education Statistics,'' estimates that enrollment in institutions of higher education will increase from 12.8 million in 1988 to 13.4 million by the year 2000. The shift is attributable in part to rising enrollment rates among 18-to-22-year-olds and an increase in the number of older and part-time students.
To meet the needs of older students, colleges and universities are scheduling more classes in the late afternoons and evenings, giving students who must work during the day a greater variety of classes from which to choose. Some schools, like the California State University system, have also extended their day-care facilities. Other schools are allowing older students to exchange their life experiences for college credits toward a degree.
 
American University in
Washington, D.C., offers a life-experience program in which older students write essays that explain and analyze important events in their lives. The essays are reviewed by professors who specialize in fields corresponding to the events and award credit based on the experience.
It is a daunting task, according to Lorraine Newlon, director of admissions and records at California State at Northridge. ''The traditional college student is giving way to older students and students returning for second dgrees,'' she said. ''At the same time, we are expecting a wave of new students, most of whom are minorities. We are devising programs to meet the needs of both groups, a task that is not the easiest to perform.''

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 27, Column 1; Education Life

LENGTH: 2046 words

HEADLINE: A SPECIAL REPORT: Numbers Please!;
Moving Targets

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
The educational-industrial complex is regularly counting the students of America (and these days that's anyone between ages 3 and 93).
After all, the numbers of students, their ages, ethnic or racial backgrounds, home states, graduation dates and rates are what make education policy go round - and round again, given the unreliability of some predictions.
Still, communities, colleges and the country at large depend on these numbers to guide education initiatives, budgets, curriculum and planning. The following pages focus on the resulting numbers game, its winners and losers.
Remedial statistics, anyone? 
STUDENTS ARE a resource, a burden and a market. That is why so many people want the definitive profile of the national student body, a week from now and a generation from now.
Everything from curriculum to manufacturing schedules depends on it.
So a lot of people are practicing some variety of demography: economists and sociologists, state education planners and village school boards, legislators and cap-and-gown makers. They project body counts and try to calculate the ages, ethnicity and location of the bodies. One problem with this exercise is that the variables seem limitless, and ever-changing. Fertility rates zigzag. Local economies bloom and fade. People move, in what seems to be no orderly fashion. And the information that is easy to come by - say, how many 18-year-olds the nation will have in 1998 - says little to school planners in Indianapolis or Biloxi, Miss.
''The education statistics - the teachers, enrollment, graduates, expenditure levels - are all involved with what goes on in society,'' said Debra E. Gerald, a statistician who is in charge of the projections published by the Federal Education Department's National Center for Education Statistics.
In any one place, what goes on in society can produce large dislocations: Los Angeles, caught between a statewide shortage of school construction money and a population boom in the inner city, has started year-round schedules because even the mobile classrooms have no more space. In northeast Queens, in New York City, 1 in 4 students in District 26 schools is Asian, up from 1 in 20 seven or eight years ago; every reading teacher must now be certified in English as a second language. In New Jersey, several state colleges that once enrolled 10,000 students now have 6,000 - and the problem of shrinking some programs.
Through a nationwide lens, these glitches resolve into a single concern that has become more compelling as the baby bust grows up and the baby boomlet enters school: that schools turn out enough educated and educable young adults for the next few decades.
''From an economic perspective, you always want to get the most productivity,'' said Lewis C. Solmon, dean of the Graduate School of Education at the University of California at Los Angeles and author of a widely used economics text. ''It becomes even more urgent when we don't have that many people to pick from.''
The 1980's were an interesting chapter, statistically speaking. Forecasters could project elementary and secondary enrollments fairly accurately, but they generally underestimated high school graduation rates. Knowing that the 18-to-24-year-old population would dip about 10 percent during the decade, they projected a decrease in college enrollments. One academic study foresaw a decline of more than 40 percent. Instead, according to the Education Department, the total between 1980 and 1988 rose almost 8 percent.
Not that demographers hadn't been wrong before. Birthrates, for example: Census Bureau forecasters missed the baby boom, seeing it as a blip of catch-up childbearing after World War II. They were baffled by the first years of the baby bust, which brought a decline in births roughly from the mid-60's through the 70's. They overestimated and then underestimated birthrates among women born in the 1950's. The number of babies born in 1987 and 1988, for example, significantly exceeded 1984 and 1985 Census Bureau projections, which means that schools do not have much more than a five-year headway on kindergarten enrollments.
 
College Enrollments Exceed Forecasts
Higher-education enrollments, at least over the long range, have regularly exceeded Government projections. In 1964, when the Education Department started publishing projections, it forecast a total college enrollment of 7.9 million in 1973; the actual enrollment that year was 9.6 million. In 1979, the center's intermediate projection for 1988 (the agency was by then issuing three sets, based on differing sets of assumptions) was 11 million; the actual head count was 13 million.
The groups that unexpectedly showed up in college in the 1980's were led by older students, particularly divorced women. Among those who did not show up were large numbers of black and Hispanic youths: their relative numbers in the 18-to-24-year-old projection are up, but their proportions in college are down.
Another trend few foresaw was that as the college population shrank, its enrollment rates grew. The ''cohort effect'' is largely the theory of Richard A. Easterlin, an economist at the University of Southern California. As he charts postwar generations, their size and college-enrollment rates generally vary inversely, in part because fewer children means more opportunity for each, since colleges prefer to maintain enrollment levels. Mr. Easterlin and two colleagues wrote in 1981 that the 1980's would see an enrollment increase.
Another who was on the right track 10 years ago was Carol Frances, a Washington-based economist and consultant to many higher-education groups. As chief economist for the American Council on Education, comprised of four-year colleges and universities, she wrote that enrollment could rise 3.5 percent during the 1980's, if colleges could take advantage of a growing economy and recruit promising nontraditional groups, like older women.
That is exactly what colleges did. Where there were concentrations of older working people, there was expansion of adult programs and heavy advertising. New York University's School of Continuing Education, for example, tried direct mail, with postcards reading, ''How to Turn a Change in Your Life Into the Chance of Your Life.'' Enrollment has risen 50 percent since 1978.
Similar efforts at many schools succeeded with high school audiences, too. And when the colleges' recruitment binge paid off, the forecasts of enrollment declines naturally turned out to be wrong.
''Every time you make a projection and people pick up on it, they start reacting to it, and their reaction changes what happens,'' said Robin Etter Zuniga, who directs projections of high school graduates for the Western Interstate Commission on Higher Education, in Boulder, Colo. ''If institutions are concerned about the decline, they will take steps to do something about it that will change the projections.''
''Sure, we missed things,'' she added. ''But we can't say that if you get better data or fine-tune your methods, they would give you better projections.''
 
More Like Economic Predictions
Ms. Gerald said, however, that forecasting had improved since she joined the center more than a decade ago, when many predictions were based on extrapolation methods. Now, she says, models account for variables like unemployment, making the whole enterprise less like an actuary's and more like an economist's. When a model goes wrong, the center tries to identify faulty assumptions; then it revises other projections.
More specific methods can be devised for more specific inquiries. In Seattle, for instance, where public school enrollment has declined from 99,000 in 1963 to 41,000 this year, district planners wanted to know where to close schools and how to anticipate patterns of demand for specialized or magnet schools and transfers to achieve racial balance. Demographers at the University of Washington divided the city into geographic units of 50 to 100 students, analyzed past patterns of attendance and transfers in each unit and projected demand for staff, buildings and special programs.
In designing the desegregation plan that took effect last year, the model was indispensable. The district also closed five more schools last year, and used the demographic analysis to redraw school boundaries.
Colleges want more details on prospective students. James J. Scannell, a vice president at the University of Rochester in New York, who has consulted to many colleges on recruiting and enrollment, said that to most institutions, ''demographics'' means market research. College administrators are ''not as sophisticated as Xerox'' in this regard, he said, ''but 20 or 25 years ago, 'demographics' was not a word in anyone's vocabulary in higher education because it was a boom time.''
The College Board, for one, has met this thirst for information with a computer program that gives subscribers data on 304 geographic markets. For any market, the program can say, for example, how many Hispanic S.A.T.-takers live there and which colleges receive their scores. A more refined version is coming.
It is not clear how much the forecasts of decline, and the actual declines in elementary and secondary schools, contributed to paring state and Federal education budgets. It is clear that education advocates did not like the message.
 
'They're Trying to Hold Down Budgets'
''Generally, the people who make their living making these projections - or at least the people who consume the information - are in the budget-making process,'' Ms. Frances said. ''They're generally agents of an administration facing budget constraints, so they're trying to hold down budgets.''
Now, while the budgets remain about the same, the population is bulging in different places. Elementary-school enrollments, which bottomed out in 1984, are climbing slowly and are projected to peak in 1996. The peak in high school enrollment is expected four years later. According to the Federal Government, the total increase from 1990 to 1999 will be 7 percent to 8 percent.
These national data are not very useful to local districts. But they can provide rough guidance to Federal teacher-training programs, textbook publishers and other large-scale consumers of demographic data.
Planning for college enrollments is trickier. Ms. Frances says demand for retraining displaced workers can increase enrollments in the 1990's, but only if colleges accommodate this uncollegiate group. Lewis Solmon at U.C.L.A. forecasts a decline. The three Federal Government projections range from a 3 percent decrease to a 12 percent increase between 1988 and 2000.
The consensus is that the older-student boom is ending as the pool of adults most likely to return to college has been heavily tapped. Total enrollments are expected to dip and then rise slightly. There is also agreement, and worry, that an increasing proportion of 18-year-olds will be unprepared for college-level work.
''We could turn the colleges into massive high schools,'' Dean Solmon said, ''but it wouldn't serve any social need. And it would be awfully expensive.''
The alternative, educators generally agree, is to invest more in lower grades and direct social spending to children. One advocate of this approach is Harold L. Hodgkinson, director of the Center for Demographic Policy at the Institute for Educational Leadership, a Washington research group. Dr. Hodgkinson told a House Education and Labor subcommittee last month that Head Start was the best way to insure that children from low-income families finished high school, given the differences in achievement 10 to 20 years later between Head Start children and control groups.
Dr. Hodgkinson is worried about the low-income constituency. Nearly a quarter of American children under age 6 live in poverty, he said, which means they are especially likely to have health and learning problems. He also cited projections showing that nearly all the increase in the school population is coming from racial minorities with much higher than average poverty rates. That prospect raises different kinds of demographic questions, and everyone agrees that they are much harder than crunching numbers.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 36, Column 2; Education Life

LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: THE SPRING REPORT;
Spawning Grounds

BYLINE: By Eric N. Berg

 BODY:
VIVIAN PALEY'S research is about as fundamental as education research gets, and original enough to win her a MacArthur Foundation grant, the so-called genius awards: she is trying to teach children to think - to come up with an idea and develop it in a logical way.
Her experiment has youngsters turning their ideas into skits. Her tools are the children; her laboratory, the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, comprising a lower, middle and high school. Founded by the educator and philosopher John Dewey in 1896, the schools are the ''granddaddy'' of all such proving grounds for teaching methods and curriculums.
''I equate lab schools with chemistry labs or biology labs in the natural sciences,'' said John Johnson, executive secretary of the National Association of Laboratory Schools, based in Indiana, Pa. ''They are spawning grounds for new ideas and new pedagogy.'' 
Today, those spawning grounds are alive with ideas, as lab schools, which have long suffered budget cuts and lack of interest, enjoy a comeback.
Carnegie-Mellon University's lab school is studying how Macintosh computers can help develop a preschooler's sense of shape and color. The lab school at the State University College at Buffalo is focusing on new teaching methods for brain-damaged children. The Illinois State University at Normal is examining how technology, physical therapy and motivation theory can be combined to benefit learning-disabled students, while the school at the University of Hawaii is trying to make science instruction more alluring by including health, technology and the environment in the curriculum.
 
Building Self-Confidence
Studies are also under way to help teachers build students' self-confidence, as at the University of Chicago laboratory school, where first-graders are encouraged to write - and never mind their incorrect spelling, grammar and syntax. ''Lab schools are a volcano that is showing signs of puffing,'' said Mr. Johnson.
Those signs are difficult to document, but suggestive:
* The number of lab schools recently started increasing. It now stands at about 100.
* In the last year, at least three universities expressed interest in starting lab schools: the University of Alabama at Birmingham, the University of British Columbia at Vancouver and the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.
* At the National Association of Laboratory Schools, the number of institutional members has risen to 65 schools, from 55 three years ago. The number of faculty members has jumped to 2,000, from 1,700. More than 150 lab-school officials attended the association's annual conference recently, up from 100 last year.
* Nationally, lab schools -particularly those specializing in elementary education - are reporting long waiting lists for admission.
Laboratory schools flourished through the post-World War II period, only to slump in the 1970's and early 1980's. On college campuses, where most of the schools are situated, administrators appreciated their purpose, but often viewed them as costly alternatives to what could just as easily be achieved in public schools. Indeed, most graduate schools of education still use public schools to give would-be teachers classroom experience and to enable them to try new teaching methods.
 
Different Backgrounds
Many teachers are going into schools where students are of broadly different economic and cultural backgrounds, said Beverly Carter, director of the Stanford/Schools Collaborative, a joint venture of Stanford University and surrounding school districts. ''To improve education in such a challenging environment,'' she said, ''Stanford has concluded that there is no better way to proceed than to go into the public schools.''
But with so many universities proceeding the same way, and the current increase in the number of would-be teachers, experimental elbow room in the public schools is shrinking - a possible explanation for the lab school's renaissance as both laboratory and teacher-trainee proving grounds.
Educators are also recognizing that the schools can be used to update older teachers. They note, too, that testing teaching methods in public schools has not produced the desired results, leaving lab schools as, potentially, the more powerful sources of change.
At the Chicago lab school, for example, one group of teachers was recently seen observing children as they took their turn handing out milk to classmates. By determining who finishes the job and who shares with whom, the teachers hope to understand how schools transmit values to students.
 
Make-Believe Car Trip
In another classroom, math is taught using a make-believe trip around the world in which youngsters were given a fictitious car with make-believe mileage and had to compute how far they could travel with a given amount of gasoline.
The availability of such innovative teaching persuaded Mary Rhodes to send her children to the lab school. Mrs. Rhodes, a resident of Chicago's wealthy Gold Coast district and now president of the Chicago lab school's Parents' Association, could easily have chosen other prominent private schools here. But she explained: ''There is a richness in the learning experience that you do not get elsewhere.''
The students agree. Andrea Jackson, 10 years old and a student at the Chicago lab school, said that from talking with friends at other schools, she believes lab schools give a little less homework, but that it is harder. ''The homework takes a lot of concentration,'' she said. ''Each page takes a long time to complete because you have to think about it so hard.''
Some parents take a less positive view. ''If there were a decent public school system in Chicago, I would not be sending my child to the lab school,'' said the mother of one student at the Chicago lab school, who asked that her name not be used. ''Most of us send our children there by default.''
Lab schools' flexibility can be traced in part to their status as independent, not-for-profit institutions, like that of private schools. Lab schools are not governed by an often-political board of education; rather they are run by the faculty, supervised by a board of directors and financed through tuition fees and alumni donations. Their ties to the universities are few but salient: the university's education school sends students to the lab school for teaching experience or to conduct research.
Also, like most private schools, many lab schools charge hefty tuitions and serve large numbers of professors' children. This has exposed them to charges that they are enclaves for upper-middle-income students fleeing inner-city public schools.
Nonetheless, because they draw from a larger pool of prospective students than a typical public school, and because they can be selective, lab schools tend to create a student body that, while generally well-to-do, is also ethnically and racially diverse. ''The Chicago public schools were too segregated for me,'' said Kathy Dawkins, an assistant teacher whose kindergarten at the Chicago lab school includes children from Taiwan, Nigeria, Mexico and Iran.
Despite this allure, many people think the current resurgence in lab schools may be short-lived, especially when a number of their supervisory universities are facing budget pressures that, because many lab schools are on university-owned land, could force them off the campus.
 
An Issue of Space
At the University of California at Los Angeles, the issue is space: The lab school is on nine acres of parkland on which the university wants to build. Lewis Solmon, dean of U.C.L.A.'s Graduate School of Education, has said the university is pledged to safeguarding the school's autonomy should it join the local public schools, and is seeking exemptions from state laws that might restrict its experimentation. But parents and school staff are dubious.
So are administrators at other lab schools. ''Somebody has got to be the custodian of education, keeping it alive and constantly updating it with new ideas,'' said Loretta Krause, administrator of the lab school at the University of Hawaii. ''Lab schools view themselves as that custodian.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 31, Column 1; Education Life

LENGTH: 1439 words

HEADLINE: A SPECIAL REPORT: Numbers Please!;
A House Divided

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
HIGHER BIRTHRATES and a stream of new immigrants are driving up the number and proportion of black, Hispanic and Asian people in the United States so fast that soon after the year 2000 they will make up a third of the nation's students.
With their symphony of languages and cultures, these minority members, who at present total about 23 percent of all Americans, will occupy one of every three desks in America's classrooms. Their numbers will present challenges unlike anything most states have seen since the great migrations of the turn of the century. Schools will be hard pressed to prepare these Americans, many of them poor, for a more sophisticated work force. ''What's at stake,'' said Dr. John F. Noonan, president of Bloomfield College in Bloomfield, N.J., where half the 1,600 students are members of minorities, ''is the future of the country.''
The record so far is not encouraging. The 1988 study, ''One-third of a Nation,'' concluded that: ''America is moving backward - not forward - in its efforts to achieve the full participation of minority citizens in the life and prosperity of the nation.'' It concluded that since the mid-1970's minorities have become comparatively poorer and increasingly segregated in distressed, urban neighborhoods where schools sometimes harbor failure. Their financial picture grows dimmer as tuition rises leave financial aid further and further behind. 
 
Decline in the Colleges
A smaller percentage of minority members are going to college. In 1976 the percentage of black high school graduates who enrolled in college was 50.4. By 1988 it had dropped to 46.6 percent. During the same period, the college participation rate for white students rose from 53.5 percent to 58.6 percent. Hispanic students' participation also declined, but not so severely as that of blacks. In 1976 48.9 percent of Hispanic high school graduates were in college. By 1988 the figure had slipped to 47.1 percent.
In addition, blacks, especially black men, earned fewer bachelor's and master's degrees over the last decade. Fewer became teachers, which could hurt black students looking for someone to emulate.
The picture is markedly different for Asians, but even there educators see trouble. From 1976 to 1986, Asian enrollment at two- and four-year colleges increased 126 percent, and could double again over the next decade. But many of the newest and fastest-growing groups of Asian immigrants, those from Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, may not be able to repeat the success of earlier immigrants. For one thing they are poorer; their rate of poverty, 35 percent, is as high as that for Puerto Ricans and Mexican-Americans. They also arrive with less preparation for learning and lower expectations.
As the number of minority students surges, demographic forecasts indicate that past problems could quickly multiply. From 1968 to 1986 Hispanic students' enrollment in public schools nationwide doubled, from 2 million to 4.1 million, while enrollment for whites dropped 16 percent. During the same period, black enrollment rose 5 percent, from 6.3 million to 6.6 million. Students from Asia, currently America's fastest-growing minority group, jumped 55 percent in the 1980's alone, from 749,000 to 1.2 million.
Already in 25 of the largest American cities and metropolitan areas, more than half the public school students come from minority groups. But also in towns and villages that 10 years ago were nearly all white, substantial and growing numbers of minority students have arrived, bearing special talents and needs.
 
Schools Being Forced to Change
They have already forced schools on all levels to change. New Rochelle, N.Y., has a new-arrivals program in two elementary schools to handle Mexican and Salvadoran immigrants. In East Orange, N.J., where schools are 98 percent black, troubled students identified as potential dropouts receive special support each week for 27 weeks, starting as early as the fourth grade. Gettysburg College, in Pennsylvania, has opened a genealogical research center specializing in slave records and uses it to attract black students.
Perhaps the most profound shift is that schools are beginning to understand that they no longer can simply label minority students Hispanic, Asian or black, making generalizations about their needs and talents. Rather they must take into account students' economic, social and education backgrounds, differentiating Cubans from Mexicans, Vietnamese from Chinese. ''It's a tremendous challenge,'' said Dr. Ronald H. Rolph, the superintendent of schools in Holland, Mich., a city of 24,000 residents on the shore of Lake Michigan.
Twenty years ago Holland was an almost completely white, Dutch Calvinist community. Today, Dr. Rolph said, 28 percent of the district's students are from minorities. Most are Mexican-Americans who traveled the migrant-worker stream from Texas and decided to settle. The others are Cambodian, Laotian and Vietnamese boat people sponsored by local religious groups.
Holland now has two bilingual programs, in Spanish and Vietnamese. College night is held in both English and Spanish. When the only high school guidance counselor left three years ago, the Holland district searched a full year for a bilingual-bicultural counselor to replace her.
 
Transforming School and Community
By their presence alone, these minority students transform a school, a district and a community. Bobby Fong, dean for the arts and humanities at Hope College in Holland, says his 5-year-old son, Jonathan, comes home from kindergarten talking about his Mexican friends and saying ''Adios, amigos.''
Dr. Fong's appointment at Hope College in itself represents a shift in attitudes. He is the first Asian-American and the first person from outside the Reformed Church to head a department at the 2,700-student Calvinist school.
Alfredo M. Gonzales, appointed assistant dean for multicultural life two years ago, said the college was hiring more minority faculty members and revising its curriculum. It probably will require all students to take courses in ethnic culture or non-Western literature before graduation.
For Hope, the demographic trends are still in the future. But at Incarnate Word College in San Antonio half the student body already is either black or Hispanic. One of the fastest-growing private colleges in the Southwest, Incarnate Word has doubled its enrollment, to 2,500, since 1985, with Hispanic students taking substantially more of the new seats than whites. The Roman Catholic college spends about $1 million a year in advertising, printing half in English and half in Spanish. It also increased its financial aid, to $2.3 million a year.
Corina Cortez of George West, Tex., is one of the students attracted to and helped by the college's new outlook. The 21-year-old senior accounting major comes from a family of five; her parents did not graduate from high school, and Spanish is spoken at home.
Miss Cortez said Incarnate Word had contacted her and invited her to the campus. Because there was so little money at home, she said she thought she might attend for one year and then go to work. ''Never in a million years did I think I'd get a degree in four years,'' she said. With financial aid from several sources she is now in her fourth year of college.
As they graduate, students like Miss Cortez leave behind an academic landscape whose changes extend beyond recruitment and financial aid. Educators are realizing that many cultures now represented in the classroom have been largely excluded from the history, arts and philosophies that students have been taught. ''Increasingly,'' said David Abalos, a professor of religious studies at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., ''what scholars are asking is not just what history has said, but what history has not said.''
Mr. Abalos, who is Mexican-American, spent a year helping the New Jersey Department of Education develop a curriculum with a global approach to literature and world culture. Other states, including New York and Minnesota, are undertaking similar revisions.
''What's happening is deeper and wider than demographics,'' Mr. Abalos said. He noted that when American public schools were established in the 19th century, a main goal was to make immigrants good Americans, which usually meant hiding their languages, customs and religions. As classrooms fill with more people of color, Mr. Abalos believes that is no longer the case.
''We are now living in a world clearly international, clearly multicultural,'' he said. ''We now know that we don't have to be just American.''

GRAPHIC: Graph: percentage of white, black and Hispanic 18- to 24-years olds who graduated high school and attended college, 1978 vs. 1988 (Source: National Center for Education Statistics)
