PUB-DATE: April 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 18, Column 2; World of New York Magazine

LENGTH: 3084 words

HEADLINE: WHAT REALLY MAKES NEW YORK WORK: EVERYDAY NECESSITIES;
ERRANDS OF THE RICH AND FAMOUS

BYLINE: BY JOAN KRON; Joan Kron, the editor in chief of Avenue magazine, is the author of ''Ms. Faux Pas: A Non-Guide to Glitterati Manners.''

 BODY:
Lyn Revson's banker told her she was wasting her time paying her own bills, so she found Carol Wolse to do the job for her. Twice a month the New York socialite reviews and initials her bills, then puts them all in a Federal Express envelope and ships it 60 miles away to Mrs. Wolse, a Long Island housewife who used to work in a bank. Mrs. Wolse checks the bills for irregularities, writes the necessary checks and ships them back so Mrs. Revson can sign them. ''Carol has 12 years of my paid bills in filing cabinets in her garage,'' says Mrs. Revson (once the wife of Charles Revson, the founder of Revlon). And in those 12 years, Mrs. Revson and Mrs. Wolse have seldom met face to face. ''We have a wonderful relationship,'' states Lyn Revson.
Peter Duchin, the band leader, delegates many tedious chores. ''I may have done two or three errands in my life,'' he says. His driver, Slim Hyatt, who has worked for Mr. Duchin for 30 years, ''makes drop-offs and pickups all the time.'' And Dixie Taylor, Mr. Duchin's 27-year-old assistant, handles just about everything else for him and his wife, Brooke: writing notes, making appointments, renewing car registrations, arranging doctors' visits for the Duchins' five birds and five children, making sure school tuition is paid and the piano is tuned, and ordering endless gifts from the Madison Avenue Bookshop. 
''I don't get my own errands done nearly as well as I do Peter's,'' says Ms. Taylor, who reckons that on some days there are a million of them. ''I wish I had someone to run my errands,'' she says wistfully.
Errands! Those tedious, inevitable tasks. In an article entitled ''Errands,'' included in the book ''People in Places: The Sociology of the Familiar,'' Professor Martin Wenglinsky calls them ''the busywork of day-to-day existence, the time-consuming, ever present, usually dull necessities of social life that for the most part are hardly memorable in themselves.''
''Life is one big errand,'' moans Harriet Weintraub, the New York public-relations executive who handles accounts for the fashion houses of Christian Dior and Christian Lacroix. ''An errand is something that has to be done,'' says Eileen Ford, a co-owner of the model agency. ''Either you do it or you get someone else to do it. But it gets done.''
Errands can be considered the preparation and maintenance of life's activities: hosting a dinner party is an activity you are expected to do yourself - writing the invitations, doing the marketing and perhaps the cooking are the errands; going to a movie is an activity - standing in line for the ticket is an errand; attending college is an activity, sending transcripts and applications are the errands; starring in a film is an activity, picking up the award is an errand.
Professor Wenglinsky, who teaches sociology at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn., defines three classes of errand. The first involves ''material wherewithal'' - personal presentation, body maintenance and setting maintenance (finding a place to live and fixing it up). The second concerns all things legal and bureaucratic - paying bills and taxes, registering to vote, getting tickets, licenses, a passport, visas, insurance, job references. Professor Wenglinsky's third category has to do with ''smoothing the course of interpersonal relations'' - keeping in touch, writing letters and thank-you notes, buying and sending gifts.
The professor's categories can also apply to one's professional life. Errands are not necessarily part of one's job description, but they are often peripherals that enable one to do one's job.
Increasingly these days, one person's errands have become another person's occupation. This may be why a sizable portion of New York City's economy is involved in service - from messenger services (listings filled almost eight pages in the 1989-90 Nynex Manhattan Yellow Pages) to personal shoppers, interior decorators, theater-ticket brokers, caterers, florists, travel agents, dog-walkers, accountants.
With their extensive interlocking social, business and charitable involvements, New York's working rich are in particular need of help, and they have ingenious systems for handling their errands, depending on staffs and all manner of services. Indeed, a good part of New York's perpetual gridlock is probably due to the army of surrogate errand-runners - searching, buying, standing in line, delivering and picking up, often in the family car. (''I'll send my driver'' - never call him a chauffeur.) One such errand-runner is Desmond Gorges, a butler who once worked for Asher Edelman, the arbitrageur, and for Sam Spiegel of Hollywood. He is an owner of Manhattan Party Planning. When asked about errands, Mr. Gorges said, ''It's hard to talk today. I'm running all over Manhattan trying to find basil for Dina Merrill. A simple errand like that and I'm going absolutely crazy.''
Evidently, the rich and famous will press anyone into errand service. Ann Charnack, who runs Out of Arcadia, a food shop in the Citicorp Center, says, ''Clients have sent everyone from a Japanese houseboy on a bike to car services, messenger services, twin housekeepers and mothers-in-law'' to pick up orders. ''Mothers love to run errands for their married sons,'' she adds. '' Especially when it comes to food.''
Roberta Morrell, president of Morrell & Company, a major wine retailer, gets her interior designer, who lives near a shoemaker, to take her shoes in for repair. He's not the only one who helps out. ''My caterer called before a party to ask if there was anything I needed,'' she recalls. ''I was out of perfume, and he miraculously had some when he arrived.'' Jon Gilman, the owner of Taste Caterers, Inc., says clients are always asking him to run errands. ''I've had a client call at 4 P.M. for a caviar cocktail party at 6 P.M. and ask me to go to Tiffany's and buy a special serving piece.''
Publicists get a lot of special requests. ''People in the service business are experts at errands because they know how to get anything done,'' says Sam Rudy, a senior associate with Shirley Herz Associates, which does entertainment publicity. ''And that means anything. Find a doctor for an out-of-town performer, get an engraver to do something for Tyne Daly on the opening night of 'Gypsy.' Requests for theater tickets are our biggest errands. Joe Baum [the food impresario of the Rainbow Room] wanted tickets to 'Other People's Money' for his wife's birthday. It must have taken a dozen phone calls to run this little errand,'' Mr. Rudy says, but he got the tickets.
''I use girls from Chapin, my alma mater, as gofers,'' says Dean Patterson Bauer, president of her own residential renovation firm, referring to the private school on Manhattan's Upper East Side. ''They can do tons of handy things - return books, make phone calls, pick up produce.''
Camille Lavington, an international communications consultant, uses executives between jobs to pick up her phone messages and sort her mail when she goes out of the country on business. ''You get a very high-level job performance, she says. ''These people are very senior in their wisdom and judgment.''
Like many executives, Jack Avrett, the chief executive officer of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, the advertising agency, relies on his office staff for errand assistance. ''I leave every morning with a shopping bag full of instructions from my wife, and my secretary takes care of them,'' he says. But neither his wife nor his secretary chooses his ties. For that, Mr. Avrett turns to his partner, the agency's creative director and president, Frank Ginsberg. Says the satisfied Mr. Avrett: ''Frank has a spectacular eye. He art directs my life.''
The banker Mary G. Roebling - the first woman governor of the American Stock Exchange - gets by with a little help from a friend, and several executive assistants. The friend shops for her clothes. Says Mrs. Roebling, ''She has known me a long time. More than 20 years. She knows my taste exactly. She hardly ever misses.''
Henry Jaglom, a director noted for his idiosyncratic films about the lives of himself and people he knows, depends on a former girlfriend, Barbara Flood, to handle all the esthetic decisions pertaining to his New York apartment. Miss Flood is a personal shopper, and, besides knowing his taste, she doesn't object to the hours Mr. Jaglom, an insomniaclikes to keep: ''Everything must be delivered and installed between midnight and 4 A.M.,'' she says, recalling the night last year when she brought over a whole roomfull of small pieces of furniture and bric-a-brac in a fleet of taxis because she couldn't find a trucker who would work so late.
Fitness trainers are frequently enlisted for errands. ''You can't believe what clients will ask you to do on your way to their homes,'' says Timothy Callaghan, who trains many socialites and film stars. ''One woman asked me to pick up cigarettes and four pounds of pastries from Dumas. I've also had to stop by the cleaners, drop off library books and park the Rolls. You name the errand, I've run it. One woman had me walk her two Irish wolfhounds to the vet and pick up her parrot.''
But one good turn deserves another. Often, Mr. Callaghan's clients help him with his errands. ''When I told a client who wanted an extra lesson I was having a dinner party and didn't have time to shop, she sent over her chef who prepared a fantastic meal for five guests. She let me pick the wine from her cellar. And her housekeeper cleaned up for me afterward,'' he says. Another client lent him her laundress for a month. ''I was getting my shoelaces washed and my T-shirts pressed. It saved me countless errand hours.''
Other people depend on the kindness of strangers. ''There's a little deli near where I live,'' says Joan McGivern, an associate of Ellen McCluskey, Inc., a design firm. ''They will accept anything c.o.d. It's like having live-in help. The owner is my other mother. She sells me postage stamps, cashes my checks and even pays the maid.''
Trust is the key to errands, says Ms. McGivern. ''The number of errands you can have done by others depends on the amount of trust you are willing to place in someone else's hands, and the importance of the outcome. Must it be perfect? Then get perfect hands to do it for you, or do it yourself.''
But sometimes more than simple trust is needed. The legal, pseudolegal and bureaucratic aspects of errands often require expertise. One can't ask a Chapin student to assume power of attorney.
Twelve years ago, a well-known theatrical producer wanted someone to take care of everything in her life while she wrote her memoirs, so she advertised for a woman who was literate, intelligent, well organized and discreet. Ruthe Peyser, who had run a domestic employment service for years on Long Island, answered the ad. Her children grown, she and her husband had just moved into the city. ''The vibes were right,'' says Mrs. Peyser. ''She was an outspoken woman who had difficulty holding onto cooks, maids, secretaries. I took over getting staff. Then trust funds, dealing with banks, a gift for her sister in California.''
Eventually things ran so smoothly that Mrs. Peyser was seldom needed. A lawyer friend suggested she take on other clients and call herself a ''personal affairs administrator.'' She has since worked for many people, mostly wealthy widows who don't know how to handle their finances. Besides the financial work, she has been called on to attend co-op meetings, supervise parties, deal with art appraisers, hire and fire help. She is so trusted that clients often give her power of attorney and make her executor of their wills. Mrs. Peyser, who is not taking any new clients, admits that these errands make her privy to ''everything'' about her clients - even about when they're short of cash. ''I could never tell anyone their spending is out of hand, but I might say 'We currently don't have enough money in our checking account.' It's their money, they're entitled to spend it.''
Personal assistants like Mrs. Peyser and Dixie Taylor have become ubiquitous. Everyone, from socialites such as Anne Bass and Jayne Wrightsman to the advertising executive Jerry Della Femina and his wife, Judy Licht, the Channel 5 reporter, seem to have them Their duties, of course, depend on their employers. John V. Fahey, Tyne Daly's personal assistant, says the star of ''Gypsy'' ''does her own grocery shopping and her own laundry drop.'' But he still has his share of errands. ''I shop for stationery, address envelopes, and go to the post office and stand in line,'' he says. Then there are the celebrations. ''When we did our 200th performance'' - on the road and in New York - ''I got 200 white balloons and went to Shubert Alley and released them. Tyne is a very generous person. There are always several birthdays in a cast of dozens I get little cards and gifts for her. I shop for tea bags and spring water to keep in her dressing room; light bulbs for her chandeliers at home; I had a chair seat caned, and for opening night in New York she bought antique silver jewelry that I had to get polished and engraved and put on a chain.'' (Apparently Sam Rudy helped him.) But Mr. Fahey refuses to waste the star's money. ''When Tyne says, 'Get a case of Moet brut,' I get a kick out of finding the best deal.'' His hardest errand was shopping for panty hose, ''the kind in a large egg. I had never done that before.''
For many people, systems are the key to errand competence. Bruce Bierman, an interior designer whose office is in the same building as his home, has major grocery shopping done for him once a month. From a master list of 132 items, including light bulbs, sugar, bread, soap, etc., his assistant checks off what's needed. The housekeeper comes in three days a week, one of which is devoted to household errands: ''She'll pick up a light dimmer or have the vacuum repaired,'' says Mr. Bierman. ''My bookkeeper will pay my bills, give me an allowance and take care of charitable contributions.''
Even the purchase of such personal items as clothing can be systematized. A prominent woman banker buys one good French designer suit and has it cloned in several colors in Hong Kong where she used to live and still goes on business. She does the same thing with blouses. And she buys hosiery by the three dozen and always wears the same shade and quality.
Ms. Thomas has systems for gifts too. ''I always send the same wedding gift to everyone,'' she says. Something she owns herself that can be ordered by phone: Tiffany's hollow-stem champagne flutes.
Eileen Ford believes in delegating gift wrapping. A governess who used to work for her is called upon to do special packages - otherwise ''anyone in the Ford agency with two hands free'' pitches in. ''If there are hundreds of gifts that have to be wrapped for whatever special occasion, we don't care what your title is. You wrap!'' she says.
But there are some errand requests that must be refused. Desmond Gorges, the quintessential butler, tries never to say no. He didn't balk when an employer on a business trip in Toronto asked him to fly from New York with four pills that hadn't been packed. Nor did he flinch when Asher Edelman asked him to take ''his tiny tot to an enfant jamboree exercise class. There I was with all these yuppie mommies playing toesy and kneesy with this baby, he says.'' And Mr. Gorges had no hard feelings when a British employer ''asked me on a bitter cold night to trundle all over New York to find the ingredients for this odd drink that I happily mixed for him - and he never took a sip of.'' But Mr. Gorges drew the line when, as he recalls, ''One lovely couple asked me to lay out their recently deceased father, which, of course, I politely refused to do.''
If the errand-runners occasionally draw the line, so do some errand-delegators. ''A lot of things you have to do yourself,'' insists Letitia Baldrige, the etiquette advisor, who devides her time between New York and Washington. When in New York she has a technique for getting a lot of errands done quickly: ''I'll pick out the right kind of taxi driver and get his home phone number and say, 'Look, could I borrow you for three hours on Saturday morning?' Then I can zip all over.'' Her do-it-myselfs include: ''Selecting a gift, getting a personal item fixed in a certain way, and, if you're getting something engraved, deciding whether the lettering should be tailored, large or small. Maybe it's arrogance,'' she says, ''but I'd rather do the little things myself on my way to work so I know they'll be right when I pick them up.''
Ms. Baldrige's attitude could be called errand backlash - and it's spreading. ''I would never have anyone choose gifts for me,'' says Harriet Weintraub. ''And you must write thank-you notes yourself if they're to have any meaning. Personal touches make all the difference today. The more people use impersonal help, the more I value the personal touch.''
There are some errands that simply cannot yet be delegated. ''I can't send anyone to the Vertical Club for me three times a week. I have to do that myself,'' says Nikki Haskell, club denizen and cable TV commentator. The devilish jewelry designer Kenneth J. Lane, whose fake pearls are Barbara Bush's signature, says he wishes he could expand errand limits: ''I'm thinking I may have someone else make love for me because it saves time.'' And Roberta Morrell wishes ''I could send somebody in my place to get my hair done.''
Ms. Morrell has figured out how beat movie lines. ''I'll send a messenger to stand in line for me, and when it's only eight minutes away from moving inside the theater, I can walk over and get a good seat.''
In a city where it's an achievement to travel across town in half an hour, getting the errands done, whether by oneself or with an army of helpers, leads to an euphoric sense of control - or what sociologists might call ''errand satisfaction.'' Speaking for just about everyone, Charlotte Ford, the socialite and etiquette adviser says, ''I like having my little list and crossing items off. It sort of make you feel like you're moving along. Getting things done.''
And for those who can't get it done, for the ''errand incompetents,'' there are errand apologies - those cute greeting cards that say ''Oops, I forgot your birthday'' - and the time-honored tax-filing extension. The only problem is - whom to send to pick up the former and apply for the latter.

The New York Times

 April 8, 1990, Sunday, National Edition

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1232 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
The Plus Side of Condo Auctions in New England

BYLINE: By NANCY PIERETTI

DATELINE: LINCOLN, N.H.

 BODY:
After several years during which too many condominiums were built, followed by sluggish sales and plunging prices, many developers here are defaulting on loans, forcing distress sales of vacant units in partly occupied projects.
Often these sales have been auctions that produce prices far lower than the occupants paid for their units. Sometimes banks are taking back properties in foreclosure. In either case, the sales have paved the way for finishing off construction, paying delinquent bills of the original developers and enabling other buyers to get houses at affordable prices. 
The experiences of residents at two condominium developments in Lincoln, N.H., seems to confirm the longer-term benefits that these procedures have brought to resident owners and their condominium.
At the 102-unit Nordic Inn condominium, Numerica Savings Bank of Manchester, N.H., auctioned 45 unoccupied units in for $50,000 to $60,000 each in February. The development is in a ski village near the Loon Mountains in the heart of New Hampshire's White Mountain resort region.
John Price, president of the Nordic Inn Condominium Association, had paid $106,000 for his own 1,000-square-foot unit only two years ago. Nevertheless, he said he expects long-term benefits from the auction.
Some weeks earlier the bank that had financed the development itself bought back the inn's health club and pool. The facilities have been closed since the developer defaulted. But since the bank acquired title, prospects for a reopening have improved. The condominium association itself hopes to buy them from the bank - at a price well below what they would have cost had the developer been successful.
On the opposite side of town, at Deer Park Condominiums, a development of town houses and apartments, owners voted to increase association dues by 50 percent after the developer defaulted on bank loans and association dues. Of the 315 units, 168 are complete and sold to individuals - 15 of whom live there year-round - and nine were started but not finished.
The developer, the Satter Companies of New England, based in Lincoln, has built more than 1,000 vacation homes in the White Mountains in the last eight years. Its total debt to its principal lender, United Savers Bank of Manchester, is about $43 million.
''It will take time and effort to reap any benefits from the situation, but the end result may be a better development because of the sense of community among property owners,'' said William Flannery, president of the Deer Park Property Owners Association.
''The best scenario is when the bank takes over,'' said Wayne Hyatt, a lawyer at Hyatts & Rhoads in Atlanta, a nationwide firm specializing in community-association law. ''Then you go from a bad situation to a better one, instead of bad to worse.''
According to the Community Associations Institute of Arlington, Va., one of eight Americans - or nearly 30 million people - live in community-association situations. There are 130,000 such organizations now, with 225,000 expected by the year 2000. Representatives of these associations tend to hail any sale method that brings revenue and occupancy to new developments, and completes the facilities they are supposed to offer the residents. They attach little significance to the fact that unit prices in an auction may be well below the prices that occupants initially paid.
''Once you get through the auction stage, values are not affected at all,'' said David Mercer, a community association lawyer practicing in Alexandria, Va. ''As inventory decreases, prices tend to stabilize and will eventually go back up.''
That is what happened to Thomas Lizotte. He bought his first house, a 1,550-square-foot town-house condominium with a garage at the Valley West development in Manchester, in southern New Hampshire, at a preconstruction price of $62,000 in 1986. Construction delays and financial problems prevented the developer, Forrest Sells of Manchester, from finishing the unit for a year and a half and 25 percent of the 140 units were not finished at all.
Despite rising property prices in southern New Hampshire from 1985 to late 1987, units were mired in bankruptcy proceedings and were not auctioned until last year.
''Technically, my unit was worth $85,000 if you factored in the marketplace,'' Mr. Lizotte said. ''But at the auction in 1989 people paid about what I had paid in 1986. Now we're beginning the ascent again.''
Property owners also benefit if a new buyer begins to pay the common charges to the association on which a developer may have been in arrears. In some cases, when a developer or a unit owner has defaulted on association fees, which are needed for maintenance and the operation of common spaces, they have had to be reassessed to the other owners, said Donald Dyekman of the law firm of O'Connor, Cavanagh, Anderson, Westober, Killingsworth and Beshears of Phoenix.
Problems with such defaults have led to the adoption in some states of the ''super lien'' under which the community association gets higher priority than the holder of the first mortgage. But that law has been adopted by only a few states while others slowly re-evaluate their statues.
At issue, too, is the responsibility of the new owner to finish amenities and honor warranty work after the property has been auctioned. Generally, the lender who has foreclosed on a property and buys it back finishes the job, Mr. Mercer said.
The New Hampshire Attorney General's office is studying what the new owners' responsibilities are and the time given to comply.
At present there is no move to change the statute, said Terry Robertson, senior assistant in the state's Consumer Protection Division, but heroffice has hired three lawyers to handle consumer complaints. Last year the office reported 533 complaints related to real estate, compared to 447 in 1988.
New Hampshire's slow economy, coupled with announcements by banks here that millions of dollars will be added to loan-loss reserves because of nonperforming real estate loans, has resulted in more auctions. John Allen, a banking and securities lawyer at Russos, Hages & Hodes in Manchester, said that ''as the general credit market tightens up and bank regulators enforce stricter banking industry regulations,'' fewer banks are willing to lend additional money to developers to whom they have already made loans. A result, he said, is ''more auctions.''
Sheldon Good & Company of Chicago, one of the nation's largest real estate auctioneers, auctioned $75 million in property in the first quarter of 1990 in New England. Auctions have been taking place elsewhere in the country, said Steven Good, president of the firm, and are new only in New England.
James St. Jean, a Manchester auctioneer, said he conducted 325 auctions in New Hampshire last year and 170 in the first three months of 1990.
Industry analysts, among them Russell Thibeault, president of Applied Economic Research of Laconia, N.H., an economic forecasting and research firm, said the deepest discounts on condominiums are on projects of more than 100 units in fairly remote areas of the state where developers built in anticipation of a market that never happened.
''The upside,'' Mr. Thibeault said, ''is the more reasonable products are now selling for 50 percent of what they would have sold for in 1987 during the height of the market.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Busy Young Director Sees Lean Years Vanish

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
GORDON EDELSTEIN, the newly appointed associate artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, was recalling the lean years, when he was a struggling director ''waiting tables, doing word processing and ready to give up.''
''I didn't go to grad school,'' he said. ''I had no slick personality and no sexy credentials. I almost quit 500 times.'' 
Now 35 years old, Mr. Edelstein is the self-described ''artistic right hand'' to Arvin Brown, the artistic director of Long Wharf, which is having its 25th anniversary season. His first directorial assignment for Long Wharf's Main Stage, Eugene O'Neill's ''Anna Christie,'' is on view through April 29, and Mr. Edelstein is holding rehearsals off Broadway as the director of ''Tales of the Lost Formicans'' by Constance Congdon, a resident playwright of Hartford Stage Company. The play, under the producing banner of the Women's Project, is to begin previews on April 17 in preparation for an opening on April 24 at the Apple Corps Theater, 336 West 20th Street.
 
Directing Departure
And come June, Mr. Edelstein is expected to resume, for the fourth summer, his position as associate artistic director of the Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., where he is the head of the theater's second stage, the Unicorn.
Overseeing an O'Neill play is a departure for Mr. Edelstein, who is best known for collaborating with contemporary playwrights, like Ms. Congdon, as their works evolve. He made his Long Wharf debut as a director with ''A Dance Lesson'' by David Wiltse, which developed from the theater's workshop series to a Stage II production last year.
Commenting on his approach to the early O'Neill play, a 1922 Pulitzer Prize winner that is not considered one of the playwright's masterpieces, Mr. Edelstein said:
''A lot of O'Neill's dialogue, steeped in immigrant colloquialism, is almost unsayable. Some scenes border on the overmelodramatic and clunky. But I'm very attracted to plays of grand passion and to singular voices who are driven to write. And we know how O'Neill was driven. You can feel the pulsing passion on every page, and that's something palpable to work with.''
 
'Closet Feminist Play'
In the play, Anna Christie, who had been a prostitute in St. Louis, goes to New York to join her father, the skipper of a coal barge. Her lover, Mat Burke, leaves her when he learns of her shady past - but they are reconciled.
'' 'Anna Christie' is a closet feminist play,'' Mr. Edelstein said. ''Women were economically driven to prostitution. Anna spent a life being used, abused and owned by men, and her consciousness was raised by that. When she confronts Mat with his male sexual hypocrisy -he has a prostitute in every port, but Anna's 'unclean' to him - the audience cheers.
''The play has been discounted by O'Neill scholars. He was criticized for copping out with a happy ending. But O'Neill was too honest for that. He felt the real point of the ending was missed; it's a coda of foreboding. People don't change, and we spent a great deal of rehearsal time on the last two pages, just to get that ending right.''
In contrast to having to breathe new life into a war horse, Mr. Edelstein has been involved in the evolution of Ms. Congdon's new play through six productions in the past three years.
 
'Honoring the Playwright'
''It was just a series of scenes about a family in Colorado in the 1960's,'' he said. ''And it began to develop as a study of suburban culture - as seen through the eyes of alien anthropologists in the future. It's a sad and goofy look, from the future as well as the past, at the nature of our lives, not just our life styles.''
About his credo as a director, Mr. Edelstein said: ''Directing is like conducting. You sculpt out the themes that are prominent to you. My own ego is not on my agenda, only honoring the playwright - and making it clear and visceral for the audience.''
Mr. Edelstein grew up in Woodmere, L.I., and graduated from Grinnell College in Iowa. He has been directing, fitfully, since 1978 in regional theaters, off Broadway and off Off Broadway. Three years ago, he married Dr. Joan Berman, an obstetrician and gynecologist. The couple, who have a 9-month-old daughter, Marlene, divide their time between an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side and a home in Lenox, Mass., near the Berkshire Theater Festival.
About the turnaround in his professional and personal life, Mr. Edelstein, who is to direct the world premiere of two one-act plays by Joyce Carol Oates at the Long Warf's Main Stage next sesason, said:
''I had seven years of bad luck just trying to survive in New York City. Then everything changed. My marriage. The Berkshires. And when the Long Wharf job came up, I was in the right place at the right time.
'' 'A Dance Lesson' worked. They asked around about me, and my network of contacts came through. What a blessing. It would be awfully indecent of me to complain.''

HEADLINE: Novelist Uses The Island's Gold Coast As A Setting For A Clash of Cultures

BYLINE: By CAROL STRICKLAND

 BODY:
A NEGLECTED property next door, the nightmare of every suburban homeowner. Imagine how much worse for John Sutter.
He is living on a 200-acre Locust Valley estate, complete with a 50-room McKim-Mead-White mansion, while the neighboring hulk is a Spanish Colonial villa with a leaking roof, bashed-in windows, moss-covered interior walls and squirrels nesting in the plumbing.
John Sutter should be ecstatic when the new owner's horde of handymen restores the white stucco walls and red-tiled roof to their former splendor. Right? Not exactly. 
Why? Because Mr. Sutter, the main character in Nelson DeMille's latest novel, ''The Gold Coast,'' is a descendant of original Long Island gentry, his wife is a blueblood socialite and his new neighbor happens to be the boss of New York's most powerful organized-crime family.
 
Premise for a New Book
This clash of cultures is the premise for Mr. De Mille's new book about manners and morals, which will be published April 16. Referring to F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby,'' a classic parable of Gold Coast life during the Roaring Twenties, Mr. De Mille said that his book ''is sort of Jay Gatsby meets the Godfather.''
Mr. De Mille, who lives in Garden City, has published five books since 1978, each selling more than a million copies. The last two, ''The Charm School'' and ''Word of Honor,'' made The New York Times best-seller list, and ''The Gold Coast'' is a Book of the Month Club main selection for May.
Peter Guber of Columbia Motion Pictures acquired film rights to the book for $750,000, hired Frank Yablans of ''The Godfather'' as producer and John Gregory Dunne and Joan Didion to write the screenplay.
With a major novel and film approaching, the Gold Coast, accustomed to basking in a glow no stronger than a lighthouse's dim beacon, is about to be hit by the glare of klieg lights.
The Gold Coast extends from Long Island Sound to Northern State Parkway and stretches from the Nassau County line in the west to Centerport.
Comprising about a third of Nassau County's area, the Gold Coast once included about 500 lavish estates built from the turn of the century until the Depression.
It is still arguably, as the novel puts it, ''The best neighborhood in America, making Beverly Hills or Shaker Heights, for instance, seem like tract housing.''
Mr. De Mille, known as an author of cold war thrillers, among them ''The Talbot Odyssey,'' decided to set his latest narrative on the Gold Coast because, he said, ''it was not well-documented in literature. I see Long Island's North Shore as a microcosm of our changing society.
''I've always been fascinated by the Gold Coast. The homes themselves are spectacular, unlike anything you'll see other than in Newport, Bar Harbor or Palm Beach. It's a very special area that, because of local demographics, is not going to survive much longer.''
Mr. De Mille was born in Jamaica, Queens, and educated at Elmont High School and Hofstra University, and so he knows the area well, although he calls himself ''a member in good standing of the middle class.''
His interest in the Gold Coast estates first arose when his father, a French Canadian immigrant during the 30's, was a contractor on some of the mansions, among them the W. R. Grace estate and Greentree, the Whitney estate.
To research the book, Mr. De Mille infiltrated behind the wrought-iron gates with a tree surgeon who has worked on the estates for 30 years.
The author also consulted amateur historians, among them Robert and Audrey Whiting, to learn, as he put it, ''the social history that you can't find in books.
''Someone local can tell you who lived in what mansion,'' he said, ''who was having love affairs and who murdered whom.''
The Whitings live in the gatehouse of a 127-acre Old Brookville estate that is now the corporate headquarters of Banfi Vintners, maker of Riunite wine.
The estate, built in 1927 for Sir Samuel Salvage, an English knight, and later owned by the widow of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, ''played a prominent role in the social life of the Gold Coast,'' said Carmel Tintle, Banfi's vice president of public relations. It was then that debutantes curtsied at glittering soirees.
Now, opulently restored by John Mariani, Banfi's chairman, and his brother, Harry F. Mariani, the company's president - both are friends of Mr. De Mille - the mansion will be the site of the publishers' reception for the debut of ''The Gold Coast.''
The novel presents a sharply observed portrait of the upper crust, the privileged ''old-money people'' who frequent exclusive clubs like Piping Rock, The Creek and the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.
 
'Locust Valley Lockjaw'
It would be difficult to find a snootier ''silk stocking'' than the protagonist's wife, Susan Stanhope Sutter. Whether cantering through her estate on horseback or sprinting down a private road in her Jaguar, she is the quintessential robber baroness.
Susan's speech is characterized by ''Locust Valley Lockjaw'' or, as Mr. De Mille writes:
''The ability to speak in complete and mostly understandable sentences - including words with lots of broad vowels - and do so without opening one's mouth, like a ventriloquist.''
Yet, despite her hauteur, Susan's family estate, $400,000 in arrears in taxes, is on the block, the victim of colossal heating bills. Clearly, Mr. De Mille sees the graffiti on the mullioned window and hears the bulldozer in the courtyard.
''I was concerned with the social history of the area, what it was like to live on these huge estates and how the world changed,'' he said.
''There are a lot of books about the passing of the English aristocracy, but the vast majority of Long Islanders don't understand their own backyard. It's a private preserve.''
 
A Conquering Don
What distinguishes the book from an American version of ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' the British television gem, is the advent of the conqueror, Frank Bellarosa, the Mafia don who diversifies his holdings into Gold Coast real estate.
''The thing that gave the book its fire and engine was the idea of an old WASP family getting involved with a Mafia crime family,'' said Mr. De Mille.
''Like all good novels, this is based on truth. There are Mafia families that have bought magnificent houses on the North Shore, although not yet the great estates because they don't want that kind of high profile.''
Mr. De Mille, who is half Italian, spoofs the decor of ''Mafia Manor.'' The novel's aristocratic narrator, John Sutter, labels Mr. Bellarosa's ''new three-tiered marble fountain from which water spouted and cascaded, lit by multicolored lights,'' as ''early Italian catering hall.''
The parvenu Mr. Bellarosa is seen as Gatsby's heir, the paradigm of nouveau riche excess. Scott Fitzgerald's Gatsby, whose gaudy, champagne-drenched parties in his Great Neck chateau epitomized the Flapper Era, was the very image of the financial moguls who made - and spent - their fortunes on the run.
Mr. De Mille's Bellarosa is the modern equivalent of Fitzgerald's Gatsby, with his fictional, ostentatious Easter party rivaling in vulgarity those that the financier Otto Kahn used to give on his 600-acre, 125-room Woodbury estate.
''To make the hunt interesting,'' Mr. De Mille writes of Kahn's parties, ''each colorfully painted egg contained a $1,000 bill. This was a popular event, and an original way to celebrate the Resurrection of Jesus Christ.''
The disparate worlds of Snob and Mob are evident in the epigrams each lives by. For John Sutter, an alumnus of Yale and Harvard Law School, ''The most important WASP dictum is, 'Never touch the principal.' ''
In contrast, Mr. Bellarosa candidly acknowledges his more primitive management style: ''Sometimes I got to fire people, but sometimes I got to fire at people.''
Despite his tough talk, however, this Mafia don is no ordinary thug. Educated at Oakdale's La Salle Military Academy, Mr. Bellarosa quotes St. Jerome and has read Dante and St. Augustine. Unfortunately for society, he has absorbed all too well the precepts of Machiavelli's ''Prince.'' As for a summary of his education, Mr. Bellarosa says: ''You asked me what I learned at La Salle? I tell you one thing I learned. No matter what kind of peace treaties you got, you post a 24-hour guard.''
Mr. De Mille emphasizes the gangster's prep-school background to pose the question: ''What if a man with this kind of education and brilliance made it to the top and used that education for evil?''
The novel implies that, although you can take the mobster out of his murderous milieu and plunk him down amid gazebos and reflecting pools, you cannot take the murder out of the mob. After vividly depicting love and lust among the ruins of the ruling class, both upper class and upstart are ruined.
Mr. De Mille, who says the Mafia's ''influence on Long Island seems to be waning,'' intended to show, he said, ''the passing of two different kinds of culture at the same time.''
After the waning of old money and the downfall of corrupt money, what is next?
''The hamburger chains, shopping malls, 24-hour convenience stores, pizza parlors - they're here already,'' writes Mr. De Mille.
 
Pondering the Flip Side
As builders pour asphalt over the former Stanhope estate, where Mrs. Sutter once lived, her husband ponders the flipside to economic development: ''Another few hundred acres had gone from rural to suburban, from pristine to scarred.''
''This country needs an esthetic revolution,'' said the author, pointing out his office window to where ugly, institutional condominiums have replaced a park and the elegant, Georgian-style Garden City Hotel.
''The Europeans, with more population density and less land, have managed their countryside and urban landscapes better than we have. Here we emphasize the rights of landowner rather than society at large. It's not a healthy thing.'' Mr. DeMille's novel concludes the guided tour to what Fitzgerald called ''that slender, riotous island'' with a postscript. For Gatsby, ensconced in his Gold Coast mansion, the American dream, Fitzgerald wrote, ''must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it.''
Sixty-five years later on the Gold Coast, Mr. DeMille writes, ''There are dreams that can come true, and dreams that can't.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; Nelson DeMille, author of ''The Gold Coast,'' at Banfi Vintners in Old Brookville (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: AKRON, OHIO;
Pinning Hopes On a Tower

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

 BODY:
THE first new, privately financed downtown office building here in nearly a decade is under way, giving hope to local officials that a changing economy in the area - from rubber manufacturing to research and technology - will benefit the city's center.
The new building, a $30 million 18-story structure, is the first phase of the $60 million mixed-use Main Place complex. It will be completed next year and occupy nearly half a block. It will have 288,000 square feet of offices and 45,900 square feet of retail space; 128 new parking spaces and an underground walkway linking the offices to existing nearby parking spaces; a skywalk to the adjacent 26-story First National Tower, and a new central bus station. 
The developers have not yet decided whether the second phase of the project will be more office space or a hotel.
Announced last December by the Brenlin Group, a local conglomerate whose companies manufacture a variety of products, the project comes after a decade of city efforts to renovate the block of buildings, several of them vacant. Seven - the oldest is the 1918 Strand Theater - will be razed and six small businesses will be relocated.
''Over the years we have tried to encourage the restoration of these buildings, but our downtown just hasn't been active in redevelopment in the last 15 years,'' said James Alkire, director of Planning and Urban Development.
While the developers are optimistic about filling the new space, they say the project was conceived not out of demand but as a civic effort to create more interest in downtown, which has become service-oriented and could cater to the needs of research and technology companies.
The project is a result of two years of planning by David L. Brennan, chief executive officer of the Brenlin Group, and his partnership in the Main Place venture with other longtime Akron businesses. Among investors who have raised $11 million for the project thus far are First Bancorporation of Ohio and the Brenlin Group.
''No one is knocking down our doors for offices in downtown, but there is interest out there,'' said Michael A. Kunce, vice president of Bowery Management, the local manager of the project, in which no space has been preleased.
The city has agreed to advance the developers the $3 million needed for land acquisitiion, demolition and site preparation. This will be repaid over the next 15 years from property taxes. In addition, the Metro Regional Transit Authority is overseeing a $7.5 million beautification project along Main Street and the city has committed $500,000 to link Main Place to public parking through an underground concourse.

HEADLINE: Huntington Is Facing Deadline on Housing

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS

 BODY:
HUNTINGTON is facing a deadline to begin building ''affordable'' housing on a rocky site now occupied by 500 commuter parking spaces.
But town officials do not want to allow any building until they can provide equivalent parking that would be lost once the housing project got started.
Money for a new multilevel parking garage is being sought and should be forthcoming by the end of the year, Huntington officials said.
The plan is to build a 10-acre housing development on Broadway, north of the Huntington Station railroad tracks. The term ''affordable,'' meanwhile, appears to be a sticking point. The deadline is next year. 
 
Sources of Funds
''The garage must be built before the housing project,'' said Tom Mazzola, Huntington's director of transportation and traffic safety, who expects to get half of the $7 million cost of the garage from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, 25 percent from the Federal Urban Mass Transit Authority and 25 percent from the state.
The town acquired 8.6 acres of the 10 acres in 1987 by paying $534,447.47 in back taxes to Suffolk County. In negotiations with the county, it was agreed that affordable housing would be a good use for the land.
According to the deed, development of the land must be started within four years or it will revert to the county tax rolls.
''The term 'affordable' is a loose one,'' said Councilman Kenneth Christensen, head of the Citizens Advisory Committee formed after the deed was signed. '' 'Affordable' is not subsidized housing.''
To arrive at an affordable price, analysts used the median income of Huntington town employees, $37,000 a year, and the average price of houses in the surrounding area, $200,000 to $300,000. The three-bedroom units would be affordable to households with an income of $74,000, they calculated.
The Huntington Station Revitalization Plan was completed by the consulting concern of Conklin Rossant of New York City in November 1989. The concern's report suggests a 247-unit housing project, starting at $107,000 for a one-room studio and going to three-bedroom units for $207,000.
 
Requests for Proposals
John Trench, head of the Citizens Advisory Committee, said the committee was preparing a formal proposal for the new Town Supervisor, Stephen Ferraro. The analysts estimate that the project will generate about $36 million in revenues; however, costs will not be known until the town receives requests for proposals from developers, Mr. Trench said.
Negotiations are under way to acquire the site of a burned-out car dealership next to the station depot as a site for the garage. The site, which is slightly less than one acre, will probably cost the town $1.3 million to $1.5 million, Mr. Christensen said.
''We will definitely use that site,'' said Councilman Quentin Sammis, who was involved in the county negotiations and was the first head of the Citizens Advisory Committee. ''It's an ideal site, and the garage will be finished before the housing project is started so that commuters will not be inconvenienced.''
''Any plan that replaces 500 parking spaces in close proximity to the train station with housing is ill conceived,'' said Vincent de Pass, the only speaker at a public hearing on Federal financing for the garage. A garage, he said, could worsen problems with vandalism and traffic congestion.
 
Dependency on Commuters
''The economy of Huntington is, to a certain degree, dependent on the resident who commutes to the city but pays his real-estate taxes here,'' Mr. de Pass said.
The Conklin Rossant report recommends that ''the annual cost of parking at the station should be at least as much as the cost [$168 a year] of commuting by HART bus to the station.'' The Long Island Rail Road monthly ticket from Huntington to New York is $163.
The housing project, as proposed, would have 300 parking spaces, and the garage, with 600 spaces, would not add significantly to the number of spaces available to commuters.
At present, the infrequent traveler with no parking sticker has a difficult time finding a parking space near the station during the week, Mr. de Pass told the Town Board.
Like the existing garage, which holds 1,250 cars, a new one built with Federal funds would have to accommodate out-of-town commuters who have permits, as well as Huntington residents.
Between 1986 and 1988, the Town of Huntington issued 18,000 two-year stickers to Huntington residents, who can park on town-owned lots or in the garage. There are 3,000 spaces on 13 town-owned lots at Huntington Station and 272 spaces on the street near Huntington Station.
Additional lots are in Northport, Greenlawn and Cold Spring Harbor. The town also issued about 800 permits in each of those years to nonresidents, who are limited to parking in the garage.
 
Fee Going Up
Out-of-towners pay the same amount, $10 a car, as Huntington residents. The town recently moved to change the parking fee to $30 a car for a one-year permit for Huntington residents, starting next month, but has yet to determine the cost to nonresidents.
A Long Island Rail Road survey last fall showed that 5,860 passengers board at Huntington Station between the hours of 6 and 10 A.M.
''Huntington Station has become a hub,'' said Supervisor Ferraro, because electrification of the tracks ends at that point.
There has been no presention of a study to the Town Board since he took office, he said, and he plans to halt negotiations until he gets suggestions from the public, ''especially Huntington resident commuters, whose right to parking must be protected,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Money Isn't Everything in Greyhound Strike

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 8

 BODY:
With almost daily episodes of sniper fire, windshield smashing or threats to the substitute drivers, the Greyhound strike is about as nasty as strikes get these days, and it does not seem that it should be.
The 6,300 striking drivers want more money. But those at Greyhound's Midwestern hub here, as in many other cities, readily find temporary and part-time work driving trucks and other companies' buses, so complaints of mortgages going unpaid and children unfed are rare.
Nor do many strikers complain about Greyhound's health benefits or pensions, concerns that have led other workers to join picket lines.
 
A Threatened Way of Life
Something else is at work here: pride and a way of life. Greyhound was the king of the highway, assuring low-budget travelers a safe trip home for funerals and holidays. Drivers counted themselves among the aristocrats of organized labor - captains of aluminum-sheathed behemoths who kept peace on board, mastered the secrets of urban and rural streets and gave old people a hand. 
''You're the boss,'' said John Noha, a 44-year-old driver who has been with Greyhound for nine years, resting in the Chicago strike headquarters from picketing.
''Passengers recognize that uniform as a person they can trust,'' said Bill Coker, 44, a driver for three years. ''They don't go to management. They don't go to the supervisor in the terminal. They come to us. It gets in your blood.''
So Greyhound's effort to hold down the drivers' wages strikes not only at their paychecks, but also at their pride, a pride that is further wounded by the company's paying top rates to substitute drivers with just a few weeks' training. Furthermore, management has promised the substitutes that their jobs are permanent, threatening the strikers with not just lower pay, but no pay at all.
Over the weekend, rumors circulated that the drivers were mounting an effort to save their jobs through an employee takeover of the company. ''We've been informed that there's a buyout going on and that there might be an announcement on Tuesday,'' said a labor leader here who asked not to be named.
Jeff Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Transit Union in Washington, said, ''We may be having an announcement Tuesday.'' But he said he did not know the subject of it.
Fred G. Currey, the chairman of Greyhound, said he had not heard the reports but added, ''This business is not for sale.''
The company's goal in the labor dispute is to keep down its costs, especially wages. It faces acute competition for passengers from railroads and airlines, and very thin profits.
But pay is a complex concern in this industry. A decade ago, veteran drivers' incomes exceeded $30,000 a year, putting them comfortably in the middle class, and the pay made the jobs something that other drivers aspired to. Now for the first time drivers realize they may never see that kind of pay again.
Moreover, management has humiliated the men and women on the picket line in showing that it can readily find substitute drivers who, after three or four weeks' training, have shown that they can deliver their passengers, less expertly, but deliver them nevertheless. And management is paying the top wages to substitute drivers, rather than requiring that they spend a decade working up to it, and it has unequivocally assured them that their jobs are permanent. The more drivers Greyhound hires as the strike, now in its fifth week, persists, the fewer union drivers will be able to rejoin Greyhound.
The company is telling the strikers, ''You're nothing but a bunch of dumb bus drivers,'' said Lenase Brown, 45, a driver for 10 years. ''I'm more hurt than mad.''
Ronald J. Peters, a professor of labor and industrial relations at the University of Illinois, said, ''There's a feeling of a loss of status, a loss of input, among people who have given the best years of their lives to the company.''
 
Powerful Forces at Work
Drivers for Greyhound, like airline pilots and skilled industrial workers, and their employers as well, have become victims of forces much larger than they. They have been caught in the maw of economic transitions, from a more benign time when unions would win higher wages and benefits, and employers would raise prices and fares to pay for them. In transportation, Federal deregulation broke the process by creating greater competition in fares, and in industry foreign competition had much the same effect.
The Greyhound strike is also a reminder, if one is needed, of something else: that labor unions have lost much of their membership and power in recent years, that crossing a picket line to fill a striker's job is not automatically regarded as an unspeakable act.
The changes in business and industry have been especially harsh on Greyhound. Passengers rode Greyhound 10 million miles a year a decade ago, but with deregulation-provoked cuts in airline fares, traffic had dropped to nine million pasenger miles in 1983. To help arrest the decline, the drivers accepted a 25 percent cut in their basic wage, from 40 cents per mile they drove to 30 cents. But the decline persisted, to six million passenger miles in 1986.
Three years ago, Mr. Currey, the current chairman, and other investors bought the ailing line, and the drivers agreed to live with the 30-cent wage another three years in return for bonuses for safe driving, gains in passenger traffic and Mr. Currey's assurances that they would eventually regain their status of the nation's best-paid drivers as the company grew. But the bonuses and gains in ridership have been small. Passenger miles had climbed to 7.5 million last year, and after two years of huge losses, the company recorded a minuscule $730,000 profit last year.
When contract talks that are now on hold began late last year, the drivers expected the 40-cent wage to be restored. Instead the company offered more performance-related incentives and later, in an effort to avert the strike, it offered a three-cent raise. The drivers now contend that they were deceived by the man they call ''Drop Dead Fred'' on their picket line buttons and signs.
''He made promises,'' said Mr. Coker. ''He said, 'If you help me bring this company back to where it's making money, I'm going to pass on the money to you.' It was a boldfaced lie.''
Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Phoenix, said: ''He promised these people he would take care of them come the contract. Boy, he sure did.''
Mr. Currey answers that what is happening to the drivers' wages in today's economy ''is a shame.'' But he said, ''The union has formally stated time and time again that what the company can afford to pay is irrelevant, that the fact that Greyhound wages are higher than all but a handful of over-the-road operators is irrelevant.''
 
Shots Fired at Buses
The tensions of the strike are being played out across the company's route system, with at least 20 shootings, four involving buses based in Chicago; shots at terminals, including one in Chicago, and numerous other incidents, many of which never appear on a police department log.
Here as in many other cities, the courts have enjoined strikers from harassing the substitute drivers, and their passengers. But intimidation is constant. The other day here, a picketer stood outside the terminal with a video camera on his shoulder filming drivers coming and going.
''I left here headed for Indianapolis,'' said a replacement driver. ''I heard a noise,'' she said. ''I thought the toilet lid in the back had dropped. I got to Indianapolis, and they discovered that the bus had been shot in the bathroom window.''
One replacement, a tall, muscular former truck driver, said he was getting ready to retaliate. ''I'm not going to run,'' he said. ''I'm tired of those clowns.''
Union people, who insist that they do not condone the violence, say they are skeptical that their members have anything to do with such incidents. ''It could be the company hiring goons,'' said Bill Pearsall, a driver and Chicago business agent for the Amalgamated Transit Union. He said the replacement drivers could be doing it, too.
But the only person arrested and charged so far in a shooting incident, a man in Connecticut, is a striking driver, and Mr. Pearsall acknowledged that some drivers are angry enough to retaliate.
In one of the latest incidents, a replacement driver was charged yesterday in Washington with carrying a dangerous weapon. Officials said the suspect, Charles E. King, 45, brandished a rifle Saturday during a confrontation with strikers at the Greyhound terminal after discovering that his car had been vandalized.
The recruits say they intend to stay with Greyhound. ''I was driving a truck for a steel outfit,'' said Bob K., 58. ''I was making about $500 gross every two weeks. This is about $1,200 gross. This is the best paying job I've ever had.''
They also say they believe their jobs are secure. In 1983, the previous owners of Greyhound hired replacement drivers during a strike and assured them they could stay, but after the strike ended they were let go.
Edward A. said that he left a machinist job for Greyhound and that he had ordered from Greyhound $301 worth of uniforms. Other drivers interviewed said they had ordered uniforms, too.
Greyhound now makes about half as many trips as usual from Chicago. Passengers interviewed said they did not often encounter more than jeering as they pulled in and out of terminals. The bus is still the cheapest way to go, so they put up with the jeering, Greyhound's truncated schedule and with the new drivers' inexperience.

In Chicago, strikers set up an office in a school bus outside the Greyhound terminal. (The New York Times/Jonathan Kirn) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Pepsi Will Be Bartered for Ships And Vodka in Deal With Soviets

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In the largest deal ever between an American corporation and the Soviet Union, Pepsico expects to sign an agreement today to barter Pepsi-Cola for ships and vodka. The accord is valued at more than $3 billion.
The expected deal will greatly expand Pepsi-Cola's availability in the Soviet Union. And for the first time, Pepsico will take out its profits not just in Stolichnaya vodka, but in oceangoing freighters and tankers as well. 
Since 1974, Pepsico has shipped its soft-drink syrup to the Soviet Union, made it into cola and sold the bottled product, taking out its profits in Stolichnaya, which is sold through a third party in the United States. Under the new deal, the Soviet Union will trade at least 10 tankers and freighters, ranging in size from 28,600 tons to 65,000 tons, with a total value of more than $300 million.
 
Cumbersome Bottles Used
The new agreement will enable Pepsico to more than double its Soviet bottling network and eventually make possible the nationwide distribution of soft drinks in aluminum cans and plastic bottles, rather than in the cumbersome glass bottles currently used.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has said that ending shortages and poor distribution of consumer goods poses a critical test for his leadership. The Pepsico deal is being closely watched as an indicator of whether Western companies can prosper in the Soviet market, which has 287 million consumers who have had little to buy.
Pepsico was the first large American company to enter the Soviet market, led by its former chairman, Donald M. Kendall, who is now the chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Kendall, a former co-chairman and now a director of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, has actively encouraged other Western businesses to invest in the Soviet Union. He once told an interviewer, ''If we can get the Soviet people to enjoy good consumer goods, they'll never be able to do without them again.''
Pepsico, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., had sales in 1989 of more than $15 billion, making it one of the largest consumer-product companies in the world. Its brand names include the Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut restaurants and Doritos tortilla chips.
''This deal is going to make the Soviet Union a very big business for us,'' said John Swanhaus, president of Pepsico's Wines and Spirits subsidiary. Pepsi consumption in the Soviet Union is small - currently about 40 million cases, or about the annual consumption of the Orlando, Fla., metropolitan area, with a population of about one million people. (That does not include nearby Disney World, where, in any case, the Coca-Cola Company has an exclusive concession.) Pepsi sells in the Soviet Union for the equivalent of 75 cents for an 11-ounce bottle.
 
Limited by Infrastructure
Although bottling plants are running at full capacity, Mr. Swanhaus said Pepsi's business was limited by such basic considerations as poor roads and the availabilty of trucks. ''There is no infrastructure in place if tomorrow you triple your business,'' he added.
In the new contract's most significant provision for the consumer-product sector of the Soviet economy, Pepsico will increase the number of bottling plants to 50, from 26, and modernize current production. The bottling plants each have an average annual capacity of about 1.5 million cases a year and have been running full throttle.
Pepsico currently sells its soft drinks in glass bottles, which are relatively expensive and cumbersome to deliver. The result is that distribution in the Soviet Union is generally limited to within 20 miles or so of the company's bottling plants.
Pepsico plans to introduce aluminum cans and plastic bottles in the next several years, which will make national distribution possible. These lighter disposable containers not only require less fuel for transportation but allow trucks to return from deliveries with other goods rather than cases of empties.
The $3 billion value of the contract represents retail sales of Pepsi-Cola and Stolichnaya vodka until the year 2000. That figure assumes a devaluation of the ruble, which is not freely traded on world currency markets. Using Moscow's official exchange rate for the ruble, the deal's value is closer to $9 billion: $1.5 billion for vodka and $7.5 billion for Pepsi in the Soviet Union, officials said.
Pepsico last year sold soft drinks in the Soviet Union worth about 300 million rubles, valued at $500 million at Government exchange rates. Stolichnaya sales in the United States totaled about $156 million last year. American law prevents Pepsico from operating restaurants where alcoholic beverages are served and importing alcohol, so Stolichnaya is sold in the United States through Monsieur Henri Wines Ltd., an importer.
The nonconvertibilty of the ruble is a substantial obstacle in the Soviet Union's bid to import more consumer products because many Western companies insist on ''hard,'' or convertible, currency. The Gillette Company, for example, has tentatively agreed to build a razor blade factory in the Soviet Union but is demanding hard currency payment.
Pepsico's profit is also slight because it must keep a relatively large support staff in the Soviet Union for a relatively small sales volume. Officials would not be more specific.
 
Boom in Imported Brands
Vodka sales in the United States have been flat, but imported brands have boomed. Stolichnaya is the second-largest foreign brand - after Sweden's Absolut - with more than one million cases sold last year. Stolichnaya's sales have fluctutated with swings in Soviet-American relations. Sales plummeted, for example, after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in December 1979.
Pepsico will use foreign exchange credits from the sale and leasing of the Soviet ships to provide some financing for two Pizza Hut restaurants scheduled to open in Moscow this year. Fast-food restaurants are expensive to establish in the Soviet Union because of the underdeveloped Soviet food industry.
The new Pepsico contract is scheduled to be signed in Moscow today by senior officials of the Soviet Commission of Agriculture and Procurement; Sudoexport, a shipbuilding agency; Sojuzplodoimport, which has authority over soft drinks and vodka, and Mr. Kendall.

(The New York Times); graphs of cases of Pepsi sold in Soviet Union and cases of Stolichnaya sold in U.S. from '74 to '89 (Source: Pepsico) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Rethinking Foreign Aid

 BODY:
It's time to rethink foreign aid. America no longer needs to view countries through the distorting ice of the cold war. Instead, it can shift emphasis and resources toward building a less fortified, more truly secure world. Such a shift would also serve U.S. interests in a new era in which weapons count less than economic success.
Many of America's present aid programs aren't designed for this new world. Spending is narrowly focused on security assistance and earmarked for a few strategically placed allies. Two of every three aid dollars go to just five countries: Israel, Egypt, the Philippines, Turkey and Pakistan. 
A program for the 1990's needs to embrace more countries and emphasize free-market approaches. It can build on development-oriented programs already in place. But a comprehensive reordering of aid programs is called for.
Americans never relished spending tax dollars on foreign causes. Now that the cold war no longer rallies patriotic support, taxpayers have understandably begun to ask why America should be responsible for raising living standards abroad.
The answer was demonstrated by the Marshall Plan 40 years ago. America best promotes its own economic well-being by helping to consolidate democracy and expand free markets.
Today's greatest opportunities lie in Eastern Europe and Latin America. Assistance efforts are best aimed at encouraging private investment and underwriting large, but one-time, transition costs. The ideal mechanism is multilateral action through both new and existing development banks. Here are some of the more pressing needs and some ways to address them:
Investment incentives. To attract private capital into risky new marketplaces, investment insurance, loan guarantees and preferential credit programs need to be enlarged. New mechanisms can also be developed to give East Europeans and Latin Americans themselves better access to credit.
Lowered barriers. Cold war impediments to technology transfers, especially in computers, can be further reduced. Protectionist restrictions against farm and manufacturing imports can be eliminated, so that developing countries can earn the hard currency needed for expanding trade.
Financial relief. Bank regulators can encourage more debt-reduction deals by private banks. Governments can provide direct help by contributing to currency stabilization funds and reducing official debts. These steps will also free financial resources for trade and investment.
Transition expenses. Eastern European and Latin American governments need to invest in infrastructure. Adequate unemployment and welfare systems are necessary to help workers temporarily between jobs. Devastated environments require renewal to attract new economic activity.
The newly established European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is ideally suited to meet such needs in Eastern Europe. In Latin America, the Inter-American Development Bank provides an appropriate vehicle. And in all regions, the World Bank can play an expanded role.
These programs will take bucks, but not megabucks. The whole idea of market-based reform is to rely increasingly on private investment, not government subsidy. And the responsibilities can, and should, be shared with Western Europe and Japan.
Some in Congress have begun to think about new approaches to aid. But so far the Administration has proposed only patchwork change. Worse, Washington seems locked into positions that make needed shifts all but impossible.
Powerful Congressional constituencies appear determined to preserve existing aid formulas. The White House proclaims the need to provide aid to many new countries, but then rejects the two most promising ways of paying for it - a clearly identified peace dividend or a tax increase.
America has the resources to fund worthwhile domestic and foreign programs. But as a result of the last decade's fiscal follies, those resources are not now available for public purposes.
Americans have made sacrifices for decades in the name of a freer world. Now such a world seems at hand. Will Washington keep the U.S. constructively engaged, or let fiscal and political inertia compel a shameful, costly retreat?

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A Tale of Two Priorities

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
All right, George Bush fans, let's reconcile the following two news items:
The Pentagon has leaked the idea of cutting by two-thirds the funds intended for research into high-definition television. The result would be to make the U.S. armed forces dependent on foreign suppliers like Japan for an important military technology, while also damaging the hard-pressed U.S. electronics industry.
Meanwhile, in the Senate, two Republicans not known for being soft on defense, William Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona, have proposed cutting twice as much out of the Pentagon budget as President Bush has projected - primarily from the B-2 bomber, a new ballistic missile, and the Star Wars strategic defense program.
So can anyone explain why the Administration wants to cut research into high-definition television, one of the most important pending technological developments, while it demands billions in the Pentagon budget for missiles, bombers, and a Buck Rogers antimissile system few scientists believe will work? 
The proposal to cut HDTV research funds comes in the teeth, moreover, of a report by a high-powered Pentagon advisory panel of businessmen, academics and labor leaders. The panel's report calls for a vast increase in funding for HDTV, on grounds that the alternative is ''unacceptably high levels of risk to our national security.'' Increased investment also is necessary, the report's authors argue, to keep U.S. computer and semiconductor industries competitive.
But the Administration's one hand apparently does not know what its other hand is doing. The proposed cut in HDTV funds - $20 million out of $30 million - would be used to ''study'' how to reform Pentagon purchasing procedures, and to provide foreign aid for Panama and Nicaragua.
Not just budgetary but ideological considerations apparently are at work here. Richard Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Michael Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, are reported to be opposed to Pentagon research that would reinforce commercial research and development in the U.S. Why? They think providing such funds smacks of ''industrial policy.''
What rot! For years the Government touted the space program and various military projects for their ultimate commercial applications. Now the Bush Administration finds it ideologically distasteful to give strong backing to HDTV, despite its valuable military potential. Yet, it proposes an overall 1991 defense budget that actually is higher, in dollars to be spent, than the 1990 budget. Only the projected rate of increase has been reduced.
This absurdly high level of military spending has been proposed in spite of developments in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union that clearly make it all but impossible for a Warsaw Pact invasion to be launched against the West. And William Webster, the director of the C.I.A., with the approval of James Baker, the Secretary of State, has told Congress that this course of events is irreversible.
Senators Cohen and McCain now have joined the Senate's Democratic military authority, Sam Nunn of Georgia, in calling for far more extensive cuts in the Pentagon budget than President Bush and his Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, have proposed. Under the Cohen-McCain plan, by 1995 military spending would be $50 billion less than in the current year (discounting inflation). For example, they would have the European allies assume primary responsibility for heavy ground forces and air defense in Europe; and they would reduce the present 14 aircraft carrier battle groups by one or two.
Surely such sensible reductions in the U.S. military establishment are more than warranted by the collapse of Communism and the Warsaw Pact, and the numerous internal challenges facing the Soviet Union. Surely, too, such cuts make far more sense than reducing research and development for the future. Does George Bush really want to cede high-definition television, with all its ramifications for defense and the economy, to Japan, while pouring money into the B-2 bomber and Star Wars?
Here, too, is the real measure of Mr. Bush's cheap political pledge, ''no new taxes.'' If cuts in military spending cannot be made fast enough or big enough to pay for other developments the U.S. desperately needs - high-caliber research, education, a rebuilt infrastructure - a true leader would not hesitate to ask this wealthy nation to pay the necessary bill.
