HEADLINE: Higher Fares Increase Lines And Evaders

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The recent increase in New York City's subway and bus fare, which rose to $1.15 from $1 on Jan. 1, has resulted in longer lines at token booths, a rise in fare evasion and a decline in ridership that could eventually cost the Transit Authority millions of dollars.
Riders who hoarded tokens in the closing weeks of the $1 fare have depleted their caches and are returning to lines already slowed by the complexities of making change from the new fare.
The Transit Authority guidelines say subway riders should wait no more than three to four minutes for a token. In the busiest stations during rush hour, the wait has stretched to 10 minutes - time enough to miss a rush-hour train.
The rate of fare evasions has been rising steadily over the last year, but Transit Authority officials suspect that the wait and the increased cost may be causing more riders to jump turnstiles or pass through fare gates illegally. For January, estimates by the authority indicate, about 5.3 percent of the riders did not pay, up from an estimated 5.1 percent for December. 
The Transit Authority estimates that fare evasion cost the authority about $48 million last year.
 
Remedies Are Suggested
In the last year, the average weekly subway ridership has decreased by about 84,000.
Transit officials and consumer advocacy groups have suggested a variety of remedies, from changing the number of tokens in multiple packs to make the transactions simpler to setting up remedial change-making classes for the clerks.
The subway clerks complain of growing hostility from riders and say they themselves are shouldering too much of the blame for the token booth lines. The clerks say riders contribute to the wait in several ways - by paying with pennies or crumpled dollar bills, by being indecisive about how many tokens they want once they reach the window or by buying only one token at a time.
''They treat us like dirt, call us dirty names and accuse us of making the lines long,'' said Mary Perry, a token clerk at the Times Square station at 42d Street and Broadway. ''I wish they could see how stupid it is for them to be buying one token everyday.''
Many New Yorkers say they are frustrated not only with the 15-cent fare increase, long lines at token booths and fare evaders but also with broken turnstiles, dirty subway stations, the number of homeless people and beggars on the subways and a general decline in the quality of service.
''People who use the subway frequently are very disgusted,'' said Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, a Manhattan Democrat. ''They wait in line for five to seven minutes to buy a token and then they can't get through the turnstile while others are not paying and running through for free. The whole thing is really ludicrous because the paying customer is subjected to such bad treatment.''
 
'Only Way I Can Afford'
''Every time I wait in this line I just get angrier and more confused,'' said Jessie Nye, a mail clerk from Queens who catches the N train at 47th Street and Seventh Avenue. ''The subway is the only way I can afford to get home, and I have to be subjected to this, this garbage,''
Some people no longer take mass transit, choosing instead to walk or take a taxi. Weekday ridership on subways and buses declined 2.1 percent in January to 5.28 million passengers, compared with 5.44 million riders in the month last year, the authority reported recently. Transit officials say weakening of the economy in the metropolitan area has contributed to the lag.
Although ridership declined in January, revenue from subway operations rose 11 percent because of the fare increase. Still, subway revenue was 3 percent below what the Transit Authority had forecast.
 
The Change Problem
Bus service is not a viable alternative to the subway, many riders say. Buses do not accept dollar bills and require either a token or $1.15 in exact change, which many people generally do not carry. The authority has also cut service on many bus lines in the last year because of low ridership.
In an effort to reduce the wait at token booths, the transit officials say they are opening additional windows at booths in the busiest stations, conducting an information campaign to encourage riders to buy tokens in bulk and to use exact change, and selling tokens in vending machines.
But so far those efforts have done little to shorten lines. The average waiting time during rush hour is still about five to seven minutes at most stations, transit officials said, and some riders have waited as long as 10 minutes at heavily used stations like Grand Central, Times Square, and Chambers Street in Manhattan, and Jamaica Center in Queens.
The situation has worsened in recent weeks because thousands of riders who hoarded tokens at $1 each in December have used up their supply and are returning to token booth lines.
The authority estimates that it will lose about $9.1 million this year because riders hoarded so many tokens in December, the final month of the $1 fare. Of the 85 million tokens minted, about 25 million tokens are normally in circulation. By the end of December, about 70 million tokens had been collected by riders who hoped to avoid paying the $1.15 fare for as long as possible.
 
Struggling to Make Change
Many token clerks are still struggling to make change, even though they have hand-held calculators and fare charts. About half the Transit Authority's 3,800 clerks have been hired since 1985, when the fare was last increased, to $1 from 90 cents, and they have never had to make change with coins. Although some clerks caught on quickly and are now adept at making small change, others still are having trouble and are being given remedial help, transit officials said.
Carol Meltzer, the authority's chief station officer, who supervises the subway stations, including token booths, said the lines should get shorter in a few weeks, when the initial flood of riders who hoarded tokens starts to subside and token booth clerks gain more experience making change.
''We are hoping to reduce the average waiting time at token booths to three or four minutes, but riders can play a major role in reducing the size of the lines by buying packs of 10 tokens and using exact change,'' Ms. Meltzer said.
Consumer advocacy groups like the Straphangers Campaign suggest that the Transit Authority consider introducing packs of 13 or 7 tokens that would make for a faster transaction than the current 10-pack. Priced at $14.95, a 13-pack would allow passengers to plunk down $15 or $20 and get a nickel or a nickel and a $5 bill in change. A 7-pack could be sold for $8, giving a nickel savings that could encourage people to buy packs in advance, the groups have said.
 
'Should Do Something'
''Unless the authority offers a special deal, those lines are going to remain in place until another fare increase,'' said Joseph Rappaport, a spokesman for the Straphangers. ''The T.A. should do something to accommodate the passengers since it raised the fare.''
Kevin Hyland, the Transit Authority's chief revenue officer, said the agency had studied various packaging alternatives for tokens and found that the added expense in making packs of 13 and 7 tokens would far outweight any time saving that might come on the lines. He said the current 10-packs are ''enormously popular'' with riders - 43 percent buy them - and that the authority planned to continue to sell them.
Tokens can be bought from machines at most of the major subway stations and at some banks and public agencies. But few people are using the token machines, transit officials said. During a recent rush hour in the Grand Central station, lines at token booths stretched 20 people long while a token machine that was five feet away was not being used.
One rider has refused to pay the extra 15 cents. Regina Bruce, a student at the New York Institute of Technology, said she pays the token clerk a dollar and proceeds through the fare gate or jumps over the turnstile.
''When you look at what you get -filthy cars, trains that are always late, dirty stations - it's not worth another 15 cents. and I urge people not to pay it,'' said Ms. Bruce, who lives in Harlem. Token clerks often refuse to take her dollar, she said, so she leaves it in the money slot at the token booth window.
Transit officials said most fare abuses could be eliminated with automated fare collection, an electronic system that allows passengers to pass through turnstiles using a prepaid fare card. The authority is seeking funds from the state to introduce such a system.
In the interim, the officials said that they planned to install full-height railings in stations and automated gates controlled by token clerks and to place transit police officers at stations that have high levels of fare evasion.
One such station is at 125th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem, where the turnstiles are almost always broken and riders are told to deposit their tokens in a fare box. On a recent afternoon, fewer than one in 20 passengers put tokens in the fare box. The token clerk at the station declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Guidance or Censorship? New Debate on Rating Films.

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The designation of two new films as X-rated has rekindled debate over the 21-year-old movie-classification system of the Motion Picture Association of America.
An X rating means that no one younger than 17 is permitted to see a movie, and an R means that people under 17 are admitted only in the company of adults. Despite those restrictions, Jack Valenti, the president of the industry trade group that started the ratings system in 1968, insists the system is nothing more than a guide to parents that in no way dictates behavior to filmgoers, film makers or exhibitors.
But many film makers and distributors maintain that the system is a form of censorship. They say it prevents serious adult films from reaching a wider audience because the advertising and distribution of X-rated movies are severely limited and may affect their subsequent acceptability on cable channels. 
Many of these critics of the system, saying it fails to distinguish between films that have adult themes and those that are exploitatively violent or pornogaphic, are also calling for a new ratings designation.
The two X-rated films in question are ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' and ''Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer.'' Both were submitted to the association and were given an X; their distributors then rejected the X and decided to release the movies unrated. Producers voluntarily submit their films for a rating because they are given wider release in theaters. If they don't get the R rating they want, they may decide to release the films unrated in hopes that they may appear in a few more theaters than they would with an X rating.
 
What the Reviewers Said
''Cook,'' playing in Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Kansas City, Miami, New York, Washington, San Francisco and Seattle, is a drama of revenge by the British writer and director Peter Greenaway. In chronicling the rise and fall of a vicious gangster who abuses everyone around him, including his wife, the film depicts murder and maiming of people. There are explicit sex scenes, a child is tortured and there is cannibalism.
Roger Ebert, writing in The Chicago Sun-Times, said of the film, ''This isn't a freak show; it's a deliberate and thoughtful film in which the characters are believable and we care about them.''
Caryn James, in her review in The New York Times, called ''Cook'' ''elegant, stylized and brutal,'' adding that ''though it is not easy to sit through this film, which begins by pushing the thief's most repulsive behavior in our faces, Mr. Greenaway creates such intensity that it is impossible to turn away from the screen.''
But David Edelstein said in The New York Post that Mr. Greenaway was ''coldly and majestically ladling slop for human pigs.''
''Henry,'' directed by John McNaughton, is on view only in Austin, Tex., Detroit and New York City. The film's subject is a drifter who winds up on death row in Texas. It graphically portrays the mutilation of the killer's victims.
Richard Corliss, in Time magazine, called Mr. McNaughton ''a coroner with a touch of the poet.'' Ms. James, in The Times, said the film was ''profoundly disturbing.''
 
Defending the System
Mr. Valenti, in an interview, defended the X ratings in general and the system. ''We are getting no letters from parents demanding that we end the rating system,'' he said. ''And our opinion polls for years have shown that 70 to 73 percent of parents find it useful. All the complaints are coming from producers, who want to push the outer edge of the envelope.''
Richard D. Heffner, chairman of the association's classification and rating administration, said, ''The X rating is the only means we have of saying to parents, 'We think that due to violence, language, sexuality, nudity or other reasons, this film is not for children.' '' He said of film makers: ''We're not asking them to censor their films. No film has to participate in the process, or even stay with the rating we give them.''
Mr. Heffner's California-based rating board consists of parents who are not otherwise involved in the movie business. The board has nine voting positions. Mr. Heffner is also the parents' advocate before hearings of the appeals board in New York. It has 22 members from the movie industry, and a film maker can ask it to change a rating.
 
How an X Rating Cuts the Audience
Russell Schwartz, the executive vice president of Miramax Films, which is distributing ''Cook,'' took issue with Mr. Heffner, saying, ''The X rating can keep a film from finding an adult audience.''
''A lot of newspapers won't accept X-rated ads, and many theater chains have problems accepting X-rated films,'' he said. ''Often, they're not allowed to play them in malls due to real-estate contracts that forbid X-rated films. The lack of an R rating is already limiting the outlets we have across the country.''
The competition to have rated films shown in the most desirable theaters means that unrated films are at a disadvantage, but not as much as if they were rated X. The New York Times considers ads for X-rated films case by case and does not accept such advertisements ''unless we believe there is some artistic or cultural significance to the film,'' said Robert P. Smith, manager of the advertising acceptability department. The Times has accepted ads for both ''Cook'' and ''Henry.''
David Whitten, president of Greycat Films, the distributor of ''Henry,'' said: ''To members of the general public, an X rating means pornographic or dirty or blood-and-gore. When the rating system started, 'Midnight Cowboy' and 'Last Tango in Paris' were X-rated and enjoyed commercial success. But that wouldn't be possible today with an X.''
 
Defending the Content
It is up to individual theaters to enforce the association's rating system. At the releasing companies' requests, theaters that are playing ''Cook'' agreed to bar people under 18, and those showing ''Henry'' agreed to exclude people under 17.
Mr. Greenaway, the director of ''Cook,'' said in an interview, ''This film is obviously about a consumer society and its abuses.'' Several of Mr. Greenaway's previous films, like ''The Draughtsman's Contract'' and ''The Belly of an Architect,'' have been highly praised by critics.
''I don't think it's pornographic,'' Mr. Greenaway said of ''Cook.'' ''I don't think this film is obscene any more so than the society it depicts is obscene, and I would certainly wish that its messages be taken seriously.''
 
'A Very Rough Movie'
Helen Mirren, who stars as the gangster's wife, said: ''The style is avant-garde, and the film is not intended to commercialize and take advantage of elements of sadism in an attempt to manipulate people. There are no exploding heads in this movie, yet when one looks at the kinds of films that are given an R rating -'Friday the 13th' and 'Halloween' -it's outrageous.''
Mr. Whitten said of ''Henry'': ''It is a very rough movie. But there's an embedded message that it's an indictment of the whole idea that you should be able to sit in a theater and watch murder as an entertainment. The ordinary movie with R-rated violence has desensitized the public at large to the violence it depicts. And here is a film that shows murder as a heinous event, not as something that is enjoyable.''
Mr. Valenti said the association could not be held responsible for the limited distribution of X-rated films. ''If people are hurt by this, I'm sorry, but we say to the exhibitors, 'Play anything you want to play,' '' he said. ''I can't ask or force an exhibitor to do anything, and I can't ask or force a director to cut one bit of film. Whatever he does on an economic basis is up to him.''
 
Tyranny of the R In the Real World
For film makers, the R rating is ''a necessity,'' said Paul Schrader, the director of ''Patty Hearst,'' ''Mishima,'' ''Blue Collar'' and ''Hardcore.'' ''Every contract I sign says, 'I agree to submit an R film of no more than 120 minutes' - so it's a contractual obligation. The producers of a $30 million film don't want you to go out with an X. And no major release will go out unrated.''
In practice, ''this means that usually you make the movie you want, and show it to the ratings board,'' he said. ''And they say this and that is a problem, and you change it, to get an R. So they're saying that they're not censoring anyone, but what's happening is that you have to censor yourself, and then you come back to the board, and they may imply, 'You haven't censored yourself enough.' ''
The producers of ''Henry'' and ''Cook'' say they think they were given X's because of overall content rather than specific scenes. When overall content is the reason that an R rating is denied, it can create issues of artistic control for directors. ''If the ratings board says you won't get an R,'' Mr. Schrader said, ''then you know you have to make cuts - but how deeply do you cut - a tiny bit? But maybe it's not enough, so then the studio says: 'We know how to do it. We'll make the cuts.' And then the studio gets involved in your movie.''
Mr. Heffner, the ratings board chairman, said: ''The matter of tone is so much nonsense. I've never seen a T rating for Tone.'' He would not comment on the specific reasons for giving ''Cook'' and ''Henry'' X ratings. But he said: ''We are simply saying that this work of art is in its overall content too strong for children. If from stem to stern it's violent or objectionable, we can't give them a laundry list.''
The distributor of ''Cook,'' Miramax Films, has used the disagreement over the X rating in its publicity for the movie and has made Ms. Mirren and Mr. Greenaway available for television and newspaper interviews. The company has issued press releases deploring the idea that ''a major international artist might be subjected to censorship.''
Mr. Valenti said the ratings system was often assailed for publicity purposes. ''We've seen again and again - they want to hype their picture,'' he said. ''A good publicity man complains about censorship and gets a lot of publicity.''
 
A New Category? Pros and Cons.
Mr. Whitten said the association, ''by not copyrighting the X, participated in allowing that rating to be co-opted.''
Indeed, the association did not copyright the X rating, although it did copyright its G, PG, PG-13 and R ratings. As a result, the makers of pornographic and gory exploitation films have been able to make use of the X rating - and XX or XXX designations - to advertise their films.
''We didn't copyright the X rating from a legal standpoint,'' Mr. Valenti said. ''It had to be an open-ended rating, so that if somebody doesn't want to submit a picture, they can use the X. Otherwise, we could be challenged on First Amendment grounds.'' Those grounds, he said, would be that the association was engaging in a form of censorship: that film makers' and movie patrons' free-speech rights were being abridged by limiting the release of the film to selected audiences.
Mr. Schwartz of Miramax, echoing other film makers and distributors, said: ''This whole archaic rating system should be changed. The M.P.A.A. should copyright another letter and set up a system that has a designation for adults.''
The motion picture industry changed the rating system in 1984, when a PG-13 rating was instituted to serve as a stronger warning to parents of children under 13.
''I think the M.P.A.A. needs to add one more letter,'' Mr. Whitten said. ''If they called it A and copyrighted it, they could award it on the merits of the film. A would mean 'Adults only, no one under 17 admitted,' and they could stop giving the X rating since it's been co-opted by the pornographers.''
 
Why It Might Not Work
Mr. Valenti disagreed. ''More than 450 films a year come up for rating, on average,'' he said, ''and why should we change this rating system, which is working, because of one or two or three films a year where this is a problem?''
Mr. Valenti said that since the rating system was created on Nov. 1, 1968, 419 films had accepted the X rating, ''though twice as many may have made the decision to make excisions to get the R rating,'' he said. The association keeps no statistics on how many films have been unrated.
''If you have two ratings, one for 'serious' slasher movies and one for 'pornographic' slasher movies, then people can sue you over this, saying, 'You're putting me in the leper category.' We have to be fair to everyone. The strength of the current system is its voluntarism. It's survived several lawsuits because it is not Government- sanctioned and because no one has to submit to it.''
If a new rating was created, Mr. Valenti added, ''no matter what letter you give it, it would soon take on the patina of pictures that inhabit that particular category.'' In addition, he contended, it would ''be difficult to distinguish between serious and exploitative films. ''Sometimes the distinctions, say, between 'erotic' and 'porn' are not that easy to judge.''
Mr. Heffner commented: ''Who in the world is the person who'll stand up and say that 'mine is not a work of art'? Right now, the horror fans are saying to the ratings board, 'How can you do this to horror fans?' '' He referred to X ratings given to violent horror films. ''They claim they have their own art form: the gore horror film. So they are saying we're forcing them not to enjoy what it is they enjoy.''
 
Ratings Translation
 
How the Motion Picture Association of America defines its ratings.
 
G: General Audiences - all ages admitted.
PG: Parental Guidance suggested; some material may not be suitable for children.
PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for children under 13.
R: Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent of adult guardian.*
X: No one under 17 admitted.
 
* Age varies in some jurisdictions.

Companies
Pepsico expects to sign the largest deal ever between an American company and the Soviet Union, bartering soft drinks for vodka and at least 10 oceangoing ships. The deal is estimated to be worth more than $3 billion. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Senator Defends Help For Lincoln

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee yesterday defended his intervention with Federal regulators in 1987 on behalf of a Phoenix developer, Charles H. Keating Jr., saying that Mr. Keating was a business constituent in Michigan, his home state. The chairman, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., said he had received no indication that Mr. Keating had done anything improper.
In one of his few recent public comments on his involvement with Mr. Keating, Mr. Riegle asserted that in 1987 he and others did not question the activities of the Phoenix developer, who was then battling Federal regulators over restrictions on the investments of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.
''He was a business constituent in my home state - had made major investments in Detroit at that time in the redevelopment of downtown Detroit,'' said Senator Riegle, a Michigan Democrat. ''That was the nature of my relationship with Mr. Keating.'' 
Five United States Senators, including Mr. Riegle, met with regulators in April 1987 and questioned them intensely on actions they were taking against Lincoln. The Senators' action has become the focus of a Senate Ethics Committee investigtion.
The regulators, officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, have since asserted that they felt pressure from the Senators to treat Mr. Keating leniently and not to take aggressive action to stop his speculative investments.
The interview yesterday on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' included a sharp exchange between interviewers and Mr. Riegle that left the Senator pressed to defend his involvement with the developer. Asked if he had any concerns in 1987 about Mr. Keating's activities, Mr. Riegle responded, ''Well, no, I don't think so.''
When asked about the propriety of accepting a political contribution of $76,000 from Mr. Keating, which he returned after it was questioned, Senator Riegle replied that the Bush campaign had accepted a $100,000 contribution from Mr. Keating.
The exchanges were a rare occurrence for the Senator, who has generally declined interviews about his role in the Keating affair.
Though some officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board wanted to seize Lincoln as early as 1987, it was not until April 1989 that the institution was taken from Mr. Keating's control. After Lincoln was seized, the Government filed a $1.1 billion suit against Mr. Keating and his associates, charging lending fraud. He is also the subject of criminal investigations by the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
To a question about public outrage over responsibility for the savings and loan crisis, Mr. Riegle responded in the interview: ''I became the chairman of the Banking Committee a year ago, and I feel the very frustration and the outrage that you suggest. I think anybody that's dealt with this problem feels that way.''
Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to manage the savings and loan bailout, have said that the Lincoln collapse will cost taxpayers more than $2 billion, making Lincoln perhaps the costliest of all the failures.
Senator Riegle has acknowledged that he received large campaign contributions from Mr. Keating and his associates early in 1987. Soon afterward, he urged Edwin J. Gray, who then was the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, to meet with five Senators who were concerned about the regulatory treatment of Lincoln. Mr. Keating had contributed heavily to the campaigns of the five Senators, who include four Democrats, Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Senator Riegle, and one Republican, John McCain of Arizona.
Senator Riegle has had a hard time putting the Keating affair behind him. He frequently says it would be improper for him to comment on the matter while the Ethics Committee is investigating.
On March 29, Senator Riegle suffered a political embarrassment when he proclaimed on the Senate floor that his committee was likely to reject the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to be director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. Mr. Ryan won by a single vote in committee the next day, and last week the full Senate approved his confirmation by a surprisingly wide margin, 62 to 37.
 
Cost of the Bailout
Questions in yesterday's television interview may have taken Senator Riegle by surprise. The topic of the 30-minute interview show was the savings and loan crisis, not explicity Mr. Keating and Lincoln.
On Friday, the Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, told Mr. Riegle's committee that the 30-year cost of the bailout would be substantially greater than the $257 billion that the Bush Administration initially projected. Mr. Bowsher said the cost would be at least $325 billion and could go as high as $500 billion.
At the same time, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, said the cost of the bailout could very well be as high as $500 billion. He noted that as his agency has studied hundreds of troubled and insolvent institutions over the last year they have found the losses to be considerably greater than initially projected by regulators.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Low U.S. Profits For Foreigners

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FEW issues raise more of a fuss these days than foreign ownership of American businesses. European and Japanese companies are elbowing their way into manufacturing, retailing and other fields, and they are capturing profits that otherwise would have made Americans wealthy. Or so goes one popular theme in the debate. The problem with this theme is that foreign operations here are not showing much profit.
That surprises Government officials and economists, and they offer various explanations. One widely held view is that foreign investment in factories, machinery and buildings has boomed only in recent years, which means that start-up costs have been too high to permit much of a payoff yet. Another holds that foreign companies, trying to increase sales here, have held down prices and profit margins. 
Citing such views, Yoshindo Takahashi, director of the Normura Research Institute (America) Inc., said, ''Japanese companies can live with low returns in the United States because high profits in Japan offset weak earnings here.''
But other explanations are more cynical. Some economists believe that the Commerce Department's income data cannot possibly capture the true profitability of foreign operations in the United States. The reason, in their view, is that most of the $380 billion in foreign direct investment in the United States comes from global companies that are indifferent to whether they report a profit or a loss here.
These giant corporations have operations in many countries, and their common goal is to maximize their worldwide bottom line. To achieve this, a company has to operate in the huge American market, but it does not have to report a profit here. Costs can be spread among the various countries, according to this view, and books are often doctored in pursuit of a fatter worldwide profit or sometimes out of bureaucratic habit.
''How costs and profits are divided up among a company's overseas subsidiaries can't escape being overwhelmingly arbitrary,'' said Raymond Vernon, an international economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. ''For that reason, I cannot take the Department of Commerce figures at face value.''
Neither does the Internal Revenue Service, which announced recently that it was examining the returns of many American subsidiaries of foreign companies to determine whether they had understated their profits in recent years and had underpaid their taxes by as much as $12 billion.
One motive of these companies might have been to escape a corporate tax rate that was among the highest in the industrial world until the 1986 tax law reduced the rate sharply and presumably eliminated an important reason for understating United States profits.
Norman Glickman, a Rutgers University economist who was the co-author of a book on foreign investment, offers an illustration of one important way in which global companies understate profits: A German or Japanese computer manufacturer might have a factory in Malaysia that makes chips and another factory in the United States that imports the chips to make a computer. But instead of being charged $10 for each chip, the price an outsider would pay, the American subsidiary shows on its books an intracompany charge of $20.
This higher ''transfer price'' results in more profit for the Malaysian subsidiary and less for the subsidiary in this country. But by showing the profit in Malaysia rather than the United States, the parent makes more money because the corporate tax rate in Malaysia, in this hypothetical example, is lower than the one in the United States. ''That's one reason for the low return on foreign investment in the United States,'' Mr. Glickman said, ''but by no means the only one.''
The Commerce Department data seem to bear him out. The corporate tax rate in the United States fell sharply as of 1987, presumably removing a main reason for holding down profits reported within the country. But the pretax return on foreign direct investment has averaged only about 4 percent a year since 1982, and did not rise in the last three years. Finally, the 4 percent is only half of what American-owned companies earned on their investments within this country in the same period.
Transfer pricing might be one reason for this. But for most experts, another factor is the expensive, highly advanced factories that foreign companies have tended to put in the United States -factories that take awhile to pay off. Whatever the reasons, profits and tax payments are probably not the best guidelines for judging the value of foreign investment.
''The answer to that question is whether the country would be better off without the investment,'' Mr. Vernon, of Harvard, said. ''Does a cluster of Japanese auto factories keep car prices down, improve worker productivity and bring technology to the country? Probably it does.''

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise 3.93% in Tokyo

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 9

 BODY:
The primary index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged nearly 4 percent this afternoon, helped by the yen's rebound against the dollar.
The Nikkei average of 225 issues gained 1,150.93 points, or 3.93 percent, to 30,429.71 in late-afternoon trading. It ended the morning session up by 886.67 points, or by 3.03 percent, to 30,165.45. The index last exceeded 30,000 points on March 29 with a close of 31,026.16.
On Friday, the Nikkei gained 1,029.72 points, its fourth-largest daily advance.
''Buy orders are appearing for a broad range of issues,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an equities analyst with Daiwa Securities.
Mr. Nishiguchi said the market had responded favorably to talks between the United States and Japan on lifting restrictive trade policies and to a meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized countries, both held last week.
Monetary authorities from the seven nations - Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States - agreed in their meeting in Paris on Saturday that the yen's recent downswing could have ''undesirable consequences.''
They also promised to keep the exchange markets under review and renewed their commitment to coordinate economic policies, including cooperation in exchange markets.
The dollar ended the morning session at 156.55 yen, up by 0.75 yen from its opening at 155.80 yen. After opening at 1.67 yen lower than its close of 157.47 yen on Friday, the currency fell as low as 155.60 yen and rose as high as 156.90 yen during today's trading.

HEADLINE: Airline Fares Are Defended

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
United States air passengers are being offered more flights at lower fares than in the mid-1980's even though there are fewer airlines, a Transportation Department official said last week.
''Deregulation works,'' Jeffrey Shane, an Assistant Transportation Secretary, told a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on Thursday. ''Any effort to re-regulate would do more harm than good.''
Mr. Shane said that even though the number of leading airlines has fallen from 16 to 8 since 1984, there are more flights and fares have declined 15 percent after adjusting for inflation.
But some senators expressed uneasiness that the eight airlines control 90 percent of United States air traffic and that individual airlines often dominate business at their hub airports.
The committee is considering a bill that would require operating slots to be regularly reallocated at the most restricted airports: Kennedy and La Guardia in New York, O'Hare in Chicago and National in Washington. Mr. Shane said the bill would not solve capacity problems.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Browning-Ferris's Strategic Retreat

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
NO one disputes that hazardous-waste disposal is a huge, lucrative market destined to become much larger. Nevertheless, Wall Street's first reaction was decidedly upbeat when Browning-Ferris Industries said after trading ended Thursday that it would bail out of the business.
In the Thursday announcement, the Houston-based company said it would take a $295 million after-tax charge against earnings to cover the cost of discontinuing hazardous-waste operations. In Friday trading, its shares rose $1.50 to $37.875 in heavy volume on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Although Browning-Ferris is the nation's second-largest waste handling enterprise after Waste Management Inc. and has been one of Wall Street's favorite growth stocks for much of the past decade, the company encountered a series of problems in its attempt to follow Waste Management into the hazardous-waste field.
''Browning-Ferris screwed up that business ever since they got into it in the late 1970's,'' said Kay Hahn, an analyst of environmental stocks at the Chicago Corporation. Such assessments were highlighted by a second announcement on Thursday that Browning-Ferris had pleaded guilty to one criminal count of violating Ohio's environmental laws at its hazardous-waste disposal site near Cincinnati. The company was fined $25,000 and agreed to pay $3.5 million to settle related civil claims.
The write-off, which equals $1.93 a share, will be taken in the company's second quarter, which ended March 31. It will leave the company narrowly profitable for the year, many analysts project. That's a stiff price to pay for shedding operations that account for just 2 percent of the company's revenue, but good news for investors, the analysts say.
''It's now the best stock in the waste-handling group,'' said Vishnu Swarup, who follows environmental stocks for Prudential-Bache Securities. ''It could move to the low 40's in the near term.''
Behind such thinking is the view that Browning-Ferris's decision marked an overdue recognition that the company had made too many missteps in the hazardous-waste field ever to regain its footing at a reasonable cost. By pulling the plug on Cecos International Inc., its hazardous-waste subsidiary, Browning-Ferris is now free to concentrate on expanding its highly successful solid-waste business.
''It was a good buy before, but now it's better,'' said Douglas Augenthaler, who follows the company for Oppenheimer & Company. Mr. Augenthaler said the write-off would add $255 million to cash flow this year by sheltering operating income from taxes. He also said he saw a good chance that the share price would rise to $41 by summer, allowing the company to call $345 million in convertible debentures and reduce its debt to close to historic levels.
''This stock is selling at a 10 percent discount to the market based on projected 1991 numbers,'' Mr. Augenthaler said. ''That doesn't make sense. It's a growth stock with steady cash flow and strong resistance to the effects of any recession.''
To be sure, some analysts are less enthusiastic. ''The focus on solid waste going forward is positive, but I'm concerned about their financial flexibility,'' said Marc H. Sulam, who follows environmental stocks for Kidder Peabody. ''I don't think they will outperform the market over the next nine months.''
Another doubter, Richard F. Rossi of Dean Witter Reynolds, said, ''I don't think anybody can be really confident at this juncture that the reserves are adequate'' to cover the actual costs in coming years of closing Cecos's discontinued operations and cleaning up the sites.
Perhaps the most negative assessment has come from Scott Jay Wollins, who follows environmental stocks for Tucker, Anthony Inc. in Boston and had been recommending that investors sell Browning-Ferris even before Friday's price jump.
''People will come to view that jump as temporary insanity,'' he predicted. ''They are abandoning the business that will provide the greatest earnings opportunity in the environmental field over the next 20 or 30 years. It shows their inability to diversify and general management problems. We wouldn't buy the stock until it got down to $26.''
But the analysts seem unanimous in one conclusion: that Browning-Ferris's hazardous-waste woes say little about the prospects of other waste disposal companies. Because Cecos's operations had already become so constrained by its ongoing run-ins with regulators, its disappearance is expected to have little impact.
Cecos does have one jewel though - a huge disposal site scheduled to open in May, 70 miles east of Denver. Analysts say that Chemical Waste Management Inc., the publicly traded hazardous-waste subsidiary of Waste Management Inc., might be blocked from bidding for the site by antitrust regulations. That could provide Laidlaw of Canada, the second-largest hazardous-waste handler in the United States, with a golden strategic opportunity to close the gap.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Spate of New Offerings Undercuts Bond Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market analysts say a heavy schedule of new Treasury borrowings over the next month is likely to offset any positive effect of a slowing of economic growth and inflation.
As a consequence, long-term interest rates are likely to remain in the relatively narrow trading range of 8.50 percent to 8.70 percent that they have occupied for the last six weeks or so.
A rising supply of new securities in the market usually tends to put upward pressure on interest rates.
Late Friday, yields on the Treasury's closely watched 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 stood at 8.51 percent, the low end of the range. $40 Billion on Schedule Through mid-May, the Treasury is expected to sell more than $40 billion of new intermediate- to long-term securities. Moreover, the size of the weekly auctions of three-month and six-month bills has been raised to $13.4 billion, from $13 billion. 
The heavy debt load, prompted in large measure by the rising needs of the Resolution Funding Corporation to finance the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, comes at the time of year when heavy income-tax payments usually reduce the Treasury's need for new cash.
''It will be another month before the market will want to behave well,'' said Robert A. Brusca, the chief economist at Nikko Securities International. ''There are just too many securities that will be sold over that period to enable rates to soften. But then I think we will see further evidence of a weaker economy.''
Rates would then come down, he added.
 
Effect of Jobs Data
March employment data, which were much weaker than expected, have made the task of coping with the coming supply somewhat easier.
Although nonfarm payroll employment rose by 26,000 jobs last month, the lowest monthly increase since June of 1986, the figure would have been negative if 58,000 Census workers had not been added.
The weak report followed two months of strong employment gains distorted by unseasonably warm weather.
As a result of the March figures, ''the fear that developed in response to the strong January and February numbers that the economy was growing too fast will dissipate,'' said John R. Williams, a managing director at the Bankers Trust Company.
Bad news for the economy is good news for the fixed-income Government securities markets because signs of economic strength raise inflation fears and higher inflation means lower real rates of return on the securities.
 
Reports on Sales and Prices
Economic data for March, including reports this week on retail sales and producer prices, should improve the market's tone somewhat, Mr. Williams said. But he and other analysts agreed that the figures will not be soft enough to persuade the Federal Reserve Board to alter its stance on monetary policy.
''We do not expect any change in policy until late in the second quarter or early in the third quarter,'' analysts at MMS International, an economic information and forecasting firm, wrote late last week. ''By that time, the need for further easing will be apparent.''
Most economists are projecting that because of falling energy prices,producer prices rose by only one-tenth to two-tenths of a percentage point last month, after an increase of four-tenths of a percentage point in February. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, producer prices probably rose by three-tenths of a point in March, most analysts say.
 
Watching Foreign Exchange
In addition to the Resolution Funding Corporation's bond sale this week, the credit markets will pay close attention to developments in the foreign exchange markets, where any immediate substantive results from the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven nations are most likely to be seen.
Specifically, bond traders will be looking for weakness in the dollar's value against the Japanese yen after the Paris meeting. The finance ministers and central bankers issued a communique after their meeting expressing concern about the fall of the yen and said they had agreed to ''keep these developments under review.''
Neither Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady nor the officials of other countries would state specifically what had been decided at the meeting.
The Group of Seven nations are the United States, Japan, Britain, Canada, France, West Germany and Italy. The ministers generally meet three times a year to review economic conditions around the world with the aim of keeping international markets on a steady course.
The Treasury auctions begin on Tuesday, when $3.5 billion worth of 40-year Resolution Funding bonds will be sold. They continue on Wednesday, with the auction of $7.5 billion worth of new seven-year notes. In early May, the Treasury is expected to sell some $30 billion of notes and bonds at its regular quarterly refunding auctions.
 
Bigger Response Expected
The first sale of the 40-year Resolution Funding bonds in January was an unqualified disaster and was one factor that helped to drive up interest rates in the first quarter.
This time, however, traders and analysts say they expect a stronger response.
''I think the Refcorp issue will be well received,'' Mr. Brusca said. ''Interest rates are at a higher level now than they were then, the inflation picture is likely to improve, and the economy looks a little weaker. In short, the investment environment is more favorable, and that makes the environment for these 40-year bonds more favorable.''
Bond traders added that the reduced size of the offering, from the $5 billion sold in January, should prove beneficial.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
International Trade Group Reorganizes

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
IN an effort to raise its profile to the level of other advertising trade groups, the International Advertising Association announced a management reorganization on Friday that will bring the group its first full-time professional leadership.
The association named Norman Vale, who was until January managing director of Grey International, to be its first director general. Richard Corner, a former executive at Ogilvy & Mather and the Philip Morris Companies in Europe, who has been the association's acting executive director since November, will serve as executive director of the organization. 
The association, which is based in New York, represents marketers, ad agencies and communications companies in 77 countries. But unlike the leading American advertising trade organizations, which have long had full-time senior managers to oversee operations and serve as industry spokesmen, the international association has vested much of its operational authority in a part-time president elected from the ranks of senior corporate or agency management.
Members say the president's responsibility to his regular job has hindered efforts to build the organization.
''With Norman Vale, we can take a lot of the weight off the shoulders of the elected president,'' said Clay S. Timon, the head of worldwide advertising for the Colgate-Palmolive Company and the association's current president. He drew an analogy between Mr. Vale's new role and that of the head of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. ''Like John O'Toole of the 4A's, he is the man to be called on to be truly a spokesman,'' Mr. Timon said. ''As elected president, I was not good at that, because I work for Colgate.''
The association's decision to enhance its management comes at a crucial time for the advertising industry around the world. The scheduled elimination of trade barriers in Western Europe in 1992 and the development of market economies in Eastern Europe are flooding that continent with advertisers, agencies and media companies. Likewise, the development of Asian economies continues to draw increasing advertiser interest.
But, particularly in Western Europe, the pending opening of borders is also inciting a drive among some governments to regulate the content of advertising. The French Government, for example, has proposed banning tobacco advertising and the sponsorship of events by tobacco companies, and restricting the advertising of alcoholic beverages. While concerns for public health are behind some of the legislative efforts, the association executives contend that some Governments see advertising restrictions as a way to protect their own established industries, many of which are state-owned, from competition from foreign companies once the trade barriers fall.
The association's leaders say that with professional, centralized management, their organization can wage a fight against regulation by conducting and disseminating research on the effect of advertising restrictions in the countries that have enacted them.
''More critical than simply providing information,'' said Mr. Vale, who is 60 years old, ''we can and should become the world resource for assisting governments and people in the communications business to protect freedom of commercial speech.''
The new managers also say the association can act more effectively as a clearinghouse for information that will help member companies expand their operations globally. As an example, Mr. Corner, 56, noted that the association had recently helped a British newspaper find an advertising sales representative in the United States.
These two sides to global marketing - expansion and censorship -will be the main topics at the association's biannual convention, which is scheduled to be held in Hamburg, West Germany, from June 10 to 13.

HEADLINE: As Gridlock Mounts, Region Buys More Cars

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
The number of motor vehicles registered in the New York metropolitan region has risen more than 25 percent since 1980, planners say, and some suburbs will soon approach the unenviable position of having as many vehicles as people.
The increase came as the region's population grew only modestly and in spite of traffic that is among the worst in the nation.
Planners attribute the surge in cars, trucks and vans largely to a revitalized economy that generated more jobs, drew more people into the work force and pushed incomes up. Some also said that the growing reliance on motor vehicles showed that mass transit in the region does not take some commuters where they need to go, especially in the suburbs.
 
A 'Precipitous' Rise
Since 1980, there have been 2.5 million more vehicles registered in New York City and the 26 counties that surround it in New York, northern New Jersey and Connecticut, according to calculations by the Regional Plan Association. The increase in the number of vehicles in the region is the largest since the internal combustion engine was invented. 
In a report commissioned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to help in its planning, the association called the rise ''precipitous.''
The size of the increase was considered a surprise. The percentage of additional vehicles in the 1970's was half that of the previous few decades, and given the uncertain economic outlook and congestion then, the growth rate had been expected to stay about the same or even decline.
 
'Disaster on Our Hands'
''Instead of flattening, the curve suddenly kicked up,'' said Boris Pushkarev, former vice president for research and planning for the association, a Manhattan-based research group.
The metropolitan area is expected to become even more clogged with cars in coming years. The association believes there are likely to be 38 percent more motor vehicles in the region by 2005 and 50 percent more by 2015.
Asked about the impact of such an increase, Robert R. Kiley, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said that unless more measures were adopted to manage the growth of vehicles ''we'll have a disaster on our hands.'' Mr. Kiley and others have called for an increase in the gasoline tax, to raise money for transportation projects and, perhaps, to discourage driving.
To many in the region, traffic might already seem like a disaster. The Long Island Expressway already accommodates twice the number of vehicles for which it was designed. On the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the Kosciuszko Bridge now carries 30,000 vehicles per lane a day, the plan association said. Hourlong waits to cross the Hudson River into Manhattan are common.
''Even reverse commuters are running into problems,'' said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group based in New York.
Mr. Goldstein noted that New York City has failed to meet standards adopted by the Federal Government in the early 1970's for certain automobile pollutants. ''If traffic keeps increasing,'' he said, ''we may never achieve national health standards.''
 
Commuter Train Ridership Up
Projections by the plan association showed that the number of vehicles registered since 1980 rose 41 percent in the city's northern suburbs, 28 percent in Connecticut, 27 percent in New York City, 26 percent in northern New Jersey and 23 percent on Long Island.
The plan association defines the New York metropolitan region as stretching from New Haven County, Conn., in the east to Warren County, N.J., in the west, from Ocean County, N.J., in the south to Ulster County, N.Y., in the north.
In the mid-1980's, the growth rate for vehicles was greater in New York City than in those areas, a trend Mr. Pushkarev said was probably the result of higher incomes and the poor performance of the subway system before the current rebuilding program.
But there seems little doubt that the suburbs will bear much of the brunt of the additional vehicles in the future.
Automobile trips into mid- and downtown Manhattan are increasing slower than they were several years ago, at least in part because of congestion. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, has classified congestion in New York City as the third worst in the nation, behind Houston and New Orleans. At the same time, ridership has risen on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road. #80 Vehicles Per 100 Residents By 2005, commuting into Manhattan is expected to increase by 13 percent, but commuting within suburban counties is expected to rise 22 percent and commuting between suburban counties is expected to increase 28 percent.
The plan association believes that at that time the number of motor vehicles in the metropolitan region will exceed 15.4 million, almost 4 million more than there are now. Mr. Pushkarev said the projection was based on the historic relationship between vehicle ownership and the per capita income in the region, which has been rising since World War II and is expected to continue to do so.
Planners and transportation officials say the number of motor vehicles is rising throughout the nation. But the trend seems particularly worrisome in the New York region, since the city's wealthier suburbs have traditionally had high rates of car ownership.
On Long Island and in the northern New York suburbs, for example, there already are more than 80 vehicles per 100 residents - a level planners say rivals that of California and other car-clogged parts of the country.
 
Three Car Families
''We observed that auto registration has far outpaced population growth,'' said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. ''Now, both husband and wife work. That's at least two, maybe three cars. And if there are any teen-age children, you can add cars for them.''
Some suburban commuters have little alternative to the car. The L.I.R.R., for example, runs mainly east and west, but many people need to travel north and south to get to jobs in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Planners also note that many of the new suburban office complexes were not built along rail lines.
As for bus service, Mr. Koppelman said that ''in Suffolk, on some of the routes, you can wait an hour between runs.''
''You don't encourage a lot of people to take buses if they have to stand in the cold and rain and heat and wait,'' he said.
 
Just Catching Up
Lanes are being added to the Long Island Expressway and other highway projects are under way or envisioned. But Mr. Koppleman said they will ''just catch up with the traffic that's already there.'' He said he hoped the Island's relatively stable population and the trends toward flexible work schedules and more home offices would ease traffic growth.
Mr. Kiley said he believed that measures to limit traffic on some highways and bridges, like tolls, were overdue.
The transportation authority is spending $16.2 billion largely to rehabilitate the region's transit lines that exist now. It is seeking another $10 billion to $15 billion to continue its rebuilding effort and also to begin to expand the transportation system. Projects under consideration include the extension of a subway or rail line from New York City to New Jersey, rail links to Kennedy and La Guardia International Airports and resumption of work on the Second Avenue subway line, which has been mothballed.
But it is far from certain how much money will be available to the transporation authority, since one of its major sources, New York State, is experiencing huge budget gaps.
Mr. Goldstein said that additional financing for the expansion of transit lines could be raised by increasing the state tax on gasoline.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has already raised the possibility of a gasoline tax increase to help solve the state's fiscal problems.

HEADLINE: OBSCURE ENGINEER NOW THE FAVORITE TO LEAD PERUVIANS

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 9

 BODY:
Alberto Fujimori, an once little-known obscure agricultural engineer who campaigned in traditional Japanese robes, displaced the novelist Mario Vargas Llosa today as the favorite to become Peru's next President.
''If the vote were this week, Fujimori would win this election,'' said Manuel Torrado Bermejo, the head of a polling company, echoing the analysis of other polling experts, politicians and diplomats interviewed here today.
The latest projections from a study of votes cast in 200 precincts on Sunday gave 31 percent to Mr. Vargas Llosa and 29 percent to Mr. Fujimori, whose parents were Japanese immigrants. But 25 percent of the vote was split among three leftist parties. Alienated by Mr. Vargas Llosa's free-market economics, those voters are expected to throw their weight behind his vaguely centrist opponent in a runoff to be held within eight weeks. 
 
Pullout Is Rumored
Final official results of Sunday's voting will not be known until April 20, but the projections of leading polling organizations are widely accepted here.
Rumors raced through this capital today that Mr. Vargas Llosa might quit the race. The 54-year-old writer made no public statements and remained with advisers and family members in his home overlooking the Pacific Ocean.
''A lot of people are worried that Mario will pull out,'' said a Western diplomat, recalling that last May the novelist quit the race briefly in disgust over infighting among his supporters.
 
Ruling Party Fares Badly
In contrast, the ebullient Mr. Fujimori, who six weeks ago scored only 3 percent in public opinion polls, repeated his determination to stay in the race.
''If you were Fujimori, two points short of Vargas Llosa and the polls were saying you could win, would you give up?'' a diplomat asked.
The ruling left-of-center Aprista party of the departing President, Alan Garcia, fared poorly; its candidate, Luis Alva Castro, received little more than 16 percent of the vote.
The party, one of the three whose supporters are seen as pivotal in the runoff, today appeared to give a boost to Mr. Fujimori's candidacy when a leading member, Luis Alvarado, said, ''The support of the Apristas for Mr. Fujimori is implicit.'' Mr. Alvarado, who is President of the lower house of Congress, added that the party could formally endorse Mr. Fujimori.
 
'Blew Up in Our Faces'
Today, political analysts tried to come to grips with the sudden emergence of what is called the ''Fujimori phenomenon.''
''This blew up in our faces,'' said Saul Mankevich, general manager of Mr. Torrado's polling organization, Datum.
Across town at the American Embassy, a diplomat said with self-deprecating humor, ''We don't know anyone on Fujimori's list - another victory for American diplomacy.''
In contrast to Mr. Vargas Llosa, who proposed a free-market ''shock'' program for Peru's economy, Mr. Fujimori presented himself as a centrist and a consensus builder. He first achieved a moderate amount of notice here in the late 1980's when he was host of a television program called ''Concertando'' - roughly ''working things out.''
Until entering politics last year, Mr. Fujimori was president of the Agrarian University and president of Peru's National Association of College Presidents.
 
Japanese Roots Emphasized
To gain attention in a field of nine candidates, Mr. Fujimori emphasized his Japanese roots. His parents immigrated here from Japan in the early 1930's. Claiming to be the direct descendant of an illustrious samurai, the 51-year-old bespectacled engineer posed for campaign photographs wearing Japanese robes and waving a samurai sword.
In one recent public opinion poll here, 33 percent of respondents cited Japan as the country they admired most. Mr. Fujimori promised to bring Japanese investment and technology to this Pacific basin country. The bulk of Peru's Japanese are concentrated in Lima and numbers abou 10,000.
With the slogan ''Work, Technology and Honesty,'' Mr. Fujimori, a Roman Catholic, attracted campaign support from Evangelical Christians.
Today, he said he would form a Government of ''experts,'' and he sketched an economic program that would revive agriculture and retain large state companies under public ownership.
 
'Only Loose Ideas'
''Behind the Fujimori candidacy there is no Government program -only loose ideas and isolated proposals,'' La Republica, a Lima newspaper that backs his candidacy, wrote today.
The candidate has proposed easing Peru's terrorism problem by easing rural ''misery.'' He does not appear to have a public position on Peru's coca leaf cultivation - a major concern in the anti-drug strategy of the United States Government. In 1988, when Mr. Fujimori was president of the Agrarian University, the institution declined a United States Embassy invitation to serve as an impartial evaluator of a coca plant herbicide.
The candidate, who did postgraduate work at the University of Wisconsin and at the University of Strasbourg, speaks Spanish, French, English and Japanese. But no elected office appears on his resume, printed by his political party, Change 90, which was formally registered only in September.
Political skills will be needed if he is elected. Projections from the congressional vote on Sunday give Mr. Vargas Llosa's Democratic Front the largest block in Congress - about one-third of all seats.
Mr. Vargas Llosa's electoral collapse appears to have occurred in inverse proportion to the rise in his popularity overseas generated by his candidacy.
 
A Sharp Drop in Support
A New York-based political consulting company, the Sawyer/Miller Group, advised his campaign, reportedly for a $1 million fee. In the six months of its consultancy, Mr. Vargas Llosa's popularity ratings dropped by half - from 61 percent to 32 percent today. The Americans complained that the candidate did not listen to their advice; Peruvian campaign experts said that several of the American consultants did not speak Spanish.
The foreign glitter around the Vargas Llosa campaign may have alienated an impoverished electorate composed largely of people of mixed Spanish and Indian blood. President Garcia is known to harbor a personal dislike for Mr. Vargas Llosa.
Some of the novelist's supporters winced Sunday night when a French reporter asked the opening questioning in a nationally televised press conference and the novelist responded in French.
''Vargas Llosa also associated in public with the right, with the rich, with the whites,'' Mr. Torrado said.
He cited a $100,000 television advertisement that featured Roxana Valdivieso, a singer with entirely European features, who sang a dreamy love ballad to Peru, backed by a supporting cast of 2,000. Deemed to miss the mark, the advertisement was pulled after 10 days.

LENGTH: 658 words

HEADLINE: Greek Right Gains One-Seat Majority

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, April 9

 BODY:
The leader of the New Democracy party, which emerged victorious from the Greek election, won the backing of an independent rightist today to secure narrow parliamentary support for the country's first conservative government in nine years.
Its principal challenges, most commentators agreed, will be to cement its hold and confront an economic crisis.
With returns from Sunday's election completed today, the New Democracy leader, Constantine Mitsotakis, champion of a rightist vision of economic change, had won 150 of the 300 seats in Parliament. His principal rival, the Pan-Hellenic Socialist Movement of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, had won 123. 
Of the rest, 19 went to an alliance of leftists and Communists, and two went to Muslim candidates from the small ethnic Turkish minority. One went to an ecological movement and four to candidates running on a joint Socialist-Communist ticket.
 
Rightist Pledges Support
One seat was won by a small party led by Costas Stephanopoulos, an independent rightist who pledged today to support Mr. Mitsotakis and thus give him a majority of 151 seats.
Mr. Stephanopoulos's announcement after a 45-minute meeting with Mr. Mitsotakis, commentators said, seemed to seal the demise of what has become known as the Papandreou era, a heady period of anti-Americanism and Socialist fervor that gave way to decline and scandal.
Some commentators said the one-seat majority injected a sense of fragility into the planned new government. The Greek stock market nonetheless soared by record margins when the announcement was made, reflecting a surge of business confidence.
Mr. Mitsokakis has promised to form a government by Wednesday. Its composition is not yet known, but the conservative leader, a 71-year-old veteran of Greek politics from the island of Crete and a longtime adversary of Mr. Papandreou, is expected to become prime minister.
 
Rivalry Dates to 1965
His dispute with Mr. Papandreou dates to 1965, when he and others withdrew from a liberal Government headed by Mr. Papandreou's father, George, to protest the son's radicalism. Greek leftists have since blamed the withdrawal for starting a period of instability that enabled the military to take over in 1967.
During seven years of military rule, Mr. Mitsotakis was detained briefly and then left the country, returning when civilian rule was restored in 1974. He joined New Democracy in 1978 and was Minister of Economic Coordination and of Foreign Affairs before the conservatives lost power to Mr. Papandreou in 1981. He became leader of New Democracy in 1985.
The election Sunday was the third in Greece since the collapse of Mr. Papandreou's scandal-steeped administration last June.
''I think a lot of people were getting tired of the uncertainty, and they diverted their votes to what seemed to be the winner so that there would be a government,'' said Adamantios Pepelasas, a former financier and respected commentator and economist.
 
Papandreou's Electoral System
The results, however, robbed Mr. Mitsotakis of the unambiguous victory he had sought, reflecting an electoral system designed by Mr. Papandreou to give his smaller allies greater parliamentary influence.
New Democracy officials and commentators said one priority of a Mitsotakis government could be to follow a traditional practice by changing the electoral law and to seek a more substantial parliamentary majority.
Some commentators argue that the authorities will need a strong base to pursue unpopular economic measures.
''The economy is in a bad way, and a frontal attack is required,'' Mr. Pepelasas said. ''We must deal with it brutally.''
Technically, an investment analyst said, the Greek economy is ''in a mess.'' But the formal economy that appears on the state ledgers accounts for only about half the country's economic activity. The rest is conducted on an underground cash economy where tax evasion is routine.

SECTION: Section A; Page 4, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: Panama Journal;
Trafficking in People: Was It One More Racket?

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
No sooner do the doors of Panama's Department of Immigration and Naturalization open for business than the waiting room fills to overflowing with dozens of anxious Chinese, accompanied by lawyers or interpreters and talking nervously among themselves in Mandarin, Cantonese or Hakka.
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega may have been driven from power, but the daily confusion at immigration headquarters here constitutes perhaps his most bizarre legacy.
In the six years he was commander of the Panamanian Defense Forces and dictator of Panama, General Noriega, now in custody in Miami, was repeatedly accused of trafficking in drugs, arms and intelligence.
But it is now clear that he and his fellow officers also earned themselves several hundred million dollars by selling Panamanian visas, residency permits, identity cards and passports to thousands of foreigners, most of them Chinese citizens desperate to flee their troubled homeland. 
 
Sale of Documents Cut Off
With General Noriega gone, the country's new civilian Government, installed during the American invasion on Dec. 20, must cope with the consequences of what Roberto Troncoso, president of the Panamanian Committee on Human Rights, calls ''Noriega's wholesale trafficking in nationality.'' President Guillermo Endara's administration has already cut off the sale of Panamanian documents to Chinese abroad and now wants the thousands who are already here illegally to submit their papers to inspection, pack up and go home.
''These people are victims of the corruption of the previous Government,'' Soong Chang-chih, Taiwan's Ambassador to Panama, said of the flood of Asian newcomers, many of whom come to the immigration office here seeking guarantees that they will be allowed to stay. Many others have now gone underground.
''They are living 8 to 10 to an apartment,'' Mr. Soong said, ''unable because of the language barrier to work or to study, and terrified they will be expelled to the China mainland.''
Panamanian officials say the center of this extremely lucrative trade was the Panamanian Consulate in Hong Kong, where General Noriega's cousin Ciro Noriega was Consul General. Panamanian officials and Chinese immigrants say the going rate for a Panamanian tourist visa there was $5,000 to $7,000, payable in advance, plus $10,000 to $15,000 for a Panamanian identification card and passport, to be paid after arrival.
Mr. Soong estimated that 40,000 to 50,000 Chinese have arrived in this country of 2.4 million people since 1982. The Panamanian Government's figures show that slightly more than 20,000 have been admitted in the last five years. A few better-off Hong Kong Chinese have also arrived, worried about the British colony's return to Beijing's control in 1997.
 
A Source of Huge Profits
The flow rose dramatically last year, a result of the political unrest and Government crackdown in China and of General Noriega's eagerness to profit from that turmoil. Jose Chen Barria, the director of Panama's Department of Immigration and Naturalization, said 8,850 Chinese acquired Panamanian visas and entered the country by way of Hong Kong in the first 11 months of 1989, providing the Panamanian military with enormous profits.
''If you multiply that figure by $15,000 you will get a figure well over $100 million,'' said Mr. Chen, himself a member of Panama's large Chinese community, which first came when the Panama Canal was built.
Though the Chinese provided the largest source for the sale of Panamanian documents, General Noriega and his associates appear to have been engaged in the same business around the globe. Panamanian Government officials and diplomats here said 13,000 Cubans are in a situation similar to that of the Chinese, along with several thousand others, including Nicaraguans, Colombians, Indians, Pakistanis and Arabs.
To encourage the illegal Chinese immigrants to leave Panama, the new Government in January announced a ''voluntary repatriation program.'' But Mr. Chen said that in the first two months of the program only about 600 had accepted the offer, which expires April 15 and is expected to be followed by much harsher measures.
Members of the underground Chinese community that has sprung up here said they were reluctant to accept the offer because of conditions in China. A 38-year-old college professor from Shanghai who works as a cook here said he had arrived in October, disgusted by the Tiananmen massacre and hoping that his wife and two children would eventually be able to follow him. ''China has no future, and neither do I if I stay there,'' he said. ''My generation already lost a decade to the Cultural Revolution, and I want a new life, one with opportunity and without repression.''
Tony Zhu, a successful young businessman from Guangdong who recently bought a nightclub here, said he did not know what he would do when his Panamanian residence card expired this spring. He left China last April, but is worried because, he said, the Beijing authorities have learned that the company he ran made large donations to the protest movement. ''Everybody is worried about what is to become of us,'' he said.
Many of the Chinese say they are hoping that Mr. Endara and the legislature will grant an amnesty that will permit them to stay. But the Panamanian Government has ruled out any possibility of pardon.
''That would be an unpopular measure,'' Mr. Chen said. ''How are you going to sell an amnesty in a country whose economy is destroyed, with unemployment so high, on behalf of people who, when they are unable to get a job, fall into crime? Let them find another country to go to.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Panama's new Government has cut off the illegal sale of Panamanian visas, passports and residency permits. Immigrants crowd the Department of Immigration and Naturalization, trying to legalize their presence. (The New York Times/Roberto Armocida)

HEADLINE: False Fears About Japanese Stocks

 BODY:
Tokyo's financial markets are reeling. Since the beginning of the year, Japanese stocks have dropped almost 30 percent, the yen about 10 percent. Worried that the chaos would spread, the finance ministers of the U.S. and six other industrialized powers, meeting in Paris last weekend, put the issue at the top of their agenda. 
What did the ministers commit themselves to do? Nothing, which is exactly right.
Americans and Europeans have little to fear from financial turmoil in Japan. So far, Wall Street prices have not been affected. But even if U.S. stock and bond prices do start to fall, the Federal Reserve Board has ample tools - as it proved in 1987 - to keep the economy on track.
It's always hazardous to speculate on why stock markets move up and down. Yet part of the Tokyo collapse is surely due to higher Japanese interest rates, which make stocks more expensive to buy or hold. Whatever the reason, many Americans fear that the turbulence will spread to Wall Street and then to Main Street, causing output to fall and unemployment to rise.
These fears are unfounded. For one thing, the impact of collapsing stock prices in Tokyo on U.S. financial markets is uncertain. Some Japanese investors will sell U.S. stocks and bonds in order to meet margin calls at home. But others will buy U.S. stocks and bonds as a safer alternative to Japanese investments. This ''flight to quality'' helps explains the calm on Wall Street.
And in any case, a decline in stock prices need not affect the real economy of production and employment. To put the Tokyo plunge, 30 percent in three months, in perspective, recall that U.S. stock prices fell 20 percent in just one day, Oct. 19, 1987. Yet the U.S. suffered no economic downturn. The Federal Reserve Board pumped money into the economy, thereby lowering interest rates. The rally in bond prices offset part of the loss that investors suffered on stocks and spurred spending; the economy kept humming along.
If an alert Fed can insulate the economy from sudden, direct chaos on Wall Street, it can surely protect the economy from gradual, indirect chaos in Tokyo.
At the Paris meetings, the U.S. could have succumbed to Japanese pressure and agreed to prop up the yen. To do that, it would have to drive down domestic interest rates with a loose monetary policy, thereby making the dollar less attractive to hold. In all likelihood, that would succeed only in igniting domestic inflation. The U.S. was correct to reject the risky Japanese entreaty.
Financial chaos can and does hurt people. The 1987 crash shocked individuals whose wealth evaporated in hours - even though in many cases they have since recovered - and devastated the investment bankers who lost their jobs. New York City's regional economy has yet to recover. There will be similar victims this year in Tokyo.
But for the economy as a whole, the 1987 stock market collapse brought no tragedy. It showed that able policy makers can keep economies growing even when markets shrivel. Financial chaos never brings joy, but it need not deliver disaster.
