HEADLINE: Why This Year Fashion's Thinking Green

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is more to fashion's underpinnings than was cited in ''Fashion World's Green Movement'' (front page, March 25): the need for the ready-made clothing industry to survive.
The phenomenon of fashion developed in the middle of the 14th century when all clothing was custom-made. Artisans and artisanship developed to meet the new demand. Then fashion as a social process evolved as the rising middle classes demanded ''equal opportunity'' with the aristocracy.
A fashion trend is the result of a convergence of political, economic and other social factors and it meets a need for affiliation and value affirmation, particularly important in our heterogeneous, multiracial society.
Moreover, the article might have considered that many of the environment-conscious youths of the 60's are now executives holding decision-making power and are serious about saving the earth. Fashion is the expression of the latest political, artistic and literary ideas, the spirit of the period. If a designer wants to be considered among the vanguard, to be viable in the profession, he or she must take into account the new ideas.
Capitalizing on grass-roots commitment to ecology may have the concomitant consequence of raising public consciousness. It is possible that in our time the power of the image may be stronger than the power of the word, and ''ecology chic'' clothing may encourage greater awareness and an ongoing commitment to saving the earth. As Brendan Behan suggested, it was the wearing of the green that made the Irish in New York count.
 
RUTH P. RUBINSTEIN
Assistant Professor of Sociology
Fashion Institute of Technology
 New York, March 28, 1990

HEADLINE: For a Space Visionary, Persistence Nears Payoff

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 9

 BODY:
At 75, Dr. Lyman Spitzer Jr., professor emeritus of astrophysics at Princeton University, has a string of scientific accomplishments behind him. He had a leading role in the development of sonar in World War II and of in early concepts for controlled fusion energy.
But what may be his most lasting contribution is sitting on a launching pad here: the Hubble Space Telescope, set for liftoff Tuesday morning to an orbit where it will view the heavens almost to the edge of the universe. The first detailed ideas for a large space telescope were Dr. Spitzer's, and over the years his tenacious advocacy won over astronomers, fought off budget cutters and sustained the project through adversity and repeated delays.
This tall, lean professor has never shied away from the big problems of science and technology requiring bold and imaginative solutions. ''I have a weakness of character - a fascination with the spectacular,'' Dr. Spitzer likes to say of himself. ''But then I have a sort of theory about our weaknesses being our strengths.'' 
To be sure, the $2.1 -billion project, the most expensive and complex undertaking in unmanned space science to date, has grown beyond the embrace of any one person. It has become a manifestation of big science, involving vast teams of researchers and technicians, enormous costs, fierce competition and bureaucratization.
But everyone associated with the project acknowledges Dr. Spitzer as the intellectual and political father of the Hubble telescope.
''He's been the driving force from the very beginning,'' said Dr. Jeremiah Ostriker, chairman of the astrophysics department at Princeton.
In a history of the project, ''Space Telescope: A Study of NASA, Science, Technology and Politics,'' published this month, Dr. Robert W. Smith, a historian at the National Air and Space Museum, writes that Dr. Spitzer's ''involvement in arguing for, justifying, and then helping to develop the space telescope stretches back longer than the commitment of anyone else.''
''Lyman has been the father-spirit of the project,'' added Dr. Charles J. Pellerin Jr., director of astrophysics for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
Forty-four years ago, when the German rockets of World War II had awakened people to the possibilities of space flight, Dr. Spitzer elaborated on the value of placing a large telescope in orbit high above Earth's obscuring and distorting atmosphere. He did this as an addendum, entitled ''Astronomical Advantages of an Extraterrestrial Observatory,'' to a 1946 study of artificial Earth satellites conducted by the Rand Corporation for the Air Force.
''Such a scientific tool,'' he wrote, ''could revolutionize astronomical techniques and open up completely new vistas of astronomical research.''
Dr. John N. Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N. J., said: ''That paper was like Lyman himself. It was simple, very clear but very audacious.''
Although Hermann Oberth, a German-Romanian member of the V-2 rocket team assembled by Dr. Wernher von Braun, wrote in the 1920's of the possibility of space telescopes, it was Dr. Spitzer who expanded the concept with specific plans. His outline of the four main research goals for the telescope was especially prescient.
A telescope with a 200-inch mirror, he predicted, could measure the extent of the universe, determine the structure of galaxies, resolve the individual stars now hidden in the hazes of globular clusters and learn the nature of other planets. All four are high on the Hubble's agenda for discovery.
Only in one respect have events overtaken Dr. Spitzer's vision. He predicted the telescope might settle the issue of whether there was intelligent life on Mars. That possibility was ruled out by spacecraft visiting the planet. But the Hubble telescope, astronomers hasten to add, could help identify planetary systems around other stars and thus encourage the belief in extraterrestrial life far beyond the solar system.
 
Embodiment of a Struggle
As Dr. Spitzer recalls, the evolution of the Hubble telescope occurred in four stages of roughly one decade each. He worked mostly alone in the first decade, but would come to embody astronomy's struggle to initiate and defend the project through its long, troubled history.
No one paid much attention to the idea at first. Space flight was still futuristic. But Dr. Spitzer left Yale University in 1947 to become head of astrophysics at Princeton, where he had earned his doctorate. One condition of his employment, he said, was that he be allowed to pursue his vision of a space telescope.
Working with Dr. Martin Schwarzschild at Princeton, he sent telescopes to the fringes of space with sounding rockets and balloons in what was called Project Stratoscope. In 1957, a 12-inch telescope was lofted by balloon to 80,000 feet to make revealing studies of the Sun. The information gathered by the telescopes, recorded on spectrographs, was recovered when they were brought back to earth.
That was a few months before Sputnik was launched in October, inaugurating space flight and the second decade of Dr. Spitzer's crusade for the telescope.
''The Air Force came to me with an urgent request for ideas about how satellites could be used for astronomy,'' he said. ''They didn't have to twist my arm.''
 
Ultraviolet Scannings
Manufacturers of optical systems were hired to develop lightweight mirrors. Electronics companies were assigned the task of devising instruments. When NASA was created in 1958 and took over space astronomy, one of the first programs incorporating the new technologies inspired by Dr. Spitzer was the Orbiting Astronomical Observatory.
The two successful observatories, launched in the late 1960's and early 1970's, included 30-inch telescopes designed to observe the heavens in the ultraviolet wavelengths. These radiations are almost entirely blocked out by Earth's atmosphere. With the spaceborne ultraviolet telescopes, scientists were able for the first time to examine the interstellar dust and gases, remnants of exploded stars and the breeding ground for new stars. Dr. Spitzer and Dr. Schwarzschild had been the first, in the 1940's, to realize that stars had to come from somewhere and that it might be possible to observe their birth processes.
Dr. Spitzer's own research with the second observatory, called Copernicus, earned him the Crafoord Prize from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. For astrophysicists, this is the nearest equivalent to the Nobel Prize.
 
Fear of the Expense
Although many astronomers were skeptical, Meanwhile, Dr. Spitzer had prevailed on the National Academy of Sciences to study and recommend proposals for a large space telescope. Many astronomers were skeptical. Even if a space telescope with a mirror more than 100 inches wide might be feasible, the critics y preferred a more conservative approach using a number of different smaller telescopes. They feared the big scope would be so expensive it would kill off more modest and more certain endeavors.
Dr. Spitzer was undeterred. In his history of the project, Dr. Smith quoted a colleague as saying, ''Lyman is a master of listening to everybody and doing in the end what he wants to do.''
Others attribute this dauntless persistence to the mountain-climbing side of the man. Dr. Spitzer has scaled many peaks in his life, and still tries to do some rock climbing once a week. About a decade ago, he was sighted at dawn working his way up the wall of a gothic tower at Princeton, and was arrested by campus police.
After a conference of astronomers at Woods Hole, Mass., in 1964, a board of the academy recommended that NASA proceed with the project, to be known initially as the Large Space Telescope. NASA first considered an instrument with a 120-inch mirror. During a preliminary design study, prompted by Congressional resistance, the size was scaled back to 94 inches to save money and simplify construction.
 
'Great Orbital Device'
By all accounts of his colleagues, Dr. Spitzer is a quiet, gentle and modest man. But he saw the idea through the science and NASA bureaucracies with aggressive vigor that the initials for the Large Space Telescope, L. S. T., were said by insiders to stand for the Lyman Spitzer Telescope.
Reminded of this, he merely chuckled and changed the subject. The adjective ''large'' did have to be dropped, he recalled, because the telescope was not as large as envisaged and because it was thought to frighten Congressional budget makers.
''A friend of mine,'' Dr. Spitzer remarked, ''suggested that we call it the Great Orbital Device, which would give it an interesting acronym.''
A more appropriate and evocative name was conceived in 1983: the Edwin P. Hubble Space Telescope, honoring an American astronomer who discovered 60 years ago that the universe was expanding. It was Hubble's findings that set the stage for modern cosmology's theory that the universe began some 10 billion to 20 billion years ago in an explosion, the Big Bang, that send matter and energy hurtling off in all directions.
 
Close to Foundering
If the success of Copernicus, demonstrating the benefits of a space telescope, and the design studies by NASA highlighted the third decade in Dr. Spitzer's chronology, the whole project came close to foundering. In 1975 and 1976, NASA's budgets were unusually tight, and Congress was reluctant to authorize any new spending for space. NASA was on the verge of canceling the project. Dr. Spitzer became a lobbyist.
''John Bahcall and I divided up the names of key Congressmen and decided who would see whom,'' he said. ''We spent a lot of time in Washington. We called on other astronomers, who got their friends to get their friends to put on the pressure. The response was overwhelming.''
In 1977, NASA received approval to start the project, at a cost estimated to run $435 million. Designs were completed, contracts were let to industry, and fabrication began. The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company would build the spacecraft, and the Perkin-Elmer Corporation would produce the mirror and major telescope components. Launching was planned for 1983.
The project's fourth decade proved even more turbulent. Technical problems with the telescope held up its completion. The Government's General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, uncovered major serious shortcomings in project management, which led to a general shakeup of operations at NASA and the contractors. Costs had escalated, with $1 billion now the conservative estimate.
 
Chance to Improve Controls
Even the new launching date in 1986 could not be met, but this time it was no fault of the Hubble team. When the space shuttle Challenger exploded in January 1986, all missions were grounded indefinitely. The new delay added another half a billion dollars to the expense, but it did give managers a chance to revise entirely what was discovered to be an inadequate computer control system, or software program, for operating the telescope in orbit.
In the last few years, Dr. Spitzer has taken a lesser role in the project, acting only as chairman of the board that oversees management of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, the center responsible for planning, executing and processing research with the Hubble telescope. He has been instrumental in selecting the project's new scientific leaders. But Dr. Riccardo Giaocconi, director of the institute, has become the dominant figure in the program.
Even in his heyday, Dr. Spitzer lost a few battles. He had led a campaign to have the telescope science institute situated at Princeton, but Johns Hopkins University won out. His team at Princeton sought the contract to develop the telescope's main camera system, but the California Institute of Technology won with what Dr. Spitzer concedes is a ''superior'' electronic device.
 
Telescope of His Dreams
But Dr. Spitzer has the telescope of his dreams. By November or December, if it is functioning properly, he will get to use the instrument for observations of the interstellar medium, the gases and dust between the stars. Other scientists will be looking for answers to the questions Dr. Spitzer raised in his 1946 paper.
''The most important discoveries,'' Dr. Bahcall said as the countdown for the launching was getting under way, ''will provide answers to questions that we do not yet know how to ask and will concern objects we have not yet imagined.''
The vision of Dr. Spitzer also incorporated this faith in finding the unexpected.
''It should be emphasized,'' he wrote in first proposing the space telescope, ''that the chief contribution of such a radically new and more powerful instrument would be, not to supplement our present ideas of the universe we live in, but rather to uncover new phenomena not yet imagined, and perhaps to modify profoundly our basic concepts of space and time.''

HEADLINE: Designing an SST: Noise, Sonic Booms and the Ozone Layer

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the United States quietly pursues a new effort to develop a plane to carry passengers over long distances at twice the speed of sound or faster, it is focusing unusual attention on environmental problems that could ground the plane before it takes off.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration says preliminary studies it commissioned on a high-speed civil transport indicate that building such an aircraft is possible. But the effort will depend upon technological advances to make such a plane environmentally and economically acceptable, the agency says.
Parallel studies done in the past two years by Boeing Commercial Airplanes in Seattle and the Douglas Aircraft Company of Long Beach, Calif., a division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, indicate there will be a market after the year 2000 for a plane that can carry between 250 and 300 passengers at speeds between 1,350 and 2,000 miles per hour over distances of at least 6,000 miles.
The last attempt to build an American supersonic transport, or SST, ended in 1971 when Congress killed the program because of environmental concerns about excessive noise, possible damage to the ozone layer and whether such a plane could operate economically in an era of rising fuel prices. 
Attempting to learn from the past, the agency plans to spend $284 million over the next five years to find out whether a high-speed transport is feasible. The program will center initially on technology related to environmental issues.
The chief concerns are sonic boom, airport noise and engine emissions that could help reduce the atmosphere's protective ozone layer.
 
Confronting the Bottom Line
''We don't want the country to invest money in another round of supersonic transport development until these environmental questions are answered,'' said Howard L. Wesoky, NASA's program manager for high-speed transport research.
''We are looking at environmental issues ahead of hardware issues, which is unusual for a technology project,'' Mr. Wesoky said. ''The bottom line is that if we can't solve the environmental questions, the plane will not be built.''
To underscore these concerns, NASA has established an advisory committee on environmental problems that includes representatives of technical agencies concerned with aircraft, people from the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and representatives of environmental groups, such as Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, senior scientist for the Environmental Defense Fund.
''We're starting a process that may go on to become a model for Government, industry, environmental groups and others getting together before a technology is developed to see about doing it right,'' Dr. Oppenheimer said. ''This wasn't done for the first SST, nuclear power or some other technology that hasn't worked out.''
The preliminary studies by Boeing and Douglas are cautiously optimistic that technology can be found to overcome environmental difficulties.
 
Promising Engine Designs
Current aircraft technology, including the best material and engines available today, could not produce an acceptable aircraft, said Michael L. Henderson, Boeing's program manager of the project. But proposals for new aircraft materials, such as low-weight composites that can withstand the high temperatures of supersonic flight, and new engine designs that promise to be cleaner and quieter, are promising, he said.
The only supersonic airliner in service is the 100-seat Anglo-French Concorde; only 16 were built, and all but about a half dozen have been retired. The aircraft, which sees limited service between the United States and Europe, proved too small and short-range to be profitable and has been the source of many complaints about noise.
The resurgence of interest in supersonic airliners in the United States is in response to surveys that show passengers want a faster way to reach far-flung areas of the world, particularly Asia and the Pacific Rim, and that there would be intense international competition for a market for at least 650 such planes.
Aerospatiale, the French aircraft company, is studying a next-generation SST to replace the Concorde and the Japanese government has begun serious research. The Soviet Union has begun studies on a transport plane that could fly at five times the speed of sound, and is exploring the possibility of jointly developing a smaller, supersonic business jet with an American company.
To withstand the stresses of supersonic speed, the proposed planes would have to fly in the thinner atmosphere between 55,000 and 60,000 feet (the Concorde flies at just over 50,000 feet). The heat of the planes' engines would produce nitrogen oxides, which would drift up to higher levels and destroy ozone, a form of oxygen that screens the Earth from potentially damaging solar ultraviolet rays.
 
Effect on Ozone
Dr. Harold S. Johnson, a professor of chemistry at the University of California at Berkeley whose research on this reaction in the early 1970's helped scuttle the American SST, said a fleet of 500 supersonic airliners using existing engine technology would seriously deplete the ozone layer, which many researchers say is already being damaged by man-made chlorofluorocarbons.
According to a recent computer model study by Dr. Johnson with Douglas E. Kinnison and Donald J. Wuebbles of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, this fleet would reduce ozone by 15 to 20 percent, almost three times the damage predicted from chlorofluorocarbons.
Dr. Johnson said this worst-case prediction would probably not come true because engineers believe they can make jet engines that produce only one-tenth to one-hundredth as much nitrogen oxide as existing ones.
''I'm not the one to say this is impossible to do, but someone has to show that this is safe and practical,'' Dr. Johnson said, ''You can't start building planes on the promise that these problems may be solved.''
Flying faster than sound creates pressure waves in the air that cause a plane to leave a conical shock wave in its wake. The pressure waves that reach ground are heard as jolting sonic booms, which critics say disturb humans and animals, and produce vibrations that can damage property.
Mr. Graf of Douglas Aircraft said the sonic boom problem is important because his company's analysis indicates a supersonic airliner might not be economic if it were restricted to overwater flights.
Since sonic boom is affected by a plane's shape, size and mass, the aircraft makers say they are looking to new materials and manufacturing techniques to cut weight without sacrificing seating capacity. In addition, they are looking at different nose configurations and plane contours to reduce sonic boom.
 
'It Looks Very Good'
To deal with noise around airports, there is much research on cutting engine noise and improving the proposed plane's lift so that it rises quickly to leave the area sooner.
Jet engines powerful enough to push a big plane to supersonic speeds are inherently noisy, but engineers are looking at new types of engines that change their configuration so that they act and sound more like subsonic engines at takeoff and landing. Work is also progressing on new types of sound suppressors.
''I think it looks very good for producing a plane like this after the year 2000,'' said Mr. Wesoky of NASA.
Dr. Oppenheimer of the Environmental Defense Fund said he was not as optimistic that the problems could be solved and was particularly concerned about the effects a supersonic fleet could have on the atmosphere.
 
Concerns About Impact on Environment
In studying the feasiblility of an ultra-high-speed passenger plane, NASA researchers will focus on three environmental questions.
 
Sonic Boom
Can noise and vibrations associated with breaking the sound barrier be cut to acceptable levels?
 
Ozone Layer Damage
Will nitrogen oxide emissions drift up to the ozone layer and catalyze significant chemical destruction?
 
Airport Noise
Can engine configurations and sound suppressors be developed so noise of takeoff and landing is reduced?

HEADLINE: The Human Side of Harlem Troupe's Crisis

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Cheers and whistles filled City Center as the curtain fell after a recent performance by Dance Theater of Harlem for the city's public-school pupils. The children at City Center's Young People's Dance Series roared with laughter at the wry guide to the history and technique of ballet provided by Eddie J. Shellman, a principal dancer with the ballet company. They marveled at the height of the ballerinas' leg extensions and the men's leaps and at their daring one-handed lifts.
But the mood backstage was somber, for the 54-member company would not be dancing together again for six months except for a June 13 fund-raising show at Manhattan Center. Arthur Mitchell, who founded Dance Theater of Harlem with Karel Shook in 1969, announced the layoff in January, describing it as part of the strategy to meet a projected $1.7 million deficit in the company's $7.3 million budget because of unexpected cancellations of dates in California and Europe.
Faced with extended unemployment, what would the Harlem dancers do? Many said they were still numb from the shock of the announcement and from a three-month national tour that had just ended at the Kennedy Center in Washington. 
''As Mr. Mitchell said, we've all been in overdrive,'' said Valencia Yearwood, a corps dancer who joined the company this year. ''I don't think the reality set in until then, that this was really it.''
 
School Is Not Closing
In addition to laying off dancers, technical staff and most of the administrators, Mr. Mitchell had originally announced that the company's school would close for the summer. He said the moves were necessary to show the company's fiscal responsibility. Since then, the company has received grants of $50,000 each from Chase Manhattan Bank and the New York State Council on the Arts. With a $200,000 challenge grant from the Shubert Foundation and nearly $50,000 from individual donors, the money will help the school stay open this summer. But the dancers will be without work until October.
Major American dance companies commonly have a 40-week year, with 12 weeks of unpaid layoff built into the dancers' contracts. But longer layoffs are becoming more common as hard-pressed dance companies deal with financial setbacks. Dancers in those major companies cannot simply glide into the nearest temporary employment office and sign up for six months of performing, however, and New York State unemployment benefits bring them only $245 a month.
Several of the Harlem dancers said they would have to turn to their families for help. Others said they had gotten teaching jobs or would make guest appearances with other companies. Some said they might study or explore new fields. Most worried about how they would stay in shape with no performances and with the requisite daily dance class costing an average of $9.
 
Other Lands, Other Jobs
Virginia Johnson, one of the company's leading ballerinas, said she would continue to work on a bachelor's degree in history at New York University. ''I'm not sure I can afford it now, though,'' she said. ''I'll have to look into Hunter and City College and see what I can do.''
Cassandra Phifer will work on marketing and development for the company, choreograph dances in London and Seoul, South Korea, and coordinate a summer dance program for New Jersey children.
Lorraine Graves, a 12-year member who is now a ballet mistress and principal dancer, has been offered a three-month teaching job in Norfolk, Va., her hometown. With a bachelor's degree in dance, she is also thinking of beginning studies to become a certified undertaker so she can help out in her family's business. ''My brother said he thought I would be good,'' she said. ''And I've been away from my family for 12 years. They've been so good to me. I feel I could give something back. We know we're not going to be able to hop on our points forever. This has forced me to think, to make some decisions about my life in the next four to five years.''
Mr. Shellman, a principal dancer who joined the company in 1975, will teach at Iowa University for two weeks. And he and another company member, Endalyn Taylor, are to be married. ''I'm sending out resumes,'' he said. ''And I would like to speak about ballet more at colleges.'' #3 Directions at Once Lowell Smith, a principal dancer who joined the company 13 years ago, said, ''I'm taking courses in fashion illustration and design at the New School. I'm starting acting lessons at the HB Studios. The William Morris Agency is sending me out on auditions and stuff. All of it will either come together or fall apart.''
''People are contacting us,'' Ms. Graves said. ''We're all looking for jobs for each other. And my mother invited everyone to Norfolk.''
The layoff is harder for the younger, newer dancers. ''They're just getting started,'' Mr. Smith said. ''I think for them there was hysteria and panic and still is. Where are they going to get a job?''
Ms. Phifer worries, too. ''Most of them are not experienced enough to teach,'' she said.
Ms. Graves said, ''And I think most of the kids want to save themselves for Dance Theater of Harlem's return.''
Derick Reid, a corps dancer, joined the company only last May. ''I worked pretty hard to get to this point,'' he said. ''It was a shock when this happened.'' But Mr. Reid may be one of the lucky ones, for there may be a job for him in the 10th-anniversary celebration of Harbor Place in Baltimore. ''It's not dance, and I may be doing anything from public relations to stuffing envelopes,'' he said. ''I do want to stay in New York. I've set up my home here now. But you have to go where you can make a living.''
 
The Lost Momentum
Most of the dancers talked as much of the pain of separation from the company as of their job plans and economic worries. Dance Theater of Harlem, which is unusually close-knit, is a company with a mission. Today one of the nation's leading classical ballet companies. At the start, Mr. Mitchell, a dancer who became one of New York City Ballet's most popular performers, set out to prove that blacks can dance ballet.
Many of the performers said the company was dancing better than ever. ''Mr. Mitchell said, and I agree, that the company is so cohesive now and dancing so well on the technical and artistic levels,'' Frances Harper, a corps dancer, said. ''It's such a weird time for this to happen. That's what's so sad.'' It will be hard, the dancers say, to get the momentum back quickly.
 
The Clan Gathers
They are still haunted by the memory of the night Mr. Mitchell drew them together after a performance on tour and announced the cutbacks in a motel conference room in Pasadena, Calif. ''He was really drained,'' Mr. Shellman said. ''It was very difficult for him to tell us. He's the rock.''
''And he did everything he could for the rock not to crumble,'' Ms. Graves added. ''He was very quiet. But we all knew.'' There had been telltale signs that the company might have to curtail activities. But the announcement was still devastating. ''Mr. M. had always pulled something out of the hat,'' Mr. Smith said.
There was a long silence after the announcement. Then a group of dancers formed a circle around Mr. Mitchell, much as they do to inspire each other before performances. ''Just to support him and let each other know that we cared about each other,'' Mr. Smith said. ''He looked at that point like a dad who couldn't feed his kids.''
Will Dance Theater of Harlem return? ''No one is worried about the company folding,'' Ms. Yearwood said. ''There is just a feeling of sadness that we have to leave each other and D.T.H. for six months. We really love what we do, and where we do it.''
Mr. Smith said: ''The majority of the kids consider this their home. We're just waiting for Dad to finish building on some extra rooms before we come back.''

An article on Tuesday about the financial difficulties of the Dance Theater of Harlem misstated New York State's unemployment benefits.
They are $245 a week, not a month.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Triple-A Hero: Ambitious, Arrogant and Awful

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Titmuss Regained
By John Mortimer
281 pages. Viking. $19.95.
In John Mortimer's entertaining new novel, ''Titmuss Regained,'' England's green and pleasant land is threatened not by the building of industrialism's dark satanic mills but by the erection of 1980's style suburban housing projects and shopping malls.
Developers, it seems, have discovered the lovely Rapstone Valley, and their plans to create a cute new community named Fallowfield Country Town (complete with mock-Georgian shopping centers, huge parking lots and condominiums for yuppie commuters from London) immediately sets off a confrontation between liberals and conservatives, environmentalists and entrepreneurs. It's a confrontation that quickly obsesses all the Rapstone Valley residents, a confrontation that provides Mr. Mortimer with lots of opportunities to look at England's uneasy accommodation with recent social changes: the emergence of a new status-hungry middle class; the growing acceptance of American ideas and values; the spread of suburban development to once-bucolic areas. 
As his earlier novel ''Paradise Postponed'' (which first introduced readers to Rapstone Valley and its residents) demonstrated, Mr. Mortimer isn't interested in studying these matters in a ponderous, academic way. Rather he is content to dispense his sociological observations in passing while giving the reader a charming comedy of manners, full of eccentric characters, absurd liaisons and wacky subplots - the same sort of thing that made his ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' novels so deliciously entertaining.
Though the results are frequently as funny as those produced by Evelyn Waugh, there's none of Waugh's viciousness or malice. It's obvious that Mr. Mortimer sides with the lovers of a pastoral past, but he remains remarkably evenhanded in his satire, sending up the sentimental excesses of the ''green welly brigade'' even as he reserves a modicum of sympathy for his awful hero, the Right Honourable Leslie Titmuss, Secretary of State for Housing, Ecological Affairs and Planning (HEAP).
Titmuss, as readers of ''Paradise Postponed'' will doubtless remember, is a scheming, social-climbing Member of Parliament who has risen to his current position of prominence from an impoverished childhood in the Rapstone Valley. His politics are impeccably right-wing, his wealth vast, his power seemingly secure. When we first meet him in ''Titmuss Regained,'' he has achieved ''all but two of his ambitions.''
''He had reached high office in a government which had ruled the country for so long that most young people could not remember another. And he had survived some temporary embarrassments, such as the death of his wife in the anti-nuclear protest at Worsfield Heath, to become a national figure. He was respected, enjoyed, if not liked, as a sardonic wit, a card, a man who gave honest utterance to the feelings of all ordinary citizens and who didn't give a damn for what the liberal intellectuals thought of him.''
Titmuss's two remaining ambitions are to become Prime Minister and to make a brilliant second marriage -''he wanted a wife who would make him the envy of his few friends and, more satisfactorily, his many enemies.'' The first, even the arrogant Titmuss concedes, is probably beyond him. The second he sets about accomplishing with somber dispatch. The object of Titmuss's marital campaign is one Jenny Sidonia, the beautiful widow of a highly respected Oxford don.
Central to Titmuss's efforts to woo Jenny is Rapstone Manor, an impressive country house that looks out upon acres of gardens and woodlands. Titmuss has already gone to rather extraordinary lengths to acquire this mansion, and it now appears that he will have to go even further to hang on to it. If the Fallowfield developers have their way, the mansion will soon be surrounded by expressways and malls. Titmuss has the power to block the developers, but it's not so easy for him simply to veto their proposal. After all, as a gung-ho conservative who has made his reputation praising the virtues of the free-market economy and denouncing rich socialists with converted farmhouses, he can't just reverse himself and take the side of the conservationists. To do so would be to open himself to charges of hypocrisy and conflict of interest.
To prevent the Fallowfield development and hold on to his reputation for fairness, Titmuss comes up with a complicated plan involving blackmail, political gamesmanship and dealings with some unlikely allies. Those allies include Fred Simcox, a left-wing doctor who has developed a crush of his own on Jenny; Dot Curdle, a loud-mouthed rabbit farmer whose livelihood is threatened by the development plan, and Hector Bolitho Jones, the warden of the Rapstone Nature Area and an ardent environmentalist pledged to fighting anything that might endanger ''rain forests, the black rhino, badgers, otters.''
Many of the subsequent developments in ''Titmuss Regained'' seem contrived, silly, even downright preposterous. Subplots bloom and wither; digressions proliferate to no apparent purpose; loose ends go untied. Oddly enough, none of these problems really seem to matter. In the course of relating his meandering story, Mr. Mortimer creates so many amusing characters, dispenses so many funny apercus that the reader quickly forgets the novel's slap-dash plot and remembers only its charms.

HEADLINE: Weak Effort to Aid Yen;
The Group of Seven Shows Less Urgency When the Dollar Is Not Directly Involved

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The United States and its allies in the Group of Seven industrial nations are making only a modest defense of the weakened Japanese yen, and this means the effort may have little impact.
The problem of the yen was of far less concern to the Group of Seven than a similar problem with the dollar would be, so there was no consensus for bolder action. The move that would have a real impact is a change in interest rates, but the Group of Seven is unlikely to do that. Consequently, there was little the officials could have done other than issue a communique and back it up with some modest dollar-selling around the world yesterday. 
All these factors make this venture, announced in Paris on Saturday, riskier than usual for the Group of Seven. But taking no action at all could have been even worse, both for the yen and the credibility of the group. Still, no matter what the Group of Seven does, the main responsibility for supporting the yen remains with Japan.
Dollar-selling yesterday by the Group of Seven, which consists of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, had little impact by the time trading ended in New York. The yen had strengthened in Tokyo to 155.70 to the dollar, partly because the newspapers in Japan took an optimistic view of the Paris developments, with headlines promising ''concerted'' intervention.
But in late trading in New York the yen had slipped to 158.34 yen to the dollar, leaving it weaker than Friday's 157.70. At midday today in Tokyo, the yen was trading slightly above 158 to the dollar.
What makes this move by the Group of Seven different and more difficult than in the past is that the dollar, for the first time since 1985, is not the central problem.
Because the problem is with the yen, some countries in the group, especially the United States and West Germany, are not being harmed enough to worry or to take action to support the yen. The West Germans would prefer that their currency get even stronger to help them ease the inflationary pressures arising from the economic union of the two Germanys. As for the United States, a weaker dollar would add to its inflationary pressures.
Concerns about the weak yen have also been reduced by the fact that the Tokyo stock market, off sharply this year in part because of the weak yen, has yet to pull the rest of the world's markets down with it. In fact the recent activity on the Tokyo exchange might calm people even more: the Nikkei index jumped 1,029 points on Friday, and yesterday it added another 1,119. At the end of today's morning session in Tokyo, the Nikkei had given back some of those gains, showing a loss of 349.07 points, to 30,048.86.
All in all, there is no expectation that the central bank intervention will be followed by interest rate cuts in West Germany and the United States to shore up the yen. Such rate cuts would aid the yen by making the dollar and the mark less attractive to investors.
 
Signs of Reluctance
''Its clear to me that no other Group of Seven member is willing to alter its policy to help support the yen,'' said John Lipsky, director of international bond trading at Salomon Brothers in London. But he said the meeting's outcome would have been worse had the finance ministers and central bank presidents not expressed their concern about the weak yen and not followed that communique with market intervention.
''To have remained silent on the yen would have been a virtual invitation for a speculative attack on the yen,'' he said, ''and would have been interpreted as a failure of the Group of Seven.''
Stephen King, an international economist at James Capel Inc. in London, said: ''The stakes or benefits of cooperation are a little lower than they were. I'm afraid it's still a case of waiting for the Bank of Japan to raise the discount rate. There is a bit of sympathy from the Group of Seven, but nothing more.''
 
Action at Previous Meeting
In September, the last time the group met and made a major move in the foreign exchange market, the situation was different. The issue then was the dollar's strength against the yen, the mark and other major currencies. That situation did produce a response, because everybody needed help.
A communique issued in Washington said the dollar was too high. After that, there was repeated dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan, the Federal Reserve and European central banks. In addition, the monetary authorities in West Germany and Japan raised their key interest rates in October. And the dollar fell. If the latest Group of Seven effort manages to stall, even temporarily, the decline of the yen - and the drop in the Japanese bond and stock markets - there might be enough time for the Japanese Government and the Bank of Japan to bury their disputes and act together to calm their markets, most likely by raising interest rates again. If that happens, then the Group of Seven action, in hindsight, will look effective.
But if the yen continues to decline and the world's other stock markets begin to feel the impact of a further decline in Tokyo, then the Group of Seven may have to consider more forceful action when it meets again in May in Washington.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MCI to Acquire Telecom USA

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest provider of long-distance telephone services, announced a $1.25 billion agreement yesterday to buy Telecom USA Inc., the No. 4 company.
The deal is the latest and largest in a series of acquisitions by MCI, which has reported sharply higher profits in each of the last three years and is seeking to expand its 12 percent share of the nation's $52 billion long-distance market.
Bert C. Roberts Jr., president and chief operating officer of MCI, said yesterday that the $42-a-share price was not excessive and reflected estimates by MCI and its financial adviser, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, of the potential for cutting costs and raising revenues. The acquisition will dilute MCI's earnings for a year but add to profits after that, he said. 
 
Fiber-Optic Links
Telecom, based in Atlanta, has 3,000 miles of high-quality fiber-optic cable in the Midwest and Southeast, half of it linking communities where MCI has no such cables, Mr. Roberts said. Telecom caters mostly to small and medium-sized businesses, while MCI, based in Washington, has focused on residential and large corporate customers.
The transaction represents further consolidation in the dwindling ranks of regional long-distance companies.
Telesphere Communications Inc. announced two weeks ago that it would pay $75 million for National Telephone Services Inc., creating the nation's sixth-largest long-distance company. Of the 10 biggest long-distance providers, five mostly regional companies, including Telecom itself, are products of mergers since mid-1987.
Economists and Wall Street analysts say it is difficult to determine the effect of such mergers on competition and prices. The combined companies are better able to compete with the giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but the mergers reduce the number of competitors and make it harder for large corporations to break into the industry by buying a small company and investing heavily in it.
Telecom's shares posted the largest increase in percentage terms of any stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, soaring $16.25, to close at $38.125, a gain of 74.3 percent. Telecom also led a rally in long-distance telephone stocks.
But MCI fell $1.125 a share, to $35.75, in over-the-counter trading, amid concerns that its earnings would be diluted. ''They're paying a pretty rich price compared to the current stock price,'' said Jack B. Grubman, a telecommunications analyst at Paine Webber Inc.
The boards of both MCI and Telecom have approved the agreement, which is subject to approval by Telecom's shareholders, the Federal Communications Commission, the Justice Department and several state regulatory agencies.
In part, the acquisition is a response to recent steps by the F.C.C. to loosen regulations on A.T.& T., said Mr. Roberts, who added that the transaction creates ''a single, stronger competitor.''
But the Competitive Telecommunications Association, a Washington trade group that represents Telecom and other regional companies, said the deal would reduce competition. ''It tends to support our concern that consolidation of the industry could lead to oligopoly,'' said James M. Smith, the group's president.
Telecom, which has 5,000 employees, had revenues last year of $713 million. MCI, with 19,500 employees, had 1989 revenues of $6.5 billion.
 
Other Deals Are Likely
The takeover agreement announced yesterday may not be the last among the regional providers, analysts and industry executives said. Although MCI is not in discussions with any other regional telephone company, Mr. Roberts said, it will be looking for further strategic acquisitions in the next five or six years.
MCI was begun in 1963 as Microwave Communications Inc. In the last seven years, it has bought two international telephone businesses and a satellite-based domestic system.
Also in the market for long-distance companies is Francesco Galesi, a New York-based builder of shopping centers who has acquired half of Telesphere and a quarter of Advanced Telecommunications, the No. 7 long-distance company.
''I do think there's going to be more consolidation in the industry,'' Mr. Galesi said in a telephone interview yesterday from his horse farm in Jamaica. ''I hope to be a person who will be instrumental in doing that.''
The premium price for Telecom reflects the industry's large economies of scale. Costs reflect mostly the initial installation of equipment and not the volume of calls.
Regional long-distance companies are having trouble winning and retaining large business clients, which increasingly seek to buy all telecommunications services at discount rates from one or two large companies, said Howard M. Anderson, the president of the Yankee Group, a consulting firm in Boston.
Both Mr. Roberts and Herb Linnen, an A.T.& T spokesman, said the deal would intensify competition.
But Eli Noam, an economist at the Columbia Business School and a member of the New York Public Service Commission, said the effect on competition was unclear. While strengthening MCI would provide more competition to A.T.& T., the acquisition may also indicate that medium-sized companies are being bought up before they can grow into national competitors, he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 4.95 in 2d-Slowest Day of Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rose slightly yesterday, and trading slowed to its second-lowest level of the year.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 4.95 points, to 2,722.07, and volume fell to 114.97 million shares,from 137.49 million last Friday. On March 12, volume was 114.79 million shares, the lowest point of 1990. Declining stocks outnumbered advances,839 to 652. 
''Most portfolio managers no longer appear to expect a market decline because the market is very quiet,'' said David B. Bostian Jr., the chief investment strategist for Jesup & Lamont. ''But I think of it as the eye of the storm.''
 
'Could Be Vulnerable'
''With the onset of earnings reports soon,'' he said, ''the market could be vulnerable.'' He said he looked for earnings to be weaker than generally expected.
Economic problems in New England, banking problems in general and big merger deals continued to dominate the market. Banks, drugs, food, beverages and telephone stocks gained; gold weakened and computers were mixed.
Ames Department Stores, which has had difficulty turning around its Zayre stores, headed the New York Stock Exchange's most-active list, falling 1/4, to 3 1/4, on 4.14 million shares. Institutions accounted for most of the selling. Ames said last week that sales in March fell 12 percent.
Telecom rose 16 1/4, to 41 7/8, the second-most-active Big Board stock, on 3.56 million shares. It announced with MCI that the telecommunications companies had agreed to merge in a deal in which MCI paid $42 a share for Telecom. MCI headed the over-the-counter active list, falling 1 1/8, to 35 3/4, on 3.4 million shares.
Among other telecommunications stocks, United Telecom rose 1 3/8, to 39 3/4, and Rochester Telephone rose 1 1/8, to 36 7/8.
 
Banks Show Strength
Among the bank stocks, Citicorp rose 3/4, to 23 5/8; BankAmerica rose 7/8, to 26 3/8, and Norwest of Minneapolis fell 1/4, to 18 3/8, all in heavy trading. the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, rose 1 3/8, to 33 3/8, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, rose 1 3/8, to 66 5/8.
After weakness last week, Charles W. Peabody, a banking analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, recommended BankAmerica, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, Mellon, Norwest, J. P. Morgan, Suntrust and First City of Texas.
Chase rose 1/2, to 28 1/2; Manufacturers rose 5/8, to 31 5/8; Mellon rose 7/8, to 25; Morgan rose 1 1/8, to 35 3/4; Suntrust rose 3/8, to 21 1/2, and First City rose 1/2, to 32 1/2, all in brisk trading.
Near the start of trading, the market seemed to respond for a time to the stronger tone of Japanese stocks. But by 11 A.M., after advancing by about 12 points, the Dow industrials drifted for the rest of the session.
Except for Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola, none of the stocks among the Dow Jones industrials rose by as much as a point. P.& G. rose 1 1/8, to 69 3/4, on 391,000 shares. Coca-Cola rose 1 3/8, to 79 1/4, on 475,000 shares. I.B.M., one of the more closely watched industrials, fell 3/8, to 105 1/2.
Pepsico, which is not a part of the Dow industrials, rose 1 1/2, to 66 1/2, on 775,000 shares, after it announced a barter deal to swap more than $3 billion of the soft drink for Soviet ships and vodka.
The Dow Jones transportation index fell 3.03 points, to 1,171.05, with UAL continuing to account for most of the change in either direction. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 2 1/2, to 161, in strong trading as uncertainties persisted over its unions' plans to buy the carrier.
 
Food Shares Gain
Food shares were strong, with Kellogg up 1 1/2, to 63 5/8; CPC International up 1 1/8, to 70 7/8; Hershey up 1, to 33 5/8, and Quaker Oats up 1 1/4, to 50 3/4.
Among individual stocks, the Tribune Company rose 1 7/8, to 43 1/2, after it announced a 10-year cooperative production deal for six Tribune television stations, including WPIX in New York, KTLA in Los Angeles and WGN in Chicago, to join the CNN.
In another sign of nervousness over earnings, Network Equipment, a maker of communications products, fell 5 3/4, to 15 1/8, in heavy trading. After saying last week that it expected a disappointing fourth quarter, it said yesterday that it expected revenues for the fourth quarter ended March 31 to total about $44 million.
Other market indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 1.29, to 341.37; the Amex market-value index fell 1.33, to 359.68, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.72, to 430.18.

HEADLINE: Bailout Cost Rise Is Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The Bush Administration conceded today that the bailout of the savings and loan industry would cost taxpayers more than previously estimated.
''There's no question that the cost is increasing, and we'll have to take that into account in deciding future actions,'' the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said. 
He responded to a report on Friday by the General Accounting Office, the investigatory arm of Congress, that the 10-year cost of the program would be $243 billion instead of the $166 billion estimated by the Administration. The General Accounting Office said the 30-year cost of the program would be $325 billion to $500 billion, depending on the country's economic performance.
''We don't have an analysis either to endorse or reject the G.A.O. numbers, except to say there clearly are going to be additional costs,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
Mr. Fitzwater rejected as ''total nonsense'' the contention by Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General and head of the General Accounting Office, that the Administration had deliberately understated the cost of the bailout.
Mr. Bowsher, interviewed on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC, said Sunday that the Bush Administration had set an artifically low cost on the bailout to let the Government appear to meet deficit-reduction targets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Report on OPEC Production Sends Oil Prices Skidding

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Crude oil prices plunged yesterday, largely on a report that OPEC's production had soared to its highest level since 1981. Global demand for oil has also been declining because of the uncommonly mild winter in the Northern Hemisphere as well as softening in the economies of industrial countries.
At the close of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest energy market, the spot contract for West Texas intermediate-grade crude oil, for delivery in May, plunged 71 cents a barrel, to $18.44. That was the lowest level for a spot, or near-term, contract since last August. 
The exchange's spot contract for unleaded gasoline dropped 1.22 cents a gallon, to 60.89 cents, and heating oil for delivery in May declined 0.64 cent a gallon, to 53.07 cents. But the exchange's lively new natural gas contract, which began trading last Tuesday, rose 0.012 cent, to $1.637 per 10 million British thermal units.
''The industry knew that some OPEC members were exceeding their output quotas,'' said Peter C. Beutel, energy specialist at Elders Futures Inc., ''but when the Middle East Economic Survey reported that the group as a whole was pumping over 24 million barrels a day, which puts it at a nine-year high, the news hit the market hard.''
While the total reported output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was about a million barrels above the levels of a year ago, demand has fallen. Mr. Beutel noted that domestic demand for heating oil in the first quarter of 1990 dropped 8.5 percent, largely because the winter was unusually warm.
Domestic consumption of unleaded gasoline fell 1.2 percent in the first quarter. For all of 1989, gasoline use fell four-tenths of a percent, the first decline since 1982, a recession year.
Bradford H. Hughes, energy analyst at Cargill Investor Services, noted that the rising flow of OPEC oil was taxing storage capacity in the United States and Europe ''and undoubtedly depressing prices.''
The mild winter also encouraged refiners to switch production to gasoline from heating oil earlier than they otherwise would have done. This has resulted in an oversupply of gasoline and has weakened prices.
Mr. Hughes noted more pessimistic news: the postponement of a planned strike by Soviet oilfield workers in Siberia. The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, and its exports account for an estimated 80 percent of its foreign earnings.
Mercantile Exchange traders also reacted negatively to some technical news from London. They often use London energy contracts to hedge their domestic positions, but the price of London's April heating oil contract, which expires today, is an usually large $10 a ton above the contract for May delivery. Should the expiration in London of the April contract cause the price for May delivery to plunge, it could unravel many hedges on the New York exchange.

HEADLINE: Chip Index Shows Gains

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed continued strength in March, as United States semiconductor orders and shipments increased, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.09 for the three-month period ended in March, up from 1.05 in February and a revised figure of 1.06 in January. 
The book-to-bill compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1.09 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $109 was ordered, a sign of increasing demand.
Orders for the three-month period ended in March were up 5.4 percent, at $1.27 billion, from $1.20 billion for the period ended in February and slightly higher than the figure posted a year ago, which was $1.26 billion.
Three-month average shipments for March totaled $1.16 billion, up from February's $1.14 billion. At $1.30 billion, United States market shipments for March were 15.2 percent higher than February's $1.13 billion.

HEADLINE: Japan Keeps Up the Big Spending To Maintain Its Industrial Might

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIMITSU, Japan

 BODY:
At a time when some Americans are worrying about how much Japan is investing to buy real estate and companies from New York to Honolulu, the bigger concern for the United States may be how much Japan is continuing to invest on its industrial prowess at home.
Even after some turbulent months for the Japanese economy, the nation is expected to far outpace the United States this year in spending for new plants, equipment, research and development. This will be the fourth year in a row such a gap has existed.
While some of the investment is going into consumer products long associated with Japan, like advanced televisions, video cameras and computer chips, much of it is headed into industries that only a few years ago looked dead, like steel and shipbuilding.
 
'Laboratory for the World'
''It's a bit scary,'' said Kenneth S. Courtis, the senior economist of Deutsche Bank's capital markets operation in Tokyo. ''The United States usually spends to add capacity; Japan's investments are driven by a strategy to fundamentally reposition industry. A third of it is going into productivity; a third of it is going into innovation, new products. What we are seeing is Japan becoming the new-product laboratory for the world.'' 
The Japanese economy is about 60 percent the size of the American economy. Yet Mr. Courtis estimated that Japan last year invested more than $750 billion, or about 24 percent of its gross national product, in this kind of spending, known as capital investment. The United States spent more than $500 billion, or about 10 percent of G.N.P.
The rate of increase in that spending will probably slow somewhat this year in Japan because of the stock market plunge in Tokyo and growing fears that Japan's economic boom may be weakening. But interviews with executives of leading Japanese companies suggest that they still plan to spend heavily.
The evidence of investment even in old-line industries is dramatic in places like Japan's largest steel plant, situated in this town of 90,000 people across the bay from Tokyo. A few years ago the belching smokestacks were a symbol of the kind of inefficient heavy industry that the Government was committed to paring down in the face of heavy competition from South Korea.
But today, after hundreds of millions of dollars of investment and a program to retire or retrain excess workers, the Nippon Steel Corporation's giant Kimitsu Works has caught up with its lower-cost Korean competition, and 13,000 workers keep Kimitsu running at close to capacity. The company is planning to invest $1.1 billion this year to automate Kimitsu and several other plants yet again, an expenditure few of its American rivals could even think of making.
''Cutting back investment in new products and new technology is not a good way to economize,'' said Koichi Danno, the director of corporate planning for Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, which has helped lead the revival in Japan's machinery and shipbuilding businesses. ''Our attitude is wait and see. We don't want to cut back.''
Other companies say they have built such huge reserves of cash that they can pay for expansion without resorting to the chaotic markets.
 
Maintaining Its Lead
Whether that view is sustained will probably be the true test of the strength of the Japanese economy in coming months. While initial surveys indicate that the growth rate in such investments in Japan will decline, the growth will still be far ahead of that in the United States.
Until 1987 the United States exceeded Japan in capital investment. But after a September 1985 international agreement to weaken the dollar, thus strengthening the yen and making Japanese goods more expensive abroad, Japanese companies mounted a large and expensive effort to automate factories and cut their work forces.
The idea was to remain competitive even if the yen approached 100 to the dollar. But no one expected that the high level of spending would persist or that the yen would weaken as it has in recent months, to nearly 160 to the dollar. International monetary officials met last weekend and expressed concern about the weak yen, but Japanese industry is quietly delighted with the situation because exporting is becoming far more profitable than anyone had predicted.
 
The Benefits of Low Rates
The large growth in capital spending in Japan cost less than it would have in the United States because of lower interest rates in Japan and a surging Tokyo stock market that made it easier to raise money. Now as interest rates have risen and Japan's stock market declines, some smaller companies have begun to pull back on capital investments.
But most large companies that have built huge cash reserves are not yet making significant cuts, although there are signs of nervousness. The Sony Corporation, for example, is said to be scaling back its capital spending plan for this year, though its investments would still rise modestly from last year's high levels.
Japan's capital investments are most remarkable in industries that lack the high-tech gloss of consumer electronics, computers and biotechnology. In Nagasaki, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is finishing a new luxury cruise ship, one of several under construction in the country. And in machinery and other heavy equipment, once slow-growing industries, Japan's expansion overseas has created record demand for giant lathes, metal-pressing machines and other equipment used to produce everything from picture tubes to auto parts in Japanese-owned factories in Asia and the United States.
 
Big Demand for Robots
Japan's leading robot maker, Fanuc Ltd., can barely meet demand for its machines, which are crucial to efforts to automate manufacturing operations and make up for a huge labor shortage in this country.
For some older industries, new technologies have brought new vigor. Makers of railroad cars recently put on display in the middle of Tokyo Station a prototype of Japan's first linear motor car, a high-speed alternative to the ''bullet trains.'' The linear cars are elevated above the track and are propelled by magnetic force. The display was a reminder that 25 years after beginning bullet train service, Japan is ready to spend heavily to build faster, quieter trains.
In part the revival of Japan's heavy industries is being pushed by an unlikely ally, the United States. American trade negotiators have been pressing Japan to speed up its intensive program of public works projects, rebuilding airports and highways and erecting new government buildings.
The American hope is that some of the work will be awarded to construction companies, architects and other specialists from the United States. But the biggest beneficiaries are Japanese companies.
 
Some Favored Stocks
Already, some investors are accumulating Japanese ''S.I.I. stocks,'' named for the ''structural impediments initiative'' round of talks aimed at changing the way the American and Japanese economies interact. Among the hottest investment choices are Japanese makers of sewer pipes and concrete.
What worries some Americans here is not the investment in public works but the sustained level of investment in private industry. The Japanese Government has occasionally frowned upon big increases in capital spending because they threaten to increase Japan's trade surplus, but such expressions of displeasure have had little effect.
Recently, for example, the Government lost a telling face-off against the Toyota Motor Company, Japan's biggest auto maker. Toyota was eager to expand its manufacturing capacity because the car market in Japan continues to boom. The Government is concerned that such expansions ''could be a disaster,'' a senior official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said recently. The ministry's fear is that the domestic Japanese car market could cool, tempting manufacturers to ship more cars abroad, which would add immensely to the trade imbalances. Nevertheless, Toyota said its capital investment would rise 25 percent.
 
Plans for Steelmakers
In the case of the steel industry, the recovery did not happen exactly the way the Government planned.
The goal was to reduce Japan's steel capacity, while pushing companies into new businesses that would provide jobs for the displaced workers. The first half of the strategy worked. By the end of this year Japan's biggest steelmakers will have closed 34 blast furnaces and trimmed their work force by 50,000 workers.
But the second part of the plan called for pushing Japan's heavy industries into new high-tech businesses. One after another they rushed into difficult-to-master tasks like developing gallium arsenide computer chips, biotechnology products, artificial intelligence programs and advanced computer technologies. So far the results are mixed at best.
Nippon Steel, for example, opened and then quickly closed a mail-order business. It also shut an international business communications center. Ventures in electronics, specialty materials and biotechnology are growing, but slowly; last year they accounted for 4 percent of the company's revenues. Nippon Steel says that will rise to 14 percent in 1993.
Later this month the company will go even farther afield, opening Space World, a theme park on the site of a remote plant that was closed.
What has saved the steel industry is something no one expected: the return of steel.
With huge investments in automation, the Kimitsu Works here reduced the cost of its hot coil steel to less than $400 a ton, making it competitive with that of Pohang Iron and Steel, the Korean giant. ''We've become one of the world's lowest-cost producers,'' said Bunichiro Kawasaki, the general superintendent of Kimitsu Works. ''But it took a long time and much money.''

HEADLINE: Pilsen Journal;
G.I.'s or Russians? Time to Show the Snapshots

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PILSEN, Czechoslovakia, April 7

 BODY:
With lots of American flags and the beer that made this Bohemian city famous, Pilsen is cheerfully preparing to celebrate a truth that it holds dear but has rarely been able to tell. The last time was 22 years ago, during the brief spring of freedom in 1968.
What Pilsen had to keep secret is that 45 years ago it was the United States Army that liberated it from six years of German occupation. So intent were the Communists who ruled Czechoslovakia from 1948 until last autumn to be servile to the Soviet Union that they covered this fact to create the fiction that the Red Army freed all of Czechoslovakia. 
The liberation of Czechoslovakia east of here, and of all the lands east of here, was, of course, the work of the Red Army.
 
A Day for the Truth
But Anoa Hostickova, a municipal architect who grew up in Prague, said she thought a movie was being shot when in 1968 she saw people marching through the city with American flags. It was only when she mentioned this at work the next day that she learned that on May 5 and 6, 1945, two divisions under the command of Gen. George S. Patton Jr. drove the German Army from the city.
Jaroslav Rezac, a teacher of history and Czech literature, said textbooks gave the Soviet Union all the credit for Czechoslovakia's liberation and never mentioned the United States. He recalled that when he worked as a student guide at an exhibition in 1973 he told a class of schoolchildren that a photo giving the impression that Soviet troops drove the Germans from Pilsen was a misrepresentation. The teacher turned him in, and he was censured by his dean for telling the truth.
''They tried to erase history and create new history,'' said Vaclav Zeman, a lawyer. ''Teachers taught children that it was Russian soldiers in American uniforms who liberated us.''
This May 6, the truth will have its day in what is planned to be a great popular feast. President Vaclav Havel is expected to come to give credit where it is due, and Ambassador Shirley Temple Black will be there to receive it for the 16th Armored Division and the Second Infantry Division. #30 Vintage Jeeps Mr. Zeman, a member of the preparatory committee, which is part of the Civic Forum, the movement that under Mr. Havel's leadership overthrew Communist rule, said he had booked every room in the largest hotel to accommodate the many veterans of the two divisions who plan to come. After a reception at City Hall, all guests will repair to the brewery for lunch.
About 30 surplus jeeps, which the American Army sold to the Czechoslovaks before it withdrew at the end of 1945, are being put into running order to meet Mrs. Black at the former demarcation line between the American and Soviet occupation zones and escort her car to town. They will fly American flags and be driven by men wearing pieces of American uniforms that Pilsen people have kept as souvenirs.
In a rare display of cooperation between armies of the opposing alliances, a Czechoslovak contingent is to march to the music of an American Army band that is expected from West Germany, Mr. Zeman said. Negotiations are under way with an Austrian military museum to exchange an old Czechoslovak tank for a World War II American Sherman that Mr. Zeman's committee would like to make the centerpiece of an exhibition of liberation memorabilia.
A memorial to the Second Division will be put up, and the foundation stone laid for one for the 16th Armored.
Pilsen was forced to abandon the truth when the Communists seized power in 1948. A pedestal for a monument had been installed shortly after the liberation. During the three years in which Czechoslovakia enjoyed democratic government, the American liberation was duly celebrated.
On the first anniversary after the Communist coup, the pedestal, on a grassy island at a busy intersection, was the center of several days of implicitly anti-Communist demonstrations, as citizens came bearing American flags, flowers and candles, which the police removed overnight.
 
Lapels With American Flags
In later years, as anniversary tributes continued, first the base was removed, and when tributes continued at its former site, the traffic island also disappeared. Money that had been donated by citizens to commission the monument was sent by the Communist Government to North Korea during the war there.
Jaroslav Rezac Sr., the teacher's father and himself a teacher of English who was a volunteer interpreter for the Army, apologized for his moist eyes as he recalled the brief return of the truth in 1968. ''It was extraordinarily beautiful for us to hear the American anthem again,'' he said.
Many a lapel here carries pins bearing the American flag or the insignia of the two divisions, the product of enterprising citizens taking advantage of the occasion and the freeing of the once rigidly state-run economy. A local printer has run off stacks of American flags on paper, and cloth flags are expected any day.
 
'We Will Never Forget!'
A poster shows the two national flags (48 stars in the American one) and a photo of two G.I.'s on a tank in front of Pilsen Cathedral. In both languages there is an inscription, ''We Will Never Forget Boys!''
As late as last year, said Frantisek Rezac, a leader in a new, independent labor union who is not related to the teachers, several people were briefly detained on May 6 when they spoke at a forbidden meeting at a monument commemorating victims of the Nazis, and thanked Pilsen's real liberators.
''This is why this year it will be a popular festival,'' the union leader said. ''The lying about who liberated us meant one thing to the people here. The Communists took us for stupid.''

GRAPHIC: photo: When American troops liberated Pilsen, Czechoslovakia, in World War II, Pfc. Benjamin V. Bednarz handed out chewing gum to the children. Mr. Bednarz, who lives in River Edge, N.J., said recent events have laid to rest his fear that the children thought he had duped them. After the Communists consolidated power in 1948, children were taught in school that Pilsen was liberated by Russians in American uniforms. (U.S. Army); map: Pilsen, Czech.
