HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
The News of Lithuania, But With Kremlin Spin

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 10

 BODY:
When it comes to reporting on the situation in Lithuania, Soviet news organizations have reverted to the one-sided, polemical style of the pre-glasnost era.
Some intellectuals who have benefited from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's encouragement of greater openness now fear that it may be taken away from them under the pressures of ethnic separatism and economic decline.
As an example, such critics point to the nationwide evening television news program ''Vremya,'' which has been bending over backward to cover the opposition to the independence movement in Lithuania, where the newly elected Parliament, led by President Vytautas Landsbergis, proclaimed sovereignty on March 11.
''They're not reporting,'' a Russian philosophy professor said as the program began on Saturday night. ''They're preaching at us.'' Report on Vilnius Rally After showing scenes from a pro-independence rally in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, that was said to have attracted 300,000 people, the ''Vremya'' correspondent, Aleksandr Barkhatov, briefly interviewed a demonstrator who said he did not feel that there could be freedom in Lithuania without full independence. Mr. Barkhatov said Soviet Army loudspeaker trucks and a helicopter that dropped leaflets on the crowd were the only attempts to provide an opposing point of view, and he read the contents of one of the leaflets before the camera. 
Then followed a three-minute interview with the deputy director of the Committee of Citizens of the U.S.S.R. in Lithuania, Gennadi S. Tarasov, who complained that while Mr. Landsbergis said he wanted a calm and reasoned dialogue with the Soviet authorities, the new Lithuanian Government would require residents to sign loyalty oaths to get identity cards. ''I won't sign this, but I'm staying,'' he said. ''I'll be a second-class citizen.''
Eduard M. Sagalayev, chief editor of Soviet television's news programs, said in an interview Monday that he recognized that ''Vremya'' did not give a balanced picture. ''We'd like it to be, but there is pressure from the Government, from the military, from the Communist Party Central Committee,'' he said. ''Not from the President, but now that things have calmed down perhaps the pressure will ease and we can be more objective.''
 
No Formal Censorship
He said that there was no formal censorship, something that a new law on the press being discussed by the Supreme Soviet in Moscow this week will ban, and off-beat news shows like the weekly ''Vzglyad'' program sometime take a tack quite different from ''Vremya.'' But the ''pressure'' apparently affects others as well.
The official Soviet press agency Tass, reporting from Vilnius on Saturday about a Lithuanian proclamation encouraging young people to refuse the Soviet draft on May 4, clearly took sides against resisting induction.
Tass said many families of future draftees had been ''at a loss'' to understand the proclamation. ''One cannot but take into consideration the fact that many republican newspapers, radio and television are going hand in hand with the Sajudis leaders and are giving one-sided coverage of events in Lithuania,'' it said.
Last week, the television news coverage from Vilnius, from which foreign correspondents are now barred by the Soviet authorities, consisted largely of strikes by ethnic Russians opposed to Lithuanian independence. Lithuanian spokesmen said that participation in the protests was low and that they had little effect on the situation.
In the 1979 census, the latest for which data are available, 80 percent of Lithuania's 3.39 million people were ethnic Lithuanians. Russians were the second largest ethnic group, with 8.9 percent of the population, and Poles were next with 7.3 percent.
 
Letters in Pravda
Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, has been running letters from citizens elsewhere in the country expressing concern about Lithuania's moves toward independence.
Today Pravda ran an unusually long dispatch, billed as a ''subjective'' report, by its correspondent Yuri Shabanov. It sensitively described the feelings of ostracism an ethnic Russian reporter experienced in a republic bent on throwing off the Russian yoke, but concluded that Sajudis was dictating anti-Soviet positions to the Lithuanian Parliament and that Mr. Landsbergis was trying to dictate to Moscow, too.
Yuri Bandura wrote in Moscow News, one of the few newspapers independent of Government or Communist Party control in Moscow: ''Official Moscow reports on the Lithuanian situation generally have a dry, tough and exacting tone,'' That newspaper, too, was critical of the way Mr. Landsbergis and his Lithuanian Government have handled the situation, with a series of what it described as unilateral ultimatums to Moscow.
Tankred Golenpolsky, editor of a new independent publication, the Newsletter of European Soviet Culture, said ''independence'' in the press here was still a relative thing.
''Where do you think the printing presses are?'' he said. ''Where does the newsprint come from?'' His newsletter is printed on the presses of Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper.
In Vilnius, Soviet armed forces seized the printing plant where the main Lithuanian independence newspapers are printed more than a week ago, but so far have not stopped them from coming out.
 
Editor's Ouster Stopped
In a case of attempted interference on the national level last year, Mr. Gorbachev tried to dismiss the editor of the country's most popular critical journal, Argumenty i Fakty. But buoyed by support from his staff, the editor, Vladislav A. Starkov, stood fast.
As the Communist Party newspaper, Pravda has no such claim to independence, and a resolution published in it on Saturday made clear that the party's view of what the role of the press should be had not really changed since Lenin's day. Pravda should support the party line by printing the truth and only the truth, it said, and help to make it the avant-garde of Soviet society -something prescribed by law in the Soviet Constitution until the party decided in February to relinquish the right to be the country's leading force.
Specifically, the resolution said, Pravda should report the news in a way that increased support for Mr. Gorbachev's policies of restructuring the economy. Pravda's longtime chief editor, Viktor G. Afanasyev, was replaced last October by Ivan T. Frolov, an aide to Mr. Gorbachev.
The resolution said that all the country's news organizations should lead an active fight against ''nationalism and chauvinism in all its forms,'' meaning, in the narrow sense, the kind of nationalism that led Lithuania to proclaim its independence.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 788 words

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Mattingly: Yankees' Last Tradition

BYLINE: By Dave Anderson

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
On the morning after signing a $19 million contract, somebody else might have awakened with a champagne hangover. Or fluffed the pillow and slept until noon. But if you're wondering why Don Mattingly deserves to be baseball's highest paid player and why all that money isn't likely to change him, consider the guest book near the weight machines and stationary bicycles in the health club of Stouffer Tower City Plaza hotel where the Yankees are lodged.
Just as the Yankees' opener last night with the Indians was postponed because of rain, 10 names were in the guest book. Nine were unfamiliar, probably those of traveling businessman. On the second line, in black ink, was ''Mattingly.'' 
If any of the other Yankees had worked out, none had signed the guest book. But after the announcement of his five-year, $19.3 million deal that begins in 1991 and averages $3.8 million a season, the Yankee first baseman had dutifully perspired. You'd think he was down to his last $2.5 million - his salary this season.
In the only Yankee tradition that George Steinbrenner has been able to maintain, Mattingly joined Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle, Jim (Catfish) Hunter, Reggie Jackson and Dave Winfield as baseball's highest paid player. At least until Jose Canseco or Bo Jackson gets a better deal.
With a .323 career average after having batted over .300 in each of his six full seasons, with 164 homers and 717 runs batted in, although he won't turn 29 years old until April 20, and with a threat to test the free-agent market, Mattingly had backed George Steinbrenner against the vault. And the principal owner opened it. ''Don Mattingly,'' the principal owner said humbly, ''will attract people to come and see my ball club play.''
For now it's still Steinbrenner's ball club, pending the outcome of Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation of the principal owner's dealings with Howard Spira, an indicted extortionist and self-described gambler, in obtaining information to discredit Winfield's foundation.
Too bad the Babe and Joe D and Mickey weren't in pinstripes when George had the key to the vault. Then again, maybe they were better off. Imagine if George operated in the take-it-or-pump-gas era before free agency and not-so-free inflation.
When cynics questioned the Babe in 1930 for signing an $80,000 contract when President Hoover was making $75,000, he replied: ''Why not? I had a better year than he did.''
 
But that was the
Babe's highest salary. He had to argue with Ed Barrow, the steel-fisted general manager, for $75,000 in 1932, for $52,000 in 1933, and for $35,000 in 1934 before being traded to the Boston Braves.
When DiMaggio demanded $40,000 for 1938, his third season, Barrow reminded him that Lou Gehrig was making $43,000 after 13 years.
''In that case, Mr. Barrrow,'' DiMaggio said in those years long before agents, ''Mr. Gehrig is a very underpaid ballplayer.''
DiMaggio accepted $25,000 that year, but by 1949 he emerged as baseball's first $100,000 player, thanks to Toots Shor, then New York's most celebrated saloon keeper. DiMaggio was offered $85,000 plus an attendance bonus, but Shor advised him to go for $100,000 without a bonus. ''Be the first to make $100,000,'' Shor said. Dan Topping, then a co-owner with Del Webb, agreed to the $100,000 salary, but Webb demurred.
''I'm not going higher than $90,000 with the attendance bonus,'' Webb told Shor.
''Del,'' said Shor, ''ain't it worth another $10,000 to get your picture in all the papers with baseball's first $100,000 player?''
Webb's picture soon was in all the papers at a time when there were few television sets.
Mantle, who was rewarded with only $35,000 for his Triple Crown in 1956, finally made $100,000 in 1963, but baseball salaries didn't soar until Catfish Hunter suddenly became a free agent because of a missed 1974 bonus payment by Charles O. Finley, then the Oakland Athletics' owner. Hunter took Steinbrenner's offer of a five-year, $3.35 million contract that included insurance policies and attorney fees.
Then Reggie Jackson joined the Yankees in 1977 for $2.66 million over five years. And when Dave Winfield arrived for 1981 he signed a 10-year $23 million deal that outsmarted Steinbrenner who had not considered its compound-interest clause.
Steinbrenner's annoyance at Winfield's contract eventually inspired the prinicipal owner's $40,000 payment to Howard Spira that has inspired the commissioner's investigation. And now Steinbrenner's involvement with Spira has inspired the principal owner, desperate with what might be a desperate team, to open the vault for Don Mattingly.
If money is the root of most investigations, it's also the root of the last Yankee tradition.

HEADLINE: Help the Poor, but Don't Call It Welfare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Yes: Drive Down the Deficit/ No: Don't Punish the Poor'' (editorial, March 18), which opposes deficit reduction at the expense of the poor and advocates increased taxes to improve poverty programs, undercuts its economic and moral argument by stating, ''Americans may not want to help the poor . . . but they surely can afford to.''
The common misperception that Americans do not want their taxes to support programs for the poor has been time and again disproved by well-designed scientific studies. These have found that most Americans oppose any program labeled ''welfare'' but are willing to support any program for the poor not tarred with this term. 
This was widely noted in 1977 in a national poll undertaken for The New York Times and CBS News to provide background information for reporting on the Carter Administration's welfare reform proposal. When asked, ''Do you approve of most Government-sponsored welfare programs?'' 58 percent answered, ''No.'' However, when asked whether they supported specific welfare programs not labeled as such, 82 percent approved of the Government's using their taxes ''to pay for health care for poor people'' (i.e., Medicaid); 81 percent approved of the Government's ''helping poor people buy food for their families at cheaper prices'' (i.e., food stamps), and 81 percent approved of the Government's ''providing financial assistance for children raised in low-income homes where one parent is missing'' (i.e., aid to families with dependent children).
Only 13 percent disapproved of these largest and most expensive programs for the poor, with approval cutting across rich and poor, conservatives and liberals.
In analyzing what the survey called the ''seeming contradiction'' of ''an American public that is deeply antagonistic to the concept of public welfare yet strongly supports what welfare programs do,'' your report concluded:
''The very word 'welfare' raised a kind of social red flag. But once the word is set aside, Americans display a deep compassion for those who are destitute and helpless.''
More than compassion, the poll found most Americans willing to have their tax dollars support programs for the poor.
Those findings may surprise or dismay others, but they are accepted as commonplace by social scientists familiar with similar polls and studies. Some have developed conceptualizations to describe the anti-welfare labels and pro-welfare programs orientation of most Americans. Seymour Lipset speaks of those with such attitudes as ''ideological conservatives'' and ''operational liberals.''
The excuse most often used for not providing adequately for the poor by politicians from the President on down is that the public won't stand for it. Particulary at this time of increasing hunger and homelessness, and decreasing Government assistance to the hungry and homeless, it is important for those demanding that the Government meet its obligations to assist the poor - to know - and to let the politicians know - that the great majority of Americans supports this demand.
 
ALFRED J. KUTZIK
 Brooklyn, March 25, 1990
The writer has served as a consultant to the welfare departments of Maryland and New Jersey.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Why Not a 'Solvency Dividend'?

BYLINE: By James J. Blanchard; James J. Blanchard, a Democrat, is the Governor of Michigan.

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
With all the talk in Washington about a peace dividend, we're in danger of overlooking another kind of windfall, one that's enjoyed by Michigan and other prudently managed states.
I'm talking about a ''solvency dividend,'' the payoff in lower borrowing costs from making the tough choices to balance the budget and keep it balanced year after year.
As we put together our 1990-'91 budget proposal this winter, we took a moment to add up how much our strong financial management (including five credit rating upgrades since 1985 and seven consecutive balanced budgets) has saved the state in reduced borrowing costs. The total surprised even us - $1 billion since 1983, when we faced a $1.7 billion deficit in a $5 billion budget. 
We've taken that $1 billion and invested it in such things as education, economic development, law enforcement and environmental protection. We've increased state aid to elementary schools by 93 percent per pupil since 1983 and established an aggressive preschool program for ''at-risk'' 4-year olds. We have been able to invest in tomorrow's challenges rather than pay off yesterday's debt.
The $1 billion got us thinking. If the Federal budget were balanced - and kept balanced - how much could the country save?
Washington will spend at least $174 billion for interest on the national debt in 1990 - equal to about $1,500 for every taxpayer in America. Roughly 14 percent of the budget goes toward interest payments - into thin air, not clean air. Nor is the money going for education, the war on drugs and crime, housing or any of our nation's other pressing needs.
Total Federal spending on education, the environment, law enforcement, drugs, agriculture and transportation under President Bush's proposed budget doesn't equal interest payments on the national debt.
If there were no Federal debt, each state could receive a Federal solvency dividend. In Michigan, that would equal $7 billion annually, a sum nearly equal to our entire budget. New York would receive $17.5 billion a year. Indeed, if there were a Federal solvency dividend, the fiscal problems faced by many Northeastern states, including New York, would be erased; in fact, 45 states could eliminate all of their taxes.
This may sound farfetched. But it bears pointing out that if Washington had run balanced budgets since 1983, there still would be a solvency dividend to Michigan of about $3.5 billion each year. Since 1983, interest on the Federal deficit has doubled, illustrating the pervasive and spiraling nature of deficit spending.
We cannot afford to squander the opportunity to take the benefits of peace and invest them in the future. We must work for a solvency dividend and the financial freedom it will provide our own nation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: Dinkins Asks U.S. To Halt Development of S.I. Naval Port

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins has asked the United States Defense Department to stop development of the Navy port that has brought one cruiser to Staten Island and may bring several other ships there.
The Mayor sent a letter stating his opposition to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. Although the Dinkins administration's disapproval cannot by itself block the project, it sends a clear signal to Congress, which is already questioning whether it should spend billions of dollars more on new ports.
Ten of the 12 members of the House of Representatives from New York City have already told Mr. Cheney in a letter that the strategic rationale for home ports is no longer compelling, given changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and budgetary constraints. 
 
'No Reasonable Justification'
''At a time when the Navy is closing facilities, reducing its fleet and realigning its forces, there appears to be no reasonable justification for the construction of six new home ports,'' including one at Stapleton, Staten Island, the Congressmen's letter said.
In 1986 Congress authorized $198 million for construction of the Staten Island port, of which nearly $175 million has been spent. The port is 90 percent complete, and the Department of the Navy has requested an additional $20 million, which would bring the center's total cost to $218 million.
Mayor Dinkins's letter is the latest assault on the Staten Island port, which has so far survived lawsuits, strident grass-roots protests and bitter political tussles.
 
At Odds With Cuomo
His request fulfills a campaign promise to oppose further development of the base and puts him at odds with its supporters, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, the former United States Representative who led the fight for the port in Congress.
In his April 6 letter to Mr. Cheney, the Mayor said changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, reductions in the defense budget and concerns about the safety of having ships that might carry nuclear weapons in New York Harbor outweighed arguments for the Staten Island port. He has proposed finding nonmilitary uses for the port. Noting the Navy's decision in January to mothball the battleship Iowa, which was to have been the jewel in the crown of the port, whose full name is Naval Station New York, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I urge you to forgo any steps to replace the Iowa with another battleship or other nuclear-armed vessels and I urge you to act now to cancel the proposed home port on Staten Island.''
There have been no known nuclear accidents involving the kinds of ships that would use the base.
 
Proponents Point to Revenues
A Defense Department spokesman, Lieut. Comdr. Gregg Hartung, said that Secretary Cheney had not yet received Mayor Dinkins's letter and that therefore the department declined to comment.
Proponents of the port called the Mayor's letter irresponsible and questioned how, given New York City's budget deficit, he could reject the $387 million a year that the Navy has estimated the port would generate in revenue for the city.
''When you have a city drowning in red ink, and the Mayor is coming out every day with more and more bad news, this doesn't make sense,'' Mr. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, said. ''I think it's irresponsible on his part, and I wonder how he plans on digging out of the fiscal plight the city is in.''
Mr. Molinari said he would not ask President Bush to intervene, although he has been a consistent supporter of the President. ''It would be improper to ask the Commander in Chief to make a decision like this based on friendship,'' he said.
Opponents of the port said the Navy's estimates of its economic benefits were calculated on the assumption that the battleship Iowa, with its crew of about 1,600 and significant maintenance and repair requirements, would be berthed at the Stapleton base along with a six-ship support fleet. The Navy has designated Stapleton as the home port for the cruiser U.S.S. Normandy, which has a crew of about 364, but it has not said whether it still intends to berth the other six ships there.
Representative Ted Weiss, the Manhattan Democrat who has led the opposition to the port among the city's Congressional delegation, called Mr. Dinkins's letter ''a very significant step forward.''
''It never really made any strategic sense, it never made any budgetary sense, and whatever military reasons there were for it went out the window when they mothballed the Iowa,'' Mr. Weiss said.
The Stapleton port and other home ports came off the drawing boards in the Reagan Administration when the Navy anticipated a 600-ship fleet and was worried about running out of space at existing ports. The strategic rationale was to eliminate the possibility that the Navy would be crippled by an attack on a large base.
 
Scaled Back to Six Ports
The original plan called for 13 bases scattered around the country, many in the districts of influential members of Congress, but the plan has since been scaled back to six.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who originally supported the port program, said last month that the Staten Island base ''makes no sense,'' and Senator John Warner, Republican of Virginia, who cast the crucial vote in favor of the home ports in 1986, has asked Secretary Cheney to reconsider the program.
In a letter responding to Senator Warner, who was Secretary of the Navy in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, Mr. Cheney said, ''The Navy, in particular, is re-evaluating the Strategic Home Porting Plan along with other parts of the shore-based infrastructure.''
In its bid for the Staten Island port, which was supported by the Koch administration, the city agreed to spend $11 million to repair the bulkhead at Stapleton and $22 million to upgrade streets. A spokesman for Mayor Dinkins, Leland T. Jones, said that money for the bulkhead would remain in the budget but that expenditures for street repairs would be reconsidered.
He said the city has not considered what it might do if the Navy goes ahead with the port.
 
Concern With Safety
Mayor Dinkins has opposed the port since it was proposed in 1983, primarily on safety grounds, which he raised again in his letter to the Defense Secretary. Nuclear weapons may be deployed on ships based at Stapleton, and opponents fear that a mishap might result in the release of plutonium over a densely populated area. As a matter of policy, the Navy does not confirm which ships carry nuclear missiles.

HEADLINE: Tax Revolts and Cuts in Aid Batter Schools

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 10

 BODY:
Local school districts across the metropolitan region are facing some of the stiffest financial pressures in years, just as their states, also struggling to balance budgets, are cutting aid to them.
Last spring taxpayers rejected school budgets in scores of communities in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. Officials say their budgets for the next school year are meeting even greater resentment now as soaring health-insurance costs and rising teacher salaries have again pushed increases well above the inflation rate.
School superintendents seem more concerned this year with placating residents who are angry over high property taxes, which have grown steadily over the last decade even as school enrollments have declined.
 
Budget Cuts and Teacher Layoffs
From Bergen County, N.J., to Fairfield County, Conn., even the most affluent suburbs have cut hundreds of thousands of dollars from budgets and prepared to lay off teachers. 
But officials in all three states say the reductions in state aid are compounding their difficulties. ''We've just put a very bad year behind us, and there's the specter of another one coming up,'' said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association.
In New Jersey and Connecticut, many school superintendents feel state authorities are double-crossing them. Both states have proposed providing significantly less in local grants than stipulated by their school-aid formulas, guaranteeing either higher property taxes or educational cuts, critics say.
''There's hypocrisy at both the state and Federal levels,'' complained Frederick J. Stokley, the Schools Superintendent in Ridgewood, one of New Jersey's highest-achieving districts. ''The cry from our 'education Governor' and our 'education President' is we have to get our children ready for the 21st century. They all verbalize about their commitment to education, but the rhetoric is not being backed up. Schools are moving backward.''
In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio has proposed $2.6 billion in aid for local districts next year, $517 million less than the state's aid formula stipulates. His proposal is also $656,496 less than current spending, meaning the state's 40.4 percent share of local educational expenses would drop sharply.
 
'Very Short-Sighted'
In Connecticut, Gov. William A. O'Neill has proposed $871 million in aid, $62 million less than stipulated by his state's aid formula. Unless some money is restored by the General Assembly, the state's share of local educational costs will drop from 44.7 percent to 44.1.
''I think it's very short-sighted and a tragedy for education in Connecticut,'' said Terry Cassidy, executive director of the Connecticut Association of School Boards. ''The state has greater latitude for increasing taxes than local school boards. But the state doesn't seem to have the will to support its schools at the rate they should be.''
In Ridgewood, officials recently cut $500,000 from a proposed budget of $38.9 million. Then the state announced that it was providing $262,000 less in aid than the district had anticipated.
Stung by last spring's budget defeat, only the fifth in Ridgewood since 1946, school officials decided against further increasing a proposed tax increase of 7.9 percent, or about $275 on the average home. Instead, Dr. Stokley said, they will try to recoup the $262,000 in a new teachers' contract.
This maneuvering is so much minutia to Harry Whitmore, whose youngest child graduated from Ridgewood High in 1968 and whose annual property taxes are $6,000.
''I just look at the bottom line and at my taxes, and they just can't keep adding and keep adding and keep adding,'' he said. ''Most people feel the budget is higher than it needs to be.''
 
Good Schooling vs. Taxes
With a vote on the Ridgewood budget due on April 24, high-school students are organizing to get supporters out to vote, and debate among residents is brisk.
''It's a superior school system, and the kids are serious about their education, said Marie Sullivan, the mother of four children. ''I'm not for shortchanging them.''
But Karen Klempner, the mother of a 5-month-old baby, said her $7,000 property tax bill had stymied the sale of her town house for six months. ''People just are not buying the 'good schools' argument anymore,'' she said. ''They say the taxes are outrageous.''
State aid problems also are looming for districts in New York. For the state budget that was to have gone into effect on April 1, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo recommended increasing the state's current $8.5 billion in local school aid by $240 million. But that is $725 million less than recommended by the state's Board of Regents, said Mr. Grumet of the School Boards Association.
 
Taxes or Service Cuts
''It takes $593 million more a year just to stay even in terms of state aid,'' he said. ''Every penny we come in below that figure means local property taxes will skyrocket again or services will be cut.''
The bleak state aid picture comes a year after the region's deepest assault on school budgets in years. Last April, 38 percent of New Jersey's 1989-90 budgets - 210 of 553 - were defeated in the worst anti-tax wave since 1975.
In New York, 21 percent of budgets - 135 of 642 - lost in the first round of voting a year ago, the highest rejection rate since 23 percent of the budgets lost in 1981.
Connecticut's school budgets are reviewed by local boards of finance, not voters. Of 120 district budgets checked by the Association of Boards of Education a year ago, 80 percent were rejected or cut deeply by the finance boards, Mr. Cassidy said.
Cost-cutting seems commonplace now across the region, regardless of a district's wealth and reputation.
In Westport, one of Connecticut's premier systems, the finance board has ordered an $890,000 cut in a proposed budget of $33.2 million. The cut is triple the highest one in previous years, school officials said.
 
Average Salary $50,150
Officials say the average teacher salary in the Fairfield County suburb is $50,150. Like many districts, Westport, after a decade of little hiring, has many older teachers at the top of the pay scale. In addition, Connecticut, like many states, has pushed to raise teacher salaries. Teachers now sense a taxpayer backlash.
''There's a teacher-bashing mentality out there,'' said Richard Leonard, president of the teachers' union and an English teacher at Staples High for 30 years. ''When we were making $25,000 and $30,000, people were less critical. Now that we're up in the 50's, people are saying they don't want to pay that kind of money.''
If the $890,000 cut prevails, at least seven teaching jobs will be eliminated, officials said.
In Danbury, Conn., the 8,300-student system is still reeling from last year's loss of 62 jobs, including those of 42 teachers, after city officials halved a proposed 11 percent budget increase. School officials, hopeful that a new city administration will be more sympathetic, have again proposed an 11 percent increase to the district's $50 million budget.
''Even if we get the full 11 percent, we could restore only 17 of the 62 positions we lost last year,'' said Danbury's Schools Superintendent, Anthony Singe.
 
Insurance a 'Real Killer'
Among the district's problems are premiums for health and dental insurance for employees, which have grown to $6.6 million for 1990-91 from $3.5 million in 1987-88, Dr. Singe said. ''That's a real killer for us,'' he said. Insurance premiums in Perth Amboy, an old industrial hub in New Jersey, have gone from $2.9 million in 1988-89 to nearly $5 million for 1990-91. Half of an original $2.2 million increase for the 1990-91 budget was for health-insurance premiums, said Superintendent Frank N. Sinatra.
But then the state proposed giving Perth Amboy $3.4 million less than it anticipated, leaving a $5.7 million bill for taxpayers, Mr. Sinatra said. ''They'll never accept that,'' he said. Imposing a wage freeze and forcing staff members to pay a part of health-insurance premiums are the most likely solutions, he said.
 
Fighting 'Frills and Luxuries'
Taxpayer resistance in the region was localized until Tax Pac, an anti-tax group, was created a year ago in Suffolk County, L.I., by David J. Willmott, the 51-year-old publisher of a weekly, Suffolk Life. Mr. Willmott says Tax Pac has 30,000 dues-paying members spread across 90 percent of Suffolk's 960 election districts. School officials in Albany consider the group the state's strongest foe of school budgets.
''We want to eliminate from school budgets all frills and luxuries that taxpayers cannot afford and have nothing to do with mainstream education,'' Mr. Willmott said.
Budgets should finance only state-mandated core curriculum and elective courses, he said, and activities like football and drama clubs should have their own budgets and be voted on. If these budgets lose, the parents of participating students or booster clubs should finance the programs, he said.
He also wants the state to finance fully all programs that it mandates, except for the core curriculum. On that point, he sounds like some New Jersey superintendents angry about chronic state underfinancing of local aid.
''There's talk among school boards about not paying for state-mandated items like asbestos removal and radon monitoring,'' Dr. Stokley said. ''If they don't fund their law, why should we follow their mandates?''
Harold Morris, Superintendent in Teaneck, N.J., complained: ''They don't obey their own law, yet they can impose programs on districts and say we have to obey. It's a double standard. For years, taxpayers have been shortchanged and fooled by the state, and that's unconscionable.''

HEADLINE: For a Burned Church, Help Pours In

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
All day long, donations and expressions of sympathy poured in for the Church of the Holy Apostles, the Chelsea landmark heavily damaged by fire Monday night.
A stranger, moved by the ravaged building, walked up to a church official, wrote a $100 check and left. Religious and community organizations, preservationists and friends and neighbors all sent messages to the Episcopal parish, offering to help restore the church. 
The expressions of support revealed New York's deep feelings for the church, a 142-year-old structure at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street that operates the largest soup kitchen in the city.
 
More Volunteers
Yesterday, more volunteers than usual came to the soup kitchen in the adjacent mission house, which was untouched by the fire. They served a cold meal of macaroni and tuna salad and fruit and juice. The chef changed the menu from chili because the electricity had been cut off.
''We served 950 meals today,'' the rector, the Rev. William A. Greenlaw, said.
As he surveyed the smoke-blackened building, its roof now bearing a gaping hole and its chancel strewn with charred timber and debris, Mr. Greenlaw said he was devastated.
''I am asking the people of New York to respond generously to our need or we won't be able to make it,'' he said.
He estimated damages to be from $3 million to $4 million, adding that he hoped insurance would cover most of it.
He said more than half of the church's 19 stained glass windows were damaged, including 5 of 10 ''priceless panes'' by the 19th-century designers John and Willial Jay Bolton. The newly completed slate roof, which the church raised $500,000 to renovate, ''is close to a total loss,'' he said.
The wood beams over a third of the building were destroyed, and all the interior plaster was damaged by smoke. Assistant Commander John Mulligan of the New York City Fire Department said the blaze was considered ''an accident'' caused by workers using a propane torch that ignited the roofing material.
Waiting in the line at the soup kitchen yesterday, Nathan Johnson, an unemployed morgue supervisor who said he lives ''out there,'' said he was shocked when he heard of the fire and was afraid the lunch program would be canceled.
''I didn't know where I would get a meal today,'' he said, ''but had faith that God would direct me.''
Many anxious parishioners and neigbors have been stopping to ask where they can send donations to the church, said James T. Novack, volunteer coordinator at the soup kitchen.
Mr. Greenlaw said people have begun to rally around in a show of solidarity. He expressed appreciation for a call from a representative of John Cardinal O'Connor's office, which offered the use of a Roman Catholic center.
 
'Deeply Concerned'
The Church of St. Luke in the Fields, which was rebuilt after a 1981 fire, sent a check for $500. Other churches in the neigborhood have offered help.
One of the first callers was the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, who asked what she could do, Mr. Greenlaw said. He said there were also calls from from Deputy Mayor Barbara Fife's office and Assemblyman Richard Gottfried.
''All the preservation community is deeply concerned over this unnecessary hardship and impressed with the resilience and determination of Rector Greenlaw,'' said Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, who heads the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation.
She said the church ''deserves our regard and financial help.''

GRAPHIC: More than half of the Church of the Holy Apostles' stained glass windows were damaged by fire on Monday, including 5 of 10 ''priceless panes'' by the 19th-century designers, John and Willial Jay Bolton, the church's rector said. A worker removed pieces of a broken pane yesterday. (The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles)

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Work Force Failing To Meet Math Needs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Although the fastest-growing occupations require a mathematical background, a new report contends that a growing number of people entering the work force will not have the required training.
''Unless changes occur, the nation's needs for mathematically skilled teachers, scientists, engineers and hosts of other workers for business, industry and government will not be met,'' said the report, issued today by the National Research Council, a private group that advises Congress on scientific issues.
By the year 2000, the need for workers in these fields is expected to rise by 36 percent over the 1986 figure, the report said. But at the same time demographic trends indicate that the traditional pool of scientists and engineers, white males, will fall at roughly the same rate. 
There will be 21 million new jobs a decade from now, the report said, with most requiring mathematical backgrounds and post-secondary education.
 
Change in the Work Force
The report said 85 percent of new entrants into the work force are minorities and women, but few minorities and women enter engineering and science, a field including mathematicians.
To compound the situation, the report said the existing shortage of qualified math teachers at all levels will grow worse in the next decade if the pattern does not change. ''The current number of new doctoral degree holders taking academic positions in the United States will not even be sufficient to replace faculty lost to retirement,'' it said.
Within the next 20 years, black and Hispanic students will make up 30 percent of the college-age population, yet few minority students pursue mathematics as a career, according to the study, ''A Challenge of Numbers: People in the Mathematical Sciences.''
 
Few Minorities in Math Field
Only six percent of those who have doctorates in mathematics are minorities.
Although women are receiving bachelor's degrees in mathematics in numbers equal to men, only 17 percent of those receiving mathematics doctorates are women.
''There are simply not enough people studying math and the sciences,'' said William E. Kirwan, the president of the University of Maryland at College Park, who serves as chairman of the Committee on the Mathematical Sciences in the Year 2000, which produced the report. ''I am hoping that the signs of economic trouble will waken people to the consequences.''
The report was the second of three in a series on trends and needs in mathematics education.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
About Education

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
The shaping of child-care legislation is made difficult by long neglect. How can this nation catch up with care that should have been provided years ago and that has long been available in other industrial societies? The problem is compounded by a similar backlog of other unmet social needs, like health insurance and care for the elderly. the issue boils down to money; creating a new child-care structure is expensive.
The median start-up cost of an early childhood education center, for example, is estimated at $48,500. In some places, however, the cost can go as high as $900,000. These figures come from a report, ''Early Childhood Education: What Are the Costs of High-Quality Programs?'' done by the United States General Accounting Office and presented to the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources. The report put the average cost of early education for a 4-year-old at $4,797 in fiscal 1988. 
On average, 69 percent of that cost was paid by parents, with 15 percent more coming from other private sources, like churches, colleges and fund-raisers. Only 16 percent was covered with public funds. This suggests that little money, and therefore little child care, was provided for poor families, the very people who need it most.
''Despite increased enrollments in early childhood education programs,'' the report says, ''disproportionately fewer low-income and minority children receive a preschool education than children of higher-income families.'' At last count, only 33 percent of 4-year-olds from families with annual incomes below $10,000 had the benefit of preschool education, compared with 67 percent from families with incomes over $35,000.
The G.A.O. study surveyed 265 accredited centers serving 4-year-olds full time and all year. At the core of the problem are staff salaries, which amount to nearly three quarters of a center's costs. Early childhood teachers earn an average salary of $16,000 a year, the report estimates, compared with $38,000 for public school teachers nationwide. As a result, highly qualified people willing to work in the centers are hard to find, and many of the best leave child care for regular teaching jobs.
Dismal as the G.A.O. numbers may be, many economists consider even those figures overly optimistic. Victor R. Fuchs, a professor of economics at Stanford University who has been researching the child-care field, emphasized that there are also many part-timers working for extremely low hourly wages.
And the Child Care Employees Project, a nonprofit group in Oakland, Calif., says the average hourly wage for child-care workers in 1988 was $5.35, amounting to an annual income of $9,431, placing them near the poverty line. It is not surprising that every year about 40 percent of these workers quit their jobs.
Professor Fuchs points to the French child-care experience: Staff members get the same training and pay as elementary school teachers. They also usually have to take care of about twice the number of children as they would be required to supervise in American centers. (The G.A.O. report speaks of a ratio of 10 or 11 children for each adult as ideal.) But the greater pay appears to promise greater stability in staffing and higher-quality personnel.
The G.A.O. study addresses only a partial step toward a solution. The issue is no longer merely early childhood education but how to care for children virtually from birth.
The report reminds the Senate that the percentage of employed women with children under age 6 has tripled in the last three decades and now stands at 63 percent and rising. This answers the well-intentioned but out-of-date conservative view that child care should be placed in a mother's hands.
Scandinavia has led the movement to have full-time child care available from early morning until early evening, even for infants. It is expensive. In Denmark, the cost for a child is between $5,000 and $7,500 a year, and the charge to parents who can afford to pay is about $230 a month until age 3 and $150 thereafter.
The Swedish model is much more lavish - it comes to about $10,000 a child - but its costs could undoubtedly be reduced by increasing the number of children per adult, which is currently three or four.
Whatever the best model for the United States, a vast effort is required to train high-quality people and provide competitive pay. As child-care legislation once again moves through Congress, the next few weeks may suggest some answers about just what price Congress, President Bush (who has threatened to veto costly proposals), local communities and parents may be willing to pay. Cost and quality of child care are obviously linked. Millions of children, if neglected in their early years, will eventually be a heavy - and expensive - burden to society.

HEADLINE: A New Museum's Bright Future Grows Dim

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

 BODY:
Once a bright gleam in the cultural future of Massachusetts, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, a projected $86 million complex for contemporary art, has lost much of its luster. Some in this financially strapped state are calling it ''the miracle that's become a mirage.''
The idea of using a vast abandoned factory site in this economically depressed town as a home for art of the postwar era was conceived by Thomas Krens, now the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York.
But this state's fiscal crisis and concern about the museum's ability to generate predicted economic benefits have diminished the enthusiasm of some supporters and bolstered the resistance of its opponents.
A glowing feasibility study and master plan, now being reviewed by the state's Office of Administration and Finance, says that the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art - popularly known by the acronym Mass Moca -can ''be a cultural attraction of international magnitude and appeal, and an economic agent of great potential for Northern Berkshire County.'' The museum, which is to occupy a 13.5-acre maze of courtyards and mill buildings that make up the abandoned Sprague Technologies plant here, would work, the study asserts, ''by combining the allure of art with the forces of commerce in a mixed-use plan that is both dynamic and practical.'' 
The study was done by the executive planning group of the Mass Moca Cultural Development Commission, a nine-member body appointed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and headed by Mr. Krens.
A $35 million bond issue to help finance Mass Moca was approved two years ago by the State Legislature. And the museum's sponsors have tentatively scheduled the first phase of its opening for March 1993. Should Art Outrank Schools and Aged? Yet as Massachusetts confronts its economic crisis, legislators and their constituents are questioning whether to go ahead with the project when funds for education and care to the elderly have been cut and state spending for the arts, which two years ago stood at $27 million, was slashed to $17.3 million in January.
''When you can't pay the mortgage, you don't put a deck on the house,'' said Christopher J. Hodgkins, a Democratic State Representative from Lee, in the Berkshires. ''Although I voted for it, I was dubious from the beginning. It's a creative project, but one whose costs aren't meshing. There's a lot of smoke and mirrors involved.''
Yet Governor Dukakis and some state officials and legislators, particularly those from the area of North Adams, where the closing of the Sprague plant in 1985 abolished some 3,500 jobs, are still pushing for Mass Moca. They see it as a way to create jobs and tourist revenue. And other officials say the museum will not draw on the state's $12 billion operating budget. They point out that the $35 million general obligation bond issue will be sold to private investors, although interest payments to bondholders, made higher by a downgrading in the state's bond rating, will come from state money.
What's more, within two years after its opening, the project could -as have other Massachusetts cultural institutions - call on the state-financed Massachusetts Cultural Council for operating money. Richard Schwartz, a spokesman for the council, said that the agency was ''a bit nervous'' about that possibility, because ''it could be a very large sum for us.''
A decision on the feasibility study will probably occur this spring, said Gary A. Shepard, the state's Assistant Secretary of Economic Affairs. ''If we decide that it's do-able from an operational and functional point of view, that our money will be invested properly with a good chance of a return on our investment, then we will O.K. it,'' Mr. Shepard said. ''If our decision is positive, we will hopefully get money flowing within this fiscal year.'' West German Idea Set in the Berkshires Mass Moca was conceived by Mr. Krens in 1985 when he was the director of the Williams College Art Museum in prospering Williamstown, next door to North Adams. Inspired by the example of a factory converted for use as an art gallery in Cologne, West Germany, he envisioned the Sprague plant as an arena for installations of large-scale contemporary art. The museum, designed by a stellar architectural team headed by Frank Gehry and Robert Venturi along with David Childs of Skidmore Owings & Merrill, would help pay for itself by incorporating commercial facilities, such as a luxury inn, three restaurants and design-related shops.
''It came into being because I and others believed that no cultural institution existing today had the capacity to deal with large-scale postwar art,'' Mr. Krens said recently. ''Mass Moca is solely an opportunity that came up by the convenient conjunction of the financial success of Massachusetts, the relative financial distress of North Adams, the availability of a concentration of land and buildings and the recognition that maybe this kind of thing could work.
''I don't have all the answers for Mass Moca. I think it needs a champion and I'll continue to act in that capacity. But it also needs reinforcement in the collective will of the artistic community - artists, collectors, curators, dealers.''
Mr. Krens, who appears bent on setting up an international network of museums under the Guggenheim's aegis, said that the Guggenheim had no financial involvement with Mass Moca. And he denied that pressure from the Guggenheim's board had caused him to distance himself from the North Adams project. He said he was in close touch with Joseph Thompson, Mass Moca's director.
He added: ''Look, I am the last person to spend $35 million of state money if Mass Moca is not going to be successful. I don't need it as an albatross around my neck.'' Home for Great Art Needs Great Art One hurdle seen by David Ross, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston and one of the nine Mass Moca commissioners, is ''whether great collections would indeed materialize.'' He elaborated: ''All of us on the commission feel very strongly that if the museum has to function as a kunsthalle without an extremely long-term collection of very important material, would it provide the draw? It needs the goods, and they must be goods that will draw people from all over the world.''
As a start in stocking the museum, which would focus on the art of the 1960's, 70's and 80's, Mr. Krens says he has pledges for the long-term loan of major holdings from Count Giuseppe Panza di Buomo of Milan, the New York dealers Ileana and Michael Sonnabend, the English collector Charles Saatchi and the German Architectural Museum in Frankfurt. He maintained that the Panza loan for Mass Moca has nothing to do with a recent agreement between the Guggenheim and Mr. Panza for the purchase and gift of more than 200 works from his collection.
Works from the Panza collecton, for instance, to be installed at Mass Moca, would include large-scale light and space installations by the artists James Turrell and Dan Flavin and sculptural pieces by the English artist Richard Long, as well as works by well-known Conceptual artists. e Count Panza has said that he is ready to lend Mass Moca 300 works, although the difficult financial situation in Massachusetts makes the prospect uncertain. Mrs. Sonnabend said recently that she was also committed to lending her collection, which was traveling for a year and a half. ''When it comes back, we'll see,'' she said.
The museum's ultimate cost, originally projected at $77.5 million, is now put at $85.7 million because of increases attributed to inflation through 1997. Already $1.7 million of the bond issue has gone to finance the feasibility study. Some $38 million -including the remainder of the bond issue, $33.3 million, plus $5 million to be privately raised - would be spent on Phase 1 of the building program before Mass Moca could open its doors, providing over 200,000 square feet of exhibition space, a climate control plant and a museum shop and cafe. Private developers would simultaneously build a luxury hotel, three restaurants and retail shops, all for $17.8 million. Akira Tobishima, the head of a major Japanese construction company, who was recently made a trustee of the Guggenheim Museum, has expressed interest in building the hotel.
Phase 2 of the program would add an additional 180,000 square feet, at a cost of $27.2 million more. An additional $12.5 million would be raised for endowment.
The only new building at the factory complex would be a prefabricated structure for large-scale changing exhibitions, Mr. Thompson said. Seeing the Future In Other Pasts ''The museum will be the first permanent platform for large-scale art of the past 30 years,'' he added. ''It will present in depth the kind of art which is now only sampled in most public collections.'' Economically, Mass Moca would in the long run ''decrease the drag on social services in an area that hasn't enjoyed great prosperity anyway,'' Mr. Thompson continued. He also said it would add an enriching presence to existing cultural institutions in the Berkshires -including the Sterling and Francine Clark Institute in Williamstown, the Williamstown Summer Theater, Jacob's Pillow and Tanglewood -that would increase visitor potential to the area.
But there are those who dispute the optimistic projections. They point out that although Mass Moca forecasts an annual attendance of 150,000, the Clark Institute, a small gem of an encyclopedic museum noted for, among other things, its large collection of Renoirs, averages only 120,000 visitors a year, partly because of the relative inaccessibility of the northern Berkshire area. In addition, the art to be shown at Mass Moca, much of it austere and intellectual in concept, is less appealing to a general audience.
''New England has traditionally been behind in contemporary art, so we would hope that such an undertaking could succeed,'' said James Welu, the director of the Worcester Art Museum. ''But we don't want it to be a white elephant. A major concern is whether a constituency could be developed to support such a large undertaking into the future. Historically, museums follow affluence, they don't usually create it.''
But David Ross said, ''We all feel we have to struggle, but if another powerful institution was created that would help bring more energy and money to the state - well, a rising tide lifts all ships.''

CORRECTION-DATE: April 17, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the projected Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, in North Adams, misattributed a feasibility study. It was made by outside professional organizations, not by the executive planning group of the Mass Moca Cultural Development Commission.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices Off Sharply as Supplies Rise

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Oil prices continued to tumble yesterday as mounting surpluses of petroleum caused increased waves of selling here and overseas. The May contract for crude oil settled at an eight-month low of $17.68 a barrel, down 76 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest energy market.
Citing the recent sharp drop in oil prices, the official press agency of Saudi Arabia predicted ''evil consequences'' if members of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued to exceed their self-imposed production quotas. Some analysts said the Saudis were merely warning that overproduction would bring harmful economic consequences to everyone; others took it as a warning that the Saudis, OPEC's largest producer, would chastise fellow members as they have in the past by flooding the market and driving prices still lower. 
The oil market had long known that OPEC members were exceeding their quotas and selling increasing amounts of crude at discounts from posted prices. But it was not until the surpluses began swamping storage tanks here and in Europe that buyers began rejecting offers from OPEC exporters.
After the New York Mercantile Exchange closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the nation's stocks of crude oil rose for the week and were well above levels of a year earlier.
The spot May crude oil contract ranged between $18.55 and $17.59 during the frenetic trading session before closing below $18. The same contract fell 71 cents the day before and $1.13 last week.
Meanwhile, the spot contract for unleaded gasoline plunged further, losing 2.46 cents a gallon, to 58.43 cents. The spot May heating oil contract declined 0.67 cent a gallon, to 52.40 cents.
''We were all surprised by the selling momentum,'' said Joel Faber, who heads an oil trading company bearing his name. ''Most of us expected at least a modest technical rally after the long decline in crude prices.''
The selling of crude oil contracts spilled over into the gasoline market. One reason is that supplies of the West Texas Intermediate grade oil that is traded on the exchange are also more than ample.
Mr. Faber also noted that while heating oil prices declined at this time of year, the unusually mild winter prompted many refiners to switch to gasoline output weeks before they normally would. ''This situation has produced some tightness in heating oil supplies here and there,'' Mr. Faber said.
Broker calls for more cash margin added to the selling momentum, he added, ''and we can expect even more margin calls to go out after today's selloff.''
Peter C. Beutel, energy market analyst at Elders Futures Inc., the domestic trading arm of the big Australian financial house, said much of the selling pressure came from the breakdown of technical support levels. Most commodity investment funds depend on computer programs to provide buy or sell signals. Mr. Beutel said the selling had washed out the last technical support level of $17.78, ''and it has been replaced by $16.91, a level last seen on Feb. 1, 1989.''
Meanwhile, he continued, the overseas energy markets also weakened. In London, the price of the spot May contract for high-grade North Sea Brent blends fell a further 65 cents a barrel, to $15.95. Further discounts are being made for crude oil with high-sulfur and metallic contents.
Bradford H. Hughes, an energy specialist at Cargill Investor Services, noted that while the A.P.I. reported nation's crude oil stocks were up 8 million barrels and stood at 45 million barrels above levels a year earlier, refinery runs were off 1.8 percent in the latest week, because of seasonal switching from heating oil to gasoline.
''This factor and the seasonal upturn in gasoline demand may account for the 2.8-million-barrel drop in the nation's gasoline stocks in the latest week,'' Mr. Hughes said. ''Still, gasoline stocks are only down two million 42-gallon barrels from a year ago.''
The A.P.I. also reported that the nation's inventory of heating oil fell 2.5 million 42-gallon barrels for the week, but stocks were 4.5 million barrels above the level a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Way to Hedge On 'Junk Bonds'?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
ROBERT GORDON, president of Twenty-First Securities in New York, thinks he has found a way to permit those who own ''junk bonds'' to sleep better at night. His proposed sedative is a hedging strategy, a hybrid of stock and bond-futures trades, that he says will offset some of the risk of investing in the volatile, unrated debt issues.
Mr. Gordon is one of the better-known financial tinkerers on Wall Street, and his boutique firm carries out a variety of hedging and arbitrage strategies for major institutional investors. If his hedging theory passes muster on Wall Street, more institutional investors may be willing to put capital into the junk bond market, providing much-needed liquidity. 
But skeptics in the junk bond arena are taking a ''show me'' attitude about Mr. Gordon's somewhat vague assertion, which he will outline for institutional investors and money managers at an invitation-only conference on May 3 in New York.
''Sure, if you could hedge, you could take a bigger position in the market, but you can't, so it's academic,'' said one junk bond trader. ''You can only hedge apples with apples and oranges with oranges.''
But in Mr. Gordon's view, junk bonds are a sort of financial fruit salad. ''What we're doing is breaking a high-yield bond into its component parts - interest-rate risk and credit risk,'' he said.
Mr. Gordon declined to provide his specific hedging formula, which he developed in partnership with Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, investment managers in Los Angeles, until he has presented it to his clients. But he said it involved a ''blended'' use of Treasury bond futures contracts and other equity-hedging techniques. ''We think we can hedge the risk of owning about 60 percent of the junk bond universe,'' he said.
By coincidence, that percentage roughly corresponds to the portion of the $200 billion junk bond universe made up of debt issued by companies that also have common stock outstanding, suggesting that Mr. Gordon's ''blended hedge'' incorporates the common stock of junk bond issuers.
If so, that would rule out Mr. Gordon's technique for junk bond issuers with no common stock outstanding -about $80 billion worth of the market at the end of 1989. It also may not be useful for insurers and other regulated investors who may be barred by state rules from using common equity-hedging tools like short-selling, which is the sale of borrowed stock by an investor who expects to replace the shares with new ones purchased at a lower price.
Nevertheless, Mr. Gordon's tinkering is another sign that Wall Street is putting some mental and financial muscle into the task of getting the junk bond market back on its feet. Indeed, it is the second such signal this week. On Monday, Salomon Brothers announced that it had purchased Drexel Burnham Lambert's junk bond data base and software, beating out more than a dozen other bidders. In addition, the firm has hired at least one of the senior computer technicians who ran the data base at Drexel's junk bond office in Beverly Hills, Calif.
C. Daniel Tyree, managing director and head of Salomon's junk bond operation, said Salomon was eager to acquire the exclusive use of the Drexel data base because it ''complemented'' his firm's other recent commitments to the junk bond market. ''We have upgraded our staff tremendously,'' he said, noting that several junk bond experts from Drexel and other firms have been recruited. ''With this data base, we will have the complete mosaic: the people and the information.''
The informaton is, by all accounts, awesome. It includes the description, underlying financial data, research reports, prospectuses, yield calculations and pricing history of 3,000 securities. Mark E. Fields, a managing director and head of junk bond sales, said that roster includes 500 issues that were sold by Drexel through private placements, for which public data are almost nonexistent.
Armed with its new data base, Salomon expects to be able to ''be more aggressive'' in matching buyers and sellers in the junk bond market regardless of whether a new hedging technique emerges, Mr. Fields said. ''But looking at the market in general, perhaps 1 percent of the outstanding junk-bond market is in dealers' hands,'' he said. ''If there were a hedging mechanism, that would help dealers provide more liquidity and more capital in the secondary market. That percentage would go up. And that would help.''

HEADLINE: Air Travel Gridlock Seen for Europe

BYLINE: By BURTON BOLLAG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 10

 BODY:
Air travel in Europe will come to a ''near standstill'' by the end of the decade if radical improvements are not made, a study released today predicts.
Traffic is growing so rapidly that congestion at airports and in air corridors will reach ''catastrophic'' proportions as early as 1995, says the study, commissioned by the International Air Transport Association, which represents 190 of the world's big airlines.
The report, calls for a ''once-for-all outlay of about $3.5 billion,'' beyond currently planned investments, to expand airports and increase air traffic control capacity to meet the demand for the next two decades.
The number of passengers for flights within Europe is expected to almost double to about 500 million in 2000 from 267 million in 1980 and to triple to about 740 million by 2010. 
 
Patchwork of Systems
But as important as investments, the study says, is the willingness of governments to set aside air space reserved for military flights, and to make the patchwork of national air control systems compatible.
Transport ministers from the 23 member countries of the European Civil Aviation Council are expected to agree to an air traffic integration plan that industry officials consider ''a major step forward'' at a meeting on April 24.
The plan calls for an eight-year period during which the different national air traffic control systems in Europe would adopt the same standards and computer software, allowing them to communicate with one another better and hand over control of flights with little effort.
Western Europe has about half the density of flights of the Northeast United States, yet the fact that each country keeps complete sovereignty over its air space makes coordination of flights much more difficult, industry officials say.
 
Big Political Problem
''An F.A.A. of Europe would be the best of all worlds,'' said Norman Jackson, senior director-technical of the association, referring to the United States Federal Aviation Administration. ''But it's a major political problem and could take a long time to come about.''
The study says the proportion of intra-European flights delayed by more than 15 minutes almost doubled between 1986 and 1989 to approximately 24 percent. This took place despite improvements made in coordinating national air traffic control systems. In the summer peak period, some charter flights have been delayed by 24 hours.
Industry officials, however, say safety records have actually been increasing as air controllers make planes wait on the ground instead of in the air.
The study, written by the research organization S.R.I. International of Menlo Park, Calif., says the cost of delays and inefficient routings to circumvent military airspace and other national restrictions amounts to about $5 billion each year. Those losses are expected to double to $10 billion by 2000 if strong remedies are not quickly applied.
 
Fares May Rise
Air travel can also become ''unaffordable to an increasing percentage of the European population,'' the study said, if losses associated with congestion prompt a rise in air fares.
''At least 10 major European airports'' will run out of space for airplanes that want to land there, if major new investments are not made to expand runways and terminal space, the study added. Among the most overcrowded are in Madrid, Frankfurt and London.
The study says that the proposed $3.5 billion additional investments called for would avoid more than that amount of losses caused by overcrowding. But it acknowledges that opposition to airport expansion has created a negative image problem for the industry.
For this reason the report calls on air transport association, which is based in Geneva and Montreal, to develop public education advertising campaigns to convince the European public that such investments make economic and enviornmental sense.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Sharp Drop; Gold Prices Also Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined sharply yesterday against most major currencies in thin, seesaw trading as concerns about continued central-bank intervention dampened market sentiment.
Gold prices also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375 a troy ounce, $1 lower than late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.50 an ounce, off 15 cents. 
Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York, said traders were reluctant to buy dollars for fear that major central banks would intervene to drive the dollar down again.
Several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, sold dollars in Europe and Asia to help stem the yen's decline on Monday. That action followed a weekend meeting in Paris in which the major industrialized nations, known as the Group of Seven, agreed to closely monitor developments in the yen.
The Japanese currency has been under pressure lately amid growing signs of a weakening Japanese economy and a sharp decline on the Tokyo stock market.
Also helping to weaken the dollar yesterday were reported comments from Helmut Haussmann, West Germany's Finance Minister, that he expects the mark to firm as a result of a planned economic and monetary unification of East and West Germany, currency dealers said.
Trading was described as thin yesterday because of the Passover holiday and in advance of the Easter holiday.
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar climbed 1.70 yen to a closing 158.15 yen yesterday. It was quoted at 158.60 yen in London, and at 157.60 yen in New York, down from 158.335 Monday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling sold in London for $1.6345, down from $1.6397, and for $1.64515 in New York, up from $1.63445 Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6750 West German marks, down from 1.6935; 1.4830 French francs, down from 1.4982; 5.6285 French francs, down from 5.6845; 1,230.16 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00, and 1.16925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday, were: 1.6900 West German marks, down from 1.6923 marks; 1.4955 Swiss francs, down from 1.4960; 5.6750 French francs, down from 5.6805; 1.9030 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9043; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.00, and 1.1613 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1615.
Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $375.15 an ounce, down from $375.50 late Monday. Gold also fell in Zurich to $375.25 an ounce from $376.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed down $2.16 at $376.97 an ounce.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Cavazos Criticizes Hispanic Parents on Schooling

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, April 10

 BODY:
 But when asked at a news conference what solutions he would propose, Mr. Cavazos, a sixth-generation Texan who is of Mexican descent, leveled his criticism at Hispanic parents. Hispanic cultures long placed a high value on education, he said, but "somewhere along the line we lost that."
 
'We Start by Caring'
 He argued that neither economic difficulties nor the language barrier completely explained the problems of Hispanic students because other ethnic groups had overcome those obstacles.
"I think in part we Hispanics have not acknowledged that problem," he said. "We start by caring. I think that's been one of our problems in America today. We really have not cared that youngsters have dropped out of school. We don't care, either teachers, parents, business community, elected officials. 
"We must have a commitment from Hispanics, from Hispanic parents especially, that their children will be educated," he said. "That is the first vital step."
Several local school officials and community leaders who spoke at today's hearing took issue with Mr. Cavazos. And Elena Pell, the national director for program development for Aspira, an advocacy group for Hispanic students, said of Mr. Cavazos's remarks, "It doesn't match up with our experience in working with Hispanic parents that they've lost interest in their children's education."
 
'Society Is at Fault'
 Gloria G. Rodriguez, executive director of Avance, a parent-child education program here, said: "Hispanic parents know that education is the only way out of poverty for their children. He's wrong to say the families are at fault when society is at fault for not supporting families that are overwhelmed by economic problems."
Stanley S. Litow, deputy chancellor of the New York City schools, said it was "absurd to blame Hispanic parents for the high dropout rate, based on our experience."
"These youngsters require added services like teaching English as a second language and more bilingual programs," he said. "Often we can't provide these services because of a lack of trained teachers and lack of dollars. We're laying too much of the blame on these parents, who love their children as much as anyone else."
About 40 percent of all Hispanic students in the United States drop out before graduating from high school, and the Education Department says the rate has not improved over the past 10 years even though the dropout rates of other groups have been declining. Mr. Cavazos said this would become a major national problem in the 1990's, when Hispanic youths will account for almost one-quarter of the new members of the American labor force.
Liz Cuevas, a freshman at John F. Kennedy High School here, told the Presidenial panel: "The students have to drop out just to support their families by getting jobs. I don't think that is right, but you have to do what you have to do."
The 15-year-old student complained of a lack of concern by teachers and parents, but most of all she blamed the bleak economic prospects faced by Hispanic youths. Speaking of those who abandon school, she asked, "Why bother, if I'm not going to have a future, if my parents don't have a future, if I don't know anyone who has a future?"
 
Criticism of Administration
 Mr. Cavazos became the first Hispanic-American to head a Cabinet department when President Ronald Reagan nominated him to the education post in August 1988. Mr. Bush asked him to remain in the job, but he has largely been relegated to a minor role in the Cabinet, even on education matters.
For his part, Mr. Bush has been criticized by educators and many state governors who say he places great emphasis on improving the nation's educational performance but opposes increases in Federal spending for education.
Today, Mr. Cavazos told the forum that the President was "deeply concerned about the low educational achievement among Hispanics" and added, "He recognizes that we cannot reach our national goals without improving the education of our growing Hispanic population." This was the first in a series of public hearings by the Task Force on Hispanic Education, a group of officials selected by Mr. Bush in December from several Federal agencies. The Secretary said the panel would suggest strategies for improving the performance of Hispanic-Americans in school, including ways to involve more of them in Federal efforts like bilingual education and special programs for the poor.
 
No New Programs Likely
 He indicated that the panel was unlikely to recommend major new Federal programs. Instead, he said, the aim was "to discover how the Federal Government can contribute to innovative solutions developed at the grass-roots level."
Other speakers called for more spending on programs at almost every level of education, from parenthood classes for the mothers of preschool children to scholarships for college students.
While declaring that Mr. Bush was eager to remedy the problems of Hispanic students, Mr. Cavazos also emphasized the Administration's view that programs and financing must come from the state and local levels.
One exception is bilingual education programs that help Hispanic children rapidly become proficient in English. Unlike his predecessors under Mr. Reagan, Mr. Cavazos has strongly supported such programs. While Federal aid to bilingual education declined through the 1980's, the Bush Administration has proposed a 10.6 percent increase in spending on these programs for the 1991 fiscal year.
Mr. Cavazos today emphasized the Administration's view that the design of bilingual eduation programs should be a local concern and that the goal should be to help students learn English as quickly as possible.
The next hearing in the series will be in Boston on April 26, followed by Chicago on May 11, Miami on May 18 and Los Angeles on June 5.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said Hispanic students' high dropout rate would become a problem when they enter the work force. (The New York Times/Craig Stafford)
