HEADLINE: FEDERAL OFFICIALS REPORT THE CENSUS LAGS SIGNIFICANTLY

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
With hundreds of thousands of census forms not delivered to the proper addresses and with millions of people not returning the completed forms, Federal officials said today that the 1990 count of the United States population is lagging significantly.
Congressional researchers estimated that in the end, as few as 60 percent of the forms may be returned to the Census Bureau. The bureau's director, Barbara Everitt Bryant, who notified Congress today of the sluggish rate of return, said in an interview that 55 percent of the forms had been returned and that the final return rate would be ''solidly in the mid-60's.''
Even that figure is below the bureau's original goal of a 70 percent return rate. A decline of each percentage point in the return rate means that 950,000 additional households must be visited in person by enumerators. 
 
Urgent Need Reinforced
Census officials have argued for months that they would make up for those who did not mail back the forms by dispatching census-takers to track them down, starting April 26. The officials brushed aside any speculation that so many people now needed to be counted by census-takers going door to door that the job was impossible.
But the Congressman who heads the House subcommittee that oversees the census, Thomas C. Sawyer, said today that he had discussed with Dr. Bryant the urgent need to reinforce the bureau's efforts. Representative Sawyer, an the Ohio Democrat, said more census-takers would have to be hired at an additional cost of $50 million to $150 million.
The budget provides for about 300,000 enumerators, a figure that would have to be increased by 25,000 to 75,000 to compensate for the lag in the mail returns, Congressional auditors said.
 
Bureau Beset With Criticism
''I am distressed - that's not too strong a word,'' said Mr. Sawyer, the chairman of the Census and Population Subcommittee of the House Committee on Post Office and Civil Service. ''It's fair to suggest that the integrity of the census could be in jeopardy if Congress doesn't work in concert with the bureau.''
The final count becomes the basis for Congressional and legislative reapportionment and for the annual distribution of at least $50 billion in Federal funds and millions of dollars more in state and local money.
The low return rate of census forms come to light as the Census Bureau has been beset with criticism and as reports abound about people who never received forms and who could not get through to the bureau's toll-free information number (800 999-1990) or who received no help when they did get through.
In some cases, entire neighborhoods or apartment buildings have received no forms. On occasion, even whole towns, like Ross, Calif., have received none.
Census officials said that some of the overall problem lay with the Postal Service's failure to deliver some forms and with the failure of independent contractors to correctly address others.
But the officials, as well as independent monitors, said a big part of the problem, and a potentially more difficult one to grapple with, is that people are simply not mailing in their census forms.
Response rates as of today were as low as 34 percent in central Brooklyn, 43 percent on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, 41 percent in Boston's high-rent Beacon Hill neighborhood and 49 percent in Hollywood, Calif.
Regional and local Census Bureau officials said that low rates of return cut across the socio-economic lines. That surprised them because they had thought residents of well-to-do neighborhoods would mail back their forms at higher rates than residents of poor or working-class neighborhoods.
''The thing that would help us most is if everyone who hasn't returned a questionnaire got them in fast,'' Dr. Bryant said.
 
Some Cities Responding Well
In some cities, the census count is going well. In Orlando, Fla., 59 percent of the census forms were being returned, and the district office manager, Mary Shepherd, said she expected no problem in reaching the 70 percent goal.
There were also optimistic reports from San Diego, and Dr. Bryant said Cleveland was well ahead of the national rate on the returns.
It is not clear why Americans are not returning the forms. Although regional census officials believe the return rate to be lower than a decades ago and believe the census to be more troubled than earlier efforts, they cannot cite figures. The bureau says it did not keep figures for midway points in past census counts, only for final tallies.
The final count of forms that have been mailed back will begin in about 10 days, and not until it is complete will the bureau be able to match this year's performance with those of previous decades.
Officials of both the Census Bureau and Congress held out hope that more forms than currently expected would come in.
 
A Test in 1988
But in 1988, during a dry-run test of the census in St. Louis, about 88 percent of all the forms eventually returned had been returned at this stage of the census process, said William Hunt, a Congressional auditor.
Dr. Bryant said an off-year test was a bad comparison because there is far less publicity about the census in an off year and no sense of what she called ''a national event.''
Some officials privately raised the possibility that, if it becomes increasingly difficult to get census returns, the bureau may have to push back its constitutionally mandated Dec. 31 deadline for providing national totals. The total count is scheduled to go to President Bush on that day, while the state-by-state counts used for reapportionment are to scheduled be out by April 1, 1991.
 
Difficulty in Recruiting
Both Representative Sawyer and Mr. Hunt expressed concern about whether enough census-takers could be recruited, particularly in some of the white-collar areas, like Boston's Beacon Hill and Manhattan's Upper West Side.
''The underreturn seems to be occurring in the same areas where they are experiencing recruitment problems,'' Mr. Sawyer said today. In New York City, at a news conference at City Hall, Hulburt James, coordinator of the city's census outreach efforts, said that city officials had been distressed that what they estimate as close to 10 percent of the households in the city have not yet received census forms. He said they were also concerned that the Census Bureau is planning to close its assistance centers for citizens on April 15, instead of keeping them open longer.
 
Dinkins Upset With Raids
Mayor David N. Dinkins was particularly upset that the Immigration and Naturalization Service had recently conducted raids in Washington Heights, where many Dominican and other Latin American immigrants live, in violation of what he thought was an understanding that such raids would not be conducted during the census, since the might inhibit participation.
Sheila H. Grimm, the regional director of the census for the New York City area, said that as of Tuesday morning, its rate for forms logged in so far was 46.2 percent.
''That rate is basically a very volatile, changing rate,'' she said. ''There is a huge backlog of forms to be checked in and we are still hand-delivering others.''
She said the preliminary figures did not mean the bureau had missed huge swaths of the city, but that it was still working and would continue hand-delivering forms through April 20. At the end of the month, she said, enumerators would go out in person to addresses that had not responded.
In Brooklyn today, a coalition of big cities, states and groups like the N.A.A.C.P. went into Federal District Court seeking to force the Commerce Department to change its guidelines for adjusting the census to make sure minorities and the poor are accurately counted.
A primary issue is over a follow-up survey the department agreed to undertake after the census to compensate for any undercounting.

HEADLINE: Omens of Intolerance Among Cairo's Muslims

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 6

 BODY:
At dusk the streets are empty and the traffic dies down and a calm settles on this most rambunctious of cities, for this is Ramadan, the Muslim month of daytime fasting that represents one of Islam's sacred duties.
As night falls, and a single cannon shot from the Citadel overlooking the city signals the end of the day's restraint, millions of Egyptians settle to their first meal since before dawn, a celebration whose widespread observance shows how deeply Islam is ingrained in the souls of most Cairenes.
Yet, this year, the month of daytime famine and night-time feast has coincided with omens of intolerance among some Muslims. They are intolerant not only of dissident voices within Islam, but also of the nation's Coptic Christian minority of five million to eight million people. 
The authorities recently jailed an Egyptian author labeled by one magazine ''Egypt's Salman Rushdie'' - a comparison to the British author whose novel ''The Satanic Verses'' drew a death sentence from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.
The Egyptian author, identified in Cairo newspaper reports as Allaa Hamed, had, according to Islamic scholars, ''lampooned the Prophet, assaulted Islam and claimed that the Koran was not inspired by God'' with a work called ''The Vacuum in a Man's Mind.''
Most issues of the book were seized when the author, who is a Muslim, was arrested. But, according to Egyptians who have read parts of it, it argues that ''religion is a curse nowadays'' and that paradise is a ''hallucination.''
The treatise has stirred a familiar debate among Cairo's intellectuals about the limits of freedom in this society. ''Each human freedom has its limit and that is not to hurt peoples' feelings or religions,'' said Tharwat Abaza, an author who is deputy chairman of a Government advisory body called the Shura Council.
As the authorities and others consider the power and pull of faith in this land of 55 million - the most populous in the Arab world and a central participant in United States regional diplomacy - their concerns focus on the wider issue of whether economic deprivation and other forces are feeding religious passions that threaten the secular fabric of the nation.
Last month, a wave of anti-Christian attacks by a small Islamic organization called Islamic Groups, left five churches in the upper Egyptian province of Minya destroyed or damaged.
Members of the group, according to Egypt's Organization for Human Rights in a recent report on the clashes, had also attacked Christian-owned charities, cars, pharmacies, stores, factories and warehouses.
''These events constitute a new wave of escalation of religious-communal hostility, which has its fairly recent origins in the early 1970's and which, during the events of last month, developed into acts of wholesale religious violence,'' the report said.
The reference to the 1970's was significant because it conjured memories of the way President Anwar el-Sadat's policies unleashed religious passions that led to communal strife and, ultimately, to his assassination by Islamic fundamentalists in 1981.
The force of religion represents a profound influence in a region scarred by Lebanon's particularly gruesome example of the destruction of a frail nation by war among religious groups. In some of those Arab countries that have experimented to various degrees in political liberalization - Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Jordan - Muslim political groups have become established as the protagonists of an alternative society based on Islamic law, also called the Sharia.
The leaflets urged all Muslims ''to defend their 'honor unto death' against those whom they called the Crusaders,'' the report said. The preachers at two mosques in the towns on Minya and Abu Gurgas took up the call in Friday prayers in early March, the report said, inspiring members of the Islamic Groups to lead ''large numbers of people and schoolchildren on a rampage of destruction, looting and burning of churches, Christian associations and Christian-owned pharmacies, hospitals, medical clinics, shops and cars.''

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Learning From Japan

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
On the high-definition television screen in Sony's Shinagawa studio, a wine glass shimmers with spectacular clarity. In Fanuc's canary yellow plant at the foot of Mount Fuji, an aisle of new robot arms twist and turn in the disjointed calisthenics of their test program. In Nissan's vast automated warehouse at Oppama, a computer sends Maximas and Infinitis to a waiting cargo ship.
These machines are the high-level product of a highly functional society. As the visitor to Tokyo immediately notices, its crowds are orderly and well dressed, its streets and subways scrupulously clean, and people go about their business with no apparent fear of crime. 
Objective measures confirm the impression that Japan works. Economic output per person is already the world's highest, though purchasing power is somewhat less. People in Japan enjoy a longer life expectancy than in any other country. And whatever it is that I.Q. tests measure, Japanese score the highest, maybe because of their rigorous and test-ridden schooling.
Mostly with becoming reserve, Americans are celebrating the triumph of their political and economic values over those of the Eastern bloc. Japan, it is widely assumed, is not a rival system but merely an Asian version of Western free market economies. The assumption bears closer scrutiny. The persistent trade crisis between Japan and the United States, probably postponed by Japan's promises last week to open up its markets, strongly suggests a society that marches to different rules.
The order and efficiency of Japanese life flow from strong pressures to conform. Japanese children cram constantly for entry to select schools. By the time they graduate from high school, they have spent four years longer in the classroom than American children. Japanese salarymen enjoy lifetime employment, but since job-switching is almost impossible they must obey the company code. Japanese citizens have few avenues of protest. In the courts, prosecutors win 99 percent of their cases. In politics, a single party has held power for 40 years. A reporters' club system clogs the free flow of news. The result: a highly educated and disciplined work force. Japan also differs notably from Western democracies in its degree of central direction. Its civil servants are a widely respected elite.
They tend to retire early and join the boards of corporations they dealt with when in government. With the aid of this network, civil service decisions rest on excellent information and well-formed consensus. The role of politicians in Japan is mostly to mediate disputes between rival ministries and industries.
As a form of government, Japan's system lacks transparency and public accountability. But its successes are undeniable. Officials have carefully shaped and tended movement into the industries they consider desirable, notably those with high technology and high added value. They have shown superb skill at responding to crises, like the oil shock of 1973. They managed the yen's sharp rise against the dollar with such efficiency that exports to the United States hardly budged. The politicians may reign, but the mandarins in the government quarter of Kasumigaseki allow little political interference in their disinterested management of affairs.
Japanese officials usually bridle at the proposition that their system differs from the West's. But it is no compliment to their skills to suppose Japan is an imitation of America. Its society is more disciplined and directed. Japan's booming prosperity during the 1980's may be suffering some financial setback. But since Japan now invests twice as much per person as America, its superior growth is all but assured for years.
Seeing the vitality in the Ginza's thronged streets, or all the consumer gadgets in the electronics stores in Akihabara, it's easy to think that Japan's distinctive society may hold lessons for others. Technology, capital investment, education - Japan has adapted its society to wield these tools of Western progress with remarkable success.
Western societies are hardly likely to adopt mandarin rule or to compel their citizens to conform, work and save. But maybe there are other ways to secure a highly educated and flexible work force, a government that creates conditions for industry to thrive and a society largely free of hard drugs and street crime.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Air War With Castro Costs U.S. Good Will

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Further on ''Losing an Air War With Castro,'' your March 24 editorial discussing technical problems and political infighting at TV Marti, which beams United States-made television programs to Cuba (and which is overseen by the U.S. Information Agency):
As one totally bilingual in English and Spanish, who was in Havana as keynote speaker at a United Nations workshop on space communications for development, I would like to share impressions I gleaned from workshop participants about the test of TV Marti, which began March 27, the second day of our meeting.
The workshop included some 70 representatives from organizations in Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America, Italy, France, Canada and the Soviet Union. Also attending were representatives of Intelsat, Intersputnik, Inmarsat, Hispasat, Caricom, the International Telecommunication Union, the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization and the sponsoring agency, the United Nations Outer Space Affairs Division. All are concerned with communications and development. 
Informal discussions on the TV Marti test made it evident that no one of this group of high-level and highly skilled professionals could understand why this action is being taken now when, if anything is needed in a world in ferment, it is nonprovocation. My personal concern is for the good will the United States has lost at a time when we are using telecommunications to promote greater international understanding and better relations. In this light, TV Marti seems totally inappropriate.
Aside from the issue of sovereign rights, there are questions of international law. We understand the International Telecommunication Union has called a special meeting of the International Frequency Registration Board to examine the regulations to determine if TV Marti is in violation.
It is a sad commentary on the way the United States is being viewed in Central and South America and elsewhere that the prevailing sentiment in any battle of the frequencies would most likely be opposed to the United States position.
My telecommunications and development colleagues at the United Nations workshop asked me, as the only United States citizen present, to try and explain what is happening and why. I could not give them a good response. It is my hope that the Government will undertake to explain its TV Marti position.
If no reasonable explanation is forthcoming, I would predict that the United States is in for some rocky rides at coming international telecommunications conferences that deal with the allocation and use of frequencies in the broadcasting spectrum.
 
LOUIS A. BRANSFORD
President, Public Service
Satellite Consortium
 Washington, March 29, 1990

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Sadly, a Far Cry From the City He Helped Save

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, was briefing young executives on Tuesday about New York City's future when one asked him to measure conditions today against 15 years ago, when Mr. Rohatyn helped rescue the city from bankruptcy.
Bad timing. At 11 o'clock the night before, as Mr. Rohatyn and his wife, Elizabeth, were walking four blocks home from a seder given by Dr. Paul Marks, president of the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, they passed an elderly couple asleep on the sidewalk, their legs protruding into Madison Avenue.
The Rohatyns were still discussing the couple's plight and the consequences of homelessness when, as they turned onto East 62d Street, a young man snatched Mrs. Rohatyn's Hermes leather purse and sprinted off. 
''When she screamed, I thought he had stabbed her,'' Mr. Rohatyn said.
Asked the next day what had changed in 15 years, Mr. Rohatyn said the incidents on Monday night crystalized one contrast.
''There is a qualitative difference today, both in terms of what you see and what you feel, and what you feel is the constant threat of something that's going to happen to you,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''It is not civilized life to consider yourself lucky when you've been mugged but haven't been killed.''
As active volunteers and philanthropists, the Rohatyns are no strangers to poverty, homelessness and scarce municipal resources. As chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mr. Rohatyn has been a persistent fiscal Cassandra, proved correct by the latest budget crisis. But in contrast with 1975, he said, social and racial pressures threaten the city's survival.
Mrs. Rohatyn said that when she recounted the purse-snatching to friends, she purposely did not mention the thief's race. ''Every single person came back and said, 'Was it a black kid?' '' she said. It was. Mr. Rohatyn said: ''Even though I believe David Dinkins's election has done much to defuse the pressures, there is still a potential problem if things were to get much worse again, and they will.
We are witnessing these kinds of problems when the economy of the city is in only the first stages of a downturn. This anti-social behavior didn't start when the Mayor first discovered there was a deficit.''
Moreover, crime statistics are understated. The Monday night purse-snatching was the third time Mrs. Rohatyn had been robbed in the last few years, none of the incidents being reported to the police. The first time, a bicyclist ripped a gold chain off her neck on Madison Avenue; then someone stole the wallet from her handbag on Fifth Avenue.
''I screamed,'' Mrs. Rohatyn recalled. ''Nobody did anything.''
What she did was alter her own behavior. Freedom, as the song says, is another word for nothing left to lose. The Hermes purse contained only a comb, a plastic compact and a house key.
She also sounded the alarm. ''I was just talking to Barbara Walters,'' Mrs. Rohatyn said. ''She often walks over to Mortimer's. She said, 'I'm not going to do that any more.' I said to my daughter, who's going to dinner two blocks from her apartment, 'Get the doorman to take you there, and the butler who serves dinner to take you home.' And she's 36. I talked to Anne Scarborough. She said she's terrified.''
Nowadays, Mr. Rohatyn said, ''there is no part of the city where the quality of life is acceptable.'' Technology, meanwhile, has made it easier for terrified people to leave town.
''We can move half our office either across the river or to Denver,'' he said. ''I can go live on the outskirts of Phoenix. Maybe I can't do as much business there and enjoy life as much, but it is feasible.''
The Rohatyns, though, are not moving, they said. Nor do they wish to be dismissed as illiberal or as whiners - ''as some rich white person over-reacting, with cab drivers being shot and people in the black community being killed and maimed every day,'' Mr. Rohatyn said.
Rather, he said, he hopes the Mayor and the Governor demonstrate the political will to join community leaders in confronting challenges that cannot be wished away as officials reflexively reduce budgets. Mr. Rohatyn again suggested a municipal wage freeze, a smaller work force and better management. In return, he said, ''people in my world would accept significantly higher taxes'' in the spirit of shared sacrifice that prevailed in 1975.
The encouraging side of what happened on Monday night, he said, was the response of waiters, who, alerted by Mrs. Rohatyn's screams, dashed out of Arcadia to join other passersby in pursuing the purse-snatcher.
''God,'' Mr. Rohatyn said one waiter told him, ''how can they do this to you? You saved the city.''

HEADLINE: Development Brings Discord to Flushing

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
From the busy corner of Northern Boulevard and Union Street in Flushing, Queens, signs of the distant past, vibrant present and uncertain future of this changing polyglot area can be seen in a glance.
Down Northern Boulevard, the wood-shingled Friends Meeting House, a 17th-century Quaker landmark, recalls some of the area's earliest European settlers.
Along Union Street, a row of stores and offices that could be out of an Asian streetscape vividly indicates Flushing's latest arrivals with a profusion of signs in Korean, Chinese and Japanese.
Farther down Union Street, a break in the building line reveals a large parking lot where New York City and a major private developer have proposed a big apartment, office and retail complex - a plan that is vehemently opposed by many residents who insist that there has already been too much development in the area.
 
A Dynamic Retail District
In this sprawling, middle-class slice of northern Queens, where big-city bustle alternates with stretches of suburban-like tranquillity, Flushing's once-declining ''downtown'' commercial section has been rejuvenated in recent years - chiefly by the area's many Asian newcomers - into one of the city's most dynamic retail districts. Several small office buildings and various apartment buildings have also been completed downtown in the last few years. A hotel and other commercial projects are under construction. 
But while proponents of the growth hail it, many other residents deplore the pace and direction of the changes. They say disorderly growth has turned downtown Flushing into a hectic Manhattan-like zone that is harming the quality of local life.
''I definitely think Flushing is at some kind of crossroads right now,'' said Regina Colletta, district manager of Queens Community Board 7, whose jurisdiction covers the heart of Flushing. ''We have a lot of civic groups here, all working for what they think is best for the community.''
But the debate involves more than just Flushing. It also raises a question with citywide implications: How can a fiscally troubled city's need for the tax revenues that accompany redevelopment be reconciled with widespread neighborhood feelings that the changes are for the worse.
The clashing perspectives in Flushing are reflected in the views of two residents, Eileen Loh, a 55-year-old fashion designer turned real-estate developer, and Pam Keating, 48, a freelance illustrator.
''Ten years ago Flushing went down,'' Mrs. Loh said of the decline of Flushing's downtown area in the 1970's. At the time, vacancy rates were growing along Main Street and on Roosevelt Avenue, two of the area's main thoroughfares.
''If we don't have more building, we'll go back to 10 years ago,'' she said. ''We have to face the fact that the structure is changing.'' As she spoke, Mrs. Loh, who arrived in the United States from Taiwan in the 1960's, stood amid the concrete shells of a mall that she and her husband, Henry, are building on 39th Avenue between Prince Street and College Point Boulevard on the fringe of the downtown district.
 
'It's Going Very Vertical'
The Lohs' mall will include nearly 50 stores and restaurants and an outdoor plaza that Mrs. Loh envisions as a site for Asian cultural events. The couple have nearly completed a second, smaller complex of stores and offices across the street.
A block away on 39th Avenue, more construction equipment roars as another developer puts up a 14-story hotel. Two other commercial buildings are rising on Main Street and on Farrington Street.
A mile away, in her clapboard, brick and stucco house on 157th Street near Northern Boulevard, Ms. Keating takes a dim view of this activity.
''Our downtown for a long time was a small-town shopping area,'' she said. ''Buildings used to be three stories, now they're 10, 12. It's going very vertical very suddenly. The whole quality of the place has changed.''
But it is more than just a matter of style and esthetics, she said. ''The infrastructure was not designed for it,'' she said. ''There's no place for anyone to park who would go shopping there. The congestion is impossible. The crowds are oppressive.''
 
The Chirping of Birds
Ms. Keating, a lifetime Flushing resident, is vice president of the Off-Broadway Homeowners Association, comprising 22 families in her vicinity, a suburban-flavored enclave that typifies many parts of Flushing.
In these areas, people live in detached private homes on quiet streets, where the chirping of birds is the most conspicuous sound on a bright spring afternoon. The blare and bustle of downtown seems a world away, as do the apartment-building clusters on stretches of Flushing thoroughfares like Kissena Boulevard and Franklin Avenue.
Overall, Flushing is generally defined as the nine-square-mile area from the Van Wyck Expressway east to Francis Lewis Boulevard and from 25th Avenue south to Union Turnpike.
More than 200,000 people live in the Flushing area. The Asian population -mostly Chinese and Korean but with a conspicuous contingent of Indians -has grown in the last 15 years to between 60,000 and 80,000, with each of these groups having its own concentration of shops and services downtown. The rest of the population is predominantly white.
 
A Moratorium Is Sought
Ms. Keating said that while many local people ''have been upset about overdevelopment in Flushing for years,'' the last straw was the Flushing Center project, a plan by the city and a private development team to build a $180 million apartment and commercial complex on the municipal parking lot at Union Street and 37th Avenue.
The proposal calls for two 16-story towers and a row of town houses with a total of almost 400 condominium apartments; a six-story office building, and a mall with more than 70 stores and a 10-screen movie complex. Many of the area's civic and business groups have vigorously objected to the plan, and the city and the developers - whose managing partner is the prominent builder William Zeckendorf Jr. - are now considering how it might be scaled back to meet the objections, said the community-relations representive for the developers, Raquel Ramati.
Lee Silberstein, a spokesman for the city's Public Development Corporation, which had sought proposals from developers for the city-owned site, similarly promised that his agency would ''work with the community'' in Flushing, whose downtown, he said, produced more retail income - about $250 million a year - than any other retail district in Queens.
But referring to the growing city budget gap, Mr. Silberstein said, ''In this tough fiscal time, the city should be generating more income from such a site than a parking lot provides.''
Such arguments do not convince the recently formed Coalition for a Planned Flushing, made up of more than 30 local civic, church and business goups. In fact, said City Councilwoman Julia Harrison, a Democrat who represents the area and is a leader of the coalition, pressing ahead with even a scaled-back project at this time would be unacceptable.
''We're asking for a moratorium on new construction in downtown Flushing until there is a master plan,'' she said. ''What's happening now is that helter-skelter buildings are going up. Between pedestrian and vehicular traffic and bus terminals it's gridlocked.''
 
A Landmark Theater
Another disputed site is the R.K.O. Keith's, on Northern Boulevard and Main Street, a surviving example of the palatial 1920's movie theater that is now closed. Its elaborate ticket lobby and grand foyer have been declared city landmarks. While its owner, Thomas Huang, a major Flushing developer, has been seeking to build a shopping complex in the nonlandmarked portion, others in the area are demanding that the entire theater be restored.
Some Asians in Flushing say that, given the role of Asian developers and merchants in carrying out most of the downtown changes, they detect an ethnic bias among some of the critics. ''I think it's always below the surface but quite clear,'' said Wellington Chen, 38, an architect and Community Board 7 member who came from Hong Kong in 1970. ''But I think it's a small minority that wants us out, not the majority.''
Mrs. Harrison vehemently denied that anti-Asian feelings were a factor in her coalition. She acknowledged that none of the area's Asian civic groups were in it, but said, ''They've never bothered to affiliate or come.''
For his part, Mr. Chen urged a more amicable discourse over Flushing's future. ''Rather than criticize or indict each other, I hope we can work together,'' he said. ''I don't think this type of squabbling is conducive to a healthy relationship.''

HEADLINE: N.J. Transit Proposes Raising Fares

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 11

 BODY:
N.J. Transit today proposed raising rail fares by 10.9 percent and bus fares by 9.9 percent for transit riders in northern New Jersey, where most of the system's 291,600 daily commuters live.
If the increases are approved after four public hearings next month, it would be the third consecutive year that mass transit fares in New Jersey have gone up.
Facing a $47.8 million budget deficit in the coming fiscal year, the agency's board of directors today also proposed eliminating eight bus routes and six peak-hour trains, cutting 200 employees and making other economies.
Several board members and agency executives said they found such cuts distressing. They said thousands of riders would be driven away by inferior service, much as they were in the 1960's and 70's when bankrupt bus and rail lines, which were predecessors of N.J. Transit, deferred regular maintenance and reduced service. 
 
No Rise in Subsidy
''We're moving in a way that clearly over time means we will deliver less attractive service and less reliable service,'' said George Warrington, chief operating officer of N.J. Transit.
If the fare increases take effect on July 1, bus and rail commuters would be among the first residents in New Jersey to feel the harshness in the state's budget for the next fiscal year. The state's subsidy to N.J. Transit would remain unchanged from this year at $218.5 million, even though revenues from ridership declined while labor and insurance costs increased.
Gov. Jim Florio has offered no additional help, saying commuters may just have to pay more. ''I would expect the transit commissioners to be able to justify to me and to the transit riders of New Jersey any request for fare hikes,'' he said in a statement.
Unlike the last two years, when fare increases were spread across all 154 bus routes and 12 train lines operated by N.J. Transit, as well as 44 private carrier bus routes that the agency subsidizes, this year's increases are restricted to the area of the state north of Trenton.
N.J. Transit officials said the 31,000 bus riders in southern New Jersey (there is no rail service there except the new line to Atlantic City) are being protected because last year's 12.5 percent increases drove away so many passengers that revenue fell by 2 percent during the first six months of this fiscal year from the same period of the previous year.
 
Estimates of Losses
''I take that to be a precursor to what will happen in northern New Jersey next year if these new increases are approved,'' said Eva Lerner-Lam of Tenafly, a public member of the N.J. Transit board. Ms. Lerner-Lam voted against today's proposal, as did one other member of the seven-member board, Prentis C. Nolan 3d of Ridgewood.
Certain long-distance bus routes in northern New Jersey will also be exempt from the increase.
N.J. Transit officials say they expect that raising fares will drive away an additional 8,800 daily bus and rail riders. Eliminating the targeted bus and rail lines would cause the system to lose another 600 riders, the officials estimate.
After several years of ridership gains through the mid-80's, N.J. Transit has been hard hit lately. A slowdown in the economy has substantially cut into the number of passengers, officials said, and the consecutive fare increases over the last two years also hurt. Before last year's fare rise, there were 301,400 daily riders. The current economic slowdown is expected to reduce riders further, and the latest proposals, if they are adopted, could drop ridership to 277,900.
But Ms. Lerner-Lam said she thought that estimate was optimistic, and the representatives of commuter advocacy groups warned that the current proposal could hurt the system far more than predicted.
 
'More Hikes and Cuts?'
A member of the New Jersey Association of Railroad Passengers, William R. Wright of Cranford, said so many riders could be lost with the new increases and service cuts that, as happened on southern New Jersey bus lines last year, N.J. Transit would gain no additional revenue.
''What then?'' Mr. Wright said. ''More hikes and cuts? An accelerated downward spiral until this board finds itself directly responsible for the total collapse of public transit in New Jersey?''
A few transit adovcates urged the board to run the trains and buses until the money runs out and then force the state to find a stable source of funds, claiming that such brinkmanship worked recently in Buffalo, where the transit system was shut down for two days. Board members rejected the idea.
The trains planned for elimination are on the North Jersey Coast, Raritan Valley and Morris and Essex branches. N.J. Transit officials say alternative service is available. Each of the eight bus routes that would stop running now carries fewer than 100 passengers daily, officials said.
In other cuts, more than 200 of N.J. Transit's 8,600 workers would be let go, merit increases would be frozen for six months and employee training would be curtailed. Vehicle-cleaning schedules will be lengthened so that buses are thoroughly washed every other day instead of every day, and trains every three months instead of every two months.

HEADLINE: Political Idealists Trying to Hold Back the Night

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 11

 BODY:
Waldemar Hille joined the Communist Party 48 years ago believing that the movement would create a more compassionate and humane America.
Today, as Communism falters in Europe, the 82-year-old Mr. Hille is fighting to preserve ''an important people's institution,'' a retirement home for political activists.
''We're not just wallowing in resignation here,'' said Mr. Hille, a pianist who is one of nine residents of the home, Sunset Hall in downtown Los Angeles. ''We're fighting for our rights.'' Other residents said their building offered them a special environment of humanistic intellectualism. 
Sunset Hall was founded in 1924 as a retirement home for ''religious liberals'' by the First Unitarian Church of Los Angeles, which was a center of social and political activity at the time. Now the home is threatened by lack of money and dwindling occupancy, and a developer wants to buy it for $26 million and turn it into an apartment house.
Sunset Hall is operated independently from the church, relying on monthly fees of $900 to about $1,400 from its residents, by the income from an endowment, and donations from supporters.
 
Death and Sagging Endowment
The endowment has dropped sharply, and several residents have died or moved. The home's directors announced in February that they planned to close the 36-room building. But there were so many protests from the residents that 10 of the 12 directors and the home's administrator resigned.
The residents are still active politically. They canvassed their neighborhood for the Rev. Jesse Jackson in his Presidential bid in 1984, and they picketed with striking Los Angeles teachers last year. They also persuaded a Superior Court judge to issue a temporary restraining order forbidding the sale or closing of Sunset Hall.
A new board of directors has not yet announced how it will raise the money for Sunset Hall to survive, but there might be a a benefit banquet and a telephone campaign to solicit donations.
Sadie Tomkin, 82, is an old Communist and former manager of ''People's World,'' a Communist newspaper. ''I am very happy that I'm living in a place where I'm free to participate in social issues of the day,'' she said. ''That's the way myself and my husband and most of our friends always lived, identifying with the community issues. We want to keep helping things move ahead, to attain a better life for the working people.''
 
F.B.I., Blacklists, McCarthy
Mrs. Tomkin says she has no regrets about the life she led, despite the questioning and surveillance she says she endured in the 1950's from agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and despite the job loss her husband, a machinist, went through after the House Un-American Activities Committee identified him as a Communist.
Mr. Hille, a pianist who worked with the singers Paul Robeson and Pete Seeger (and was blacklisted along with them in the McCarthy era), now considers himself a ''humanist'' more than a Communist. But he remains critical of the American system.
''Organized capitalism is an evil thing in itself,'' he said in an interview in a shady courtyard of the Spanish-style residence home. ''It's profits versus people.'' He feels the changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are good ''if they reflect the will of the people.'' He is sure his hero, Lenin, would have approved.
Mr. Hille, says he believes the situation in which the Sunset Hall residents find themselves reflects a growing social problem in this country. Last year, as the home's financial situation began to totter, it hired Thomas E. Brandlin as administrator. He tried, but wound up resigning this year.
''Basically, the place is broke,'' said Mr. Brandlin. ''The hall has operated at a deficit for 21 of the last 23 years and recently was losing up to $25,000 a month.'' Economic realities led the board to decide to close the place, and he concurred, he said.
 
Shadow of the Nursing Home
Retirement homes offering the kind of semi-independent living that Sunset Hall offers have high vacancy rates, Mr. Brandlin said, because most older people want to stay on their own as long as possible - until they cannot care for themselves at all and go to the nursing home.
''I was not out to get anyone,'' said Mr. Brandlin, telling why he recommended that the board close the place. ''We were just at the end of our money.'' He said the deficit this year, $95,000, was the worst ever.
The home's residents say bigger questions of social justice are involved. ''The first thing a society, any kind of society, should have on its agenda is to take care of its children, and then of the elderly,'' said Mrs. Tomkin. ''That's the way a decent society anywhere works. But in this country, we're just left high and dry.''

HEADLINE: Helio Smidt, Leader Of Varig, the Airline Of Brazil, Dies at 64

 BODY:
Helio Smidt, the president of Varig Brazilian Airlines, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Rio de Janeiro. 
Mr. Smidt, who was of German extraction, joined Varig, now Latin America's largest airline, at the age of 19 as an office clerk in Porto Alegre, Brazil, where the line was founded in 1927.
He was named regional director for Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo in 1957 and three years later was appointed director of administration and control. He was elected president of the employee-owned airline in 1980 and guided it through some difficult times.
Varig's 28,500 employees own 86 percent of the voting stock of the company through a foundation created in 1945 by stockholders, who relinquished their shares of the company to the foundation.
In 1988, while other airlines in South America were sinking in debt or struggling because of inflation, Mr. Smidt had Varig opening new routes, and adding three Boeing 747's to its fleet of 84 airplanes.
He was also president of the Varig Group, a holding company with 25 subsidiaries and was named Brazil's Man of the Year in 1987.
He is survived by his wife, Norma; a daughter, Eliana Pinto of Sao Paulo, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: An Old Liberal, a New Sermon

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Robert B. Reich is on the stump again. His audience is a cross section of the Washington establishment: nearly 80 lobbyists, politicians, businessmen, economists, union leaders and journalists. They hurried through their luncheon of salmon and asparagus, leaving ample time to hear Mr. Reich speak and to cross-examine him.
Mr. Reich, a Harvard professor, is one of the nation's best-known liberals. In the early 1980's, he popularized the concept of industrial policy, which proposed Government subsidies and incentives to strengthen American industry and overcome the Rust Belt blight. Now, he is getting a new public hearing for a fresh industrial policy, one he contends would make the United States more competitive in the emerging global economy. And this time the appeal goes beyond the liberal movement, embracing free-marketeers, although he still has plenty of critics in that camp.
 
Simple and Vivid Message
Mr. Reich, who is 4 feet 11 inches tall, arrived for the lunch at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group, carrying a worn wooden footstool that he placed behind the lectern in the crowded dining room. His message was simple and vivid, delivered with the certainty of a sermon: Business competition has changed radically, but neither public policy nor public perception has made the adjustment. 
American-owned corporations are no longer the sole source of the nation's competitiveness and living standard, he said. A Philips (Dutch) or a Honda (Japanese) shifts wealth to the United States when they put factories here, just as General Motors factories in Europe shower wealth on that continent at the expense of the United States. Therefore, Government policy should concentrate on getting the world's best companies to put their premier operations here, ignoring nationality. ''We no longer know what the pronoun 'we' means or who is 'us,' '' Mr. Reich said, repeating a favorite phrase.
Among other measures, he wants laws changed so that foreign corporations are allowed to participate in government-financed joint research. Rebuild the transportation system, he says, so any company would want to locate here. And, above all, Mr. Reich believes the Federal Government should foster education and on-the-job training to upgrade the skills of millions of American workers.
Actually, the role Mr. Reich assigns to the Government today is not much different than in 1983, when he emerged as the guru of an earlier industrial policy that also emphasized job training and subsidies. But two important changes have widened Mr. Reich's appeal.
In 1983, he wanted the Government to favor sunrise industries - the emerging makers of specialty steels, electronics, precision-built cars -while allowing low-tech manufacturing to shrink. That alienated many economists who considered market forces to be better than the Government at picking winners and losers.
 
A New Approach
Mr. Reich, a conciliator by nature, no longer disputes this view, arguing instead that the Government must upgrade the nation as a whole so that market forces will, in fact, attract the world's best investments. ''His new approach is a better one,'' said Robert M. Solow, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. ''And he is correct that there are a number of things the free markets tend to neglect, like research and job training.''
In the early 1980's, Mr. Reich and the new liberal movement that he helped shape were also more nationalistic, the goal then being to promote only American-owned companies. Now, nationality is unimportant, and that indifference appeals to many free-marketeers; they endorse unrestricted corporate investment anywhere in the world.
In fact, Mr. Reich's luncheon host, the Institute for International Economics, is an organization of free- marketeers and the institute's director, C. Fred Bergsten, welcomes Mr. Reich as an unexpected ally. ''I want to make the world safe for foreign investment and he wants to harness foreign investment to American interests,'' Mr. Bergsten said.
The speech was Mr. Reich's second appearance of the day. The 45-year-old professor, who teaches political economy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, had just come from the State Department, where he gave a similar address to senior staff members, most of them also free marketeers.
Mr. Bergsten had placed a copy of a Reich article entitled ''Who Is Us?'' at every place setting. The article, which pulls together the professor's evolving thesis, drew wide public attention when it was published in the Harvard Business Review in January. It is a prelude to a nearly finished book that Mr. Reich hopes will be as influential as his 1983 work, ''The Next American Frontier.'' Walter F. Mondale stayed up all one night to read that book and quoted from it as the Democratic candidate for President in 1984.
 
Some are Skeptical
But many of the luncheon guests were skeptical. Howard Samuels, an official of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., disputed Mr. Reich's characterization of the Japanese as good employers, saying that they resist unionization at their American plants. Assar Lindbeck, an economist at the University of Stockholm, said the borrowing required to finance Mr. Reich's Government policies would leave the private sector short of funds. And Michael Maibach, a lobbyist for the Intel Corporation, a California semiconductor company that concentrates most of its operations at home, challenged Mr. Reich's most basic conclusion: that multinational companies are shedding their national ties and operating globally.
Mr. Maibach and others argue that only a handful of huge corporations are truly global. The rest, particularly those in Japan, still try to keep most of their wealth and best technology at home, they contend, shortchanging other countries where they operate. ''The truly global corporation is not yet here,'' said Paul Krugman, an M.I.T. economist who is a co-author of a recent book on the subject.
The implication is that Mr. Reich's research might be faulty, a charge that has emerged in the past, not only for Mr. Reich but also for other economists who attempt to describe broad new trends, basing their conclusions on a mixture of statistics, personal experience, anecdotes and interviews.
Even Mr. Reich's fans acknowledge that his declarations are sometimes too black and white. ''There are times when Bob, in his effort to clarify a point, paints it in more unequivocal colors than I would,'' said Raymond Vernon, a colleague at the Kennedy School who reads the first drafts of Mr. Reich's manuscripts. ''But he is a brilliant popularizer, and he is popularizing ideas that are very important.''
 
Office in Cambridge
Mr. Reich operates from a narrow, cluttered first-floor office in the Kennedy School building in Cambridge, Mass. Two colorful paintings on the walls - both by Mr. Reich - illustrate themes from his 1970's experiences at the Federal Trade Commission, which he joined after completing Yale Law School and working for the Solicitor General's office.
The F.T.C. cases that Mr. Reich handled, as head of policy planning, first made him familiar with the difficulties then dragging down major American industries like auto making, consumer electronics and steel. His first magazine articles in the late 1970's were an attempt to describe the downfall. He has written many books and articles since then.
When President Carter lost to Ronald Reagan in 1980, Mr. Reich went on to the professorship at Harvard, which he has held for a decade. But the ''eye-opening'' F.T.C. experience and the information collected there led eventually to the proposals set forth in ''The Next American Frontier.''
Mr. Reich's research today is intertwined with teaching. He carries a full load: four courses a semester, 120 students, more than 1,000 papers to read. He devotes afternoons to teaching, mornings to writing and nights to more work, with dinner and early evening reserved for his two pre-teen-age sons.
 
Consultant to Corporations
He spends three or four days a month as a corporate consultant; 80 such sessions with executives in the last three years were a major source of information for his forthcoming book.
''We discuss how global resources are allocated, corporate strategies, what the executives expect from government,'' Mr. Reich said. ''I test each of my ideas on 15 or 20 companies in these sessions, and if they are confirmed, then I'll go to the statistics, and if there are anomalies, I work these out.''
Other forces have shaped Mr. Reich's thinking. One is his quest for consensus, in part an outgrowth of his relationship with his father, Edwin. The elder Mr. Reich, a conservative Republican, owned a women's clothing store in rural South Salem, N.Y., where Mr. Reich grew up. ''Probably my greatest political success in terms of persuading anybody of the rightness of my views has been in convincing my father to move from the extreme right to the center right,'' Mr. Reich said.
 
Product of Kennedy Era
Mr. Reich came of age in the Kennedy era and never lost what he described as a feeling of being a Camelot Democrat. After sputnik, President Kennedy's push to overtake the Soviet Union in space ''filled me with patriotism,'' Mr. Reich said.
He was a high school senior when President Kennedy was assassinated. A few months later he graduated as valedictorian in a class of 80 and went on to Dartmouth, where he was caught up in various causes, among them the anti-Vietnam War movement. After Dartmouth came a Rhodes Scholarship, where he first delved into what would become his lifelong interest: the relationship of law, politics and economics.

Reich, standing at center, maintains a full teaching load at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, where he recently instructed a class entitled ''Law, Politics and Industrial Structure.'' HEADLINE: U.S. Role In Aid Bank Draws Fire

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration faces stiff opposition from conservative Republicans, organized labor and some special-interest ethnic groups to American membership in a new regional development bank for Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
The critics are upset with the participation of the Soviet Union, whose demands for loans they expect would divert resources that should be available to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
Two of the leading opponents of the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development are the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and Senator Bob Kasten of Wisconsin, the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee. They have introduced legislation that would require the United States to negotiate a separate Eastern European lending agency with the World Bank, a lending institution that bars Soviet participation. 
 
Seeking Tough Trade-offs
''We're going to force the Administration into making very difficult trade-offs,'' Senator Kasten said today. ''I'm relatively confident that we can block participation of the Soviet Union.''
The critics point to the Soviet Union's tough policies toward Lithuania, which declared its independence last month, as a reason for their opposition. Analysts in Washington say that whether the opponents will succeed in blocking American membership or Soviet participation will depend upon how Moscow handles the crisis of Baltic seccession.
The Administration committed to American participation in the new $12 billion bank at a meeting on Monday in Paris of the 42 governments of the East and West. But the United States' contribution of $365 million depends on a Congressional appropriation, and that is where the battle over participation will be fought.
 
Kirkland Sends Letter
Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., in a letter dated last Sunday, urged Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ''to block U.S. participation in an E.B.R.D. that does not preclude Soviet participation.''
Citing ''Soviet tactics of intimidation and harassment in Lithuania and Estonia,'' the head of the 14-million-member labor organization said American participation would ''send the wrong signal to Soviet authorities of business as usual.''
Like the World Bank, the new regional development bank would provide resources to build ports, highways, schools, hospitals, communications systems and other centers in economically depressed areas of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Details of where the organization is to be based and who will be its president must still be worked out, but are expected to be resolved by the end of next month. The bank will be formally established at a treaty-signing ceremony in Paris on May 30.
With a 10 percent stake, the United States would become the largest single member of the bank. Thirty percent of the capital would be put up in cash with the balance ''callable,'' or available as needed.
The European Community will control 51 percent of the bank's capital, with Japan controlling 8.5 percent.
 
At Least 12 Groups
The American critics also object to establishing still another multilateral lending bureaucracy, after a postwar proliferation of agencies like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the African Development Bank. About a dozen such international organizations exist.
The new bank was proposed by President Francois Mitterrand of France. Many of the analysts see his initiative as a French effort to take a leadership role on assistance for Eastern Europe to balance the emerging power of Germany.
The Bush Administration initially resisted including the Soviet Union, but failed to win its point among the European Governments.
 
Compromise on Borrowing
Rather than pull out of the organization, as it had threatened to do at first, the Administration reached a compromise with the European members to bar Moscow from borrowing more capital than it pays into the bank over three years.
The Soviet Union has 6 percent of the capital, but under the 30 percent cash stipulation, it put up only $216 million, instead of $720 million. Thus, Moscow would be able to borrow no more than $216 million.
Yet under another provision of the compromise agreement, the restriction could be suspended after three years,, which would open up larger loans to the Soviet Union. Eighty-five percent of the members, voting on the basis of their capital strength, would have to approve the measure.
The United States, with its 10 percent stake, could block this only if it got another leading member, like Japan, with its 8.5 percent, to side with it.
 
Brady's Position
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has argued that with or without the United States, the European bank would have proceeded anyway and if the United States were not to participate, Washington would be sending an unwanted signal that it cared little about Eastern Europe.
''If I decide not to go into this thing, what are the conseqeunces of being left out?'' the Treasury Secretary asked recently. ''What kind of position does that present in the world's view of the U.S. interest in the march of these countries to freedom? I can just see the newspaper headlines.''
He said that with the restrictions on Soviet lending now in the bank's charter, the agency represented ''a salubrious way to help these countries make this gigantic move'' toward free markets.
 
European Dominance Cited
But Senator Kasten complained today that the bank would be ''dominated by European policy makers who are indifferent, if not hostile, to growth economics.''
Other critics, like Dr. Edward L. Hudgins, the director of the Center for International Economic Growth at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative policy research organization in Washington, contended that Soviet membership could cause problems for the Eastern European countries.
''The U.S.S.R. could delay or derail loans to these countries if they offended Moscow,'' he said. ''The U.S.S.R. also could block membership of the Baltic republics as they seek to re-establish their independence.''

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on April 12 about a new development bank for Eastern Europe misidentified the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee. He is Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, not Robert W. Kasten Jr. of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: Brazil Reform Seen Hurting U.S. Earnings

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Brazil's new economic reform program, which in three weeks has brought Latin America's largest economy to a near standstill, is expected to have a significant impact on American companies as well.
Johnson & Johnson, the health-care and consumer products company, yesterday became the first big company to announce a write-off because of the impact of the new Brazilian program. Other companies that securities analysts expect to be affected include General Motors, Ford Motor, Caterpillar, Citicorp, Union Carbide and Quaker Oats.
The American companies would first be hurt by a loss of sales if the economy falls into a sharp recession, which is expected if the new economic program is approved intact by the Brazilian Congress. In addition, a devaluation of the new Brazilian cruzeiro is expected, although the size of the devaluation is not yet clear. Such a move would result in lower gains for American companies when their earnings are converted into dollars. 
And American companies that are big exporters from Brazil, like the paper products maker Champion International Corporation, could be hurt if the tax on export earnings is increased.
The $125 million one-time charge against Johnson & Johnson's first-quarter earnings also includes the write-off and restructuring of Johnson & Johnson subsidiaries in several Latin American countries, principally Argentina. The write-off, which amounts to 38 cents a share, was not broken down. Earnings were 95 cents a share in the first quarter last year.
The centerpiece of the economic reform plan, which President Fernando Collor de Mello announced just after his inauguration on March 15, is an 18-month freeze on about 80 percent of the money in bank accounts. The purpose is to reduce consumer spending in order to fight hyperinflation. Prices have surged more than 48-fold in the last 12 months. The plan also includes a sharp reduction in Government jobs and ministries, the sale of state companies to private investors, the end of some subsidies and a reduction in import tariffs.
The Brazilian Congress has approved parts of the program but is still debating the rest of it, including the freeze on bank deposits. A significant easing of this restriction could change the outlook. But it could also dampen hope for the reduction of inflation.
 
Economy Grinds to a Halt
So far, the freeze, combined with the requirement to keep paying laid-off workers, has caused the economy to grind to a halt and raised the possibility of a deep recession. Dealers are not selling cars, cafes and restaurants are closed and hundreds of thousands of workers have been laid off.
Because laid-off workers are getting paid, the new currency is slowly getting into circulation. What makes assessments difficult is the guessing about what people will do with these few cruzeiros - spend them, save them or protect themselves by buying dollars.
Edward Kerschner and William Dinning of Paine Webber Inc. have identified more than 100 companies with affiliates in Brazil. The uncertainty of the situation, however, makes identifying the possible targets much easier than assessing the specific damage.
 
'The Impact Varies'
''The impact varies from company to company, and at this stage it is virtually impossible to quantify the impact,'' Mr. Dinning said.
According to the Paine Webber analysis, the General Motors Corporation, which produced 193,000 cars in Brazil last year, has stopped producing cars now but is still paying the workers. A sharp slowdown in sales could be a major shock because the company counts on profits from Europe and Brazil to offset losses in North America.
Citicorp, the holding company for Citibank, has a large retail banking operation in Brazil, and with two Brazilian banks, it runs the nation's largest credit card operation. The freeze, by curtailing spending, could have a striking impact here. The impact on the company's earnings, which were $1.16 a share last year, would be less than 30 cents a share if the entire credit card operation were shut down, the analysts said.
Caterpillar Inc. has revenues of more than $500 million a year from Brazil, or about 7 percent of its worldwide sales. The Union Carbide Corporation's operations in Brazil accounted for 15 percent of the company's earnings last year. So both companies could be hurt.
The Quaker Oats Company's earnings are expected to be down about $2 million this fiscal year as a result of the Brazilian situation, the analysts said.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
MCI Deal Called Antitrust Test

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher

 BODY:
THE agreement by the MCI Communications Corporation to buy Telecom USA Inc. raises several antitrust issues. The Justice Department's response to the $1.25 billion deal, in which the nation's second-largest long-distance company would buy the No. 4 company, is widely seen as a test case of the Bush Administration's antitrust policy. ''If you're going to challenge a merger, this would be the one,'' said a former regulator who asked not to be identified.
But former Government officials and other experts on the long-distance telephone industry say they doubt that the Justice Department will seek to block the deal. 
The department's reaction may also signal whether the Administration intends to continue the Government's oversight of the telecommunications industry through the judicial system, or instead give a greater role to the Federal Communications Commission.
MCI says its acquisition of Telecom will increase competition in the $52 billion long-distance market because the acquired assets will make it a more fit competitor to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. MCI seeks only to take business from A.T.& T. and does not try to compete directly with the regional telephone companies, said MCI's president, Bert C. Roberts Jr. The Justice Department declined to comment.
The department's current merger guidelines, released in 1982, do not require a general review of the Telecom deal. The Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust act does require MCI to give the department 30 days to decide whether to question the takeover.
The agreement announced on Monday between MCI, with 12 percent of the market, and Telecom, with 1.4 percent, would raise by only 34 points the index the department uses to measure market concentration. The current guidelines call for a review when the move exceeds 50 points in an industry as concentrated as long-distance service, in which A.T.& T. holds two-thirds of the market and U S Sprint has 9 percent.
But some economists have argued that market concentration indexes should not be applied to industries as heavily regulated as long distance. ''The market shares in this industry are as much a result of regulation as company cost structures,'' said Peter Pitsch, a Washington lawyer and until recently the F.C.C.'s chief of staff.
Some academics contend that the Justice Department's guidelines underestimate the extent to which small concerns and potential entrants may discourage market leaders from raising prices. By this criterion, the absorption of America's largest regional long-distance company by a market leader is harder to accept, said Alfred E. Kahn, a Cornell University economist and former chairman of the New York Public Service Commission.
The question raised by Mr. Kahn and other economists and former regulators is whether Telecom, if left alone, could grow into a fourth national competitor. Both MCI and U S Sprint needed more than a decade to become profitable national networks, and there may be cause for concern if these market leaders are then allowed to acquire other businesses trying to follow the same long road, said Eli Noam, a Columbia University economist and New York Public Service Commissioner.
Telecom's sales have been growing by 25 to 30 percent a year, reaching $713 million last year with earnings of $36.9 million. The company has completed 40 acquisitions since its founding in 1984. It has laid an extensive network of fiber-optic cable in Iowa and the Southeast, and developed several innovative products, like a special calling card that allows users to set up conference calls from any Touch-Tone telephone.
Telecom has won a strong base among small and medium-sized businesses, and in the last several years has begun to offer 800 numbers and expanded its national services. It is also the keystone of the National Telecommunications Network, a consortium of six of the largest regional carriers that seeks to coordinate their activities.
Even by the politically sensitive standards of antitrust regulation, the Telecom deal is especially touchy for the Justice Department. On the one hand, the Bush Administration has signaled an interest in increased enforcement of existing statutes, and the Telecom deal is the first large transaction with clear antitrust issues.
But the F.C.C.'s new chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, and other Government officials have been arguing that the F.C.C. should reassert some of the regulatory authority it lost when the Justice Department and Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene oversaw the breakup of A.T.& T. in 1984. A challenge to the Telecom agreement would put the Justice Department back in the center of telecommunications regulation.
The Justice Department also has a longstanding interest in the survival of MCI, having shielded it for many years until it grew into a large corporation able to compete with A.T.& T. In the end, the Justice Department may find itself hamstrung by its commitment to the current merger guidelines, Mr. Kahn said. For this reason, he said, a challenge to the Telecom agreement would be a hard case to win in court.

HEADLINE: Two Enter Guilty Pleas In Tax-Fraud Scheme

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Two businessmen have pleaded guilty to engaging in a tax-fraud scheme that involved more than $4 billion in rigged and bogus transactions in Treasury bills and other Government securities, the United States Attorney in Manhattan announced yesterday.
The men, Jeffrey L. Feldman and Paul J. Foont, pleaded guilty last week in two separate hearings. The indictment, which was handed up in October, stems from a series of transactions in 1981 and 1982 by a number of limited partnerships known collectively as the Cralin partnerships. 
According to the indictment, the scheme involved the creation of illegal losses for tax shelters through engaging in fraudulent securities trades. Those losses were then sold to investors, who could then use them to decrease their income taxes by offsetting other income. The investors did not commit a crime, the Government said.
Both men are charged with one count of conspiring to defraud the United States. They both face a maximum sentence of five years in prison, restitution and a $250,000 fine.
The guilty pleas close another chapter on the largest tax fraud case in history. That case, involving charges against Charles A. Atkins, the managing partner of Securities Groups, an umbrella organization for several investment partnerships, and two associates, resulted in guilty verdicts after a 1987 jury trial. The men were charged with engaging in a series of rigged transactions in Treasury bill futures and other Government securities to create $1.1 billion in fraudulent losses and expenses.
The gradual exposure for the jury to the words and world of Wall Street underscored a crucial aspect of the trial - differentiating for a jury of laymen between the complex and once perfectly legal financing of tax-shelter deals and the crimes Mr. Atkins and his associates had been accused of.
Mr. Feldman and Mr. Foont were charged with conspiring with officials at one of the investment partnerships in the Securities Group, known as New York Hanseatic, a dealer in United States Government and agency securities.
 
Illegal Tax Losses Sold
Hanseatic sold illegal tax losses that were created through phony transactions in Government securities to the Cralin partnerships, said Robert J. Cleary, the assistant United States attorney in charge of the Cralin case. ''They bought the losses and in turn sold the losses to their own investors,'' he said.
But in entering their guilty pleas, the two men admitted that under their supervision Cralin entered into more than $4 billion in fraudulent deals with Hanseatic to create phony losses for tax deductions for its investors.
A prearranged, fraudulent transaction in the securities would be one in which there was no economic risk to either party to the trade. In other words, both sides knew the outcome of the transaction regardless of the market.
As part of the transaction, Cralin paid Hanseatic a fee of $1 million. In return, according to the plea, Hanseatic provided documents to Cralin that made it appear that Cralin had approximately $140 million in tax deductions.
In other words, the two men pleaded guilty to simply buying the illegal tax losses, and then passing them on to their investors.
According to the Government, none of the investors in Cralin or in Hanseatic were held criminally liable for any of the activities. However, they could be found to owe taxes to the Government, as well as interest and possibly penalties.
Mr. Feldman, 42, of Skillman, N.J., will be sentenced on June 28. Mr. Foont, 51, of New York City, will be sentenced on June 21.

HEADLINE: Security Pacific's Net Increases 5%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 11

 BODY:
The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, reported today that first-quarter earnings increased 5 percent, to $188.4 million, from $179.3 million in the period a year earlier.
Earnings were $1.54 a share, unchanged from the 1989 period because of more shares outstanding.
''The continuing growth and strength in our primary markets in California produced the second-best quarterly net income in Security Pacific's history,'' said Robert H. Smith, the company's president and chief executive. Security Pacific's best quarter was the fourth quarter of 1989, when it earned $191.7 million. 
 
'Rather Positive'
Tony Howard, an analyst at Crowell, Weedon & Company in Los Angeles, rated Security Pacific's first-quarter performance as ''rather positive.'' He said, however, that losses in the company's struggling Arizona bank subsidiary would prevent it from matching the performance of some of its California competitors, notably Wells Fargo & Company.
Nonperforming loans and leases increased 6 percent, to $1.74 billion from $1.64 billion. The increase was caused in part by higher international nonperforming credits in developed countries. For example, interest rates have been high in Australia, the company said.
Net interest income, the difference between the interest the company received on loans and investments and the interest it paid on deposits and other borrowed funds, increased 2 percent, to $746.6 million from $733.8 million.
But the net interest margin, the spread between interest paid and interest received, declined to 3.95 percent from 4.21 percent. The margin was pinched because the prime rate was cut in Janaury to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent. The cut gave borrowers of loans at the prime rate a break in interest payments. Additionally, the company sold $750 million worth of credit-card loans, which contain a wide interest margin.
Non-interest income for the quarter increased 11 percent, to $479.6 million from $431.6 million.
Security Pacific's shares were unchanged today, closing at $35.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Efforts to Prop Up the Yen Have Little Effect on Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday in thin trading as dealers shrugged off continued efforts by some European central banks to shore up the Japanese yen.
Currency dealers said the dollar-selling against the yen by some European central banks had little impact on the dollar's level against the Japanese currency, which has been under pressure in recent weeks amid growing signs of a weakening Japanese economy.
Most dealers said they saw the intervention, which followed a similar move on Monday, as orders executed on behalf of the Bank of Japan rather than any concerted effort by the Group of Seven industrialized nations to stem the yen's weakness. 
''It was a token appearance,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia. ''If the central banks wanted to support the yen, they should have sold their own currencies for yen because the yen is weak against all currencies.''
 
Thin Holiday Trading
Trading was described as extremely thin yesterday because of the Passover holiday and in advance of the Easter holiday.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose 0.35 Japanese yen to close at 158.50 yen. It was later quoted at 158.15 yen in London and at 157.95 yen in New York, up from 157.60 yen late Tuesday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6427 in London, up from $1.6345, and $1.6425 in New York, down from $1.6451 Tuesday.
Against the West German mark, the dollar fell to 1.6735 marks in London, from 1.6900 marks Tuesday. It traded at 1.6720 marks in New York, down from 1.6750.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4800 Swiss francs, down from 1.4830; 5.6210 French francs, down from 5.6285; 1,230.25 Italian lire, up from 1,230.16, and 1.1644 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1692.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $374.30 a troy ounce, down 70 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $374.75 an ounce, 75 cents lower.
Gold traded in London at $374.75 an ounce, down from late Tuesday's bid of $375.15. In Zurich, the bid for gold fell to $374 an ounce, from $375.25.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.84 to close at a bid of $375.13 an ounce.
