HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Inch Higher; Trading Light

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading yesterday, as dealers cautiously bought securities in advance of reports on retail sales and producer prices.
A sharp drop in oil prices helped to spur buying early in the session. But oil staged a recovery in the afternoon, and much of the early gains in the credit markets were reversed.
A successful auction of $7.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes also provided some support. 
At the auction, the new notes were sold at an average yield of 8.62 percent, up from 8.02 percent at the last such auction on Jan. 10. That is the highest yield on a seven-year Treasury security since the 9.39 percent yield reached at the auction on April 12, 1989.
''We probably would have had a decent rally if it hadn't been for oil,'' one government bond trader said.
 
Retail Sales Projections
Anticipation of a positive report on retail sales figures for March, to be released this morning, also played a role in the market.
Most analysts are expecting the report to show that overall sales rose by three-tenths to four-tenths of a percentage point last month, continuing a period of slow growth.
''Once you adjust the numbers for inflation, there is not much growth there,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman, a vice president and senior economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. ''It seems as if sales tapered off as we went through the first quarter.''
Dealers are also expecting the March report on producer prices, expected tomorrow, to be positive as well. Mr. Hoffman is projecting that producer prices rose by one-tenth of a percentage point last month as a result of declines in energy prices.
 
Extended Holiday Break
In spite of the essentially positive outlook, an extended holiday break has made most dealers cautious.
The Government securities market will close at 2 P.M. today and will be closed all day tomorrow in observance of Good Friday.
''We have a short day on Thursday, and when the producer price report comes out on Friday a good part of the industry won't be around,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''Those factors make it hard to be anything but cautious.''
Indeed, the market was sluggish for much of yesterday.
''The Refcorp auction on Tuesday provided the entertainment for the week,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc., referring to the troubled sale of 40-year notes by the Resolution Funding Corporation. ''But now, people basically want to beat it out of town.'' 30-Year Bonds Gain 6/32 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 1/4, up 6/32, to yield 8.56 percent. Late Tuesday the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.58 percent.
Among other issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 9/32, up 3/32, to yield 8.60 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 19/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.58 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, down one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates dipped by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.74 percent. And one-year bills fell by seven basis points, to an offered rate of 7.66 percent.
Elsewhere, Baltimore County, Md., offered $119 million worth of bonds at competitive bid in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
An investor group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2010. Coupons on the bonds range from 5.80 percent in 1991 to 7 percent in 2010.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Light Corporation Trading
Trading in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, dealers said. Prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, prices of most actively traded issues rose by about 1/8 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of seven-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Fluff 'n' Stuff on Opening Day

BYLINE: By Ira Berkow

 BODY:
It was the opening of the baseball season, the sun shone - except, of course, in Chicago, where it was a typically gray, windy, mitten-required opening day - the players ran to their positions, the fans ran to their seats, or to shelter under the stands, and the air was filled with cries of ''Play Ball!'' and other glorious nonsense.
There is nothing like opening day to inspire even the most logical, the most pragmatic, the most feet-on-the-turf type person to spring into a rapturous ode on our so-called national pastime.
This thought began to ripen when it was learned that Itzhak Perlman had agreed to play the national anthem at the Mets' opener, which he did, on Monday. A number of years ago I had occasion to visit the celebrated violinist in his apartment on Riverside Drive. He had it on good authority when he moved in that this apartment, quite a large apartment, in fact, was the same one in which Babe Ruth once lived. 
''I believe it,'' Perlman said. ''There were a lot of broken windows. Babe must have practiced a lot.''
Perlman said he never had played the national anthem at a sporting event or a concert, and the inference was that he probably wouldn't.
''I want the standing ovation to come at the end,'' he said, ''not at the beginning.''
But he is a great baseball fan, and it is obvious how he could have been coaxed to stroke his sweet strings at home plate.
And then in the air was also that talk that arises concomitant with the baseball opener in America -I don't know if the winds have carried it to Canada, yet -about new hopes and new dreams and new horizons and new mown and new moon and Newman (Al, Twins second baseman).
''Opening Day is always pretty special,'' said Carlton Fisk of the White Sox, as quoted in The National. ''It's the rebirth of America's pastime after a dormant winter. It's pretty exciting, like when the apple trees blossom and when the cherry trees blossom. It's a time for celebration.''
Even august editorialists, who are generally immersed in the economy and the military and judiciary, often and willingly get their heads turned on opening day. Baseball is still supposed to be the game we played as children, and will always be so to most of us. In reference to the recent lockout of the players by the owners, it was written in The Times that ''strikes are for grumpy grown-ups; baseball isn't.''
The sentiment is laudable, but, of course, the game of baseball on a professional level is the business of baseball, as the editorialists understand, and regardless of how much the ideal is primped with national anthems and cherry blossoms and recitations of youth. Baseball as a business is an unpalatable fact in our fields of dreams, but it is fact nonetheless.
Baseball is the business of professional baseball players, as well as - and this no one seems to argue - of baseball owners.
Many fans and sports commentators resent the salaries ballplayers receive. And the more they get, the more they are resented. This doesn't mean that as soon as the first pitch hits the first bat, or the first catcher's mitt, that the fans won't be cheering. They will, and did.
But you also hear: ''Can you imagine? Mattingly is getting $19 million for five years! I don't care how good he is. No ballplayer should get that kind of money.''
Of course, little of this is heard: ''My God, Steinbrenner is paying him $19 million for five years! Can you imagine how much Steinbrenner has if he can afford that? No owner should have that kind of money.''
But George earns what the marketplace will bear, as does Don. Odd, though, how much we care about these ballplayers. Daily, for example, we've been reading about the new Darryl Strawberry, who, at age 28, says he has changed his life, after 26 days in a rehabilitation center this winter for, according to Strawberry, an alcohol problem. But he also says that this is the first time since he was a boy that he has been ''humble.''
Certainly, we root for anyone with a problem to straighten it out, especially if he strives to, as Strawberry apparently is. But newspapers for years have also been filled with stories about whether this will be the year that Darryl Strawberry grows up.
The consuming interest, however, is based decidedly more on whether he will have a good year with the bat and glove, and lead the Mets to a World Series. If it weren't, we'd be following closely the progress of others who have been through rehabilitation, like a fireman or an airplane pilot or a garbage collector.
''Isn't it terrible,'' a young woman recently said to Marvin Miller, the former executive director of the Major League Players Association, ''that teachers don't earn anything near what a ballplayer makes, and do so much more for society?''
''That's not the fault of the ballplayers,'' said Miller, ''that's the fault of society.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
GORBACHEV BRIEFS VISITING SENATORS

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 12

 BODY:
Visiting American senators said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had talked to them of making radical plans to reform the stagnant economy, but that he had also indicated he had no hard timetable for making such critical changes as price reform.
While various Soviet economists have been speculating on the likely nature of the new economic plan that is to be formed soon, the comment from the senators was the first hint of how Mr. Gorbachev might deal with a central part of the issue.
A package of a score of proposed economic reforms, including some free-market ideas on pricing, banking and taxing policies, is to be offered to Parliament within a few weeks, Soviet officials have said. 
Beyond those plans, however, Mr. Gorbachev has been given increased powers to make emergency decrees, which critics of the current economic spiral say he must use quickly and firmly if the economy is ever to be turned around.
 
'No Specific Timetable'
''He did indicate it would be done in phases with no specific timetable,'' said Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic majority leader, after a two-hour meeting with the Soviet leader, who reportedly described the economic crisis as ''the most critical stage of perestroika.''
Later, the Government press agency Tass quoted Mr. Gorbachev as telling the senators, ''We shall seek to keep processes within the democratic framework, although some of them will overstep it in some respects.''
A crucial element in the promised reform will be Mr. Gorbachev's resolve to use executive power to force unpopular economic cures on the public. In his five years in power, he has been criticized for procrastinating on true reform, fearing the disruption it will mean in Soviet life.
In those five years, the economic crisis has worsened. Mr. Gorbachev has had his economic advisers crafting the latest reform package and is scheduled to consider the final form of the package in meetings this weekend.
As the senators met privately with Mr. Gorbachev at the Kremlin, his Government kept up its steady publicity attempt to prepare the public for the promised radical changes.
 
Price Controls May Fall
The changes will mean that Government controls might be quickly dropped on perhaps 70 percent of Soviet prices, according to the prediction of Pavel Bunich, deputy chairman of Parliament's economic reform committee. He also estimated that up to 70 percent of state-owned properties might soon be leased to individuals or new business collectives.
There have been many such estimates amounting to a running debate in recent weeks by Government economists and deputies. But the only prescription and timetable that counts, Mr. Gorbachev's, has not yet been reliably disclosed.
He told the senators that the deleterious effects of the central command system of the Communist economy have meant that Soviet political reform has moved faster than the economy.
''We do not yet have a system,'' tass quoted him as saying. ''It has not yet taken shape,'' he added, noting the ''difficulties and popular concern.''
''It has become necessary to expedite economic transformation,'' Tass quoted him as saying, stressing that this was one of the main reasons why the presidency recently was equipped with stronger executive powers.

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Soviet Military Is Reported To Reassert Itself at Kremlin

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
The Soviet military, unhappy over President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and its diminished status, is trying to reassert itself in Moscow, specialists from the Rand Corporation said today.
The specialists said that in recent weeks the influence of the military appears to have grown because Mr. Gorbachev needs the armed forces to help deal with regional disputes, particularly the crisis in Lithuania, the republic that is seeking to reassert its independence from the Soviet Union.
The increase in the military's influence may account for the toughened stance Soviet officials took in Washington last week on some arms-control issues, including what limits should be placed on the deployment of cruise missiles, said Arnold L. Horelick, an expert at the Rand Corporation, a research center in Santa Monica, Calif. Mr. Horelick, a former American intelligence analyst for Soviet affairs. said the growing military influence may portend a less accommodating position in talks over German reunification. 
 
Sources of the Findings
The assessments by the experts came as the Rand Corporation released a report on the Soviet military under Mr. Gorbachev that was based in part on interviews with Soviet military officials and a study of the Soviet press. Access to Soviet officials has been possible in recent years as a result of Mr. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or increased openness.
The Rand experts disagreed on whether the resurgence of military influence was temporary.
As the report was issued, a senior Pentagon official told reporters that the Soviet military was afflicted by turmoil in its ranks and was fearful about Mr. Gorbachev's reforms.
The official, Henry S. Rowen, an Assistant Defense Secretary for International Security Affairs, said that many Soviet officers recalled the ''very searing'' disruptions that were caused by Nikita S. Khrushchev's military cuts and that they were worried that this experience was being repeated.
 
'An Organization in Trouble'
Mr. Rowen, who recently returned from a visit to the Soviet Union, said recent reports of desertions and failures of draftees to show up for induction were ''signs of an organization in trouble.''
He said he had no direct knowledge of disputes between Soviet political and military leaders, but added that ''it would be surprising if there were not strains, given what Gorbachev is about.''
After the arms talks last week, some Administration officials speculated that the tougher Soviet stance on cruise-missile issues may reflect the growing influence of the Soviet military as Mr. Gorbachev tries to deal with the crisis in Lithuania.
But other officials say that too much is being made of this theory, suggesting that the Soviet approach on arms control may be the result of bargaining tactics.
Just what lies behind Moscow's latest arms-control approach may not be clear to American officials until mid-May, when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d flies to Moscow for a final round of arms talks before the summit meeting between President Bush and President Gorbachev.
The Rand report also said Mr. Gorbachev had quietly orchestrated a wholesale replacement of senior Soviet officers in an effort to bring the military under tight civilian control.
In the first six months of 1989 alone, 12 top-level commanders were replaced, the report said.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Estonian Parliament Votes To End All Military Service

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 12

 BODY:
The Estonian Parliament has voted overwhelmingly to end all military service in the republic, in a move certain to increase tension between Moscow and the independence-minded Baltic republics, Estonians said today.
After a bitter and rambunctious debate, the legislators voted 71 to 3 late Wednesday night to rescind Soviet constitutional articles governing the draft. Angered by the proposal, 27 pro-Moscow deputies refused to take part in the vote.
Military service has become one of the most contentious issues between Moscow and the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as they seek to regain the independence they lost in 1940. 
Stalin forcibly annexed them to the Soviet Union after concluding a nonaggression treaty with Nazi Germany that included secret protocols dividing Europe into spheres of influence. Gorbachev's Warning to U.S. The Kremlin's attempts to press the Baltic republics to abandon their calls for independence have provoked words of warning and caution from many Western countries, including the United States.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that if the United States continued to preach to Moscow about its policy toward Lithuania, relations between the two countries could suffer.
Speaking to a delegation of seven United States Senators, who asked the Soviet leader to comment on his policy toward the breakaway republic, Mr. Gorbachev said Lithuania's provocative actions - declaring independence and suspending the Soviet Constitution on March 11 - had caused the current crisis, the official Soviet press agency Tass said.
The United States Senate and Congress have passed resolutions urging President Bush to recognize independent Lithuania as soon as possible. In a two-hour meeting with Mr. Gorbachev today, the Senate delegation repeated that the use of force in Lithuania would seriously damage United States-Soviet relations, the delegation leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, said at a news conference here.
 
'Political Methods Are Better'
Tass said Mr. Gorbachev responded to the Senators by saying that ''we do not need to be convinced that political methods are better.''
''Not everything depends on us, however,'' said Mr. Gorbachev, whose Administration has been bristling lately at American warnings about Soviet tactics in the Baltic republics. ''And Senators, like Americans in general, should realize this and avoid giving lectures. They might prompt resentment in our society, affecting Soviet-American relations.''
 
Routes to End of Soviet Rule
Moscow says that any republic has the right to leave the Soviet Union through a new law on secession that establishes various steps for the procedure. But all three Baltic republics insist that since they never legally joined the Soviet Union, they do not need to follow Soviet procedures to leave.
The Lithuanian and Estonian Parliaments have each, through different means, declared Soviet rule invalid on their territories and say they are in the process of re-establishing their independent statehood. The Latvian Parliament, which is scheduled to convene May 3, is expected to make a similar move.
Caught up in the political maneuverings over independence are thousands of young Baltic men who are refusing to be conscripted into the Soviet Army or are deserting their posts before their terms are completed.
Military officials and Kremlin leaders have threatened to prosecute young men who fail to fulfill their mandatory military obligations. Organizations in all three republics have sprung up to support and protect young men who refuse to serve in the Soviet military because they consider it an occupying army and who are often harassed by fellow soldiers who resent the independence drives in the Baltics.
 
Tug-of-War Over Soldiers
A group called Geneva 49 was established in Estonia in October, and has so far registered more than 3,500 men who have left their units or are refusing to answer their call to the draft or to retraining.
Soviet leaders are particularly incensed by moves to evade army service - and by official support for such actions by the Baltic republics - because they consider it a serious violation of national security and military prestige.
Moscow and Lithuania waged a tug-of-war over Lithuanian soldiers who abandoned their army service and were given refuge by a special parliamentary commission there. The Kremlin's most dramatic show of force in Lithuania, the sending of more than 100 tanks and military vehicles through Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, last month, came on the day of a deadline the military had set demanding that deserters and draft dodgers turn themselves in.
Several days after the deadline had passed, armed soldiers broke into two hospitals where some of the young men had been hiding and arrested them. Lithuanian officials say the military continues to search for the young Lithuanian soldiers.
 
Estonia Outlaws Soviet Draft
The Estonian Parliament went ahead with its decision outlawing the draft despite Moscow's moves againsts army evaders in Lithuania and despite a visit to the republic on Saturday by First Deputy Defense Minister Konstantin Kochetov, who insisted that the spring draft proceed as planned in Estonia.
The new Estonian law states that, as a result of Parliament's decision March 30 declaring Soviet sovereignty over Estonia illegal and announcing the beginning of a transitional period to independence, ''compulsory service in the Soviet Army is not lawful'' in the republic.
''It is a most logical step on our road to independence,'' said Lennart Meri, a leader of the Estonian independence movement and an adviser to the Estonian Government. ''A person cannot be forced to serve in the army that has occupied his country and that he is trying to be free of.''
The new law goes into effect immediately, in the midst of the current spring call-up for the Soviet military.
Tass condemned the law, saying it ''prods hundreds of youth to violate the Soviet law on universal military service and the U.S.S.R. Constitution.''
 
Estonians to Meet With Kremlin
A delegation of Estonian officials, headed by President Arnold Ruutel, is scheduled to meet in Moscow on Saturday with Kremlin officials for talks on the republic's course to independence.
The Estonian Parliament was also informed today that the new Estonian Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar, a leader of the popular front and a former minister of the state planning commission, would meet with the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, sometime next week.
In further defiance of Moscow's demand that they curb independence campaigns in their republics, the three Baltic Prime Ministers signed an agreement today to form a common Baltic market.
The treaty, adopted and signed at a meeting today in the Vilnius, includes an agreement to band together in their relations with the Soviet Union and in forming economic ties with foreign countries and calls for each republic to issue its own currency.
The Kremlin has specifically warned against many of the actions the Prime Ministers agreed to, such as starting independent monetary systems.

GRAPHIC: photo: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, meeting yesterday with Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, at the Kremlin. Mr. Gorbachev was quoted as telling a delegation of seven American Senators that the economic crisis is ''the most critical stage of perestroika.'' At left was an interpreter. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSH AT G.O.P. HIGH IN BLACK APPROVAL

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
After more than a generation of unswerving loyalty to the Democratic Party and its leaders, black Americans have given George Bush the highest level of sustained approval for any Republican President in 30 years, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll and a series of follow-up interviews.
Many blacks make it clear that their approval largely reflects a feeling of relief that Mr. Bush has given them no reason to oppose him. Blacks say they find the President a vast improvement over his predecessor, Ronald Reagan.
''He's fair, compared to the last one we had,'' said Lawson Kilgore, a storeroom clerk in the Cincinnati area.
 
Approval Rate Put at 56%
Mr. Kilgore was among the 56 percent of black Americans in the latest survey who said they approved of the job Mr. Bush was doing as President. Shortly after the American invasion of Panama in December, a move that was widely popular among almost all Americans, 70 percent of blacks said they approved of his work. 
The survey is the fourth consecutive New York Times/CBS News Poll in the last six months in which a majority of blacks said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of his job. In the latest survey, 26 percent of blacks said they disapproved of the job he was doing.
In the survey, which was conducted by telephone from March 30 through April 2, 1,515 adult Americans, including 403 blacks, were questioned. The margin of sampling error for the entire survey is plus or minus three percentage points; for blacks, it is five percentage points.
After noticing Mr. Bush's strong stand among blacks in the last three polls, The Times and CBS News took two extra steps in this latest survey to delve black opinion. Several questions were added to the survey and a larger than usual number of blacks were included in the survey to increase the accuracy of the findings.
 
Approval Remains Tentative
Even though Mr. Bush was elected in a campaign that Democrats said used racially divisive themes, Mr. Bush's approval in office has slipped below 40 percent among blacks only once - last May. It has remained above 50 percent since his speech last September declaring war on drugs.
But in the poll and in follow-up interviews, blacks made it clear their approval remains tentative.
''Definitely lukewarm,'' said Joanne Clark, a schoolteacher in Camden, N.J. Ms. Clark told the poll takers she approved of the job Mr. Bush was doing. But in a follow-up interview she disclosed the complexity of her attitude toward the President.
''It's not negative so I guess it is pretty good,'' she said. ''I wouldn't actually say I think he's doing a good job in any particular area. It's just I had such a low opinion before he took over the Presidency. I guess since he hasn't gotten us into any major wars and the economy hasn't completely fallen through, I guess he's doing a good job.''
One-third of the blacks in the survey, and 46 percent of whites, said their opinion of Mr. Bush had improved since he became President.
 
'Unbelievably Deceptive'
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, said Mr. Bush's high standing represented a failure on the part of the Democratic Party to demonstrate that Mr. Bush's reassuring words were not matched by action.
''He says, 'I'm the education President,' '' the chairman said of Mr. Bush. ''He says, 'I'm the environmental President.' The guy's unbelievable -and unbelievably deceptive.''
Both in general and on specific issues, blacks are more sceptical than whites, who approve Mr. Bush's handling of his job 75 to 14 percent. Blacks divide evenly, for example, on whether Mr. Bush is doing a good job handling the war on drugs, while whites approve 56 percent to 35 percent.
''I dont think he's doing enough to fight drugs,'' Ms. Clark said.''I don't think he's doing enough for the environment. At the same time, I don't feel any great hatred toward him. He's O.K. as long as he doesn't do anything really negative.''
Modern Republican Presidents have occasionally achieved majority support among blacks, but only for a short while. The last Republican President to sustain such support was Dwight D. Eisenhower, who maintained an approval rate of 50 percent or greater among blacks in Gallup Polls from 1955 through the start of the 1960 Presidential campaign, in which John F. Kennedy, made several gestures of support to blacks.
 
Republicans Hope for a Shift
Republicans have been expressing the hope that blacks' approval of Mr. Bush is the begining of an important shift in political attitudes, a weakening of the most solid part of the Democratic base.
Democrats remain sceptical that Republicans can make inroads among blacks. In the survey, only one out of 10 blacks said they would probably vote for Mr. Bush against the Democratic candidate in 1992, but another 20 percent said it would depend on the candidates.
If they do vote for Mr. Bush, it would be a considerable breakthrough for Republicans. On Election Day in 1988, 12 percent of black voters said they cast their ballots for Mr. Bush over Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic candidate, according to The New York Times/ CBS News survey of voters as they left the polling places.
Interviews with blacks suggest that Mr. Bush is benefiting from an unhappiness with the Democratic Party in which they and their parents and often their grandparents have placed so many hopes.
 
Attitudes Seen as Changing
''It's changing,'' Mr. Kilgore, the storeroom clerk, said of black attitudes toward the Democrats. ''I've been a Democrat just about all my life,'' said Mr. Kilgore, who is 54 years old. ''They don't seem to be doing what they say they're going to do. They're not putting blacks in positions they say they're going to get. They say, 'We've got you now.' They take you for granted.''
Democrats say these sentiments are mistaken, but former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, a Republican, said attitudes like Mr. Kilgore's presented an enormous opportunity for the Republican Party.
''They're trapped between a party that takes them for granted and a party that thought it had no chance,'' said Mr. Kean, who was more succesful than virtually any recent Republican candidate for major office at winning black votes. ''You have a real desire out there for an alternative - to have the same chance everybody else has.''
The former Governor said the key was for the Republican Party to clearly embrace civil rights, at which point it could speak to black voters on other issues pretty much as it would speak to any other group of voters.
Indeed, when asked to identify themselves as liberal, moderate or conservative, black voters divide almost exactly in the same proportions as whites - about 20 percent liberal, 40 percent moderate and 30 percent conservative.
 
Some Interesting Patterns
Among blacks, there are several interesting demographic patterns. For example, the best educated blacks have both the most favorable opinion of Mr. Bush and the most unfavorable opinion of Mr. Reagan. Younger blacks are more likely than older blacks to express approval of the Republican Party, although in all age groups the Democratic Party remains the overwhelming favorite.
Many blacks seem to have forgotten or have forgiven Mr. Bush for some elements of his 1988 campaign, particularly his use of advertising involving Willie Horton, the black convicted murderer who walked away from a Massachusetts prison furlough program and raped a woman in Maryland.
Lawrence Bobo, a professor of sociology at the University of Wisconsin, suggested that in the minds of many blacks the campaign was the responsibility of people like Lee Atwater, now the Republican national chairman, rather than Mr. Bush himself.
Mr. Bush's test, Professor Bobo said, will be what happens on civil rights issues, not what has happened. ''Bush hasn't had a strong test on these issues and he hasn't done anything seriously damaging of the sort that seemed to happen repeatedly in the Reagan Adminstration,'' the professor said, adding that he would expect a drop in Mr. Bush's approval ratingwhen ''a clear-cut stand comes on these affirmative action issues.''
 
A Juxtaposition of Views
This may occur if Mr. Bush vetoes legislation that would override Supreme Court decisions limiting the reach of the courts in matters involving civil rights and affirmative action.
Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has warned that the President may veto the bill, which has been approved by a Senate committee. His warning became known the same day Mr. Bush went before a dinner and spoke glowingly about how some day there would be a black President.
This juxtaposition, which infuriated some black politicians at the dinner, honoring the Joint Center for Political Studies, is also beginning to filter out to other blacks.
''On important issues, the real big important issues where it affects the minorites,'' said Ruby Tilghman, a unemployed home health care worker in West Philadelphia, ''he's doing it in a roundabout way where it doesn't look like he's aganst us, but he is.''

HEADLINE: $2.7 Million Awarded In Aeromexico Crash

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 12

 BODY:
A Federal court awarded more than $2.7 million for damages on Wednesday to the family of a man who died with his son in the crash of an Aeromexico jet after it collided with a small plane over Southern California in 1986.
Judge Manuel L. Real of Federal District Court here ruled that the family was entitled to $2,733,666 in compensation for economic and personal losses for the deaths of Joe Guzman, 45 years old, and his son Robert, 18. The judge ruled that the family was to receive $1.7 million from the United States Government and $1 million from the estate of the pilot of the small plane, which is to be divided among the families of the victims and is unlikely to be able to provide the full amount.
A Federal jury last April held the Government, because of the actions of an air-traffic controller, and William Kramer, the small plane's pilot, equally to blame for the accident.
Mr. Guzman, a Norwalk truck driver, and his son were returning to Los Angeles from a fishing vacation in Baja California on the Aeromexico DC-9. The crash killed 66 people on the planes and 15 people on the ground in Cerritos, 20 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

PUB-DATE: April 13, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3199 words

HEADLINE: Winners of the 1990 Pulitzer Prizes in Journalism and the Arts

 BODY:

Public Service
The Philadelphia Inquirer
The Philadelphia Inquirer was cited for distinguished public service for a series of articles by Gilbert M. Gaul that disclosed major shortcomings in Federal regulation of the nation's blood banks. The five articles told how, beginning in the early 1980's, the Food and Drug Administration reduced its inspections of the country's 2,000 blood banks and commercial plasma centers at the very time that acquired immune-deficiency syndrome was beginning to threaten the blood supply. The articles led to the opening of a major Congressional investigation into the blood industry late last year. Mr. Gaul, 38 years old, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1979 for local reporting. 
 
The Washington (N.C.)
Daily News
The Washington (N.C.) Daily News, a family-owned newspaper with an editorial staff of nine people, was cited for ''meritorious public service'' for more than 25 articles revealing the contamination with carcinogens of the municipal water supply, which local officials had knowingly concealed for eight years. The disclosures by the 81-year-old paper, which serves a town of 9,000 people in eastern North Carolina, led state officials to require that all municipalities test their drinking water and make the results public. Previously, only communities of 10,000 or more were required to test. The articles, written by Betty Gray, 35 years old, and Mike Voss, 32, are also believed to have contributed heavily to the electoral defeats last year of the mayor and three of the five city councilmen.
 
General News Reporting
The San Jose (Calif.)
Mercury News
The newspaper's staff won for its detailed coverage of the Oct. 17, 1989, earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area and its aftermath. Robert Ingle, the executive editor, said 300 reporters, photographers and editors were involved in the quake coverage. Within five hours of the quake, the paper published stories, photographs and graphics that occupied the first 12 pages without any advertising. The most intense coverage occurred during the five days that followed the quake, Mr. Ingle said. During that time, he said, the paper published 70 pages devoted entirely to the quake.
 
Investigative Reporting
Lou Kilzer
and Chris Ison
The Minneapolis-St. Paul
Star Tribune
Lou Kilzer, 39 years old, and Chris Ison, 32, won for a two-part series that exposed a network of local citizens who had familial and business links with members of the St. Paul Fire Department and who profited financially from fires, some of suspicious origin. Their articles led to the suspension of the Fire Chief and to Federal investigations into the relationships. Mr. Kilzer is a Yale graduate who joined The Star Tribune in 1987 after working as a reporter and editor for The Denver Post. At The Post, he was the lead reporter on a series on missing children that won the 1986 Pulitzer Public Service award for the paper. Mr. Ison, a graduate of the University of Minnesota, worked for The Duluth (Mich.) News-Tribune before joining The Star Tribune in 1986 as a St. Paul city-government reporter.
 
Explanatory Journalism
Steve Coll
and David A. Vise
The Washington Post
Steve Coll, 31 years old, and David A. Vise, 29, were honored for their four-part series that scrutinized the Securities and Exchange Commission and the way it has been affected by the policies of John S. R. Shad, chairman of the commission from 1981 to 1987. The purpose of the series was to throw light on the workings of an important and complex agency that is little understood by the public. Mr. Coll, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Occidental College in Los Angeles, joined The Post as a reporter in 1985 and served as New York financial correspondent from 1987 to 1989. Last summer, he joined the paper's foreign staff and is now the correspondent in New Delhi. Mr. Vise, a magna cum laude graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, joined The Post in 1984. A national business reporter, on Monday Mr. Vise will become the newspaper's local business editor.
 
Specialized Reporting
Tamar Stieber
The Albuquerque Journal
Tamar Stieber's articles noted the connections between a rare blood disorder and a nonprescription drug, L-tryptophan, a dietary supplement used by some to treat insomnia, premenstrual syndrome and depression. The drug has since been recalled by the Federal Government, and physicians have credited the articles for helping identify many cases of the illness that would have gone undetected and for saving time, money and suffering. Her first article was based on a tip from a Journal news stringer about four friends who were suffering unusual cases of the flu, two of whom were taking L-tryptophan. Ms. Stieber, 34 years old, did not take her first full-time reporting job until 1987, when she joined the twice-weekly Sonoma, Calif., Index-Tribune. She has been at The Journal since May 1989.
 
National Reporting
Ross Anderson
Bill Dietrich
Mary Ann Gwinn
and Eric Nalder
The Seattle Times
The four reporters were part of a team of nearly 35 Times reporters, artists and photographers covering the Exxon Valdez oil spill and its aftermath - a story that the newspaper regarded as especially important because of Seattle's ties to Alaska, said David Boardman, an assistant city editor. The Times avoided ''clinical'' reporting and ''very much told it as a human story,'' he said. Mr. Anderson, 42 years old, is The Times's chief political reporter, but is on leave writing a book about Alaska fishermen and the oil spill. Mr. Dietrich, 38, has has covered the environment since returning from a Nieman Fellowship at Harvard University in 1988. Ms. Gwinn, 38, a feature writer for the newspaper's Sunday magazine, has worked at The Times for seven years. Mr. Nalder, 43, has been the newspaper's chief investigative reporter since 1983.
 
International Reporting
Nicholas D. Kristof
and Sheryl WuDunn
The New York Times
Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times won the international reporting award for their ''knowledgable'' coverage of the democracy movement in China and its subsequent suppression last spring. Mr. Kristof, the Beijing bureau chief since October 1988, and Miss WuDunn, a bureau reporter since March 1989, were cited for a series of articles chronicling the tragedy, many written under perilous circumstances after Chinese troops attacked young demonstrators near Tiananmen Square. On May 20, for example, while Mr. Kristof was describing how a throng of a million Chinese had taken to the streets to defy martial law, Miss WuDunn told of how Government troops, awed by the spectacle, were refusing to put down the protests. Mr. Kristof and Miss WuDunn, both 30 years old, are the first husband and wife team to win simultaneous Pulitzer Prizes in journalism. In 1968, Will and Ariel Durant won the Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction.
 
Feature Writing
Dave Curtin
Colorado Springs (Colo.)
Gazette Telegraph
Mr. Curtin, a police and general assignment reporter, won for his feature story about the rehabilitation of a family after a propane gas explosion severely disfigured three members. ''I'm in a state of shock and disbelief,'' said Mr. Curtin, who is 34 years old. ''I guess that's what everybody always says, but it's the truth.'' In writing the story, Mr. Curtin followed the father and two of his children, 4 and 6 years old, through their hospitalization. He watched as the children struggled to cope with the reaction of their schoolmates when they returned to school. He ate with the family and slept one night in their home in an effort to understand their pain. ''The fact is, disfiguring burns scare people,'' Mr. Curtin said.
 
Commentary
Jim Murray
The Los Angeles Times
Jim Murray, who won a Pulitzer for his sports columns, has been documenting the egos and emotions of the athletes and characters who people the sports world for more than three decades. He was covering Hollywood for Time magazine, lunching with the likes of Marilyn Monroe and Jack Benny, when Henry Luce decided to launch the sports magazine that eventually became Sports Illustrated. Mr. Murray, now 70 years old, was on the staff at the beginning. ''There weren't very many people at Time who knew anything about sports,'' he recalled. ''I was one of maybe six or eight.'' Mr. Murray has received 14 National Sportswriter of the Year awards, 12 of them consecutively, for the sports columns that have run in The Los Angeles Times since 1961.
 
Criticism
Allan Temko
The San Francisco Chronicle
Allan Temko won for architecture criticism that blends social commentary with analysis of buildings and the environment. Among Mr. Temko's pieces were an argument for preserving a historic rail station threatened by demolition and a set of proposals for the Presidio, a large plot of land abutting the San Francisco Bay where the Army is closing a post. Mr. Temko, 66 years old, was born in New York City and attended Columbia University and the Sorbonne; he has worked for The Chronicle since 1961. He advised President John F. Kennedy and Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown of California on environmental politics.
 
Editorial Writing
Thomas J. Hylton
The Pottstown (Pa.) Mercury
The editorials that won the Pulitzer Prize for distinguished editorial writing for Mr. Hylton represent a longstanding interest in land preservation. The series of seven editorials advocating a $50 million bond issue to preserve farm land and open space in Chester County led to approval by 81 percent of the voters for the measure in a referendum last year. ''It is great to win the award, but it is more important to save the rich farm land around here from mindless development,'' Mr. Hylton said yesterday. Mr. Hylton, 41 years old, graduated from Kutztown (Pa.) State College in 1970 and joined The Mercury the following year.
 
Editorial Cartooning
Tom Toles
The Buffalo News
Tom Toles, 38 years old, who won the Pulitzer Prize for editorial cartooning, prefers to focus his artistic vision on environmental issues and on matters of economic justice, and the topics that won him the award included the savings and loan bailout, the rebellion in Tiananmen Square and the potential reunification of Germany. The particular sketch cited in the award, ''First Amendment,'' dealt with what Mr. Toles considered hypothetical restrictions that would be imposed on the exercise of free speech by a Constitutional amendment prohibiting flag burning. Since 1982, when he joined The News, his work has been syndicated by the Universal Press Syndicate.
 
Spot News Photography
The Oakland Tribune
A team of seven photographers won for their coverage of the devastation of the Bay Area earthquake of Oct. 17, 1989, particularly the collapse of the Cypress Freeway, in which 44 people died. Although The Tribune's building is just 10 blocks from the freeway, the staff got the paper out on time, said Leroy Aarons, senior vice president for news. One of the prize-winning pictures was a shot of medics lowering a victim over the railing of the freeway. That photograph was the work of Michael Macor, 33 years old, a native of Chester, Pa., who moved to the Bay Area when he was 2. Other pictures showed a victim with the rubble of the freeway in the background and a woman holding her arms aloft in a ''V'' during a memorial service. Ron Riesterer, 50, who was born in Sublimity, Ore., and joined The Tribune in 1958, directed the photo operations.
 
Feature Photography
David C. Turnley
The Detroit Free Press
David Turnley won for his portfolio documenting the year of revolutions from the massacre in the area around Tiananmen Square in China to the downfall of the Romanian leader Nicolae Ceaucescu and the demise of the Berlin Wall. Currently based in Paris, Mr. Turnley, 34, has been with The Free Press since 1980. He is a graduate of the University of Michigan and has studied at the Sorbonne. Yesterday, Mr. Turnley dedicated his prize ''to all the people I've witnessed who've put their lives on the line so their brothers and sisters can have a better life.''
 
Fiction
Oscar Hijuelos
''The Mambo Kings
Play Songs of Love''
''The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, is Mr. Hijuelos's second novel, the story of two young Cuban musicians who make their way up from Havana to the grand stage of New York during the era of the mambo in 1949. The high point in the career of the fictional Castillo brothers comes when they meet Desi Arnaz and appear on the ''I Love Lucy'' show. The novel paints a portrait of the brothers, their families, their fellow musicians and lovers, and it also brings to life the sights and sounds of an era in music and unsung moment in American life. The 38-year-old novelist is a New Yorker of Cuban parentage who received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from City College of New York.
 
Drama
August Wilson
''The Piano Lesson''
Mr. Wilson's award for ''The Piano Lesson'' is his second Pulitzer Prize for drama; he won his first in 1987 for ''Fences.'' ''It adds fuel to the fire,'' Mr. Wilson said yesterday. ''It makes me want to do more work.'' Until less than a decade ago, he was a little-known poet; then the manuscript of a play he had written was discovered by the director Lloyd Richards at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Connecticut. That play was ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' which opened on Broadway in the 1984-85 season and won much critical praise. ''Ma Rainey'' was followed on Broadway by ''Fences'' - which won the Tony Award for best play as well as the Pulitzer - and ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone.'' They and ''The Piano Lesson'' - the story of a dispute between a brother and sister over a piano that has involved their family since the days of slavery - are part of a series of plays that Mr. Wilson is writing, one for each decade, on the life of black Americans in the 20th century. The newest, ''Two Trains Running,'' is now at the Yale Repertory Theater. Mr. Wilson, who will be 45 years old on April 27, lives in St. Paul, Minn.
 
History
Stanley Karnow
''In Our Image:
America's Empire in the Philippines''
Mr. Karnow won for his study of the relations over more than three centuries between the Filipinos and, first, the Spaniards, then the Americans, and finally, among themselves in governing the islands. ''In Our Image: America's Empire in the Philippines'' published by Random House, includes portraits of colonial grandees, American Civil War soldiers and corrupt politicians. In a long career as a foreign correspondent, Mr. Karnow, 65 years old, has reported from Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Asia. Mr. Karnow's books include ''Southeast Asia,'' ''Mao and China: From Revolution to Revolution'' and ''Vietnam: A History.'' Mr. Karnow was born in New York City and lives in Potomac, Md.
 
Biography
Sebastian de Grazia
''Machiavelli in Hell''
''I like the man,'' said Sebastian de Grazia yesterday, speaking of Machiavelli. ''I like the texts he's written. And I like the way he comported himself.'' Mr. de Grazia's biography seeks to portray a more complex man than is commonly imagined and draws extensively on Machiavelli's own words. Not just his political works are quoted, but also letters, plays, and sonnets. ''No one thought of Machiavelli as being the life of the party; yet he was,'' Mr. de Grazia said. ''He could be very funny.'' In the book published by the Princeton University Press. The author helps set the personal tone of the book with his decision to address his subject by his first name: Niccolo. Mr. de Grazia, 72, received his Ph.D from the University of Chicago, served with the O.S.S. during World War II and has taught political philosophy at Rutgers since 1962. Given his admiration for his subject, why then the title of ''Machiavelli in Hell''? It is a question that Mr. de Grazia has been asked before. ''I did not consign him to hell,'' he says, laughing. ''If anything, I helped let him out of it.''
 
Poetry
Charles Simic
''The World Doesn't End''
When Charles Simic's high school friends in Oak Park, Ill., began writing poetry, he thought they were sissies. ''I wanted to show them I could do it better in five minutes,'' he said yesterday. ''But I couldn't. And I got hooked.'' Mr. Simic, 52 years old, has been writing poetry ever since, including the eight years he spent working his way through night school at New York University. ''The World Doesn't End,'' published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, is a collection of prose poems, which Mr. Simic described as an underappreciated form. The images in his work are both accessible and fantastic. A dead man climbs from a scaffold and orders two beers - one for him and one for his head. A woman uses a severed thumb as a red stub of lipstick. ''We were so poor I had to take the place of the bait in the mouse trap,'' one of his poems begins. Mr. Simic, who calls himself a fan of garlic and pigs' feet, was born in Yugoslavia and moved to the United States when he was 15.
 
General Nonfiction
Dale Maharidge
and Michael Williamson
''And Their Children
After Them''
''People on welfare and homeless people weren't anything shocking or new, since I grew up in a lot of foster homes,'' Michael Williamson, a 33-year-old photographer with The Sacramento Bee, said yesterday. He and Dale Maharidge, a 32-year-old Bee reporter, ''wanted to go to the roots of poverty and we'd both read 'Let us Now Praise Famous Men''' - James Agee and Walker Evans' influential 1941 book about Alabama sharecroppers. To produce their book, ''And Their Children After Them'' (Pantheon), ''we decided to go back and find the descendants of the people in Agee and Evans's book, and we found 128, nearly all of them,'' he said. ''Most were still poor, and 95 percent were still in Alabama.'' Since joining the Bee in 1980, Mr. Maharidge has reported on social issues in the United States, Latin America and the Philippines. Mr. Williamson's photographic assignments have ranged from Super Bowl games to the wars of Central America.
 
Music
Mel Powell
'Duplicates'
''There might be some difficulty thinking of this work as a toe-tapper,'' the composer Mel Powell said in a lecture before the premiere of his '' a Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra. Mr. Powell, a 67-year-old composer and pianist, has been head of the composition department at the California Institute of the Arts, in Valencia, since 1969. Born in New York, he began his career as a jazz pianist and arranger for Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller. But after studying composition with Paul Hindemith at Yale University, he turned toward a more abstruse compositional style, which - depending on the work - takes in 12-tone writing, semi-improvisatory forms and electronic music. ''Duplicates'' is a labyrinthine, pointillistic three-movement score in which the solo pianists and the orchestra expand upon each other's thematic material. It was given its premiere by the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Jan. 26, 1990.

LENGTH: 228 words

HEADLINE: Stop the Shell Game With Pension Funds;
Mostly Employee Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The funding of defined benefit plans to which employer and employees both contribute is a more complicated issue than ''A Bad Bill Where a Fix Would Do'' (editorial, March 26) recognizes. In particular, it is misleading to imply that overfunding of such plans is a matter of ''excess money'' that employers ''mistakenly put in.'' 
High interest rates during the last decade have made some plans so overfunded that employers have not put any money into them for years. Funds nevertheless continue to accumulate because of employee contributions and interest on past contributions. This raises a basic question, which you fail to address: Why should employers have the right to lay hands on funds that to a large extent represent earnings on employee contributions? What you refer to as excess money is the result, for the most part, of what employees have allowed to be taken out of their pay for their own financial benefit; they certainly didn't hand it over for employers to use as a kitty to build a surplus for later confiscation.
An employer is entitled to ''excess money'' resulting from its own contributions, but when employer contributions are no longer being made, it is shocking to think that the employer can appropriate earnings that exist only because of employee contributions.
 
MERRITT ABRASH
 Troy, N.Y., March 27, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 462 words

HEADLINE: Stop the Shell Game With Pension Funds;
A Better Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your editorial of March 26 urges Congress to make some compromise on the withdrawal of funds from defined benefit pension plans. But defined benefit plans are themselves the major culprit in the underlying problem. Defined benefit plans are always subject to the possibility of underfunding or overfunding. 
Worse yet is the Government's attempt to insure this type of pension through the federally sponsored Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The possibility exists that any significant number of defaults will lead to a Treasury bailout that will make the savings and loan association crisis seem pale.
Defined benefit plans promise a pension based on some arcane or arbitrary formula, typically something like 2 percent for every year of service times the final year's compensation. The final pension payments, the projected earnings on the pension fund assets and the funding required are always subject to uncertainty.
The attempt to insure these plans is a risky proposition because the ability to make the payments may rest on the credit soundness of the sponsoring corporation or on its ability to continue in business. If not, the Government insurance or eventually the Treasury may have to pick up the tab.
A basic cure would be a policy encouraging corporations, states and local governments to convert to defined contribution plans. In a defined contribution plan, the company periodically places an agreed percentage of the employees' compensation in the pension fund. At retirement, the total of contributions plus accumulated earnings is turned into an annuity. With a defined contribution plan, there can be no problem of underfunding or overfunding. What you see is what you get.
The required administration of a defined contribution plan is minimal compared with a defined benefit plan. There is no problem of portability in a defined contribution plan or any problem, if circumstances should require, of making an early payout. Most of all, there is no possible imputed liability or financial risk for the sponsoring corporation, private agency or governmental unit. The need for a Federal insurance program would be minimal.
Moreover, defined contribution plans represent a true source of savings and a direct investment of capital in our system. The funds can be placed in fixed return securities or in equities and flow into productive enterprise.
Employees can receive quarterly statements on their accounts and see how well their investments are doing. The performance of the portfolio sets the final pension. There is hardly any better method of involving the employee-citizen in the financial soundness of the economy.
 
ELI SCHWARTZ
Professor of Economics
Lehigh University
 Bethlehem, Pa., March 27, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Against the Grain

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Soviet Union, which has always promptly paid hard cash for the commodities it purchases in the West, seems to have fallen almost one half-billion dollars behind in payments due to grain exporters in the past month.
I say ''seems to'' because nobody wants to talk publicly about this unprecedented payment delay - not the grain companies, which do not want to embarrass our largest customer (America sold 21 million metric tons of wheat and corn to the U.S.S.R. in the last marketing year), and not the Soviet Union, which wants to conceal this part of its economic desperation.
However, as a result of the mountain of accounts receivable, several international grain dealers have quietly stopped selling to the Soviet Union. It means that Mikhail Gorbachev's plan to placate angry Soviet consumers by putting bread on their tables is now threatened. 
His purchasing agents have turned to Japan. When Continental Grain declined to sell any more on credit (''We're being more prudent in bidding for business'' is the way a company spokesman reluctantly puts it), the Japanese bought and paid for American grain and resold it to Moscow, hoping to be paid in six months or a year - in effect, acting as the Soviets' risk-taking banker.
What's happening here? Are the Soviets going broke?
Moscow's suppliers in America say no, that the delay must be merely a bureaucratic mixup. In the past, Moscow's export arm bought the grain with the backing of the Soviet Union's central bank. But now, as a result of perestroika's housecleaning of bank officials, the excuse is given that the necessary documentation has been mislaid, or not filled out - or the banker has been fired and nobody sits at that desk anymore.
Without the guarantee from the Soviet central bank, the sellers of grain cannot get financing to carry the Soviets from American banks. As a result, grain shipments have been curtailed; ''We got paid, finally, the other day,'' says one U.S. grain shipper, ''but most of the other guys are still being told the check is in the mail.'' ABC News's Stephen Aug reported early this week that the Du Pont company, our largest producer of agricultural chemicals, was not being paid on time by the normally punctual Russians. American suppliers have accepted Moscow's explanation that the delays were due only to perestroika's necessary decentralization.
The great grain dunning raises the stakes substantially. Although the excuse is that Boris the Banker was fired and his local replacement cannot find the paperwork, the fact is that the Soviets are systematically seeking new deals permitting six-month and one-year payment delays. That spells big credit trouble. Here's another unremarked story that helps form the background to the hurry-up Memorial Day summit conference: The same Soviet economic desperation was at the root of last month's sudden selloff of a billion dollars in gold bullion.
In case you missed it, the price of gold dropped on March 26 from $393 to $370 - not exactly a crash, but an unusual tumble. At a loss for a reason, some analysts blamed the sale of gold in London by Saudi Arabia to pay for British weapons.
The Saudis did the selling, all right, but I'm told on good authority they acted in Switzerland as brokers for the Soviet Union.
Four days before the gold dumping, Edward Gostev, deputy chairman of the U.S.S.R. Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs, appeared before the Gold Institute's annual meeting in Arizona. He said confidently that Soviet sales of gold on the world market easily covered its grain purchases, and predicted that the Soviet Union would soon publish its secret figures on gold reserves and production.
That was intended to firm up world demand for gold as the Soviets prepared to sell. Gold bugs say the maneuver was only partly successful; the Gostev speech was not widely reported until after the tumble, and the Soviet sale was not entirely at the top of the market. At any rate, the hard currency realized by the dumping did not come in time to prevent the black eye suffered by the Soviet credit rating among grain exporters.
What does Moscow's market manipulation and international check-kiting have to do with the Memorial Day summit meeting?
It means that the recent turnabout by the Gorbachev Government from half-command economy to market-systems-ahead is purely the result of necessity. It means that the Soviets have never been more vulnerable to pressure: quickly to pull troops out of Eastern Europe, to end the subsidy of Fidel Castro, to free the captive Baltic nations.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Time for Change

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
To return to the United States from a visit to South Africa is to experience a drastic difference in political climates. In South Africa, the most profound assumptions of the society are changing. In the United States, the political system is frozen.
In Cape Town a woman said: ''Nothing's happened, only the whole psychology of the country has changed.'' 
By that she meant that the foundations of apartheid are still in place; the African majority cannot vote. But everything is open to challenge now, and there is a palpable expectation that the basic rules of political life will change.
To say that fundamentals are being challenged is really to say that something important has changed in South Africa. For dissent has been brutally suppressed over the last 30 years. Anti-apartheid leaders were jailed and silenced. Until a few months ago it was a crime to publish the words of Nelson Mandela.
Now South African television, for so long the slavish voice of the state, regularly reports the views of Mr. Mandela and the African National Congress. Newspapers publish exposes of official wrongdoing for which, only recently, they would have been closed.
President de Klerk can only have opened up the stifling atmosphere of South African politics with the aim of going on to substantive change. Moreover, he has broken the power of the securocrats who were a major obstacle to change - the generals who had gradually taken over state political functions under his predecessor, P. W. Botha.
Mr. de Klerk's leadership is crucial. But the white public is also readier for change than it has ever been. Not only businessmen, now, are aware of the economic cost of apartheid. A considerable part of the Afrikaner community has come to feel uncomfortable with the status quo of moral opprobrium and international isolation.
Whether negotiation can bridge the gap between black aspirations and white desire for assurances about the future is not so clear. But there is the sense today in South Africa of a society at last trying to come to grips with its real problems.
The United States, by contrast, seems determined to close its eyes to the realities that menace its future. That is true of the Government and of the public.
American society has problems as serious today as at any time since the Depression. Savings and investment have declined; we rely on foreign capital and then, illogically, sputter when that capital acquires U.S. assets. Our infrastructure of roads and bridges and other public facilities is crumbling.
It is an ill-educated society in a world where education is increasingly essential. The United States, alone among developed countries, has no national system of health insurance; 31 million Americans have no medical insurance.
A vast underclass mocks America's reputation as a just society. Homeless men and women huddle on the fanciest streets of our cities. An expensive restaurant has a notice on the wall headed ''We all need food and shelter''; it lists places where people in need can get ''a free meal or a place to sleep.''
On these and similar problems President Bush offers no leadership worth mentioning. His economic remedy is a cut in the capital gains tax, irrelevant at best. He has nothing of substance to suggest on the country's corrupting social ills.
Mr. Bush has shown considerable skill and determination in foreign affairs. But at home he is determined only to avoid the hard problems. Why? Because he is unwilling to challenge the prevailing public mood of antipathy to government.
As Felix Rohatyn writes in the current New York Review of Books, this country is still mesmerized by the doctrines it bought from Ronald Reagan: The taxes are too high and government is the enemy. They prevent any action to break the political immobilism, to end the obsession with deficit finagling, to deal with our national problems.
It takes leadership for a country to face the need for change. This country has no leadership: not in the White House and not in the opposition party.
South Africa has an infinitely greater burden to overcome. Its legacy of history is bitter. The society is riven. Change involves enormous risks of factionalism and violence. But there is a sense of possibility, and what a difference that makes.

LENGTH: 799 words

HEADLINE: Changes Urged to Cut Delays at Airports

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Alarmed by the growing number of flight delays in the New York area, airlines are pressuring the Government to revise the region's air traffic control system, much the way it did in Chicago last year. But some of the proposed changes are already meeting resistance from controllers.
Flight delays rose 111 percent at La Guardia Airport and 52 percent at Kennedy International Airport last year. Flight delays rose 17 percent at Newark International Airport last year. Nationally, delays rose 13 percent. 
The delays have continued to rise this year, with a 67 percent increase at Kennedy and an 18 percent increase at La Guardia over the same period last year.
Federal Aviation Administration officials attributed the rise last year to unusually severe weather, occasional computer failures and a shortage of fully trained controllers. Officials said this year's rise in delays at Kennedy was partly due to an increased number of international flights.
The crash of Avianca Flight 52 in Cove Neck, L.I., on Jan. 25 raised concern that the delays may pose a safety risk as well as an inconvenience for thousands of passengers. The Avianca jet, a Boeing 707 on its way to Kennedy, apparently ran out of fuel after circling for almost 90 minutes.
Aviation officials were able to reduce delays in Chicago by rerouting planes and conducting an aggressive campaign to recruit more controllers.
 
Delays Are Costly
''The changes in Chicago made a difference,'' said Robert Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, the industry trade group. ''We haven't seen that kind of additional horsepower applied to New York.''
Mr. Aaronson, a former director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, last month urged the administrator of the aviation agency, James B. Busey, to make the New York delays a national priority. Representatives from the airline trade group met yesterday with officials from the aviation agency to discuss the problem.
The delays are costly for the airlines, both in terms of extra fuel expenses and lost consumer confidence. One airline, the Trump Shuttle, began offering passengers a certificate for a weekend flight, without charge, for a companion if a flight is delayed more than 15 minutes.
In 1987 the aviation agency made major changes in flight paths in the New York region to try to reduce delays. The changes this time are likely to be more subtle. ''We're tweaking the system,'' said John Walker, assistant manager of air traffic for the agency's eastern region.
Almost a decade after President Ronald Reagan dismissed 11,400 striking controllers, the region is still short of fully trained controllers, even though the number of flights has increased 58 percent. Controllers are reluctant to move to New York because of the intense pressure and the high cost of living.
Last year the aviation agency began offering 20 percent bonuses to controllers who move to a number of cities, including New York and Chicago, as part of a five-year test program. But only a handful of controllers, about 30, have made the move or are planning to move to New York. ''We're not seeing a large number of people rushing to come here,'' Mr. Walker said.
 
Objecting to Inexperience
The airlines have proposed that in addition to trying to persuade veteran controllers to transfer to New York, the aviation agency should also assign more newly hired controllers to New York. The controllers' union, the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, opposes the idea, saying there are already too many inexperienced controllers in New York. Barry Krasner, a union representative, said, ''They're being thrust into a world they don't belong in yet.''
Controllers also objected to the airlines' proposal that the aviation agency hire a private organization to help train controllers in New York, freeing senior controllers to work the radar screens. A similar plan in Chicago has been the subject of an investigation by the Department of Transportation which found that many of the private instructors were not experienced.
Other solutions proposed by the carriers include making more overtime pay available to controllers, banning controllers from transferring from some New York radar rooms until more people are hired, and establishing an office in Washington to oversee the problem.
The aviation agency is considering all of the airlines' proposals, Mr. Walker said. But he cautioned that delays are, to some extent, endemic to the region. With three major airports within a 10-mile radius, the flight routes in the area are among the most complex in the nation.
''We're not saying we will do away with delays in the New York area,'' Mr. Walker said. ''Our goal is, instead of having 400 delays on a bad day, we'll have maybe 80 delays.''
