HEADLINE: Collapsing Housing Market Is Taking an Emotional Toll

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

 BODY:
Across the metropolitan region, thousands of people who bought homes during the long housing boom of the 1980's are suffering wrenching emotional and financial hardships as the value of their single largest investment slips away.
Signs of distress can be seen across New Jersey, Connecticut, the mid-Hudson area and on Long Island. Housing foreclosures, delinquent mortgage payments and personal bankruptcy filings are rising.
As a result of financial pressures caused largely by high housing costs, corporate employee-assistance programs report record numbers of workers seeking emotional and financial counseling. Psychologists and social workers say they are treating more cases of stress, depression, spouse and child abuse and marital strife. 
''All of us were brought up to believe that if you saved enough money to buy a house, your economic future was secure,'' said Dr. Richard Friedman, a psychologist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook who specializes in stress management. ''Each year, as you paid off the mortgage, the value of the house went up.
''Now, for the first time in 45 years, people who have put their life savings into what they thought was a rock-solid situation are losing money,'' he said. ''This has caused unmitigated anguish. Some people are on the verge of panic.''
 
'Operating on the Edge'
In large measure, the problems stem from the region's weakened economy. Slow job growth has curbed the demand for housing and depressed prices. Homeowners who bought at the market's peak, betting that prices would continue rising, now watch the value of their houses erode as property taxes and other housing costs continue to climb.
And with the effects of corporate restructurings and a shrinking Wall Street still resounding throughout the region, workers have entered an era when job security has all but vanished.
''A lot of people are operating on the edge,'' said Tony Maccarini, a real-estate lawyer in Carmel, N.Y. ''They're having trouble making their mortgage payments. They're maxed out on their credit cards. They're very nervous.''
The pressures appear to be felt most acutely in the suburbs, but owners of condominiums and cooperatives in New York City have also been hit by the one-two punch of falling real-estate values and soaring costs.
People who bought their homes before the boom began are still, of course, living in houses worth much more than they paid for them.
The homeowners hardest hit are those who bought their property from about 1983 through early 1988, when prices rose by as much as 2 to 3 percent a month in the hottest markets.
'We Feel Trapped' By Debt on Home The median price of a single-family house in the region jumped to $183,800 in 1988 from $88,900 in 1983, according to the National Association of Realtors.
Many two-income families borrowed heavily, spending 40 percent to 50 percent of their income on down payments and mortgages, banking on the seemingly endless rise of real-estate values.
Banks generally will not approve a mortgage if a household's monthly housing costs exceed 28 percent of its monthly income. But many waive that requirement if buyers make a down payment of 20 percent or more, figuring that the buyer has too much invested to default on the loan.
In addition, changes in the Federal income-tax law encouraged homeowners to assume more debt in the form of home-equity loans. These loans, or second mortgages, allowed homeowners to borrow against their home's escalating equity and deduct the interest payments from their income.
But for many families the debt burden became too much.
When Mary Anne and Larry Liesner bought a three-story colonial in Bridgeport, Conn., in 1986, they had big plans. Real-estate prices were rocketing; the Liesners figured they would renovate the 75-year-old house, sell it in four years, buy a sailboat with the proceeds and cruise the Caribbean.
Four years have passed but things have not worked out as planned. Mrs. Liesner lost her job as a restaurant manager, and Mr. Liesner lost his as a mechanic. They found other work, but earn $500 a week less than before. To save money, they stopped taking vacations and going out to dinner. But it has not been enough to keep from falling two months behind on their house payments, which increased to $2,000 a month this year from $1,400 a month in 1986.
The rudest shock came when the couple finally tried to sell: The house they bought in the boom years for $152,000 attracted only one offer, for $115,000.
''We feel trapped,'' said Mr. Liesner, who is 41 years old. ''This house consumes every dollar we make. It's a beautiful home, but it's also a huge financial burden.''
Like many other first-time home buyers, the Liesners chose a variable-rate mortgage with a low initial interest rate. In four years, the couple's mortgage rate has increased to 12 percent annually from 7.75 percent, a difference of $325 a month for them. In addition, they have to pay back a $50,000 loan they took to cover the down payment and renovation costs.
When the Liesners decided to sell, a housing glut had spread across Connecticut and the rest of the region. On Long Island, for example, the number of homes for sale increased to 20,987 this year from 5,532 five years ago.
Selling Is Hard, And a Loss Is Likely Prices have dropped 10 percent to 30 percent since late 1987, brokers said, making it impossible for many sellers to avoid a loss.
''I always wanted my own house,'' Mrs. Liesner, 43, said. ''But now I feel I made one of the biggest mistakes in my life.''
The Liesners are not alone. The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York said 3.7 percent of the mortgage loans outstanding in New York State were at least 60 days delinquent in 1989. That compares with 2.6 percent in 1988. In New Jersey, delinquencies rose to 4.75 percent from 2.9 percent in the same period, and in Connecticut to 2.3 percent from 1.35 percent.
While still a small fraction of residential real-estate loans, the number of foreclosures is slowly rising. In New York, 0.49 percent of all residential loans ended in foreclosure last year, up from 0.47 percent in 1988. In New Jersey during the same time, the figures increased to 0.83 percent from 0.74 percent. In Connecticut, they rose to 0.26 percent from 0.18 percent.
''The numbers are a sign of financial stress,'' said Rae D. Rosen, regional economist for the the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. ''Job growth has plummeted, real buying power is close to zero and people don't feel particularly confident.''
''In the past eight years, most people in Orange County had never seen a foreclosure,'' said Michele Koebrich, a realt-estate agent in Central Valley, N.Y. ''Now they're seeing them again.''
Homeowners who cannot wait out the slump and must sell immediately fare the worst, brokers and mortgage lenders say. But even those who stay speak in bitter tones of how their once-cherished houses have sidetracked their careers or played havoc with their lives.
Playing Havoc With Career Plans David Glaser, 35, a social worker, bought a three-bedroom Tudor house in Teaneck, N.J., nearly two years ago. Mr. Glaser won't disclose what his mortgage payments are now, but he said they are triple what he and his wife, Sandi, used to pay for a two-bedroom house a half-mile away.
''If I didn't have such high mortgage payments, my wife might be able to stay home when we start a family,'' he said. ''We love this house, but our regret is whether it might affect bringing up a child.''
June Richardson, 45, a management consultant, paid $260,000 for a town house in Bridgeport three years ago. Now she says she would be lucky to get $160,000 for the two-bedroom condominium.
''I have a lot of business opportunities in California, where I'd like to move, but I can't take advantage of them,'' said Ms. Richardson, whose mortgage payments are $2,050 a month. ''I'm frustrated and I'm angry. I felt this would be a secure place to put my money. Now I feel like I've lost my shirt, and that terrifies me.''
The mortgage payments on the one-bedroom condominium that Claire McPartland, 35, and her husband Ted Mammone, 34, bought in South Norwalk three years ago have climbed to $1,400 a month from $890 a month. ''There's nothing we can do other than pray that the market picks up in the next few years,'' said Ms. McPartland.
Credit counselors and employee-assistance programs throughout the region have noticed a sharp increase in clients with financial problems, stemming largely from housing costs, their largest single expense.
Consumer Credit Counseling Services of Connecticut, a large agency based in Hartford, said 102 people signed up for help in February, the largest monthly enrollment in the company's 14-year history.
''We have clients postponing divorces because they can't afford to get divorced,'' said Beverly Tuttle, president of Consumer Credit. ''They may be just making it with two incomes. If they split up the family, those same two incomes will have to support two households.''
Debt Creates Sense Of Impending Doom The number of employees of UST Inc., formerly the United States Tobacco Company, seeking financial counseling increased to more than 120 last year, a record, from 61 in 1984.
''Housing debts contribute enormously to their financial problems and it's getting worse,'' said James P. Cassidy, director of the employee assistance program of UST, in Greenwich.
The financial drain and insecurity have created a climate of hopelessness for many homeowners. ''People feel a sense of impending doom about what may happen to them,'' said Dr. Allan L. Schiffer, a clinical psychologist who operates an employee-assistance program in Hartford.
In one foreclosed house in Goshen, N.Y., that Mrs. Koebrich examined recently, the plumbing lines were cut, light fixtures were ripped out and holes were punched in the doors.
''The people were angry, frustrated and feeling absolutely desolate, so they took it out on the property,'' she said.
In most instances, homeowners' reactions are less extreme, but no less heartfelt. Four years ago, Tamar Asedo Sherman and her family moved from a six-bedroom house in Ithaca, N.Y., to a five-bedroom colonial in Northport, L.I.
After spending $30,000 to build three outside decks and renovate a family room, Ms. Sherman said their Long Island house still ''doesn't equal what we had. That house was bigger, nicer, more interesting.''
And while her family has no plans to move back upstate, Ms. Sherman says the soft housing market on Long Island has robbed them of any real say in the matter.
''I feel very resentful that I've lost a lot of flexibility in my life,'' said Ms. Sherman, a senior news writer at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. ''I often wonder, 'Am I crazy for coming here?' ''
That sentiment is echoed particularly on Long Island, where soaring property taxes have combined with sinking property values to squeeze many middle-class homeowners.
Diana Antonelli and her family moved to a three-bedroom ranch house in the Suffolk County hamlet of Sound Beach from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn in 1984. ''I didn't buy this house to make a killing,'' Mrs. Antonelli said. ''I bought it to make a home.''
Since then, though, her property taxes have climbed to $2,700 a year from $1,900, the house has dropped in value almost 20 percent, and longtime neighbors are leaving for Florida before it gets worse.
''Living in the suburbs used to be the American dream,'' said Mrs. Antonelli, a part-time nursery school teacher. ''Now, between the runaway taxes, the commuting costs and the housing prices, it's become an American nightmare.''

HEADLINE: 3 Nominated for Expanded Board To Consider Conflicts of Interest

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday nominated three lawyers to serve on the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board, the five-member body that considers questions of ethical conduct involving city officials and employees.
The nominations are subject to confirmation by the City Council, a process that it likely to take several weeks. The new appointees, therefore, will probably not be able to take their seats until after the current members rule on whether it is proper for Mr. Dinkins to vote on the renewal of franchises held by Manhattan Cable Television and Paragon Cable Manhattan. 
The franchise renewals are scheduled for discussion on Wednesday at a special meeting of the Board of Estimate, on which the Mayor has two votes. A decision on the franchises could come then or later.
Mr. Dinkins had sought the board's opinion because in late 1985 he transferred stock he held in the Inner City Broadcasting Corporation to his son. Inner City was a partner with Time Warner Inc. in a Queens cable company, the Queens Inner Unity Cable System. Time Warner also holds interests in Manhattan Cable and Paragon.
 
Number of Members Increases
Members of the board serve four-year terms. Those named yesterday were Sheldon Oliensis, Benjamin Gim, and Shirley Adelson Siegel. Mr. Oliensis will serve as chairman, replacing Merrell Clark Jr. Mr. Gim and Ms. Siegel will fill new seats on the board. Under the new city charter, the number of board members was increased to five from three.
Mr. Oliensis, 68 years old, is a partner in the firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler and has been president of the City Bar Association in New York since 1988. His term as association president expires next month. Mr. Gim, 67, is a partner in Gim & Wong and early in his career served as an assistant State Attorney General. Ms. Siegel, 71, is on the adjunct faculty at the University of Maryland and at Columbia University. From 1979 to 1982 she was New York State Solicitor General.
Two current members appointed by former Mayor Edward I. Koch - Beryl Jones, an associate professor at Brooklyn Law School, and Robert J. McGuire, senior managing director of Kroll Associates and a former city Police Commissioner - were retained by Mr. Dinkins.
The conflicts board, which replaced the former Board of Ethics, issues advisory opinions on the application of the city's conflict of interest rules and can investigate complaints, hold public hearings, impose fines and recommend suspension or removal from city employment. Members are paid $250 for each board meeting.
Mr. Dinkins also announced the appointment of Miriam Arias as director of the new Office of Economic and Financial Opportunity. He said that the office, which was mandated by the new city charter, will oversee and coordinate city activities on behalf of small businesses and those owned by minorities and women. Ms. Arias will be paid $80,000 a year.
Ms. Arias, 40, is president and co-founder of Equity Temporary Services Inc., which specializes in providing temporary bilingual secretarial and clerical services.

HEADLINE: Dancer's Death Inspires Creation of Crisis Fund

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Monika Beerle came to New York City from St. Gallen, Switzerland, to become a dancer. She had been studying at the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance in New York for about a year when she moved into an apartment on the Lower East Side. Two months later, last August, she was killed. A roommate she hardly knew has been charged with her murder.
Miss Beerle's death stunned teachers, students and administrators at the Graham school. ''She did not have a lot of money,'' said Diane Gray, the director of the Graham School, in a recent interview. ''If she hadn't had to live in that very bad spot, with someone she didn't know very well, she might not have been murdered.'' Miss Gray decided to do something about it. She talked to administrators at other New York dance schools about establishing a fund to help students like Miss Beerle. 
The first benefit for the Emergency Fund for Student Dancers will take place tonight and tomorrow night at the Merce Cunningham studio in lower Manhattan. The benefit program will include Murray Louis's ''Deja Vu'' and dances by Max Luna 3d of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and Camille Brown of the Graham company.
What makes the benefit unusual is that it will be produced entirely by student dancers at five major New York dance training centers: the Graham and Cunningham schools, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center, the Nikolais and Louis Dance Lab, and the Laban/Bartenieff Institute of Movement Studies. The program will also include dances by eight fledgling choreographers representing the Cunningham, Graham and Nikolais-Louis schools.
 
Competition With Peers
'' 'Students helping students' is our motto,'' said Nolini Barretto, an adviser to students from abroad at the Graham school, in a recent interview at the Cunningham studio.
The event has brought together not only five administrators, who have been working on it since September, but students from the different schools as well. ''They're excited, competitive - and nervous,'' said Denise Jefferson, the head of the Ailey school. ''They are going to be seen by their peers.''
Lynn Lesniak-Needle, the head of the Nikolais-Louis school, nodded in agreement. ''And there's an inherent sense of pride,'' she said, ''because they're representing their schools.''
The benefit is to be the first in a series of four or five events intended to raise money to help ''people who are trying to do it for themselves in this inhospitable city,'' Ms. Jefferson said.
The money will be used primarily to help full-time students from abroad and American students from outside New York. ''Things tend to hit them most,'' said Suzanne Youngerman, head of the Laban/Bartenieff Institute.
Money raised for the fund will be lent to students for a variety of emergencies. Many American students go without medical treatment when they are sick or injured because they cannot afford it. ''We require foreign students to have health insurance, but American students no longer dependent on their parents cannot get insurance except through jobs,'' said Alice Helpern, the head of the Cunningham school.
 
'A Last Resort'
The Nikolais-Louis studio helped pay for telephone calls to China for one Chinese student who arrived in the United States just before the Tiananmen Square massacre and was worried about his family. An English student needed help to escape the battering of her new American husband. ''It's so hard for the foreign students,'' Ms. Gray said. ''They aren't allowed to work. If they do, they make very little money.''
Some, she added, are forced to work at several jobs and are so tired they cannot take classes. Often, foreign students' grant money comes long after their arrival, a time when they most need help.
But the program will also make information available to students on medical treatment, social services, temporary housing - and even finding a dance school they might like better. ''It's reassuring just to know there's a last resort,'' Miss Barretto said.
''We're all in such precarious situations,'' Ms. Gray said. ''The economy is so tight. Funding is dropping. Just the fact that this is pulling us together is so important.''
The benefit will take place tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Cunningham studio, 55 Bethune Street. Tickets are $10; Theater Development Fund vouchers will be accepted. For reservations, call Ms. Youngerman at 689-0740. Donations to the Emergency Fund for Student Dancers may also be made through any of the participating schools.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

Paper Moon Milano
The Milanese may be best known for their prowess as fashion pacesetters, but they are proving equally deft at tailoring restaurants that capture the public fancy. The invasion began several years ago with Bice in midtown Manhattan, which from the day it opened has made Armani fashion previews look sparsely attended. Imitation trattorias in various shades and sizes have popped up all over town, the latest and most ambitious of which is Paper Moon Milano on East 58th Street.
Paper Moon Milano is a smart and snappy environment, built for speed and style but not leg room, like a Lamborghini. It is part of a chain that owns restaurants in Milan and Tokyo. Starker and cooler than Bice, Paper Moon Milano attracts the same self-assured, crisply attired, polyglot crowd. Except for the tan tablecloths and some wood-and-brass accents, black and white is the design leitmotif, from the tiled floor and moody photos of Milan to the stylish outfits on the women dining here. The restaurant can get a bit close and clamorous at times, but I like the brisk, confident cadence of the room. And the good-looking waiters in long, white aprons glide through the premises with the agility of figure skaters. 
Upon being seated, you are given a lagniappe of savory strips of herbed focaccia. This presumably softens you up to absorb the prices of the appetizers, many of which are $10 or more. I have recently noticed that appetizer prices are quickly rising around town, and while many restaurants are lowering or at least holding down the prices of main courses, appetizer inflation seems to take up some of the slack.
The selection here is first-rate, though: buttery prosciutto di Parma with ripe melon, a superior Nicoise salad and a delicious combination of white beans, tuna and onions. Sandy arugula diminished an otherwise tantalizing salad of shrimp in a mild mustard vinaigrette. The grilled vegetable plate here is better and more varied than at most other restaurants, as is the ultrathin and earthy bresaola under shredded basil, shards of sharp Parmesan and fragrant olive oil.
Half-orders of pasta are not served, so you either split one order or go for an entree portion. I didn't encounter a dud in three visits, for the kitchen understands balance and clean flavors. Among the best are penne tossed with eggplant, mozzarella, fresh basil and a touch of oregano; a simpler but equally satisfying penne in a delicate and creamy tomato sauce with basil, and farfalle in a pink tomato sauce with slivers of smoked salmon. Penne all'arrabbiata has a gentle kick to it and a strong underpinning of garlic. And the seafood pasta is masterfully executed, with baby squid, clams and shrimp in a subtle bath of chopped tomato and olive oil. The one risotto sampled, also with mixed seafood, benefited from the same light-handedness.
Paper Moon Milano carries a few fresh and light pinot biancos and verdicchios for about $24, and among reds there are ample good choices that fit the style of food, including the 1987 Rosso di Montalcino (Altesino) for $22.
Main courses are not as consistent as starters, but a few stand out. The mixed grill offers meltingly tender charred fillet of beef, baby lamb chops, lusty pork sausage, well-seasoned veal, endive and eggplant. The sliced sirloin with green peppercorns and rosemary is a winner; so too is the grilled veal chop. Sliced swordfish with arugula and marjoram sounded enticing, but the carpaccio-thin fish was dry and tasteless. And the grilled Cornish hen had been fired to a papery texture.
A good bet for a light meal is one of the fragile-crusted pizzas, particularly the one with creamy ricotta cheese, tomato and sausage.
Aside from several appealing fruit tarts and a better-than-average tiramisu (it had a good espresso jolt), desserts are ordinary. Speaking of espresso, it's the real thing here, which is no small find in this town.
Paper Moon Milano is fueled by brio and a buoyant style. While not every dish is a winner, when it comes to scintillating pastas this moon shines brightly.
 
Carolina
As competition heats up among restaurants in the Broadway theater district, some established places will have to revitalize their scripts to keep the crowds coming. The seven-year-old Carolina, which was a novelty when it introduced its style of smoke-perfumed down-home Southern cooking to the neighborhood, is a case in point.
Recent visits indicate that the food here lacks the punch it had in the early days. Some dishes seem tentative, citified. It's a shame, for this town could use more twangy Southern fare, especially good ribs. The pork ribs here are passable, but they lack the penetrating smokiness that sends barbecue fans into paroxysms of delight.
Carolina is still one of the more attractive settings on the so-called Restaurant Row, on West 46th Street. The back room, while showing signs of wear, is still a cheerful place for lunch with its arching skylight, gray banquettes and wraparound mirrored walls. The darker front room near the bar, the smoking section, is tranquil and pleasant.
Some old standards here are still appealing: the chunky corn-and-potato soup enlivened with bits of ham and red pepper; moist and minimally sweet corn bread, and the sinewy beef brisket on lettuce in a sauce that comes on as sweet as a flirting Southern belle, then heats up in the aftertaste. The smoked sausage plate was puzzling, though. The pork sausage had a chemical taste, and another sausage, seasoned with cheese and parsley, was unpleasantly sour. An appetizer of smoked trout with a pallid horseradish sauce was just plain boring. A special at lunch one day, seafood chowder, was essentially a decent facsimile of Manhattan-style clam chowder. Better is the chunky, aggressively seasoned chili, which carries a delayed snap of pepper.
Carolina's service staff is energetic but disorganized: during our visits, tableware was forgotten and little details were left unattended. The all-American wine selection is limited - 7 whites, 11 reds - featuring mostly familiar labels at sensible prices.
I have always touted the crab cakes here, and still do, sort of. On the first of four revisits, they came out slightly greasy and looking as if the chef had dropped a heavy cookbook on them. On two further samplings, they were plumper and had a nice peppery edge that makes them a house favorite. No such rehabilitation saved the red-pepper shrimp, a colorless and dried-out assembly on skewers served over rice. One of the safer main courses is grilled duck breast, nicely charred and moist, with a sweet pear chutney.
The kitchen specializes in hot smoking, a technique that involves low-heat cooking over fruitwoods. As executed here, however, all that cooking only tightens the fibrous meat, leaving it chewy and dry. When it comes to seafood, the kitchen pulled off an extraordinary feat one day: through brutal overcooking and liberal seasoning, the chef managed to make swordfish and salmon indistinguishable from each other. Both came with snow peas and nearly raw carrots. If your main course is a flop, you might get some solace from side orders like the pleasantly sweet corn pudding or the crunchy fresh coleslaw. Alas, I never got to try the green chili souffle for the restaurant was always out of it.
Desserts remain the bright spot on the menu. Lemon tart is still a puckery delight, chocolate mud cake is irresistible, and the apple-crumb compote would be right at home at an Alabama church supper. I haven't eaten a candy bar in 20 years, but the signature dessert, pecan-caramel bars dipped in chocolate, would make one addictive snack if packaged.
At a time when America's food banner is flying high, Carolina's decline - from two stars in 1983, to one star in 1986, and to a Satisfactory rating now - is all the more lamentable.
 
Paper Moon Milano
**
 
39 East 58th Street, 758-8600.

Service: Brisk and generally professional.

Wine: Adequate selection well matched to the food.
Price range: Lunch and dinner: appetizers $7 to $14; main courses $15 to $24.

HEADLINE: Oil Worries Increasing For OPEC

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 12

 BODY:
A number of OPEC oil ministers expressed anxiety today at the sharp fall in oil prices over the last few days, hinting at the possibility of holding a special meeting to look into ways of propping prices up.
''Various options are being considered, including an urgent meeting of the eight-member ministerial monitoring committee and an extraordinary meeting'' of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Sadek Boussena, Algeria's oil minister and the group's current president, said in a statement today.
The organization is scheduled to hold a regular meeting of its 13 oil ministers on May 25 in Geneva to discuss production and pricing policies for the rest of this year, and a majority of its officials appeared reluctant to meet before that date unless, they said, prices weakened much further.
 
Drop of About $3 a Barrel
OPEC officials cautioned that Mr. Boussena's suggestion of an earlier emergency meeting was intended mainly to reassure world oil markets that the group was intent on addressing the recent weakness of oil prices. Prices have fallen by about $3 a barrel since the end of March. 
''The market has become worried by the reluctance of the key producers to curtail production,'' said Peter Gigoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in London.
Leading OPEC producers, including Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq, appeared reluctant today to call an emergency meeting of the group, opting instead for quiet consultations to rein in the group's total output, which topped 24 million barrels a day in March.
On Wednesday, Indonesia's oil minister, Ginanjar Kartasasmita, said an emergency meeting was not necessary before the May 25 gathering. Many OPEC officials pointed out during their last meeting in March that they fully expected prices to weaken in the second quarter.
''It has gone much further than they expected because they counted on demand that is not there and on a fall in supplies from independent producers that did not materialize,'' said Gary N. Ross, head of consulting services at Petroleum Industry Research Associates in New York.
The excess production has pushed the average OPEC oil price to about $15 a barrel, substantially beneath the organization's preferred target price of $18. Oil traders said these were the lowest levels in 14 months for the group's crude.
Crude oil prices resumed their decline today in volatile trading. At the close of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest energy market, the spot May crude oil contract settled at $17.78 a barrel, off 28 cents on the day.
 
Above 24 Million Barrels
Senior OPEC officials said today that the primary issue now was to cut back the high level of production by the group, which exceeded 24 million barrels a day last month and was described in this week's issue of the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey oil newsletter as ''the highest monthly OPEC crude output registered since 1981.'' The organization's official level of production, agreed to in November, is 22.1 million barrels a day.
Some OPEC officials suggested that only when prices fell further would they be in favor of a more urgent action. ''There is a red line beyond which the prices must not fall,'' the United Arab Emirates oil minister, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, told the country's official press agency today. ''OPEC will not stand with its arms folded in the face of what is happening in the oil markets.''
 
Cut in Output Preferred
The group's president, Mr. Boussena, seemed to suggest in his statement today that his preferred course of action, intead of calling an emergency meeting, was to roll back excessive production by those in the organization that are cheating and producing oil above their quotas.
Mr. Boussena said his consultations with other ministers showed a willingness ''to act responsibly in order to safeguard the stability of the oil market and restore prices to the agreed level,'' presumably a reference to the group's target price of $ 18 a barrel.
Mr. Boussena's caution seems to draw on another consideration. A number of key oil ministers, particularly Hisham M. Nazer of Saudi Arabia, OPEC's largest producer, are reluctant to have too many meetings of the group. Mr. Nazer once said in an interview that this created ''an unecessary atmosphere of crisis.''

HEADLINE: The Magic of Hollywood Math

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 12

 BODY:
''Coming to America,'' the Eddie Murphy film that was one of the top-10 grossing films in 1988, has brought in worldwide revenues of more than $275 million, including at least $125 million to Paramount Pictures, which made and distributed the movie.
But in Hollywood, which creates its own version of reality in its financial accounting just as on the big screen, ''Coming to America'' is a money loser. And that startling fact has set the stage for the most serious challenge yet to the way the industry makes its deals, calculates its profits and doles out its riches.
Applying the industry's standard bookkeeping practices to account for Paramount's costs and profits in making and distributing the film and for the cut of box office receipts guaranteed to a few stars on both sides of the camera, the studio calculated that the film lost $18 million through the end of last year.
 
A Blow to Buchwald
Paramount's finding that the movie has no net profits is a blow to the economic interests of anyone whose compensation might be tied to the movie's bottom line. In this case, the interests at stake are those of Art Buchwald and his co-plaintiff in his much-publicized lawsuit against Paramount, the producer Alain Bernheim. 
A state court here has already ruled that ''Coming to America,'' whose story was credited by Paramount to Eddie Murphy, was actually based on an idea first brought to Paramount by Mr. Buchwald. The court ruled that Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim, who had signed a deal to produce a film based on Mr. Buchwald's idea, are entitled to their contractual share of the net profits from ''Coming to America.''
In the next phase of the case, scheduled to go to trial this summer, lawyers for Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim will argue that the calculations that led to the film's bottom-line loss are based to some extent on bloated or improperly allocated costs, and they will challenge the fairness and legality of contracts based on the industry's current system of determining and distributing profits.
''This is like dropping a thermonuclear device in the middle of Hollywood,'' said Pierce O'Donnell, Mr. Buchwald's lawyer.
Paramount says there is nothing improper about its accounting system, which is the same one used throughout the industry for decades. Moreover, the studio and its lawyers say, the contract signed by Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim clearly defines the way in which their payment was to be calculated.
''The net profit definition in our Art Buchwald contract is essentially the same as every contract, not only with Paramount Pictures but in the entire motion picture industry,'' said Charles Diamond, a lawyer representing Paramount. ''The books and records will show the accounting we have provided is honest, straightforward and accurate.''
The case gets to the heart of what has become an economic caste system in Hollywood. Under the system, the very top stars and the most proven producers and directors can negotiate contracts that allow them to take their money right off the top through what Hollywood calls gross-profit participation. In essence, those people are getting a cut of box office receipts before the studio starts accounting for the film's costs, and the payoff can be immense.
For ''Fatal Attraction,'' another hit film made and distributed by Paramount, industry executives say that the producers, Stanley Jaffe and Sherry Lansing, together took home $20 million from their gross participation deals. Michael Douglas, one of the film's stars, got $9 million from his gross participation deal, and the director, Adrian Lyne, $5.5 million.
There are no gross-profit deals for those below the top tier of talent and success. Jack Nicholson reportedly has a gross profit deal on ''Batman,'' for example, but Batman himself, Michael Keaton, does not. Those people without gross profit deals get a flat salary or a salary plus a percentage of the film's net profits. And as ''Coming to America'' illustrates, net profits are often scarce or nonexistent, even for big hits.
 
Locking In the Profits
The ''Coming to America'' case shows where the money goes and illustrates how the studios, as well as the gross-profit participants, lock in their profits through their roles in financing, making and distributing films.
The $275 million brought in by ''Coming to America'' includes worldwide box office revenues and the sale of rights to home video, cable and broadcast television. After theater owners and others took their share, Paramount was left with revenue on the film of at least $125 million, according to court documents filed by the studio, which is a unit of Paramount Communications.
The total ''negative costs,'' or the costs of developing and making the movie, were $58.5 million. That figure includes about $39.5 million of actual development, production and post-production costs. But it also includes the payments made under the film's gross-profit deals - about $10 million paid to Eddie Murphy and $1 million to the director, John Landis.
 
An 'Overhead' Fee
The negative costs also include an ''overhead'' fee of about $8 million, or roughly 15 percent of the production costs, that the studio charged to the film's books for the use of its plant and personnel. Charging such a fee is standard industry practice, although industry executives say it usually amounts to far more than a film's fair share of maintaining a studio's lot.
Right off the top, Paramount took a fee of $42 million, or more than 30 percent of the film's rental income, for distributing the movie to theaters through its network of sales offices. That is also the standard arrangement in the industry, and the major source of profit for the studio.
Paramount then charged to the film's books the costs of distributing ''Coming to America,'' which it said amounted to $36 million. Included in that figure is $15.7 million in advertising costs in the United States, $8.3 million for advertising abroad and charges for making prints and shipping the film around the world.
The film was then charged an interest cost of $6.4 million, essentially a finance charge to be paid to the studio for the use of its money.
 
The Result: A Loss
The cost of making the film, the payments made to Mr. Murphy and Mr. Landis under their deals, the distribution fee for Paramount and the distribution and interest costs add up to $143 million by Paramount's calculation. The movie therefore lost $18 million - even though the studio and the film's star and director profited handsomely.
Although ''Coming to America'' continues to generate revenue, the movie will almost certainly never show a net profit under the current accounting system. If there were net profits, as defined by Paramount's lengthy contract with Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim, Mr. Buchwald would receive 1.5 percent of them for developing the story on which the movie is based. Mr. Bernheim's contract entitled him to 17.5 percent of the net profits. Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim could be awarded millions if Paramount is forced to change the way it calculates profits.
In not posting net profits, ''Coming to America'' is the rule rather than the exception. ''I'd say that only five or six movies a year, out of the hundreds that are made each year, pay out net profits,'' said one top Hollywood agent.
The studios argue that they deserve to take a big chunk of the profits up front because it is their money at risk, and because for every film with enough success to yield a large distribution fee, dozens are flops or are never made. Studio executives also say that it is common knowledge to those on both sides of deals that net profit arrangements rarely pay out significant sums, and that when they do, they are a bonus for a film's especially strong financial performance.
 
Many Resentful
Still, Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim have plenty of support in Hollywood. One reason is that there are almost never any net profits on films with gross-profit participants, and actors, writers, directors and others often resent watching a handful of people walk away with huge sums while they get nothing beyond their salaries - even if their salaries alone are considered exorbitant by many people outside the industry.
So Mr. Buchwald, Mr. Bernheim and their legal team are likely to have a large rooting section as they start to pick at Paramount's books. Mr. O'Donnell, Mr. Buchwald's lawyer, said he intends to challenge many of the costs charged to ''Coming to America,'' like a $300 bill for hanging a door on the set. He also wants to challenge whether the studio can include gross-profit payments made to Mr. Murphy and Mr. Landis as part of the film's negative costs when calculating its overhead charge.
But it seems highly unlikely that Mr. O'Donnell will find $18 million or more in bloated or improper costs in Paramount's books for the movie. Mr. O'Donnell is certain to bring up a clause in the contract that gives Mr. Bernheim control over whether there are gross-profit deals on the film. But the case may come down to whether net-profit deals, at least when made on films where there are also gross-profit deals, are deceptive and unfair.
Mr. O'Donnell thinks there is sufficient precedent to show that they are, but Mr. Diamond, the lawyer for Paramount, thinks that argument may not even be relevant because the case centers on a contract, agreed to by Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim, that spells out a precise definition of net profits.

LENGTH: 773 words

HEADLINE: Brazil Congress Passes Anti-Inflation Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 12

 BODY:
Brazil's Congress gave a major victory to President Fernando Collor de Mello late Wednesday by passing intact the heart of his Draconian anti-inflation plan. Economists said a severe recession was a certainty.
In a surprising vote, legislators passed by 249 to 204 a measure that freezes for 18 months all bank deposits of more than $1,200 and money-market deposits of more than $600.
''I am extremely satisfied with the result of the congressional session,'' Mr. Collor told reporters as he headed for a pizzeria in Brasilia to celebrate. 
Mr. Collor decreed the measure as part of a package he initiated on March 16, the day after he took office. He said it was central to his strategy of beating back inflation, which has run at an annual rate of 4,854 percent.
The Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, was exultant after the vote and said the legislative action would insure the success of the ''New Brazil Plan.''
But economists agreed that Mr. Collor's plan would produce a brutal recession, at least in the short term. [In approving the economic program, the Brazilian Congress did make some changes, including limiting the program for selling state industries to private investors and raising the minimum wage more than the President wanted.
But the Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, Marcilio Marques Moreira, said in an interview that it was possible for President Collor to veto the changes. If this happened, Congress could try to override the veto. [The Ambassador said Congress voted not to allow foreign banks with loans to the Government to swap these loans for shares in state companies that go private. Such a restriction could limit the scope of proposals that Brazil is expected to make when it finally resumes debt negotiations with its commercial bankers. Brazil's debt, which totals $112.7 billion, is the largest in the developing world.] ''A recession is inevitable - its duration will depend on the Government's future conduct of economic policy,'' said Edmar Bacha, an economist, who supports the plan as necessary to end chronic inflation.
 
Ubiquitous Signs of Crisis
Signs of an impending recession are everywhere. The automobile, capital goods, construction and machine tools industries are virtually paralyzed. Unions say almost a million workers have either been discharged, taken pay cuts or been put on a collective holiday.
''The Government will have to create special credit lines for badly hit sectors to prevent the recession from getting out of control,'' said Mario Henrique Simonsen, a conservative economist who served as Finance Minister between 1974 and 1979, when Brazil was run by a right-wing military regime.
''The bank confiscation has shaken the short-term confidence of investors and savers in the financial system. How they react in the longer term will be crucial'' to limiting the depth of the recession, he said.
Leftist economists were especially critical.
''You can't solve economic problems with this sort of drastic solution.'' said Paul Singer, a leading economist with the Socialist Workers Party, who predicted a depression and said he feared ''very serious social convulsions.''
 
Collective Bargaining Favored
He said the Workers Party favored collective bargaining of wages and prices between labor unions and business to bring down inflation, without producing a recession.
Representative Cesar Maia, an economist and spokesman for the center-left Democratic Labor Party, said, ''The logic of the plan is to paralyze the economy for several months and then make the recession tolerable.'' If the Government managed the plan well, he said, the economy could begin to grow again in about a year.
 
U.S. Is 'Pleased'
WASHINGTON, April 12 (Special to The New York Times) - Brazil's approval of an austere anti-inflation package is likely to unleash as much as $2 billion in support for the Brazilian economy from the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and other international lending agencies, American and other officials said here today.
The Bush Administration said it was ''pleased'' by Brasilia's action. It termed the reform program ''bold,'' and welcomed it particularly because of Brazil's importance as a trading partner.
The hope is to cushion the almost-certain recessionary effects of the package on the Brazilian public by marshaling the multilateral assistance, American officials said.
The World Bank, which lent Brazil $1.76 billion over the 11 months ended Feb. 28, is preparing several large loans, including one of $100 million, that can move forward as a result of today's action, a bank official said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why Gorbachev Delays Reforms

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
EMBROILED in the political crisis initiated by Lithuania's bid to secede from the Soviet Union, which hard-liners and anti-reformers are exploiting for their own purposes, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has deferred the decision on whether and how to carry out a ''radical'' reformation of the Soviet economic system.
There is growing evidence that Mr. Gorbachev is not yet ready to accept a definite plan and a timetable for thoroughly revising the Soviet system.
A coalition of old Stalinists, bureaucrats and military officers, seizing on the Lithuanian struggle for independence, is producing a chilling effect on political and economic reform. They could bring Mr. Gorbachev down. 
In televised remarks this week the Soviet President appeared to be trying to parry that threat by warning that the redrawing of internal borders would lead to ''bloody carnage,'' and he accused a group of Communist Party progressives of wanting to restore capitalism. It is striking that Mr. Gorbachev has used that all-purpose charge to reject proposals for the type of market reforms that he had earlier endorsed. But the rejection may only be temporary, as he fends off the orthodox Communists and the standpatters.
There are economic as well as political dangers before him that may prevent him from imposing additional economic strains in the midst of a political crisis. With the economy suffering from a suppressed inflation that is taking the form of growing shortages, widespread black markets and increasing corruption, the Soviet leader appears to have put aside plans for an early freeing of prices lest open inflation and worsening unemployment blow him and his reform movement out of the water.
With the ruble sinking into virtual worthlessness either for international or domestic uses, his chief economic adviser, Leonid I. Abalkin, the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the economic program, has said that a new package of economic proposals will not include plans to replace the ruble with a new currency or to make it freely convertible in the near future.
The Soviet Union will have to depend more and more on barter deals, like Pepsico's arrangement to produce and sell more soft drinks in the Soviet Union in exchange for vodka and merchant ships. But not many other American businesses will want to invest in the Soviet Union without greater prospects of getting their money out.
At a recent conference in Moscow, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the New Jersey Democrat who is the former chairman of Automatic Data Processing, told the Soviets that if they wanted to expand their business with the United States, there were many basic problems they had to solve, including these:
* Make it possible for foreign companies to repatriate their profits and help them ''thread their way through the bureaucracy.''
* Establish a telecommunications system that will enable companies to stay in touch with their home offices and other centers.
* Collect and publish reliable economic data that will enable foreign companies to do adequate risk analysis.
* Give foreign companies the freedom to hire and dismiss workers, and create the possibility of freer travel in and out of the Soviet Union and inside it.
* Provide protection from arbitrary political and economic decision-making by the authorities.
* Establish tax policies that will apply equally to all trading partners.
* Re-evaluate national security requirements and eliminate unnecessary barriers to trade; Senator Lautenberg stressed that such changes were essential on both sides.
But the task of opening up the economy goes far beyond what business executives or economists prescribe; it also requires winning the political battle at home. Can Mr. Gorbachev do it? The answer depends partly on an assessment of the Soviet leader's character, courage, intelligence, economic savvy and commitment to achieving the goals of a free and democratic society. As he shifts his stance on privatization and other Soviet reforms, uncertainties about Mr. Gorbachev's will and perseverance increase.
But everything does not depend just on the character of one man. He has enormous resistances to overcome: the ingrained ideology and habits of thought and behavior of the Soviet people after 70 years of Communism; the doubters and resisters within the Politburo, the Central Committee, the Army, the ministries and the bureaucracy; the unruly nationalities and republics, eager to be free of Russian dominance; the lack of a genuine social compact binding the nation's groups together, preparing them, like the Poles, to make the sacrifices that may be needed to reform the economy and achieve genuine freedom.
But Mr. Gorbachev can no longer postpone hard decisions. If he is to redeem his promises to rescue his country from a stale, rigid and failed system, he must gather people around him who are prepared to work tirelessly to build a better society.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Door Revolves Again At Top of Winnebago

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The revolving door at Winnebago Industries turned again yesterday, and out went Richard D. Conner as president and chief executive.
In a terse announcement, the maker of recreational vehicles in Forest City, Iowa, said the board had terminated the employment of Mr. Conner. He had been in the posts since December. 
John K. Hanson, the company's 76-year-old founder and chairman, who has been unable to put a successor in place, was named acting chief executive.
The company has lost money in the last three quarters, and sales of its top line of recreational vehicles are down significantly, said an analyst, Frank P. Rolfes of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis. ''The overall recreational vehicles business is not good,'' he said, ''but Winnebago is suffering more than the industry.''
He attributed Winnebago's performance to quality and production problems and misjudgment in building inventory. Yesterday's termination of Mr. Conner, however, did not move the stock, which closed at $5.125, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.
''They've had a revolving door there for several years,'' Mr. Rolfes said. ''It didn't hurt the stock today, but this uncertainty about management has hurt in the long run.''
Mr. Conner and Mr. Hanson were not available to comment, a company spokesman said. In December, when he was named to the top posts, Mr. Conner said he was not concerned about management flux. ''I've worked as a consultant for John K.,'' he said. ''We've tested out our relationship and found it extremely enjoyable and fruitful.''
Mr. Hanson, who Mr. Rolfes said has not been in good health lately, has tried out several people in the chief executive post in the last decade, including a son, John V. Hanson, and all have been found wanting. The elder Mr. Hanson is ''the key to the thing,'' Mr. Rolfes said, ''and anything that happens will be based on his influence.'' The Hansons own 45 percent of the company.
Mr. Conner, 57, joined Winnebago in 1988 as chief executive of a Winnebago subsidiary, Cycle Sat, which distributes commercials to television stations via satellite. He was made deputy chairman last August, succeeding Mr. Hanson's son, who left the company.
At that time, a 10-member management council was in operation. The council was set up after the departure a year ago of Gerald Gilbert, president and chief executive.
Mr. Conner and Mr. Gilbert once both held senior management positions at the Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis but were not well acquainted there. Mr. Conner left Control Data in 1985 after 18 years, to set up a consulting firm. He was a Winnebago board member since 1984.

HEADLINE: Net of Times Co. Halved in First Quarter

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1990 dropped by 50 percent, to $16.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $33.5 million, or 42 cents a share, in the 1989 period.
The company's income from continuing operations also amounted to $16.6 million, or 22 cents a share, a decline of 47 percent. In the first quarter of 1989, the company earned $31.5 million, or 40 cents a share, from continuing operations. The results for 1989 do not include $2 million, or 2 cents a share, for the company's cable system, which was sold in August. 
Consolidated revenues increased by almost 2 percent during the first three months of this year, to $431.2 million, compared with $423.1 million in 1989.
 
Advertising Linage Lower
The main reasons for the decline in income from continuing operations, the company said, were lower advertising linage at The New York Times newspaper and reductions in earnings resulting from the 1989 purchase of McCall's magazine, as well as depreciation and interest costs connected with the company's new printing and distribution plant in Edison, N.J.
The drop in ad linage at The Times, a decline of 11.8 percent in the quarter, reflects the continuing weakness in the New York region's economy. Most of the loss was in help wanted and real estate advertising.
The Times newspaper reported reaching record circulation levels. For the six months ended March 31, The Times notified the Audit Bureau of Circulations that its weekday circulation was 1.15 million, an increase of 33,000 over the corresponding period a year ago, with Sunday circulation just over 1.7 million, a gain of 42,000.
 
McCall's Purchase a Factor
The purchase of McCall's magazine last year accounted for a reduction in earnings of 5 cents a share.
Another 8 cents a share of the reduction came from increased depreciation and interest expense. In the first quarter, the Times Company completed the new automated color production and distribution plant in Edison as well as a new printing plant for The Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News.
The company's newspaper group, which consists of The New York Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune, reported a drop in operating profits, to $38.4 million from $55.9 million. Revenues for the group declined to $333.8 million from $343.1 million.
 
Loss for Magazine Group
The company's magazine group reported a loss of $3.8 million for the quarter, compared with a $700,000 profit in 1989, though revenues for the group increased to $79.1 million from $62.6 million. The company said both the drop in earnings and the increase in revenues were attributable to the purchase of McCall's in July.
In the company's forest products group, which includes interests in several Canadian newsprint mills, equity in earnings was $30,000, compared with $3.6 million in 1989. The company said the decrease was caused by an unfavorable currency exchange rate and an oversupply of newsprint that led to heavy discounting.
The company's broadcast and information services group, which includes several television and radio operations, reported unchanged operating profits of $2.9 million on revenues of $18.3 million, compared with $17.3 million in 1989. Increased depreciation from new plants offset increased advertising revenues.
The Times Company's share price closed yesterday at $22.75, down 75 cents, in American Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Slip in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in extremely thin trading yesterday, as dealers ignored a weaker-than-expected report on retail sales and focused on a long holiday weekend instead.
The six-tenths of a percentage point drop in retail sales reported for March was far steeper than the two-tenths of a percentage point increase that most analysts had been anticipating.
Rather than focus on the unexpected drop, which suggests that consumer spending may be tailing off, dealers instead chose to concentrate on an upward revision in the February sales figures. Even with the change, retail sales in February still declined by three-tenths of a percentage point. 
 
'Demand Just Isn't There'
Evidence of a slowdown in as large a segment of the economy as consumer spending would usually be well received in the fixed-income markets, which thrive on slow growth and low inflation.
''The market liked the retail sales number for about a quarter of a second, and then the February revision came out,'' a bond trader said.
''It's typical, because the market has ignored good news for the last month,'' the trader added. ''That's because the Street is long securities and retail demand just isn't there.''
A rumor that a large foreign account, possibly Japanese, was looking to sell $1 billion or more of bonds also served to push prices lower. Moreover, with a report on producer prices for March due this morning and the credit markets closed in observance of Good Friday, few traders were willing to establish new positions.
 
'People May Be Afraid'
''I was shocked at the market's disregard of the retail sales report, but I don't think anybody wants to put much on the table in advance of the producer prices report,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. ''People may be afraid of an unfriendly number.''
However, most analysts are forecasting that producer prices rose by a modest one or two-tenths of a percentage point last month, helped by softness in energy prices.
The bulk of the day's price drop was felt among longer-term notes and bonds.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 1/32, down 7/32, to yield 8.58 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/8, down 5/32, to yield 8.63 percent. The 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price ot yield 8.63 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 7/8, down 2/32, to yield 8.56 percent.
 
Slight Gain for Bills
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, up two basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.76 percent.
In the new-issue corporate bond market, the Hertz Corporation offered $75 million of senior one-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
The 8.70 percent notes, which mature on April 23, 1991, were priced at 100, 45 basis points over the prevailing bond-equivalent yield on one-year Treasury bills.
The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Services and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Little Change in Prices
Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very slow, dealers said, with little change in prices.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended April 2. The narrowest measure, M-1, rose by $3.4 billion.
The report was released after the special 2 P.M. close of the Government securities market yesterday. American Expressd (Shearson Lehman Hutton)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Air Bag Maker A Big Wall St. Hit

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
OEA Inc. makes a small explosive device that triggers the inflation of an automobile air bag milliseconds after a crash, and the Denver-based company's stock price has shot up nearly as fast.
Last month alone, OEA's shares rose 35 percent on the American Stock Exchange, where they closed yesterday at $43, unchanged for the day.
''That stock is going nuts,'' said William H. Steele of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''It is a pure play on the air bag industry.''
In a regulation issued in July 1984, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that by the fall of 1989 all new cars must have automatic seat belts or air bags on the driver's side. 
The agency estimated that in October there were a little over a million air bag-equipped cars on the road. It predicts that 2.9 million more will be sold during the 1990 model year and that by 1993, 5 million to 6 million cars a year will be sold with air bags. Passenger-side air bags are expected to follow, and Federal safety experts proposed this year that car makers begin installing air bags in light trucks and vans within three years.
''The air bag business holds tremendous potential and that's what is driving the stock,'' said Jerry R. Levine, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
''We forecast that air bags will become the preferred passive restraint system by 1992,'' said Mr. Steele of Dean Witter. Consumer groups, he said, have shown that many people do not like automatic seat belts, which hit some passengers in the throat and others in the forehead.
The insurance industy is also fueling sales by offering discounts on personal injury and medical coverage for drivers of cars equipped with air bags.
For investors, OEA represents one of the few ways to cash in directly on the growing popularity of air bags. The primary makers of air bag systems, TRW Inc. and Morton International Inc., are billion-dollar conglomerates, with air bags only a small part of their business.
Still, a recent Salomon Brothers report on Morton was entitled ''Air bags Should Inflate Earnings.'' Michael E. Hoffman, a Salomon analyst, recommended purchase of the stock, saying, ''We believe that the current stock price does not adequately account for the potential earnings and cash-flow contribution of the company's air bag business.'' By 1995, he predicted, air bag sales will represent 10 percent of sales for the company. Morton's stock closed yesterday at $37.875.
The investment community is less enthusiastic about TRW, but the popularity of air bags is still seen as a positive development for the company.
OEA's one competitor, CIL Inc., based in Toronto, is a division of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate.
Despite the competition, OEA has 70 percent of the market for the ''air bag initiators.'' Analysts discount the threat of additional competitors entering the field.
In the manufacture of air bags, quality and reliability are critical issues. ''You have to establish a name,'' Mr. Steele said. ''These initiators have to work 100 percent of the time. If an air bag system does fail, there is a huge potential for loss.''
It would also be expensive for a rival to develop a manufacturing process for the highly sensitive explosive device that sells for $10 to $15.
OEA also makes the device that triggers the ejection seats in military aircraft and the safety chutes in passenger aircraft, as well as the devices that help eject different stages of missiles and space vehicles.
The company's reliance on military contracts has troubled some investors. ''You can't neglect the fact that most of the sales come from defense,'' Mr. Levine said. Still, because of the nature of OEA's government contracts, Mr. Levine said the company was not particularly vulnerable to cuts in military spending.
Mr. Steele of Dean Witter said the air bag initiators would eventually become OEA's most important product. For the first six months of OEA's current fiscal year, the devices accounted for about 28 percent of sales and half of earnings, Dean Witter said. Dean Witter estimates that the company's earnings per share will grow by 20 percent a year for the next five years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed and Gold Up In Quiet Pre-Easter Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished narrowly mixed yesterday in quiet trading ahead of the Easter holiday weekend. Gold prices rose worldwide.
Activity finished early in Europe, where traders have a four-day weekend. In domestic dealings, traders spent a dull session squaring accounts ahead of what will be a short trading session today. 
''There's not much interest out there at all,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The most notable activity came from Japanese investors, who sold dollars for yen. Mr. Flanagan said there was some speculation among traders that the Bank of Japan might move to raise interest rates over the weekend in an attempt to bolster the weak Japanese currency.
 
Strength Against the Yen
Still, the dollar maintained its strength against the yen, relinquishing ground only in Asian trading.
In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.50 yen, to a closing 158.00 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 158.14 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 158.18 yen, up from 157.95 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6425, from $1.6432 late Wednesday. In New York, sterling fell to $1.6420 from Wednesday's $1.6425.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6724 West German marks, up from 1.6720; 1.4818 Swiss francs, up from 1.4800; 5.6160 French francs, up from 5.6110; 1,229.50 Italian lire, down from 1,230.25, and 1.1617 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1645.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.90 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.25 an ounce, up 50 cents.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $375.25 a troy ounce, from $374.75 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $375.50 from $374. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.07 to close at a bid of $376.20.
Silver prices were little changed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery slipped to $5.091 a troy ounce from Wednesday's $5.129. In London, silver traded at a late bid of $5.11 an ounce, unchanged from Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 12

 BODY:
After 11 months of decline Japan's trade surplus climbed in March, but economists said it was because the month's imports were being compared with an unusually large amount of imports in March 1989.
The Finance Ministry today reported a surplus of $7.09 billion in March, up from $6.61 billion in March 1989. In each of the 11 previous months, the surplus had been smaller than in the corresponding month a year earlier.
In February, the surplus had fallen to $5.01 billion from $7.23 billion in February 1989.
For Japan's fiscal year, which ended March 31, the surplus, measured when goods pass through customs, fell to $59.7 billion from $78.9 billion in the previous year, the ministry reported.
In trade with the United States, which has been pressing Japan to narrow the imbalance, the March surplus contracted to $3.77 billion, from $4.01 billion a year earlier. For the fiscal year, Japan's sales to the United States exceeded American sales here by $42.8 billion, down 12.7 percent from the $49 billion surplus the year before.

HEADLINE: The Decline of Bonwit Teller: Did Time Pass Retailer By?

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, Bonwit Teller and Saks Fifth Avenue, two of the nation's most celebrated fashion retailers catering to affluent customers, were roughly equivalent in size and approach.
But today, as businesses, they are worlds apart. Saks, owned since 1974 by a British company, has become the nation's prime seller of clothing to affluent women, has greatly expanded its men's clothing lines and is now one of the nation's most profitable retailers. Bonwit this week began going-out-of-business sales as its losses under its Australian parent company became insurmountable. 
 
Lack of Consistency Seen
The unhappy story of Bonwit's demise, analysts said, is a case of a retailer that first lost its edge in marketing and then became a repeated takeover target, with each new owner shifting strategies. Customers, understandably confused, fled to other stores. And so Bonwit's once-profitable marketing formula of catering mainly to affluent, fashion-conscious women was squandered.
''I don't mean to be unkind,'' said Marvin J. Rothenberg, head of the retail marketing consulting firm bearing his name, ''but Bonwit Teller was dead for years, only no one buried it.''
The Pyramid Companies of Syracuse, which bought the Bonwit name and the leases on two Bonwit stores, said it would heed the lessons of the retailer's decline. Pyramid plans to encourage a new top management team to focus sharply on profits, partly by giving the executives a 50 percent stake in the business.
Industry analysts said that Bonwit's problems were magnified by the operational and marketing changes brought about as at least 10 management teams altered the company with their own agendas. By comparison, Saks had three top-management shuffles in the same period, and they kept the chain's policy consistent. They also drove Saks's sales to six times that of Bonwit's - more than $1 billion, compared with $168 million - and kept the stores profitable while Bonwit suffered intermittent losses.
Both Bonwit and Saks were put up for sale several months ago, but for very different reasons. Bonwit drew no bidders, while the more alluring Saks attracted eight, leading to strong expectations that it will soon have new owners.
 
Behind the Sale Signs
The Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer that bought both Bonwit and B. Altman, went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in August and put Bonwit on the block to raise cash. Last week a Federal bankruptcy judge approved Hooker's plan to liquidate most of the Bonwit stores. As a result, there was a sharp cutback in the number of stores, to 4 from 16, effectively putting the other 12 out of business.
For its part, Saks's owner, B.A.T. Industries of London, is selling off Saks, along with Marshall Field & Company and other American retail entities, to focus on its core tobacco business and forestall a hostile takeover by Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier.
 
'It Was a Great Company'
Rival retailers express sympathy but are often caustic about the reasons for Bonwit's downfall.
''I started with Bonwit and it was a great company many years ago,'' said Ira Neimark, chairman and chief executive of Bergdorf Goodman. ''But the lack of consistent management is one of the biggest reasons why Bonwit lost its way.''
Paul Leblang, senior vice president of marketing for Saks Fifth Avenue, said: ''Bonwit's ultimately failed to satisfy its customers and no longer was the 'destination' store.' If you don't project yourself in a consistent way, you lose your spot on the positioning ladder.''
Mr. Leblang added, ''Consumers didn't quite know what Bonwit's had anymore.''
It is now up to Pyramid, whose store leases are in Boston and Buffalo, to give Bonwit a second life of sorts. Pyramid says it will also seek to replace the flagship store being closed in Trump Tower in Manhattan with another one on Fifth Avenue. Two other Bonwit stores, in Hooker shopping malls in Cincinnati and Columbia, S.C., will continue to operate under a license from Pyramid.
Robert Congel, Pyramid's managing partner, said he hoped to revive Bonwit by ''motivating a new management team we have selected, by offering its four members almost half of the business, by giving them a debt-free company and eventually a new flagship.''
Pyramid has built most of its 16 malls in the Northeast by offering partnerships to experts in finance, legal affairs, mall leasing and construction. Pyramid typically retains a 50 percent stake in those centers.
 
'Total Control' Sought
Mr. Congel said Pyramid would not restrict Bonwit stores to just company-owned malls, of which 17 new ones are in development. He said plans called for new Bonwit stores in ''appropriate, upscale locations in such cities as Philadelphia and New York.'' He added, ''We want to open at least one new Bonwit a year but we want to have total control.''
The company was started by Paul J. Bonwit in the 1880's when he opened a small shop at Sixth Avenue and 18th Street selling fine women's apparel and exclusive designs. In 1898, he formed a partnership with Edmund D. Teller.
Bonwit was acquired by the Allied Stores Corporation in 1979 from Genesco Inc., and Allied seemed to give it the expansion and confidence that competing retail executives say it deserved.
Allied moved the flagship store to Trump Tower and it seemed that after years of static ownership Bonwit might finally thrive. But in 1986, Allied was acquired in a hostile takeover by the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian real estate developer.
''One of the first things Robert Campeau told me in 1986 was that Bonwit had to be sold,'' said William Ruben, who was chairman and chief executive of Bonwit from 1983 through March 1989.
Walter K. Levy, a retail-marketing consultant, said, ''Genesco bought Bonwit for prestige, Allied bought it to go upscale and Hooker bought it for anchors for its medium-income malls.'' But Bonwit was a high-priced retailer that did not fit into some of the new Hooker malls, he said.
Even under Allied, said Jerome Chazen, chairman of Liz Claiborne, Inc., a leading women's apparel maker, Bonwit surrendered its prime focus. ''To Allied, it was regarded only as a small, nonprofitable entity,'' he added.
 
'The Wrong Markets'
But Mr. Ruben said: ''I thought that Bonwit should be expanded into existing markets, like New York, Chicago and Philadelphia, where there could be economies of scale in advertising and distribution. But Hooker took a fine, upscale retailer and put it in the wrong markets.''
In the summer of 1989, however, Hooker found itself with little money even after selling Bonwit's accounts receivables to the GE Capital Corporation.
Recalling that Bonwit in the late 1960's had an enviable 10 percent operating profit margin, Mr. Levy, the New York consultant who had also worked for Bonwit, attributed the gains to the introduction of designer clothes at the chain by Mildred Custin, then Bonwit's chairman.
''But as Bonwit's began to flounder,'' Mr. Levy said, ''it lost the sharp elbows that Saks Fifth Avenue had. Without that or a more critical mass, it meant that Bonwit couldn't get its deliveries on time nor enough exclusives to make it stand out.''
