HEADLINE: BOEING TO FINANCE NEW 767-X AIRLINER WITHOUT JAPANESE

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said today that it would finance by itself the development of its proposed 767-X aircraft. Three Japanese aerospace companies will be substantial suppliers for the 300-seat twin-engine plane but will not be partners, Boeing said after months of industry speculation about possible Japanese participation.
The arrangement may help allay concerns that Boeing might be giving away vital aircraft technology to Japanese companies in return for investments, but Boeing officials said this concern was not an important factor in the negotiations.
Some economists had argued that the proposed partnership would give invaluable help to Japan's efforts to become a power in aerospace, one of the few industries in which the United States remains a leader. In that light, some analysts view the agreement as a setback for the Japanese, who appear to have given ground to avoid criticism that they are pushing their way into too big a role in American business. 
 
Entirely New Plane
The 767-X will be an entirely new aircraft that will be larger than the existing 767 but smaller than the four-engine 747 jumbo jet.
Under the terms of the agreement signed on Thursday, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries will share responsibility for providing Boeing with 15 to 20 percent of the 767-X's airframe. The three companies already provide about 15 percent of the current 767, including fuselage panels and aerodynamic fairings - parts that smooth the aircraft's contours - and they are expected to supply similar items plus additional airframe structures for the new plane.
Development costs are estimated at $4 billion, and analysts said that Boeing would have no trouble raising such an amount by itself but that a working partnership now could have become important for more costly future aircraft, like the proposed second-generation supersonic transport.
At an estimated development cost of more than $30 billion, that aircraft will be beyond any single company's financial strength. At the end of the year, Boeing had $1.21 billion in cash; it now has a backlog of orders for 1,710 airplanes, which is equivalent to about $90 billion.
Under the new agreement, the role of the Japanese companies will be managed through the project office at Boeing and will have staff in that office. On the older 767, they are simply subcontractors arranged through Boeing's materiel division.
As a partner, the Japanese would have been much more deeply involved in sales, marketing and technology, said a Boeing spokesman, T. Craig Martin. Under a partnership, they would have sent 200 to 300 engineers to Seattle to work on various aspects, gaining valuable experience for future aircraft manufacturing in Japan. As suppliers, they will send fewer engineers, the spokesman said, and they will have a smaller role.
 
More Than the Others
The new arrangement ''signifies that the Japanese are more involved and higher up than other suppliers,'' said Lawrence W. Clarkson, senior vice president for government and international affairs of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. In addition, Boeing is interested in acquiring program management techniques and manufacturing technology from the Japanese concerns.
The three Japanese companies were to be partners in Boeing's aborted 7J7 propfan aircraft, a fuel-efficient 150-seat plane. But they were unwilling to meet Boeing's minimum 25 percent stake to play a similar role in the much larger and more costly 767-X program, Mr. Clarkson said. ''The 25 percent of that pie was really a bigger piece than the Japanese wanted to swallow, given their other commitments,'' he said.
In addition, Mr. Clarkson said, Japanese partners would have limited Boeing's ability to take advantage of domestic sources, which have lately become available because of diminished military spending in the United States.
Mr. Clarkson said Boeing had ''kept the relevant people in Washington informed'' and had not been under pressure from officials to exclude the Japanese. ''The arrangement we have does not give them access to technology they would need to compete with Boeing,'' he said.
 
There Are Critics
But the supplier relationship still has its critics, including Clyde T. Prestowitz, a former Commerce Department trade negotiator and a Japan specialist with the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. Noting headlines today in the Japanese press that Toray Industries, a Japanese company, will supply the carbon fiber for the 767-X, he said this ''suggests that an American composites manufacturer is not going to be in on one of the largest projects ever.''
And while Boeing said the Japanese decision not to invest was purely economic, Richard J. Samuels, director of the Japan Program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said he believed that the Japanese had wanted to avoid a new controversy after the strife generated by Japanese-American collaboration on the FSX, a next-generation fighter jet for the Japanese military.
''I don't believe it got too expensive for the Japanese,'' Mr. Samuels said. Accepting a less visible role was ''politically a very savvy move.''
 
Delivery in 1995
Boeing expects to receive its first firm orders for the 767-X this summer, when its designation will be changed to 777, and to deliver the first planes in 1995.
It will need to be good to compete with the Airbus Industrie A330, a similar-sized and efficient plane introduced a year and a half ago, said Mortem S. Beyer, president of Avmark Inc., an airline consulting firm based in Arlington, Va. The A330, which will begin delivery in 1993, has already ''gobbled up a couple hundred orders, and people seem to like it,'' he said.
''In this business, the guy first off the blocks has a very significant advantage,'' Mr. Beyer said. ''Boeing at this point is in the position of playing catch-up.''

HEADLINE: Simple Request by Zaire's Leader Spurs Troubling Torrent by Critics

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 12

 BODY:
It all seemed innocuous enough. In January, President Mobutu Sese Seko announced that he would hold a series of public hearings throughout Zaire, ''a direct dialogue with the people,'' to better gauge their concerns.
Not that anything was seriously amiss, Mr. Mobutu insisted. In a nationally broadcast speech, he said the political changes sweeping through Eastern Europe were ''of no concern to Zaire.'' The President vowed that Zaire would remain a one-party state, led by ''the Father and the God of the nation,'' as Mr. Mobutu is often called in party literature. 
But Mr. Mobutu's exercise in civic understanding appears to have backfired, threatening his 25-year grip on power in this sprawling central African country of 34 million people.
Spurred by promises that they can speak freely and honestly, more than 5,000 church groups, unions, business organizations and individuals have submitted written critiques to the President. The result has been an outpouring of sentiment against Mr. Mobutu and his autocratic rule.
 
'Results Are Devastating'
''This is the first true public debate ever held on Mobutu and his policies, and the results are devastating,'' an African diplomat said.
Mr. Mobutu and a coterie are accused, among other things, of mismanaging Zaire's economic development, of squandering public funds on grandiose and unnecessary schemes and of allowing corruption to flourish.
To be sure, Mr. Mobutu has also been criticized abroad for Zaire's human rights record and accused of corruption and economic malfeasance. In addition, Democrats in the United States Congress are moving to cut aid to Zaire.
But the public criticism of Mr. Mobutu's policies are is virtually unheard of at home, and those who dare to object have often been imprisoned or forced into internal exile.
So far, Mr. Mobutu has declined to make the responses public, but thousands of copies are being distributed clandestinely throughout Kinshasha. Diplomats, journalists and others who have read them say they are virtually unanimous in calling for major political and economic reforms.
 
Especially Critical of the Party
The responses have been especially critical of the ruling party, the People's Revolutionary Movement, of which all Zairians are required to be members from birth.
''The idea that the M.P.R. is the vanguard of a revolutionary movement that should have been discarded a long time ago,'' a Zairian dissident said, referring to the party by its French initials. ''Zaire is a dictatorship and everyone knows it.''
The Conference of Bishops, for example, an influential group of Catholic hierarchy, called for the adoption of a new constitution that would end the ruling party's monopoly on power. ''The social and moral environment that we live in has been contaminated,'' said the conference, a group which in the past has rarely criticized Government policies.
Similarly, a leading labor group, the National Union for Zairian Workers, called for multiparty democracy, free elections and a ''depoliticization'' of the army.
 
Security Forces Criticized
In much the same vein, a memorandum from municipal employees in Kinshasha criticized security forces for their unchecked ability to ''intimidate and repress the population.''
''We knew we were taking a chance for saying this,'' said a businessman who helped draft a memorandum calling for Mr. Mobutu to resign, ''but it is either now or never.''
Makau Mutua, the Africa Project director for the Lawyer's Committee for Human Rights, who visited Zaire last month, said, ''People have spoken up quite openly and attacked the party and the Government.''
''The cumulative message,'' he said in a telephone interview, ''is that the Government has failed.''
So far, some here say Mr. Mobutu has reacted magnanimously to the growing criticism, at least publicly. In a speech last month, the President urged citizens to ''be calm, stay calm.''
''The will of the majority will be respected,'' he said. ''We will proceed together on the changes wanted by the majority.
''But we will do it quietly, not under pressure from excited people.''
More recently, when university students protested Government austerity measures by burning vehicles and looting stores, witnesses say the police reacted with unusual restraint. Dozens of arrests were made, but generally without the beatings and other violence that sometimes follow such protests.
''Our strong impression was that the security forces were under orders not to react in an excessive manner so as not to ignite further disturbances,'' a Western diplomat said.
 
Debate in Print Quashed
At the same time, Mr. Mobutu has not been reluctant to quash debate when it seemed to go too far. Jeune Afrique, a French-language weekly on African affairs, was banned after it published excerpts from the letters submitted by the Bishops.
Mr. Mobutu then accused the bishops of leaking their comments to the foreign press and the diplomatic community. He said their actions disqualified their opinions from any further consideration.
The question now is how Mr. Mobutu will use the advice. This week the President announced that on April 24 he would unveil a series of ''major political changes,'' but he gave no hint of what they might entail.
But some statements from Mr. Mobutu have already raised expectations that will be difficult to fulfill.
''It's clear that there is increasing agitation for real reform,'' a Zairian businessman said. ''Large numbers of people, perhaps most, doubt that he's capable of making the necessary changes. That could spell disaster.''

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); EUROPE (92%); UNITED STATES (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (72%);

HEADLINE: In Appalachia, Vast Change but New Troubles

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CRANKS, Ky.

 BODY:
In Harlan County, where the coal tipples jut out from the black hills like ungainly prehistoric birds, coal is still king, but it rules a forlorn, beleaguered kingdom.
''Harlan is the sorriest place around,'' said Randy Daniels, a 24-year old unemployed laborer, as he huddled by a coal-burning heater one rainy afternoon. ''They say they're going to put factories in, but they're not going to do nothing in Harlan. From what I can tell, things are just as bad as they used to be.''
A quarter century after the nation's War on Poverty centered on the desperate squalor of Appalachia, there has been some striking progress and some tragic decay in the region, where officials estimate that 2.5 million people live below the poverty line. 
But the progress masks the economic straits of the region's 90 severely depressed counties, mostly the coal-producing areas of West Virgiania, Kentucky, Virginia and Tennessee, in the heart of the region. In the past decade 70,000 jobs in the coal industry have been lost in the region, and old economic problems are compounded by new environmental ones.
After an economic resurgence in the 1970's, life for poor people in the coal country is still much the way the Mayor of Sneedville, Tenn., Charles Turner, described the area in the 1960's when he said, ''We were below the bottom looking up to see the bottom.''
Appalachia's problems received a brief flurry of national attention recently when regional tourism officials reacted angrily to a proposed tour by a San Francisco-based group that billed Appalachia as ''the third world in the U.S.''
The group, Global Exchange, is not a tourist agency, but rather a research and education center that brings people involved in community and social causes to meet with others doing similar work, usually in third world nations. The group plans to meet in June with community organizations in Tennessee, Kentucky, Virginia and perhaps West Virginia.
''These people may have the greatest motives, but the way they marketed it says, 'the third world equals West Virginia,' '' said West Virginia's Commerce Commissioner, John Brown, whose criticism was echoed by officials in Kentucky and Tennessee.
''That reinforces a stereotype that has no credibility,'' Mr. Brown said. ''We don't all sit on porches picking banjoes and sipping moonshine.''
 
Poverty Is Greatly Reduced
In fact, much has changed in Appalachia, where many areas have diversified their economy, and where 2,500 new miles of highway has diminished the crushing isolation of some mountain communities.
''You can see the change in children's eyes,'' said Francis E. Moravitz, executive director of the Appalachian Regional Commission, formed in 1965 to foster economic development in the region running from southern New York to northern Mississippi. ''In the early 1960's, the image of an Appalachian child was a gaunt, hungry, dirty face. Today they look like children all over.''
But here in Harlan County, made famous in the 1930's by the violent labor upheaval that earned it the name ''Bloody Harlan,'' many of the faces still recall the depression-era photographs of Walker Evans.
Cranks is a mountain community of perhaps 500 people nestled in the brooding hollows between the Cumberland and Pine Mountains, where neat brick homes stand just down the road from rickety shacks with junk-strewn yards and outhouses.
Like most of his friends, Mr. Daniels dropped out of high school early, expecting to find work in the coal fields or timber mills. Instead, he is lucky to find seasonal work mowing grass at an apartment building in town.
 
'There's Just No Work'
''I went to Virginia a while back and put in 20 applications at the sawmills, but never heard from one of them,'' he said, while watching television at Flossie Brown's cluttered frame house with its weathered religious pictures hanging at odd angles on the walls. ''There's just no work nowhere.'' The coal haulers still roar through the winding mountain roads here, and coal mining directly or indirectly still accounts for an overwhelming majority of the economic activity. But after a boom in the 1970's, mechanization, competition with other fuels and now Federal clean air regulations are casting new shadows on the region.
The county's unemployment rate last year stood at 9.4 percent, but residents say the figure is misleadingly low. It does not account for those who have long since stopped looking for work, or those making do with part-time work or those who have gone elsewhere.
Unemployment in Harlan County peaked at 24.3 percent in 1983, and the work force declined to 11,682 at the end of 1989 from 13,672 in 1980. Similarly, McDowell County, in the heart of the West Virginia coal fields, lost 19 percent of its population in the 1980's, and more than half the state's 55 counties lost more than 5 percent of their jobs. #70,000 Coal Mining Jobs Lost Throughout the region, about 70,000 coal mining jobs have been lost in the last 10 years, and there is little optimism about a resurgence.
For some of those who stay, there are new environmental worries compounding the old economic ones. Wilma Garrett, old beyond her 55 years, lives in a tumbledown shack, its yard strewn with junked furniture, without any running water.
On a rainy day, water washes down, rust colored and laced with chemicals, from the mine sites in the hills and rushes, through the gullies in front of her home. More unsettling still is the deathly green color of the local lake that fishermen frequented before its pollution.
Mrs. Garrett says her 6-year-old granddaughter recently broke out in boils after playing in a polluted creek near her home. Much of the available well water is so polluted it cannot be used in any form.
''There's no way to purify it,'' she said. ''The more you boil it, the redder it gets, like syrup.''
A regional citizens' group, Kentuckians for the Commonwealth, says more than 20 percent of the water wells in eastern Kentucky have been contaminated or lost because of pollution from mining activity.
Still, many parts of Appalachia have shown remarkable progress, and people bitterly resent the caricatured ''Beverly Hillbillies'' stereotypes that still linger.
The area covered by the Appalachian Regional Commission includes parts of 12 states in addition to all of West Virginia. It includes 397 counties, of which 90 are still severely distressed.
After the poverty rate declined to 14 percent in 1980 from 31.2 percent in 1960, officials estimate that the rate has declined slightly over the past decade in the region's 195,000 square miles that the Government classifies as Appalachia. That would leave about about 2.5 million of the region's 21 million residents living below the Federal poverty line, which was $12,675 for a family of four in 1989.
Sam Dayton heads the Georgia Mountains Regional Development Center, one of the local planning groups created by the regional commission, and covers 13 counties in the northern part of the state.
 
Turnaround Called Dramatic
The counties closest to Atlanta are doing better than the ones further north, but Mr. Dayton said the overall turnaround since the 1960's was dramatic.
For example, he said Dawson County in northern Georgia had an unemployment rate of 29 percent in the 1960's, with a median family income about a third the national figure. Today it is the fastest-growing of the 13 counties Mr. Dayton oversees, with a median family income that is about 75 percent of the national average. Like much of the region, it has gone from rural to exurban, feeding off metropolitan economies and luring retirees, tourism and some small business.
''The economic turnaround seen here is nothing short of an economic miracle,'' he said.
For other areas with less apparent successes, the progress has come in the slow process of building roads, sewers and other facilities to support a more broad-based economy. In the most hard-hit areas, the same type of building is part of a strategy for preparing for a world beyond coal.
 
'We Are Going to Outlive Coal'
''If we can survive 100 years of cyclical coal, we can beat this too,'' said Roger Recktenwald, head of an area development district centered in Pikeville, Ky., where coal is virtually the only industry and a quarter of the population lives at or below the national poverty line. ''We are going to outlive coal.''
Many simply leave, heading for Knoxville or Atlanta or Charlotte. But, for the uneducated poor of Appalachia, the cities often cannot provide the economic opportunity they once did.
When the President Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty began, Appalachia was viewed as a isolated pocket that had somehow missed out on the nation's prosperity. Today, the region's problems - inadequate education, a degraded environment, lack of control over its economy - differ only in degree from the nation's.
''A lot of those people who left looking for work in Detroit are right back in Pikeville now looking for work,'' said Mr. Recktenwald.
 
Some Stay Because It Is Home
But if some stay because they have no choice, many others stay simply because it is home, a place of startling beauty and rich culture for all its problems.
One of these is Becky Simpson, whose cluttered home is the site of a remarkable 11-year-old community group, the Cranks Creek Survival Center. The center provides food and clothing for hundreds of poor mountain people monthly. Busloads of volunteers come from around the country to help in projects, including building or rebuilding 79 homes in the past four years.
The mountain hollow where Mrs. Simpson's ancestors settled and where she grew up is now a mine site. There is a silt pond where her home was, and she is fighting a strip mine she fears will inevitably bury her family graveyard.
Still, she cannot imagine being anywhere else.
''I feel peace of mind when I come back here,'' she said. ''This hollow was our whole world. You can't just forget it and walk away.''

HEADLINE: Baker Presses Lawmakers to Back A Strategy of Talks in El Salvador

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Hoping to prevent Congress from cutting aid to El Salvador when lawmakers return to work next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is lobbying Democratic leaders to give the Administration time to encourage peace negotiations between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas.
The Baker effort represents an attempt to undercut opposition from Congressional Democrats to the Administration policy of continuing substantial levels of economic and military support for the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.
Since six Jesuit priests were killed in San Salvador in November, many top Democrats have lost patience with Administration arguments that quiet pressure can improve El Salvador's human-rights performance. Officials in Washington and El Salvador are nearly unanimous in saying that the killings were the work of a right-wing death squad tied to the military. 
Democrats have responded to Mr. Baker's initiative by insisting that the Administration take a harder line on human-rights abuses in El Salvador.But there appears to be some support for trying to reduce partisan friction over aid to El Salvador.
 
Plan for Bipartisan Policy
A top Administration official said Mr. Baker was trying to duplicate his successful effort last year to build bipartisan support for the Bush Administration's policy toward Nicaragua. Mr. Baker convinced Congressional leaders to back food, clothing and other aid for the Nicaraguan rebels in exchange for Administration promises to support elections in Nicaragua. Bush aides credit that policy with ending the contra war and leading to the landslide defeat of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in February.
The Administration is proposing that El Salvador, which has received more than $4 billion in United States aid since 1980, receive $86 million in military aid and $229 million in economic assistance in fiscal 1990. Democratic leaders have threatened to slash those figures by half or more.
Mr. Baker held separate meetings last week with top lawmakers from both houses, in which he urged them to hold off proposals to cut or condition assistance to El Salvador until they could join the Administration in creating a new bipartisan policy based on negotiations and human rights.
Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said Mr. Baker's message to the lawmakers was, ''We think for the first time there is a real possibility to achieve peace but we can't help that happen if we turn El Salvador into a partisan issue.''
 
Motivation for Joint Policy
He said Mr. Baker assured the lawmakers that the Administration shared their concern on human rights and the slow pace of judicial revisions in San Salvador, and that a bipartisan approach was the way to increase Washington's leverage over the Cristiani Government.
Mr. Aronson said Mr. Baker would come back to the Congressional leadership next week, after the Easter recess, to hear their suggestions and hopefully work out a joint policy.
At least some Democrats apparently took Mr. Baker's appeal to heart. Democratic members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee postponed drafting an amendment to an appropriations bill for emergency aid to Panama and Nicaragua that would have conditioned further military aid to El Salvador on improvements in human rights.
''You're likely to get a policy reassessment with an agreement,'' a House aide said. ''This is motivated on both sides to see if a meeting of the minds can be reached on Salvador.''
 
Meetings With 40 Lawmakers
Senator Alan Cranston of California, the Democratic whip, said despite the meeting with Mr. Baker, he continued to oppose military aid to El Salvador until the Salvadoran Government ''reins in the death squads and prosecutes the killers.''
''I am not alone in this view,'' he continued. ''But I think they might be able to get enough support to keep military aid to El Salvador going, unfortunately.''
While more than 70,000 people have died in El Salvador's fighting since 1979, no Salvadoran military officer has been prosecuted for a human-rights abuse.
Mr. Baker laid out the Administration view of the Salvadoran situation to about 40 ranking Senators and Congressmen in four seperate meetings, arguing that the 11-year civil war is at a critical stage.
 
Lessons of Rebel Offensive
He said he saw the April 4 agreement between the guerrillas and the Cristiani Government in Geneva to begin regular peace talks next month as the most serious effort yet to negotiate an end to the conflict.
In Mr. Baker's view, both sides have reason to negotiate. The guerrillas, he said, seem to understand that geopolitical trends, particularly after the Nicaraguan elections and the United States invasion of Panama, are going against them. The Salvadoran Army learned from the huge guerrilla offensive in November that the rebels were not about to wither away under military pressure.
But Mr. Baker also cautioned that the Salvadoran rebels, known as the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, were preparing for a new offensive with renewed shipments of heavy explosives and AK-47 assault rifles from Cuba and Nicaragua. If Congress threatened to cut aid to San Salvador, Mr. Baker argued, it would encourage the guerrillas to launch an all-out offensive that could untrack the new peace initiative.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
New Soviet Threat 'Disturbing' to Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 13

 BODY:
Speaking with unusual force about the Lithuanian crisis, President Bush said today that he and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain found reports of a Kremlin ultimatum to the Baltic republic ''deeply disturbing.'' Mr. Bush said imposition of economic sanctions against Lithuania would violate Moscow's stated policy of seeking to resolve the stalemate over Lithuania's desire for independence without force.
''Now is no time for escalation; it's time for talks,'' Mr. Bush said, speaking for himself and for Mrs. Thatcher at a news conference here.
Mrs. Thatcher added: ''We've come a long way in relations between the Soviet Union and the free world. We wish that improvement to continue, but it could not continue if the Soviet Union were to resolve this by force.'' 
Neither the President nor Mrs. Thatcher would say what they would or could do if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev carried out a threat to suspend shipments of vital supplies, possibly including oil and natural gas, to Lithuania if certain laws are not rescinded in two days. The two leaders also tried to couch their remarks as diplomatically as possible.
Still, their statements after talks represented a marked change by Mr. Bush, who has carefully avoided commenting on developments in the Soviet Union in recent weeks. Mrs. Thatcher has also been restrained in her public statements about Lithuania, restricting herself to calls for peaceful dialogue that she and Mr. Bush repeated today.
The two leaders said they were basing their remarks on a news report about Mr. Gorbachev's threat and declined to go into much detail on the development.
Mr. Bush said the two had learned of the ultimatum only moments before their news conference began and added that their Governments had not yet independently confirmed the details. But United States officials said the White House had in fact learned of it 90 minutes earlier and that Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher had been handed the dispatch about 30 minutes before they emerged from their private conversations to take questions.
The fact that the intensely cautious Mr. Bush, acting for himself and Mrs. Thatcher, chose to bring up the news report at the outset of the news conference, before they were asked about it, illuminated the alarm with which the two leaders viewed the Kremlin's ultimatum more than their words did.
 
On Germany and NATO
Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher said the Lithuanian question, as well as broader issues of German unification and reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, occupied much of their four hours of talks at the cream-colored stucco colonial palace that is Hamilton's Government House.
Since the news report from Moscow was given to the two leaders toward the end of the talks, it was not clear how much time they could have devoted to discussing Mr. Gorbachev's demand that Lithuania rescind a series of laws its Parliament has passed since the declaration of independence.
''Obviously, there has been no time to look into this matter in detail or determine all the facts,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But we have been calling on Moscow publicly and privately for avoiding escalatory measures in favor of dialogue.''
Mrs. Thatcher said that she and Mr. Bush had agreed in advance on what he would say about Mr. Gorbachev's threat.
 
Reluctant at First
At first, Mr. Bush was reluctant to characterize the ultimatum or say whether it violated Mr. Gorbachev's promises not to use force to keep Lithuania within the Soviet Union. But he later said: ''Am I concerned about the report? If it proves to be accurate, the answer is yes, because it goes against the policy of dialogue and a no-coercion dialogue that will result in peaceful evolution of democracy and self-determination.
''So I'm concerned about the report. I'm concerned about the timing. But I just don't want to comment any further.''
Mrs. Thatcher bristled when asked about reports that Mr. Gorbachev had told a delegation of United States senators in Moscow this week that he did not want ''lectures'' from the West on how to handle Lithuania.
''We're just not lecturing anyone, but we're entitled to express a view,'' she said.
The Prime Minister added: ''We've frequently expressed it. This is not a problem that should be solved by force and which cannot be solved by force. It therefore must be solved by discussion. We had a duty to say what we think. We still think that way and we still think that is the only way to go.''
Mr. Bush has said the use of force in Lithuania would set back Soviet-American relations at a time when arms control and other issues appearing to be moving forward relatively smoothly. A major dispute in the relationship could also jeopardize the summit meeting planned in the United States for May 30 to June 3.

HEADLINE: A Museum That Looks to the Future

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 13

 BODY:
This city, which has a reputation of being the elderly custodian of the Liberty Bell and other national heirlooms, is about to exhibit 90,000 square feet of the future.
The Futures Center is to open May 4, a new $71 million wing of the Franklin Institute, which is a 57-year-old science and technology museum on Benjamin Franklin Parkway.
The center is well grounded in history. It rises above the former site of the Magdalen Society Home for Fallen Women. Quakers, who built the home in 1800, were reported to have spent an entire year trying to find a fallen woman who was willing to be reformed. But that is another story. 
The new wing of the institute has the oxymoronic billing as a museum of the future. ''You almost automatically expect museums to be about old stuff, but this one will be forward-thinking,'' said Joel N. Bloom, president and director of the institute. ''We won't try to predict the future, but show the technology that is shaping the future.''
Here, the future will always start about three years off, and visitors will see what is heading their way from the world's laboratories.
 
Dreams That May Come True
There will be exhibits of things like experimental high-speed trains propelled by magnets, or a computer microchip, lodged in the brain of Prosthetic Woman, that may help blind people to see. There will be prototypes of innovations like high-definition television and exhibits on undersea gardening.
And, deeper into the future, displays will focus on the frontiers of scientific inquiry, including nuclear fusion. The center's exhibits will deal with energy, materials, conservation, computers, health, space, careers and forecasting the future, which is what Prof. Arthur B. Shostak does.
Professor Shostak teachs sociology at Drexel University and advises the institute about his specialty, the period from 2015 to 12000. ''The center will help people sharpen their imagery of the possible, probable and preferable futures that we have responsibility for,'' he said.
A central theme of the center is that people have the power to mold the future. In the Choices Forum, a theater with 150 seats and voting buttons, the center will present documentaries about public policy issues, and then put alternatives up for a vote. People may vote for or against nuclear power or genetic engineering, and then see the consequences of their choice on the environment, economy and health.
Visitors will be able to walk into a throbing, sloshing human cell, magnified a million times to the size of a dome 30 feet across. If they wish, they can produce energy with the mitochondria, make proteins with the ribosomes or take charge of the nucleus when a virus attacks. The cell is the frontier of medicine, said Dr. Roberta Goldshlag Cooks, who developed the exhibit.
Exhibits are supposed to entertain and educate. ''People are primates; they learn by touching,'' Mr. Bloom said. ''We're show biz, and there is no conflict between that and first-class content.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Construction is almost complete on the Futures Center, the new $71 million wing of the 57-year-old Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. The center, to open May 4, is being billed as a museum of the future. (The New York Times/Chris Gardner)

HEADLINE: Climbing Tuition Tied to Shrinking Student Pool

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Competition for students and a decline in government support were the main reasons for huge tuition increases at private and public colleges in the 1980's, a new study says.
And while experts predict some relief in the 1990's, they say the price of higher education will still rise faster than inflation, at least until the last of the children born to the baby boom generation start to hit college age.
The new report, ''The College Tuition Spiral,'' was prepared for the College Board and the American Council on Education by Arthur Hauptman, an authority on higher-education finances. 
The report says the shrinking number of college-age youths has played a major role in tuition increases. Will Consumers Revolt? ''The continued decline in this age group through the mid-1990's suggests that college charges probably will continue to outpace inflation for the forseeable future,'' Mr. Hauptman concludes.
But he adds, ''It is difficult to imagine that consumers will be unlimited in their willingness to pay steadily rising college prices.'' He predicted that consumers would eventually rebel against price increases that are double the inflation rate.
From 1980 to 1987, the average annual increase in tuition and fees was slightly under 10 percent, nearly twice the overall increase in the cost of living.
The report also concludes that cutbacks in state aid in the early 1980's were a major factor in tuition increases at public colleges.
 
Why Tuition Went Up
Private colleges raised tuition to pay for better buildings, services and faculty salaries in attempts to maintain their share of a shrinking pool of potential students, the study said. The schools also expanded their own aid programs, a need provoked by cuts at the Federal level.
Furthermore, Mr. Hauptman wrote, with stagnating enrollments schools could no longer spread fixed costs over a growing number of students. And they had to spend more to recruit non-traditional students and counsel them.
Mr. Hauptman said an economic downturn in the next few years could force public institutions dependent on strained state resources to raise tuition but prompt private colleges to hold the line to keep from discouraging prospective students.
The trend of the 1980's was in sharp contrast to the late 1970's, when tuitions and other charges grew more slowly than inflation.
 
Needs Were Unmet
Richard Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, representing 1,600 schools, said colleges had to charge more in the 1980's to catch up with needs that had gone unmet.
''Now there is probably going to be some leveling off and perhaps some decrease on the average,'' Mr. Rosser said. ''But it will still be more than the rate of inflation, because that doesn't relate very well to our true costs.''
Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, said it would be harder for lower-priced schools to cut expenditures and keep tuition down because they were ''less selective and pretty strained already financially.''
But he said a combination of market resistance, the politics of the issue and a fall-off in applications would force a moderation. ''A drop in applications is a powerful statement; there's been some of that at some of the higher-priced institutions,'' Mr. Atwell said.
Charles Kolb, an assistant education under secretary for planning, said his department was taking a comprehensive look at college costs. He said preliminary research indicated that some colleges thought they could control many of the factors that fuel rising tuition. But he declined to be more specific.

HEADLINE: 2 Senators Say Peace Bonus Should Pay for Social Needs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
with President Bush and leaders in their own party, some prominent Democrats have begun to argue that the money cut from the Pentagon in the next several years should be earmarked for education, medical care and other social problems and should not merely be set aside to reduce the Federal deficit.
Their theme seems to be that the deficit was caused by Republicans and should be left to Republicans to resolve, and that Democrats should re-establish their claim as the party best suited to meet the nation's needs.
''At the very moment when so many Democrats seem timid or befuddled,'' Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said this week, ''I see a new opportunity to shape new Democratic ideas and advance enduring Democratic ideas.''
Speaking at Georgetown University, Senator Kennedy said the Democratic Party could ''never regain the Presidency, or even ultimately keep its Congressional power, by disguising or repudiating our own basic identity.'' 
 
Cranston Lists Six Targets
The Democratic whip in the Senate, Alan Cranston of California, made a similar point in speeches throughout his state this week. Senator Cranston maintained that ''the lion's share of the peace dividend'' should be spent in six areas: education, health, drug control, housing, environmental protection and public works.
If, as a result of reduced East-West tensions, military spending is reduced by an average of only $10 billion a year, or about 3 percent, for the next 10 years, the Defense Department's budget in the year 2000 will be $100 billion lower than it is now, in 1990 dollars. The cumulative saving over the decade will be $550 billion.
Although the question of how to use that money may dominate American politics in the 1990's, politicians are only beginning to stake out their positions.
The President asserts that the peace dividend is largely a mirage and that the small sums that may prove real in the next few years must be used entirely to reduce the Federal deficit.
Many of Mr. Bush's critics say he is playing a cagey political game, deliberately avoiding policy decisions that might cause him to lose popularity. Whatever the case, most Republicans seem to feel comfortable taking the same stance as the President's, although a few have broken ranks.
For example, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas says the money should be returned to the people in the form of lower taxes, while Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire favors a new ''Marshall Plan'' to strengthen the burgeoning democracies in Eastern Europe.
Among Democrats, however, a fundamental split has developed between the party leaders in Congress like the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who maintain that deficit reduction must take top priority, and other lawmakers who take the politically aggressive position of favoring new spending for social programs.
 
Polls Back Domestic Spending
So far, Senators Kennedy and Cranston are the most prominent Democrats to speak out for more domestic spending. Opinion polls show this to be popular. A New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,515 adults interviewed by telephone from March 30 through April 2 found that 61 percent support spending ''to fight problems such as drugs and homelessness,'' while 23 percent support reducing the deficit and only 9 percent favor lowering taxes. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
In his Georgetown speech, Senator Kennedy said that the ''end of the cold war'' presented his party with an opportunity to regain its footing. ''A transformed world,'' he said, ''can also transform our politics.''
He continued: ''Domestic programs, long shortchanged to finance defense, should not be depleted again in order to compensate for a deficit also swollen by the defense budget. Let us deal with the deficit as President Bush intended on the day he took office - not with a peace dividend, which he did not expect, but with a Gramm-Rudman process he has repeatedly endorsed.''
Mr. Kennedy was referring to the budget-balancing law, whose principal sponsors in the Senate were Mr. Gramm and Mr. Rudman.
Senator Kennedy proposed cutting the $300 billion military budget by 7 percent in the next fiscal year and by 5 percent more each year through 1995, figures far above the 2 percent cuts advocated by the President. Mr. Kennedy said his proposal would raise a cumulative $170 billion in the next five years.
 
How the Money Would Be Spent
Senator Cranston proposed cumulative cuts of $375 billion through 1997 and specified how he thought the money should be allocated: $123 billion for transportation, more than $60 billion each for education, housing and environmental cleanup, $53 billion for health programs, and $15 billion for crime prevention and drug control.
Neither Mr. Kennedy nor Mr. Cranston, who represent the liberal wing of their party, has the stature he once had in the Senate or in the party. But both are often successful in building coalitions behind positions they adopt.
One leading Democrat who takes issue with their approach is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. In an interview, he said reducing the deficit was the most important first step. ''Until you do that you cannot reduce borrowing,'' he said. ''Until you reduce borrowing, you can't reduce interest rates. And until you reduce interest rates, you can't jump-start the economy.''
Moreover, the Governor said, he would spend money to rebuild Eastern Europe before he began putting extra funds into domestic programs.

HEADLINE: Margaret Atwood Reflects on a Hit

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Family and friends gathered in the home of Margaret Atwood in November to celebrate her 50th birthday. With the lights off and joy and wine flowing freely, everyone was waving sparklers and singing - until the smoke alarm sounded and no one could find the switch to silence it.
In a way that incident, now taking on the aura of a family legend, is a symbol for some of Miss Atwood's more recent writing. For millions of readers in North America and elsewhere, Miss Atwood's chilling best-seller ''The Handmaid's Tale'' has become a warning about what could happen when a country is taken over by a theocracy in a quiet, almost frighteningly normal fashion. That concern is likely to increase, since a film version of the novel has been playing in the United States, Canada and Europe.
In the film as in the novel, part of a polluted United States, now called Gilead, is ruled by moralistic evangelicals who have relegated the remaining few fertile females, called handmaids, to the role of passive propagators. Miss Atwood's work, set in the Northeast, depicts a sterile, embattled world where women are divided into classes by color-coded clothing, where moral hypocrisy reigns and where abortion is a capital crime along with gender treachery (lesbianism). 
 
Multi-National Conference
The movie was produced by an American, Daniel Wilson, directed by a West German, Volker Schlondorff, adapted from Miss Atwood's novel by an Englishman, Harold Pinter, and interpreted by an international cast headed by Robert Duvall, Faye Dunaway and Natasha Richardson.
A fairly faithful adaptation of the grim and clever book, which has sold more than a million copies, the movie emerged from many hours of consultation among Mr. Schlondorff, Mr. Pinter and Miss Atwood around her kitchen counter here. Miss Atwood lives with her companion, Graeme Gibson, their daughter, Jess, and two cats named Fluffy and Blackie on a quiet, narrow residential street within primal screaming distance of Toronto's trendy Yorkville area.
In one sense the 1985 tale has helped mark an international coming of age for writers in Canada, a country that many elsewhere had long seen as a kind of decaffeinated America. Many years ago Hugh MacLennan, another Canadian novelist, described the literature of a young Canada as, ''Boy meets girl in Winnipeg, and who cares?'' But now an entire generation of worldly English Canadian writers, including Robertson Davies, Alice Munro, Mordecai Richler, Farley Mowat and Miss Atwood, are producing literature with themes that strike responsive chords throughout the English-speaking world and beyond.
 
In the Realm of Possibility
Sipping tea and munching ''sinful chocolate cookies'' in her kitchen, Miss Atwood called her best-known novel a ''what-if tale.'' The story for ''Handmaid'' began to emerge in 1980, she said, as individual images ignited by newspaper items and snippets of conversation. ''I didn't include anything that had not already happened, was not under way somewhere or that we don't have the technology to do,'' she said, For four years she collected thoughts and clippings and found that the handmaid story was interrupting her other writing. So she set other work aside and in 1984, during teaching stints in Berlin and Alabama, began writing the novel, which was published in Canada in 1985 and in the United States in 1986.
Her tale draws on details and artifacts from history and from many cultures. References, descriptions and borrowings include a Berlin-type wall, slave-breeding practices, chemical pollutants that affect human reproduction, Government birth and enforced-abortion decrees that draw from similar rules in Romania and China and codes of puritanical religious conduct that are found in fundamentalist Iran, Quaker Pennsylvania and 17th-century New England, where an ancestor of Miss Atwood's was once sentenced to hang as a witch. The white hood placed over the head of those being hanged in her tale is derived from 19th-century Canadian executions.
 
Inspired by the Bible
Miss Atwood recalled: ''I was reading the Bible - some of us still do that, you know - and I saw the tale of Jacob and his wives and handmaids, a kind of early Baby M. This is not an attack on Christianity, but the fact is Christians have long persecuted other sects and each other, as they are in Northern Ireland today.''
Then Miss Atwood applied that to some everyday themes. ''People were saying things like, 'A woman's place is in the home.' And I got to thinking, well, how would someone enforce thoughts like that?''
She is convinced that such enforcement would not come through grand pronouncements. ''The banality of evil is overwhelming,'' she said. ''People who do these kinds of things don't walk down the street frothing at the mouth and looking like Quasimodo. They don't announce, 'We're setting up concentration camps for people we don't like.' They perhaps help create chaos and then wait for society to plead for authoritarianism to help clean up the mess.''
That is the case among the rigidly puritanical and pious rulers of Gilead. As one of the ''Handmaid'' characters puts it: ''In the days of anarchy it was freedom to. Now you are being given freedom from.''
 
The Country Next Door
Miss Atwood chose to place her cautionary tale of extremism in the United States, that economically and culturally dominating neighbor many Canadians think of first when they want to feel frightened. ''The Handmaid's Tale'' seemed to gather additional credibility with the subsequent rise of the Moral Majority there, the Presidential candidacy of Pat Robertson and the sexual and financial imbroglios of various television ministries.
''In Canada,'' Miss Atwood maintained, ''they said, 'Could it happen here?' In England, they said, 'Jolly good yarn.' In the United States, they said, 'How long have we got?' ''
In Miss Atwood's mind the story unfolds around Harvard, where she attended graduate school. But because Harvard would not allow them to film on campus, the movie was filmed last year in North Carolina - around Duke University and in an abandoned cigarette factory.
Miss Atwood was fearful early on as she relinquished control of the story to the chaotic collaborative process that is movie-making. She said she provided only context for Mr. Schlondorff and Mr. Pinter, and corrected some script phrasing from British into American - changing hand cream into hand lotion, for instance.
 
Danger Averted
Miss Atwood pronounced herself happy with the movie version. ''This story,'' she said, ''could have been the most gross sexploitative film ever, sort of 'maidens on a sexual rampage.' ''
She said she enjoys the brief spurts of fame that accompany the release of a new book or movie. ''It's fun if you understand it's not serious, not real life,'' she said. ''It's interesting to experience and observe. But if you start seeing the billboards and believing you're Cinderella, then you're in very serious trouble creatively.''
Miss Atwood has stopped all outside activities to return to writing a new novel, subject unannounced, on her normal writing schedule. That involves covering a half-dozen legal pages in as many hours with handwriting each day and then typing and rewriting a handful of pages written several days previously. She finds this kind of hopscotching back and forth helps her insure consistency and gauge pacing and progress.
To relax, she consumes a murder mystery in two or three hours. ''I love them,'' she said. ''They reduce chaos to order and are not immediately threatening.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margaret Atwood, whose 1985 best seller, ''The Handmaid's Tale,'' was filmed by Volker Schlondorff from a Harold Pinter screenplay. (Camera Press/Sally Soames)

HEADLINE: Democracy Without Taxation

BYLINE: By Eugene J. McCarthy; Eugene J. McCarthy, a Democrat, was a Senator from Minnesota.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Throughout our history, protest and revolt against taxes have taken strange twists and turns.
The patriots of Boston, anticipating the Revolution, opened the antitax action by dumping tea into the harbor in protest against what they considered a discriminatory tax on their favorite (next to rum) drink. James Otis, an eminent Massachusetts lawyer, took up the cause, not by denouncing taxes, even particular ones, but by his bold and stirring declaration, ''Taxation without representation is tyranny.''
The implication of the Otis thesis -that taxation with representation was all right - was challenged in the Whiskey Rebellion of 1794. President George Washington, so far as the record shows, had not indicated in conversation, or in writing, or by lip movements, or hand signs, whether he was for taxes in general but not in particular, or against taxes in general or in particular. 
In any case, George put down the rebellion, and so the matter rested until well into the 20th century, with only minor protests - and with the positions one might expect from the two major parties in every Presidential campaign.
Neither party seriously challenged the right and need of government to impose and to collect taxes. George McGovern, in his 1972 Presidential campaign, proposed that the Government continue to collect taxes, and then return the collected revenue to all eligible persons, both to those who had paid at least $1,000 and to those who had not paid that much in taxes, or who had paid not any income taxes. The $1,000 was to fall on the just and the unjust in common, like biblical rain, taxpayers and nontaxpayers. The proposal was not well received by the electorate.
Jimmy Carter as a Presidential candidate asserted that the Tax Code was a ''disgrace to the human race,'' a declaration not wholly endorsed by Democratic members of Congress, who through the years had labored hard in drafting that code. As President, Mr. Carter proposed a variation on the McGovern proposition, and a variation on the ''rebate'' programs that the auto industry had introduced by the time he was sworn in. The amounts to be returned were smaller than that proposed by Mr. McGovern, and spread over the whole year.
Ultimately, Mr. Carter opted for what, in his campaign, he had called the ''cruelest tax'' - inflation, which rose from approximately 7 percent a year to approximately 13 percent during his Administration.
President Carter served, both through his declaration against the Tax Code rather than taxes and through his inaction on tax matters, as a precursor to President Ronald Reagan.
Under Mr. Reagan, the guiding principle became a variation of the Otis slogan: taxation with representation is tyranny. He proceeded, with a supporting Congress, to cut taxes, substituting Federal deficits and borrowed money for what had previously been called ''fiscal responsibility.'' This made future tax collections by the Government the most popular investment of the Japanese, Germans and others, who became heavy buyers of Government bonds.
The political secret of the Reagan policy was that the burden of paying off the accumulating debt would fall not on the next generation of taxpayers - who, anticipating that burden, might reject it - but on the generation succeeding them, a generation not in a position to do much about it.
President Bush has carried the anti-taxation theory of Mr. Reagan close to fulfillment, or has allowed it to be carried to that position, by the inner dynamism of the theory, which can best be expressed as ''representation without taxation.''
The danger is that, in the interim, before this idyllic state is reached, simple-minded or logical taxpayers, believing that the President is right in saying that all new taxes are bad and that most old ones should go, and members of Congress, might be moved to support Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to reduce Social Security taxes.
Beyond that, and consistent with President Bush's often declared position that people's money is best used if kept from the Government, taxpayers may, on their own, stop paying taxes, thus serving the common good and anticipating that happy state of a democracy without taxation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (92%); 

CITY: BOSTON, MA, USA (92%);

SUBJECT: TAXATION TAXES & TAXATION (96%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); US PRESIDENTS (89%); TAX LAW (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (87%); TAX RELIEF (78%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (75%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (72%); PUBLIC DEBT (71%); POLITICAL PARTIES (66%); NATIONAL DEBT (62%);

HEADLINE: Standoff Ends, but Not Mohawk Defiance

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: ALTONA, N.Y., April 13

 BODY:
When both sides put down their guns and took down their roadblocks earlier this week, an 11-day standoff between a community of Mohawks and a squad of investigators appeared to be at an end.
The Mohawks allowed the authorities a two-hour visit on their land here near Miner Lake, a dozen miles from Canada, from which someone had fired gunshots on March 30, forcing down a medical helicopter from the Vermont National Guard and wounding a doctor on board.
But now, just as the tensions seemed to have eased, there is a new impasse in the Ganienkeh Indian Territory. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued arrest warrants for at least 14 of the Mohawks, charging them with obstructing the investigation into the shooting. The Mohawks have defied the warrants, saying they are from a foreign government to which they are not answerable. 
The Mohawk encampment here poses an unusual difficulty for state officials. It is not a reservation, but land they agreed to move to in 1977 after abandoning a three-year armed siege of a former girls' camp in the Adirondacks.
While New York State says the Mohawks are on state land, the Mohawks say their territory is but the first reclaimed part of a nine-million-acre-territory - Ganienkeh, meaning ''Land of the Flint'' - to which they hold aboriginal claim. ''When you're a nation you have to act as a nation,'' Darryl Martin, a Mohawk who acts as a spokesman for the community, said in explaining why they took up guns and held authorities at bay. ''The state police came and surrounded the Indian people. What else were we supposed to do?'' A Guard at the Gateway An investigation by the Mohawks had determined that no member of the territory was responsible for the shots, he added.
The forested core of the Mohawks' 700-acre encampment remained sealed off to outsiders today. ''This land is sovereign territory and we must be left alone,'' said Onhathaias, a 21-year-old guard standing under a locked wooden gateway that proclaims, ''Repossessed Area of Ganienkeh Territory Established 50,000 B.C.''
Unlike Mr. Martin, the guard and many other Mohawks interviewed said they preferred to use their Mohawk names. The mystery over the helicopter shooting and the warrants that are keeping many Indians in virtual house arrest on their land are the latest conflicts in the undefined relationship between New York State and the Mohawks at Ganienkeh, a snow-swept land of trees and rocks that lies just outside the northeast tip of Adirondack Park.
Unlike the state's 10 Indian reservations, where both sides have reached at least a basic understanding on the extent of the state's jurisdiction, there is no such agreement here.
The Mohawks agreed to move here after ending the three-year siege at Moss Lake, an Adirondack camp once used by children of the Rockefellers and the Roosevelts. That agreement, which created an intermediary trust that allowed the Indians to use the land, took more than 200 negotiating sessions and was largely orchestrated by Mario M. Cuomo, who was Secretary of State in 1977.
 
Income From Bingo
The Indians at Ganienkeh, unlike those at reservations, accept no state or Federal aid. They make most of their money from a tax-free high-stakes bingo hall, the subject of a protracted lawsuit between the Mohawks and the state's Attorney General.
All the Mohawks want from the Government, they insist, is total non-interference in their affairs.
Tehakarorens, a bear-sized man who took part in the siege at Moss Lake, nodded in agreement. ''That is the white man's way,'' he said. ''Once there's a foot in the door, he'll push it all the way in. So we could only allow him on the land if it was on our terms.''
The Indians relented and allowed the authorities on their land after an elaborate observer system was set up. The investigators apparently found no evidence and there have been no arrests in the shooting of the low-flying helicopter, which made an emergency landing in sleet and snow on a cornfield along the Great Chazy River.
The doctor on board, 29-year-old James Van Kirk of Burlington, Vt., suffered wounds when a bullet passed through his neck, arm and wrist. He spent three days in a hospital and is now recuperating at home, Vermont authorities said.
 
'Enforceable Warrants'
Neither Mr. Martin, the New York State police, nor the F.B.I. said they knew who had fired at the helicopter.
As for the warrants, the Indians describe them as meaningless, but the F.B.I. does not see the situation that way.
''These are enforceable warrants and I would expect the parties named to surrender peacefully,'' said Wayne Alford, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I.'s Albany office. Asked what would happen if the Indians did not give themselves up, he said, ''We will approach that in due course.''
While a car with an F.B.I. insignia can be spotted cruising Devil's Den Road and other streets at the edge of the Mohawk encampment, the authorities have so far made no effort to drive onto the territory. Mr. Alford said he could not comment on whether the F.B.I. was even in the area and how the warrants might be enforced.
The Indians say they will fight back, with rifles if necessary, at anybody who enters their territory without permission.
 
Number of Families a Secret
Like the gunshots at the helicopter, much of what goes on at the encampment is shrouded in mystery. Even the number of people there - estimates range from a few dozen to as many as 30 or 40 families - is not divulged.
''We make our gardens, we tend animals, we have a fish pond, we have a longhouse,'' said Onhathaias, the guard at the locked gateway. ''That is all you need to know.''
When a visitor left by car, Onhathaias followed him in his own car and radioed word of the movements to Mr. Martin at the bingo hall, which is to reopen to the public tonight for the first time in almost three weeks.
In the tiny town of Altona, meanwhile, some semblance of normalcy has returned. Chris and Vicki Johnson, for instance, were finally able to move back into their trailer on Devil's Den Road, which they had to evacuate when it became caught between two sets of roadblocks, one belonging to the Indians and the other to the state police.
Many townspeople were shocked and angered in 1977 when the Indians moved onto what had been a barren stretch of state forest, but in recent years, relations, while less than cordial, had been civil. But few said they accepted the Indians' contention that the land was sovereign territory.
There also appears to be lingering resentment in economically depressed Altona over the tax-free bingo hall, which is often jammed to its capacity of 1,500 people and draws busloads from as far as Montreal and Syracuse.
''It's the most ridiculous thing, really,'' said Jack Gonyo, who owns the general store on Main Street. ''Since when did bingo ever become a part of their national culture? I never read anything about Geronimo playing bingo.''
Several Indians said their society had been unfairly discredited by the helicopter shooting.
''The issue was never if we would co-operate,'' said Tehakarorens, as he prepared the kitchen for tonight's expected crowd at the bingo hall. ''We did an investigation and can share the results. There was never any need for the white man to come onto our land.''

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Down 0.2% in March

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Producer prices, helped by a record drop in vegetable costs and lower gasoline prices, fell in March for the first time in seven months, the Labor Department reported today.
The department's Producer Price Index for Finished Goods declined by two-tenths of 1 percent last month after no change in February and a huge 1.8 percent increase in January, the largest in 15 years. Vegetable prices were down by 25.5 percent.
An unusually severe cold snap in late December, followed by unseasonably mild temperatures in January and February, caused the topsy-turvy price pattern. Fuel oil and vegetable costs rocketed in January. Energy recovered a month later, but food prices did not start their decline until March. 
 
'Minus Sign' Seen for April
 ''Energy prices are still coming down and in fact we have a little more to go in vegetables,'' said Donald Ratajczak, at economist at Georgia State University. ''April should be a minus sign.''
Excluding the food and energy gyrations, producer price inflation has been remarkably stable for nearly two years. Economists look to these ''core'' prices - up by three-tenths of 1 percent in March and four-tenths in February - as a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures.
They foresee little change, at least until next year. The Federal Reserve Board, they said, was keeping interest rates high enough to dampen both growth and price pressures but not high enough to derail the economy into a recession or substantially cut inflation.
''This year inflation is going to stay stuck,'' said James Annable, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. ''Without a recession, you can't bring down inflation quickly.''
Prices rose in the first three months of 1989 at an annual rate of 4.8 percent. Although the rate for the 1990 period hit 6.7 percent, economists expect the producer price inflation rate by the end of the year to come in close to last year's rate.
The March producer price inflation report was better than expected. Most economists had predicted a slight increase of one-tenth of 1 percent or two-tenths.
Food prices dropped by six-tenths of 1 percent in March, the sharpest decline since June.
Vegetables, particularly tomatoes, celery and cabbage, fell by 25.5 percent, the biggest drop since record-keeping began in 1967. However, that marked only a partial recovery from rises of 23.3 percent in February and 58 percent in January.
Prices also fell for beef and veal, dairy products and coffee. They rose for eggs, rice, pasta, pork, chickens, turkeys, fish, soft drinks and cooking oils.
 
Decrease in Energy Costs
 Energy prices over all dropped by 2.4 percent in March after a decline of 5 percent in February and an increase of 13.6 percent in January.
Gasoline was down 2.8 percent and natural gas declined by 2.5 percent. Fuel oil prices went up by 10.6 percent, but they had fallen 30.2 percent the month before.
Clothing prices for men and children rose, while the cost of women's clothing fell. Passenger car prices, in the face of weak sales, declined by three-tenths of 1 percent in March after no change in February and a seven-tenths fall in January.
The various changes put the March index for all finished goods, one stop short of retail, at 117, not seasonally adjusted. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117 last month, up from $112.10 a year earlier.
Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in March. Intermediate goods showed no change, while crude goods fell 1.4 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

HEADLINE: Late Soviet Payments Irk Sellers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Frustrated by slow bill payments by the traditionally prompt Soviet Union, some American companies are slowing shipments to Moscow or avoiding new export commitments, various industry, Government and other sources said today.
''Some of our companies have gotten tired of it,'' one official in the corn industry said. ''They're just trying to send a message'' that they want to collect their debts.
Other exporters, like E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which awaits payment of about $16 million for agricultural chemicals delivered last year, have stepped up collection efforts but so far have stopped short of curbing their business relationship with the Soviet Union. 
 
Situation Called Temporary
 ''The idea has been discussed, but we haven't made a serious threat,'' said Nancie Johnson, manager of international trade and investment for Du Pont. ''We think the situation is very temporary.''
The late-payment issue, which has attracted increasing attention in recent weeks, is highly sensitive, and several companies and trade groups were reluctant to discuss it for fear of annoying a substantial customer. They said they were inclined to accept Soviet explanations that the delays were largely bureaucratic, related to the country's political upheaval, and did not reflect an economic crisis.
Others, however, saw something perhaps more ominous for trade relations between the two countries.
 
Oil Problems Cited
 ''It's very serious,'' said Marshall Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University. He attributed the slowing of payments to a crisis in the availability of hard currency, 60 percent of which comes from oil revenues. The output of Soviet oil is said to have fallen recently, and there has also been a drop of more than 10 percent in the world price.
This shortfall, combined with reduced amounts of grain available at home, has put the Soviet Union in a severe economic bind that can be resolved only by obtaining large amounts of credit, Mr. Goldman added, and the inability to obtain such loans readily from suppliers or other sources forced a bill-payment slowdown.
''The Soviets don't like to get behind,'' Mr. Goldman said. ''That's what makes this situation so unusual.''
United States officials maintain, however, that the Soviet Union has made some progress in reducing its arrearages recently, even as some American companies have decided against bidding on new business, including contracts to supply subsidized grain to the Soviet Union under the Export Exhancement Program.
''In the past few weeks a few companies have abstained from bidding, while others have continued to bid,'' an Agriculture Department official said. ''Some companies have received back payments of what they are owed, while others are in the process of working it out.''
 
No Lasting Effect Seen
 She predicted that the slow-payment problem would have no lasting effect on the grain trade with the Soviet Union, noting that the United States recently sold an additional 300,000 tons. Last year, the United States sent 21.7 million tons of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union.
One industry source said that one way of limiting Soviet business was to load ships more slowly, but Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said he was not aware of a change of any kind in the movement of American grain.
Several large grain-trading companies were not reachable today for comment because of the Good Friday holiday, but a spokesman for Omaha-based Conagra Inc., said that ''we do not have a problem with the Soviet Union and grain payments right now.''
In the absence of its president, a woman who answered the telephone at the North American Export Grain Association said the trade group could not comment on the slow-payment issue.
 
Problem Depicted as Resolved
 William Biedermann, vice president of Allendale Inc., a research company, said the Soviet Union had now largely resolved the problem. ''What really slowed down were new sales,'' he added. ''They almost came to a halt. Then about two weeks ago, they picked up again.'' Mr. Biedermann said the industry was already in a cautious mood when Moscow sought to switch from paying cash to buying on credit, ranging from six months to a year, but shipments had nonetheless not slowed substantially. ''They've been clicking right along,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Inventories Decline as Sales Jump

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Business inventories fell in February for the second time in three months, while sales surged, in another sign that the economy has avoided a recession, the Government said today.
Inventories on shelves and backlots shrank by four-tenths of 1 percent, the steepest drop since December 1986, to a seasonally adjusted $794.6 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported.
Sales, meanwhile, rose by 1.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $535.4 billion. It was the largest increase in seven months. All of the strength came in manufacturing, the sector of the economy that had been most affected by sluggishness resulting from the Federal Reserve Board's policy of keeping interest rates high. 
 
Ahead of Inventory Rise
 In January, business sales rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, enough to stay ahead of the three-tenths increase in inventories.
''The economy is picking up a little steam and we'll see a decent first half,'' said David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association.
He and other analysts view the combination of surging sales and falling inventories as a sign of strength. A sharp buildup in inventories can lead to a recession. Retailers and wholesalers with too many goods stop ordering more. In response, factories cut production and lay off workers.
The February activity sharply reduced the ratio of business inventories to sales to 1.48, down from 1.51 in January. That means it would take 1.48 months to exhaust inventories at the February sales pace.
''That suggests as much as anything that this economy has skirted a recession,'' said James Annable, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
 
Drop Steepest at Retailers
 The inventory decline was steepest at retailers, where backlogs dropped by nine-tenths of 1 percent. Production cutbacks by auto companies have allowed dealers to reduce their stock of cars by 2.2 percent despite sluggish sales.
Wholesale inventories declined by two-tenths of 1 percent while factory backlogs edged down by a tenth.
Manufacturing sales surged by 3.3 percent in February, while retail sales fell by three-tenths of 1 percent and wholesale sales declined by a tenth.
