HEADLINE: Despite Sanctions, Steel From Pretoria Is Entering the U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has allowed thousands of tons of South African iron and steel into the United States because of the way it has interpreted a 1986 sanctions law intended by its sponsors to ban such imports.
Commerce Department officials said this week that more than 900,000 tons of the material, worth at least $350 million, had entered the United States despite the anti-apartheid law.
The law says, ''Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no iron or steel produced in South Africa may be imported into the United States.''
 
Some Applications Excluded
But lawyers at the Treasury Department have defined ''steel'' to exclude fabricated steel products like girders, beams and plates used in the construction of bridges, according to department documents, including letters to members of Congress and steel importers. 
Bryce L. Harlow, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said that ''bridge sections, structures and parts of structures'' were not subject to the embargo even if they were made of South African iron and steel. Mr. Harlow did not explain the Treasury's rationale, except to say that it was based on ''established legal principles.''
This interpretation has upset some members of Congress like Representative John Bryant, Democrat of Texas, who said, ''There is no excuse for the Administration to allow even one ounce, much less billions of pounds, of such products to enter the United States.'' He said the law ''is just as plain as it can be.''
The State, Treasury and Commerce Departments confirm that they were aware of the policy, and each says the others were primarily responsible.
When asked at a Congressional hearing in February why South African steel was still coming into this country, Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said: ''Since this is a law-enforcement question, I'll have to defer to Treasury, which is responsible for enforcing the law.'' Treasury officials say their interpretation resulted from discussions with State Department officials.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said the Customs Service appeared to be accepting ''the most outrageous legal arguments of steel importers rather than trying to assess the clear intent of Congress in statutes which govern the import of steel products.''
The problem with steel imports illustrates what members of Congress say is a pattern of lax enforcement of the economic sanctions against South Africa. In a recent report, the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said, ''The U.S. Government does not have adequate tools to effectively enforce'' the sanctions.
The 1986 law put additional economic and political pressure on the Pretoria Government to end apartheid. Besides banning iron and steel imports, it also forbids the importing of items grown, produced or manufactured by any company that is owned, controlled or subsidized by South Africa.
The General Accounting Office said that the Customs Service did not know what products were made by such companies, so it had difficulty enforcing the ban, especially when South Africa sends goods to the United States through a third country. It added that Customs depends mainly on documents submitted by importers, certifying that they are in compliance.
 
Objectives of the Sanctions
Congress passed the law, over President Reagan's veto, in part to press for the lifting of emergency-decree rule in South Africa and for the release of Nelson Mandela. The measure prohibits new lending and investment, bans flights to and from South Africa and prohibits American imports of South African coal, textiles, uranium, farm products and gold coins, as well as iron and steel.
The definition of steel was devised in November 1986 by the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control, which works closely with the State Department in regulating trade with countries subject to sanctions. The rules are enforced by the Customs Service, which is also part of the Treasury Department.
The law established civil and criminal penalties for violating the embargo. But Federal law enforcement officials said it was inconceivable that the Government would prosecute anyone who imported South African steel after getting permission from the Treasury.
Treasury officials acknowledged that large quantities of iron alloy, used in the manufacture of steel, had been imported from South Africa, but they asserted that Congress did not explicitly prohibit such imports.
With the release of Mr. Mandela early this year, Congress is preparing for fresh debate on the future of sanctions. The Bush Administration has said it would consider lifting or modifying sanctions if the Pretoria Government frees all political prisoners and makes substantial progress toward dismantling apartheid. Congressional Democrats generally oppose the relaxation of sanctions.
South Africa accounts for a relatively small part of all the iron and steel imported into the United States, supplying far less than countries like Japan and South Korea. But it provides a substantial share of imports in certain categories.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY EXPECTED TO ABSORB EFFECTS OF MILITARY CUTS

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The United States economy can absorb large cuts in military spending without serious damage, economists say, although for a while, at least, tens of thousands of Americans will lose their jobs.
That will happen mostly because military spending will shrink faster than the civilian sector can expand to take up the slack. By most estimates, the process could temporarily idle up to 100,000 people a year in the 1990's, most of them discharged from the military service against their wishes or laid off at weapons plants, which would then go unused.
The proposed military cuts, some calling for reductions that would reach more than $100 billion a year by the late 1990's, would mark the fourth big cutback in military spending since World War II. But it would differ from the others in two significant ways. Never before on the eve of a major reduction has the military represented so small a portion of the national economy: less than 6 percent of the total wealth created in the nation last year. As a result, the cutback will scarcely show up in the statistics that measure economic strength. 
 
Cutbacks Could Spur Recession
Nevertheless, this is the nation's first attempt to shrink military spending at a time of sluggish economic growth -when idle weapons factories and their workers are not really needed for civilian production. The cutbacks might be hard to spot in the national statistics, but in a weak economy they could contribute to a recession in the early 1990's.
''Probably, the weakness in the economy today has something to do with the shrinkage in defense spending that has already taken place,'' said Robert Giordano, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bankers. ''But to really take a sledgehammer to the economy, you would need cutbacks far bigger than anyone has yet proposed.''
Even if the cutbacks turn out to be footnotes in the record books, they still inflict damage in places like Lima, Ohio, and Warren, Mich., where the General Dynamics Corporation operates the only two factories still producing tanks in the United States.
 
Tank Production to End in 1993
The Army intends to end tank production in 1993, for the first time since World War II. If such plans go through, then General Dynamics insists that it will have to close its tank division, which employs 7,300 people and draws on a network of private suppliers that employ thousands more.
''What can you do with a tank factory?'' Michael W. Wynne, a vice president of General Dynamics, asked rhetorically. ''You can make tractors and heavy earth-moving equipment, but Caterpillar already has that market sewed up. If there is no defense work to support these factories, then we'll have no alternative but to give them up.''
Similar problems are hurting cities and towns in the Northeast, the mid-Atlantic and West Coast, the three regions where military spending is concentrated. And a cutback in military spending brings subtle changes that affect millions of lives.
 
Minority Workers Could Suffer
Among these changes, perhaps the most important is the impact on minority workers. The armed forces and the Defense Department's civilian payroll have been a source of jobs and training for blacks and others who have been underrepresented in the civilian sector. In addition, weapons makers and military research laboratories often pay more than civilian employers, so the military cutback might lower the national wage level. In Massachusetts, a center of arms research and production, military-sector wages averaged $33,000 a year in 1987, or 23 percent more than the average income in the private sector, according to a state government study.
More positively, a cutback in military spending would bring highly skilled people to the civilian sector. Thirty percent of the nation's engineers and scientists work on military projects, and some would be freed to develop civilian products, said Lloyd Dumas, an economist at the University of Texas.
''Take videocassette recorders,'' he said. ''We invented the basic technology, and with that head start, if we had applied enough engineering and technology talent to developing the recorders themselves, we would be ahead in the field.'' No American company makes them today.
Whatever the benefits or drawbacks, the biggest immediate issues, in the view of many economists and politicians, are retooling and retraining. Factories that make tanks or fighter planes or missiles will need to be overhauled to make civilian products. Workers at every level will need to function in a civilian business sector that marches to different values, among them working under pressure and cutting costs.
''The military environment is far more relaxed,'' said Leonard Siegel, director of the Pacific Study Center, a California research group.
To deal with the conversion problem, Congress is considering a bill that would force military contractors to draw up retooling plans and to retrain workers. Among the states, Washington recently became the first to pass a bill that appropriates money to help communities shift to civilian production.
 
Effect of the 'Peace Dividend'
Above all, the American economy in the 1990's will be shaped by the Federal Government's strategy for spending the ''peace dividend.'' The huge debate building over this issue offers two options.
One would use the savings from the military sector to reduce the budget deficit, in the belief that a lower deficit means less Government borrowing and thus lower interest rates on loans for everyone. Given these lower rates, the civilian sector would presumably borrow more to invest in new factories, stores and research operations that would replace the shrinking military sector.
An alternative is to spend much more on public works. Even strong proponents of budget cutting acknowledge that the nation's deteriorating highways and bridges, water and sewer systems, airports and mass transit make companies reluctant to build new factories, no matter how low interest rates might be. Without a good highway or railroad, for example, a new shoe factory in Wisconsin might not be a good investment because of difficulties in getting the shoes to market.
 
'Once-in-a-Lifetime Opportunity'
''The peace dividend is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to restore the nation's infrastructure to its level in the 1960's, without new taxes or new borrowing,'' said Robert Heilbroner, the economic historian.
The peace dividend, in fact, is already starting to appear. Despite all the attention on high-tech weaponry in the 1980's, the military budget has been quietly shrinking since 1985.
That development is evident when annual military appropriations are restated in 1990 dollars to discount the effects of inflation. Appropriations peaked at more than $330 billion in 1985 and then shrank by roughly 2 percent a year, reaching $300 billion in the fiscal year 1989, the Commerce Department reports. #2% Annual Shrinkage to Continue The Bush Administration would continue this 2 percent shrinkage through 1995, an annual cutback that amounts to an almost-invisible one-tenth of 1 percent of the gross national product, a measurement of the value of goods and services produced in the nation. Others would like to double or triple this cutback, to as much as $15 billion a year for 10 years.
Such sums are lost in an economy that generates $4.1 trillion in goods and services each year. The $15 billion becomes significant only if the economy remains sluggish and the G.N.P. grows at an annual rate of less than $100 billion - the situation since last fall. In so weak an economy, $15 billion could make the difference between a recession and continued expansion.
The huge cutback in military spending after World War II produced a recession, but the pent-up demand for goods and then the Korean War quickly made the economy boom. Brief recessions also developed as military spending contracted after the Korean War and as the Vietnam War came to an end.
 
Scenario for Layoffs
But quite apart from the recession issue, the proposed cutbacks do not seem likely to result in millions of layoffs. Some 3.2 million Americans work at private-sector jobs financed by military spending, said Robert Kutscher, an associate commissioner of the Labor Department. But fewer than 500,000 of these workers are making ammunition, missiles, warships and other weaponry in factories that cannot be easily converted to civilian use.
In the very unlikely event that the Defense Department halted almost all weapons programs, fewer than 50,000 of these weapons workers would be laid off each year, Mr. Kutscher said. Of the remaining private-sector workers, about 2.2 million are employed by subcontractors who also sell to the civilian sector. Most of these people are likely to keep their jobs, Mr. Kutscher added.
''A truck driver doesn't know whether his cargo is military or civilian,'' he said. ''And the same holds for machine shops that make parts, and hotels whose guests are connected with the military.''
Joblessness would also strike among the 2.1 million people in the armed services and the million civilian employees of the Defense Department. This year, 40,000 in both groups are to be mustered out or laid off, said Robert Rauner, director of the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment. A stepped-up cutback over the next five years might shrink the armed forces by an additional 200,000 and the department's civilian workers by 100,000, he added.
The layoffs would come at a time when the demand for workers is likely to outstrip the number of people entering the work force. Whereas more than two million Americans came of job age annually in the 1980's, a slower-growing population will add only 1.5 million young people a year in the 1990's, the Labor Department projects.
Still, cuts in military spending work on the economy in strange ways. During earlier postwar cutbacks, for example, weapons exports rose as manufacturers scrambled for customers. They are scrambling again - one company, General Dynamics, is trying to sell tanks to Egypt - but with the easing of East-West tensions the overseas market is shrinking.
 
Mixed Outlook for Redevelopment
Back home, the Defense Department proposed in January to close 10 large military bases and numerous smaller ones around the country. Some would be sold for industrial parks, shopping centers and prime real estate, and the network of businesses serving the military would most likely end up serving new civilian customers.
But the transition might not work for other installations, among them the three-base cluster in the Oakland-Alameda area near San Francisco. Mr. Siegel of the Pacific Study Center noted that although the bases are on valuable waterfront property, suitable for hotels, conference centers and shopping malls, hazardous waste was stored at the bases, polluting the underground water. ''Cleaning this up might delay redevelopment for years,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Peru's New Frontrunner Vows Shake-Up on Coca and Rebels

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 14

 BODY:
Alberto Fujimori, the 51-year-old son of Japanese immigrants who displaced Mario Vargas Llosa last week as presidential frontrunner, is vowing to shake up Peru, attacking coca cultivation and guerrilla violence and pushing for the entry of this Andean land into the booming economy of the Pacific.
Mr. Fujimori, known here as ''the Japanese torpedo,'' finished a close second to Mr. Vargas Llosa, the novelist-turned-politician, against a broad slate of candidates in national elections last Sunday. An agronomist, Mr. Fujimori is widely expected to defeat Mr. Vargas Llosa in a two-man runoff, to be held before June 3.
 
Dismisses U.S. Efforts
With his political stock soaring, Mr. Fujimori has been blunt in his recent statements. He has already spoken with scorn of American efforts to end coca farming in Peru, dismissing Washington's program as ''completely inefficient'' in shifting his country from its role as the world's leading supplier of the raw material for cocaine. 
Instead, he proposed in an interview that the United States help build a 350-mile railroad to convert Peru's principal coca-growing valley into a breadbasket for his nation, which must import the food it needs to feed its people.
''The United States is just fooling itself,'' he said. ''You have to give the peasants an alternative. Otherwise, they will die of hunger or join the ranks of the guerrillas.'' It is the appetite for cocaine in the United States that has in large part fueled the switch from food crops to coca cultivation in the Upper Huallaga Valley of Peru.
 
Vargas Llosa Reconsiders
Mr. Fujimori's support for crop substitution is part of a larger shake-up that he promises if he wins the runoff.
On Monday, Mr. Vargas Llosa is to announce whether he will stay in the race. If the novelist bows out, his coalition, the Democratic Front, will field a replacement, a move that would virtually guarantee a Fujimori victory.
In recent weeks, public-opinion analysts watched transfixed as Mr. Fujimori rocketed from 3 percent in the polls on March 1 to 30 percent on April 8, the day of the election. Analysts say he did so well partly because Mr. Vargas Llosa was seen as too close to the traditional politicians representing wealthy business interests and merchants.
Politicians and pollsters now predict that Mr. Fujimori will win a runoff against Mr. Vargas Llosa by attracting left-wing voters who oppose the novelist's stricter free-market platform.
Mr. Fujimori apparently outpolled Mr. Vargas Llosa in the Andean highlands, where the guerrilla group Shining Path is strongest. And his conciliatory vision of the rebels does not square with some people's image of him as a conservative businessman in a white shirt.
''In the mountains, people were dying of hunger, children were not going to school, but everything looked fine from the presidential palace,'' Mr. Fujimori said, attributing the spread of Shining Path to the ''total myopia'' of Peru's two Presidents during the 1980's, Fernando Belaunde Terry and Alan Garcia.
''They are primarily responsible for the terrorism,'' the agronomist said with anger in his eyes. ''Don't forget that people have the right to rebel in the face of social injustice. You can't allow the suffocation of a people by social structures.''
 
Two Years in Wisconsin
In a three-hour interview on Thursday night at his house in the Monterico suburb of Lima, Mr. Fujimoro spoke of his grass-roots campaign and his vision for healing his country. Occasionally he broke into rusty English, remembered from two years in the early 1970's spent earning a master's degree in mathematics at the University of Wisconsin.
In contrast to the millions of dollars spent by Mr. Vargas Llosa's wealthy backers, Mr. Fujimori said he opened his campaign with money raised by selling his tractor and pickup truck. He balked at hiring a fast-talking political consultant who wanted to charge a fee of $5,000.
Instead, Mr. Fujimori's campaign slogan, ''Work, Honesty and Technology,'' was taken door to door by volunteers from his three pillars of support - evangelical Christians, business people and university students and professors.
On his ticket, one of his vice-presidential candidates, Maximo San Roman Caceres, owns a bakery-equipment factory and is president of Peru's Association of Small and Medium-Size Industries.
 
An Evangelical Running Mate
His other vice-presidential candidate is Carlos Garcia, president of Peru's National Evangelical Council. Mr. Garcia, a Baptist minister, spent seven years as director of World Vision, the Christian charity. On Friday, the Evangelical Council issued a statement declaring its ''institutional independence from all movements and political parties.''
Protestants, largely evangelicals, account for 4 percent of Peru's 20 million people, but about a third of the candidates for congress on Mr. Fujimori's slate, Change '90, are evangelicals.
''The evangelicals went door to door for us,'' said Victor Diaz Lau, a physics professor and campaign coordinator. ''They were good spokesmen for our movement.''
The son of Buddhists, Mr. Fujimori says he is ''100 percent'' Roman Catholic, the dominant religion in Peru. But concerned about his strong evangelical support, an emissary of the Catholic Church on Tuesday reportedly urged Mr. Vargas Llosa, an agnostic, to remain in the race.
 
What the Voters Like
In interviews and in polls, voters cited the qualities they like about Mr. Fujimori: his passion for farming, his political independence and his Japanese ethnic ancestry. Polls in this Pacific coastal nation often show that Japan scores higher than the United States in public esteem.
The small Japanese-Peruvian minority, numbering about 70,000, has taken pains to distance itself from Mr. Fujimori. Peru's Japanese apparently fear that a Fujimori failure as a candidate or as president could unleash anti-Japanese sentiment. Although Mr. Vargas Llosa spoke out sharply against racism on Monday, his embittered supporters reportedly harassed Japanese-Peruvians on several occasions last week.
But Mr. Fujimori is playing the Japanese card to his advantage. He has implied that his election would draw billions of dollars of Japanese investment. To gain publicity, he has been filmed breaking a brick with a karate blow. In the interview, he confessed that he had never learned karate and that the brick had been broken in advance.
To many Peruvians, the most pressing problem is not drug cultivation or foreign debt but the violent leftist insurgency of Shining Path.
 
Revival of Rural Economy
Saying counterinsurgency is ''not fought only with firearms,'' the candidate proposed an Andean development program to bring schools, roads, health clinics and impartial justice to rural Peruvians. To revive the rural economy, he proposed ending food subsidies and allowing markets to set food prices.
Ruling out peace talks with the guerrillas because of their ''criminal acts,'' Mr. Fujimori said, ''A government with a social policy could prevent people from falling into the clutches of Shining Path.''
To restore growth to Peru's shrinking economy, Mr. Fujimori recommended ending President Garcia's policy of confrontation with international bankers over Peru's $17 billion foreign debt. Instead, he called for negotiating a debt-relief plan similar to one negotiated recently by Mexico and Venezuela under guidelines set by the United States Treasury Secertary, Nicholas F. Brady.
To win more trade, aid and investment from Japan and other Pacific economic powers, he advocated increasing Peru's integration with the booming Pacific Basin.
 
Favors a 'Free Economy'
Mr. Fujimori said his ultimate goal is a ''free economy.'' To reduce Peru's 30 percent monthly inflation - now South America's highest - he would place a technician in charge of the Central Bank, would raise taxes and public utility rates to reduce the budget deficit and would create a new currency, probably backed by silver.
On the drug issue, Mr. Fujimori said that raids on laboratories and on air strips would continue in Peru.
But noting that coca leaf prices have dropped almost below the threshhold of profitability, he said the United States should help build the infrastructure -roads and the railroad - necessary to move food crops from the Upper Huallaga Valley to markets in the major coastal cities.
''We have to be realistic - these people are not going to allow their children to die,'' he said of the estimated 200,000 families in the Huallaga Valley who depend on coca leaf cultivation for their livelihoods.

LENGTH: 1387 words

HEADLINE: Gardening as a Career: the Lure of a Dirty Job

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
Weeding and raking and digging and planting have not typically led to high-status careers. But these days, being a gardener is starting to sound better and better.
''It's fashionable,'' said Rosemary Kern, director of education at the New York Botanical Garden. ''It is a way of making a statement, like nouvelle cuisine.''
It is also a way of leaving the fast track for something that may have offered solace as a hobby, and so horticulture schools throughout the country are seeing a steady increase in adults who are thinking of leaving their careers to dig in the dirt for a living. 
Indeed, some say gardeners may become to the 1990's what chefs were to the 1980's, when a surging interest in fine foods elevated the status of cooking as a career. A similar change seems to be taking place in the garden.
 
Plants as Psychotherapy
Of course, it is not all spade work. Jobs range from greenhouse chores to designing elaborate plantings or overseeing vast estates. Training in horticulture can also lead to work in floral design, conservation, education and even psychotherapy, using plants to soothe patients.
And it is not embarrassing these days to leave Wall Street for a career in gardening.
Take Gregory McKinney, a 39-year-old foreign exchange trader who lives in New Jersey with his wife and two young children. He risks millions of dollars in split-second decisions. He makes so much money, he says, that he pays cash for his cars. But the pressure has been wrenching. ''I hear my pulse in my ears,'' he said.
 
Night Classes in Gardening
Mr. McKinney is taking night classes at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, and plans to earn enough credits for a certificate in landscape design later this year. Eventually, he hopes to buy a small landscaping company. He is sure he will be happier doing something he loves. ''Truthfully,'' he said, ''I don't have a lot of interest in Japanese yen.''
In Cambridge, Mass., applications for the landscape design program through the Radcliffe Seminars, a course of part-time study run by Radcliffe College, have been growing so steadily that ''we've run out of space,'' said John Furlong, the coordinator of the program. ''We are making it more selective,'' he added.
At the University of Pennsylvania, interest in landscape architecture -which is to gardening what city planning is to brick laying - is also rising. The class this year has 45 students, up from the usual 30 or so. Applications for the class that will start this fall are twice as high as usual.
Once trained, gardeners will find plenty of demand for their services as Americans' interest in plants and gardening continues to increase.
 
Sales Up 16% a Year
Sales of bedding plants, which include flowering annuals like geraniums and petunias, increased almost 16 percent a year from 1976 to 1988, according to Alvi Voigt, a professor of agricultural economics at Pennsylvania State University in State College, Pa. At garden centers, sales increased from $2.9 billion to $5.4 billion from 1982 to 1987, twice as fast as overall retail growth.
''There is a tremendous shortage of qualified people at all levels of the industry,'' said Terry Humfeld, the executive director of the Professional Plant Growers Association in Lansing, Mich.
No degree is required to be a gardener; like a chef, an aspiring gardener can start at the minimum wage and learn on the job. Formal training can range from a year or so of study to two- and three-year programs that include academic courses in botany and plant physiology.
Henry J. Euler, who runs the 21-month horticulture program at the New York Botanical Garden, said he has seven jobs for every graduate. ''The killer is what you get paid,'' he said. ''Starting salaries are between $15,000 and $22,000.''
 
Jobs That Pay $5 an Hour
Susan Lathrop, executive director of the American Association of Botanical Gardens and Arboreta in Wayne, Pa., said people who are switching careers for jobs in gardening often apply for internships that pay only $5 or $6 an hour.
The lack of financial prospects drove away many people who became gardeners in the 1970's, during the first flush of the environmental movement. But salaries are beginning to increase because of the labor shortage, Mr. Humfeld said.
Throughout the country, refugees from high-stress medical jobs are showing an interest in horticulture. At Merritt College in Oakland, Calif., nurses make up about 10 percent of the horticulture classes.
In New York City, Keith Lloyd, a nurse, dug and planted in the community garden on Third Avenue near 93d Street in Manhattan, growing flowers and vegetables. Gradually, the gardening became more important. He studied full time at the Botanical Garden, where he is now the orchid curator, overseeing 5,000 plants.
 
Plants Are Like Patients
Both horticulture and nursing, he said, require good hygiene and careful observation. ''In the hospital, well-being depends on it. And it is the same in orchid culture.''
But the business and financial community seems to be the New York's metropolitan area's largest source of prospective gardeners, instructors say.
''There is this really strong desire to reach out to creative fields,'' said Maryanne Connelly, a landscape architect who teaches at the Botanical Garden.
One who switched to gardening 20 years ago after a successful career on Wall Street is Jim Cross, who grows premium quality plants at Environmentals, his wholesale nursery in Cutchogue, L.I.
Mr. Cross was a partner in the investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Although he found the work exciting, he said, he did not feel inherently suited to it. ''I had to crank myself up to work at it,'' he added. Then, in his early 40's, he changed careers. ''I learned by doing it,'' he said, ''and by making mistakes.''
 
From Dresses to Dungarees
Signe Hanson is making the switch today. She used to make more than $50,000 a year administering social service programs for the State of New Jersey. ''I woke up in the morning yawning,'' she said. ''I would go to the mall and drop money on a dress because I was depressed.''
Ms. Hanson, who has a master's degree in public administration, does not have the time or the money to shop these days. She is living on her savings and studying horticulture at Delaware Valley College in Doylestown, Pa., where she puts on dungarees and boots to dig in the dirt.
Her old life is gone; the business suits hang in the closet. ''I may as well give them to the Smithsonian,'' she said. Ms. Hanson says she can live happily on less. ''I own all the toys I can possibly want,'' she said.
Last August, Elizabeth Spar, who lives in the New York suburb of Hastings-on-Hudson, gave up a long-held partnership in a market research company to take a job in a nursery in Scarsdale, where she found the work physically tiring but satisfying.
''I didn't have to go to meetings with people that drove me up the wall,'' she said. ''I didn't have the tension.'' Last August she started studying full time at the Botanical Garden in New York.
 
A New, Plain Wedding Ring
At the garden's greenhouse she can wear jeans and let the dirt remain under her fingernails. Even her jeweled wedding ring had to be put aside, for a new, plain one. ''I was there yesterday, watering the plants, and I'm hearing them all drinking,'' she said. ''It's a great feeling.'' John Creedon, a Colgate-educated son of an insurance executive, tried his father's business but left it for horticulture, getting a master's degree from Cornell. Now he owns Connecticut Cut Flower in Bantam, a borough in the western Connecticut town of Litchfield, and sells wholesale and retail flowers and plants.
''It's not unusual for people who have a fairly high level of education to go into this business,'' he said. ''If you don't have it, it's hard to pull all the pieces together.''
On the other hand, potting ivy probably does not require Ivy League credentials.
Chuck Rekemeier left his job as a crane operator at the Exxon refinery in Linden, N.J., that had employed three generations of his family. ''I was becoming bored,'' said Mr. Rekemeier, who studies at Delaware Valley College and plans to be a retail florist. ''There is nothing to equal the colors or fragrance of flowers.''

HEADLINE: Intense College Recruiting Drives Lift Black Enrollment to a Record

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
Black enrollment in colleges and universities reached record highs in the late 1980's largely because the schools developed extensive recruiting programs to tutor, counsel and provide financial aid to prospective students, educators and sociologists say.
Seeking to explain a surge in enrollment figures released last month by the Federal Department of Education, the experts said in interviews that efforts to stress to black young people the importance of higher education had found an increasingly receptive audience, mostly among young women.
The Department of Education figures showed that black enrollment had ended a long downward trend. Young women accounted for much of the increase, and the sociologists and educators said that fact supported the view that young black men generally seemed to find it difficult to believe college was a viable option for them.
 
The Route Out of Poverty
But now colleges and universities are using more and more tutoring and guidance counseling programs to raise black interest. They have also expanded their student financial assistance programs to make up for a shrinkage in Federal budgets of the 1980's. The result has been a reversal of a troubling trend, educators say. 
''We are beginning to see a collection of institutions, both black and white, that are helping black students understand again that the single most important route out of poverty is education,'' said Benjamin F. Payton, president of Tuskegee University in Alabama. ''To have a high school diploma alone is not considered to be an adequate education in a world increasingly driven by science and technology.''
From 1986 to 1988, the Federal Department of Education says, non-Hispanic black college enrollment rose to 1.13 million students from 1.08 million. The previous high was 1.10 million students in 1980.
Total enrollment in American colleges was 12 million in 1980 and 13 million in 1988. Sexes' Enrollments: a Gulf? Among young black women, enrollment rose to 687,000 from 646,000 from 1986 to 1988, but in the same period, black male enrollment rose only to 443,000 from 436,000, raising concern that an economic gulf was developing between black men and women.
Dr. Troy Duster, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley, said poor black men were more likely than poor black women to be influenced by ''macho'' attitudes, and that those attitudes made it likely that they would be driven into crime.
''Girls don't tend to get involved as much in these kinds of male bonding activities: gang life, sports,'' said Dr. Duster, the director of the Institute for the Study of Social Change at Berkeley. But he added that black culture itself had always affirmed the importance of education; black women simply had fewer counterforces to keep them from responding. Why Not the Ivy League? Last month, the National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities, whose headquarters are in Washington, said in a report based on the Education Department's findings that the greatest increase in black enrollment had come at private institutions. In the period examined, black enrollment increased by 7.1 percent in private institutions as against 0.2 percent in public colleges and universities.
There is concern on the part of educators and parents, however, that fewer black students are attending Ivy League and similarly prestigious institutions.
''This year we saw a decrease in black applicants,'' said Jennifer Carey, the senior admissions and financial aid officer at Harvard University. ''We've been listening to other Ivy League schools and the message is fairly consistent: there is a noticeable decline.''
Most black college students are in public institutions of higher education, whose costs and requirements are comparatively modest. There were 881,000 black students in publicly supported colleges and universities in 1988, as against 248,000 in private institutions, the Education Department says.
 
A Rise in College Fund Schools
Officials of the United Negro College Fund concurred in the Federal findings, but spokesmen for the fund said their research had not found a decrease in black male enrollment among the 41 black colleges and universities that are affiliated with the fund.
Alan Kruchner, a researcher for the fund, said black enrollment at the member schools had risen 10 percent from 1986 to 1988; 5 percent among men, 5 percent among women. He said he believed that black institutions were more successful in gaining black male enrollment because of special programs to attract them.
Osward P. Bronson Sr., president of Bethune-Cookman College in Daytona Beach, Fla., follows his school's football team around his state and sets up recruiting receptions to interest promising high school students. But the emphasis is academics, he said in an interview.
''We invite high achievers, merit scholars, and entertain them and their parents,'' he said. ''We give them tickets to the game. I will address the group and our director of admissions will speak.''
Bethune-Cookman alumni, many of whom are teachers, also help to promote the college to promising students, Dr. Bronson said.
 
The Issue of Financial Help
Shortly after the new programs were begun in the late 1980's, Bethune-Cookman's student body grew by 16 percent to 2,286 students. But at the same time, the institution is ''biting the bullet,'' Dr. Bronson said, by dipping into its operating budget to help needy students. More than 90 percent of the students need some kind of financial aid, he said.
''When Washington moved toward reduction in financial aid while at the same time tuition and room and board costs were going up, it made it financially impossible for a poor kid to go to school,'' Dr. Bronson said.
From 1980 to 1986, black enrollment in higher education fell nationally by 2.2 percent, a loss of 25,000 students, the Education Department's figures show.
''Both public and private institutions have been working very hard to increase the numbers of minority students in their schools,'' said Allan Ostar, president of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. ''Given the opportunity and proper motivation, minorities will do as well as or better than anyone else.''
 
Seeking the Key, Motivation
Many programs managed by colleges are now seeking better ways to motivate blacks to turn to college. These programs, from after-school engineering clubs to overnight visits to campus dormitories, give black students a chance to experience the flavor of college life and its challenges.
Mercy College in Detroit has ''adopted'' a predominantly black high school whose freshmen are evaluated. Those with a high potential are sent to the college campus, where they meet with professors and Mercy students.
''The pool of minority high school students who are graduating with the courses needed for college and the level of preparation for success in selective colleges has not been growing in recent years,'' said Phillip M. Phibbs, president of the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, Wash. ''We are trying to enlarge that pool.''
Puget Sound, where 2 percent of the 3,000 students are black, has had the help of Tacoma's chapter of the National Urban League and of the Tacoma public school system in seeking to motivate minorities toward college.
 
Adopting a High School
Last year the University of Puget Sound adopted a local school's program in which 1,000 public school students were provided with tutoring and counseling. This summer two dozen ninth- and tenth-grade students are to attend a two-week program in mathematics, writing and sciences on the university campus.
Dr. Phibbs said he was also trying to find philanthropists who would help those who cannot afford college. So far, the university has received one $60,000 four-year scholarship for a minority student.
On the University of California campuses, where 4.6 percent of the 160,000 students are black, a study group was created to determine why so few blacks had qualified for the state university system. The university branches accept only students in the top 12.5 percent of their class.
 
'Education Is the Only Way'
Ingrid Labat, 21 years old, had no difficulty measuring up to Stanford University's tough standards. But after a year and a half there, Ms. Labat said, she wanted a smaller, more supportive environment.
Now a junior at Xavier University, a predominantly black college in New Orleans, her hometown, Ms. Labat said she was happy in the school's biology and pre-med program.
''My parents have been very supportive, so it never crossed my mind to do anything else but go to college,'' Ms. Labat said. ''It's hard to survive without an education, especially if you are a minority.
''Education is the only way blacks are going to succeed. My parents always said, 'If you don't go to college, you won't be able to control your own destiny.' ''

HEADLINE: Lebanon War Spurs New Emigration

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14

 BODY:
The outbreak of large-scale fighting between rival Lebanese Christian factions 12 weeks ago has prompted major new migrations of refugees, both out of the country and inside it.
A report issued by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry at the beginning of this month said 100,000 Lebanese, primarily Christians, have left the country since the latest fighting began. Two hundred thousand other Christians sought refuge in safer areas in Lebanon, according to security officials.
As many as 800,000 Lebanese have left the country since the civil war began on April 13, 1975. This is nearly one-fourth of the entire population. 
The Mediterranean island of Cyprus, 150 miles away, has become a halfway house for Lebanese emigrants who have despaired of their country's ever becoming peaceful again. They flock to foreign consulates there to obtain entry visas. Lebanon's national carrier, Middle East Airlines, has three flights a week to Larnaca, and they are booked solid for many weeks ahead.
''Cyprus is our Ellis Island,'' said Malik Abu Jedid, a 29-year-old bank clerk who said he applied for a visa to Canada to join an older brother. #80,000 Live in France Four countries are most favored for well-off Lebanese emigrants: France, the United States, Canada and Australia. Nearly 80,000 now reside in France, two-thirds of whom are in Paris, according to statistics.
About 100 Lebanese apply daily for visas at the United States and Canadian consulates in the Cypriot capital, Nicosia. Canada is reported to process 600 a month, but only 10 percent of applicants succeed in getting visitor or immigration visas to the United States.
Hundreds apply each month for visas at the Australian Embassy in Damascus, the Syrian capital.
Many have joined relatives in South America, mainly in Brazil and Venezuela, while others have gone to African countries such as Liberia, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Zaire and South Africa, according to officials.
Thousands, desperate to get out, tried to pass themselves off as political refugees in Scandinavian countries, especially Sweden. But the Stockholm Government shut the door last month, and sent back 150 Lebanese who it said had arrived on counterfeit visas.
Many of these Lebanese tried to enter Sweden via Poland. Polish visas were easy to come by, until late last month when the Polish Embassy in West Beirut sent most of its staff home after an attempt to kill one of them. A clandestine group said it had carried out the attack to protest a Polish pledge of help to Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel.
 
Apartment Destroyed by Shells
''We have nothing left to keep us here,'' said Mrs. Edmund Jabbour, the mother of two girls and a boy between 5 and 12. She and her husband, owner of a men's boutique, were packing to leave for Houston after receiving a United States immigration visa. Mrs. Jabbour said their apartment in Christian East Beirut was smashed by artillery shells in February. Her husband's shop received a direct hit during the artillery exchanges last fall between the Lebanese and Syrian armies.
The fighting between Christians pits supporters of Gen. Michel Aoun, the leader of the Lebanese Army, against the Lebanese Forces militia, led by Samir Geagea. General Aoun opposes the Government of President Elias Hrawi, whom he accuses of giving in to the Muslims and accepting the Syrian military presence in Lebanon, and Mr. Geagea supports the Government.
Khalil Mansour, a 32-year-old engineer, said he was taking his wife and two sons, 7 and 9, to Australia. ''At least there, I can be sure they will go to school,'' he said.
Schools and universities have been closed in the Christian enclave for nearly a year now.
 
No Water or Electricity
Harig Keomedjian, a jeweler of Armenian extraction, said: ''We want to have normal life. Where I am going at least we will have water and electricity.'' He is immigrating to Montreal.
Since the fighting began, Beirut and most areas in Lebanon have been without power or water supply. Power cables and water mains have been destroyed by artillery shells.
Since no restrictions are imposed on money leaving the country, capital flight has been as big as the human exodus, contributing to the economic recession Lebanon has been suffering because of continuing violence.
The Government draft budget for this year shows a 65 percent deficit.
According to Abdel Chakour al-Shaalan, who heads the Middle East section at the International Monetary Fund, Lebanese holdings in banks abroad total nearly $20 billion.
Emigration has been part of Lebanese life for 130 years. Government statistics show that as many as 13 million people of Lebanese origin now live in 25 countries, including 2 million in the United States and 5 million in Brazil.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Military's Voice Being Heard on Lithuania, a Soviet Aide Says

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 14

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is under increasing pressure from the Soviet military for an army crackdown in Lithuania, an official of the Communist Party's Central Committee says.
The official says the military has worked out plans much like those under which the Soviet Army occupied Prague in 1968. They include a strategy of seizing the Lithuanian Parliament building, replacing the leadership that has declared independence, imposing martial law and installing other leaders who would rescind the republic's March 11 proclamation.
Word of the military pressure comes as Col. Gen. Vladimir Denisov, Deputy Chief of the Soviet General Staff, warned on Friday in the Soviet newspaper Trud that ''the carrying out of the policy of the present Lithuanian leaders for secession is pregnant with danger for the security not only of the Baltic republics and the U.S.S.R., but for all of Europe.'' 
 
'Painful Consequences'
Secession by the Lithuanians would create a breach in Soviet defenses and lines of communication to the West, the general said. ''If they don't listen to the voice of reason,'' he wrote, ''events could have painful consequences for everybody.''
The tough line is probably aimed at Western ears. But it also coincides with assessments by American intelligence officials that the rapid deterioration in the Soviet security position in Eastern Europe and the poor domestic economy have strengthened the hand of the Soviet military establishment and narrowed support for Mr. Gorbachev's policies.
Pressure from the military may also explain the threat on Friday, signed by Mr. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, to stop supplying Lithuania with essential raw materials if it does not repeal some of the measures adopted since March 11.
This move apparently represented a change in Mr. Gorbachev's position since last Tuesday. Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, who was visiting at the time, said the Soviet President had told him, ''A decision had been taken not to interrupt the flow of necessary materials to Lithuania.''
 
Threat to Gorbachev's Plans
Soviet officials who support Mr. Gorbachev's course of economic and political change now tell their Western friends that the Soviet leader's plans for reviving the economy could be threatened by the Lithuanian crisis and by the continuing collapse of Soviet strategic positions in Eastern Europe.
They are aware that harsh measures against Lithuania now would end support and encouragement for Mr. Gorbachev's policies in the West. But as Mr. Gorbachev himself complained to a delegation of American senators here last week, all the West has done so far is lecture him on avoiding force.
One Communist Party official said that if President Bush really wanted to help, he should call up the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, and urge him to make a compromise, like retracting or suspending the declaration of independence.
A Western diplomat said he would be surprised if Mr. Gorbachev himself or one of his political allies like Aleksandr N. Yakovlev or Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze had not already made such a suggestion to Mr. Bush in advance of the Soviet-American summit talks in Washington, which begin late next month.
But it would appear to have little chance of success. Mr. Bush is under pressure from Congress to recognize Lithuanian independence formally. The White House has explained that such a move is unnecessary because the United States, like Britain, has never formally recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940.
Some Soviet officials wonder what the United States or anybody else in the West would actually be able to do for the Lithuanians if there were a military crackdown, besides offering them moral support.
 
Soviet Complaints
They also complain that the United States has not shown its appreciation for Mr. Gorbachev's rapid and continuing shifts on German unification.
A few weeks ago, the Soviet leader was insisting that a united Germany be neutral and could not belong to NATO. Last week, Mr. Shevardnadze suggested that one way to resolve the issue was for Germany to belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
''We didn't expect you to accept this idea whole,'' a Central Committee figure said after the White House rejected the idea on Wednesday, ''But why don't you make some constructive counterproposal instead of rejecting ours?''
Valentin M. Falin, Mr. Gorbachev's chief adviser on German affairs, said in an interview on Monday that the dual-alliance idea was intended to provide a transition to a new all-European security structure to replace both NATO and the Warsaw Pact in five to seven years.
''Why not agree in the talks on German unification that this is the goal?'' another adviser suggested. ''That would be the kind of signal we need.''
 
Western Diplomats' Views
But some Western diplomats here think that the right posture to take on Lithuania and Germany is simply to keep waiting to see how many more positions Mr. Gorbachev is forced to cede before holding out a safety net for him. Others believe that the longer the Lithuanian impasse continues, the more Mr. Gorbachev will be boxed in by his critics in the Communist Party and the military.
If Mr. Gorbachev is indeed coming under pressure from the Soviet military to do something on Lithuania, the situation will be aggravated by the fact that both Lithuania and Estonia are urging young men to refuse to answer their draft calls next month.
Communist Party officials are emphasizing the importance of support for Mr. Gorbachev from the military, rather than from the Communist Party apparatus, because they say party support does not mean as much as it once did. Mr. Gorbachev has shifted his power base to the newly institutionalized and strengthened presidency.
Earlier in the week, the Central Committee apparatus, with the open support of Yegor K. Ligachev, the leading conservative in the Communist Party Politburo, called for driving out radicals who want to move faster toward a free-market economy. But the call was dismissed as mainly irrelevant by one of Mr. Gorbachev's aides.
''If that's the kind of party they want, most people will side with the people they throw out,'' an aide said of the conservatives.
But he was less sanguine about the economy. Mr. Gorbachev's great political gift, he said, was for compromise -which is why he keeps extricating himself from political crises - but not for decisive, radical action.
''He waited too long to start the economic reform; that's clear now,'' this man said. ''Now, most of the rest of the leadership is just sitting around indifferently waiting for it to fail. When you get right down to it, Gorbachev just has Yakovlev and Shevardnadze actively on his side.''

HEADLINE: More Nicaraguans in U.S. Going Back Home

BYLINE: By GEORGE VOLSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 14

 BODY:
Confident that the inauguration on April 25 of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will usher in an era of peace for Nicaragua, a growing number of Nicaraguan exiles are restarting their lives and businesses there.
About 150 Nicaraguan exiles in a caravan of 30 cars are to leave for home next week on a 5,000-mile drive through Florida, Louisiana, Texas, Mexico, Guatemala and Honduras.
Exiles on a similar convoy that left two weeks ago have already reached their destination, relatives say. They said that in the last several weeks about 2,000 Nicaraguans have returned to their homeland. 
After the Sandinistas came to power in 1979, about 500,000 Nicaraguans left the country, exile leaders say. Nearly 150,000 reportedly settled in southern Florida, 70,000 in California, 20,000 in Texas and 10,000 in other states.
Some fled political persecution. But according to the Nicaraguans themselves, the majority left because they could not make ends meet.
So far Mrs. Chamorro's election victory in February over the Sandinistas has not produced a huge return. Even though most exiles have only temporary work permits or none at all, many say they will wait several months before deciding whether to return.
Leonardo Laines, 46 years old, has already made his decision. He is selling his Miami service station for $350,000, and intends to expand his Managua accounting company, which remained in business during his exile. He plans to depart in a month with his wife and two teen-aged children.
''People going back are mostly professsionals for whom life here has not been easy,'' he said. ''Many Nicaraguan physicians, dentists, civil engineers and others are doing low-paid menial jobs because they were unable to obtain licenses to practice their professions.''
Jose Orlando Padron has already made two trips to Nicaragua since President Bush lifted the United States trade embargo last month. He is preparing to reopen his cigar factory in Esteli, which the embargo forced him to close in 1985, laying off 170 workers.
The expertise of entrepreneurs like Mr. Laines and Mr. Padron is the key to Nicaragua's recovery, said Jose Antonio Alvarado, a Nicaragua-born Miami banker who, with an investment of $150,000, is opening a law and financial consulting firm in Managua.
Mr. Alvarado, a 37-year-old economist who directed Mrs. Chamorro's electoral campaign in the United States, expects repatriation to pick up after April 25. But he said that thousands of Nicaraguans who became American citizens or residents would go back only to visit, and that many more with no legal status here will make every effort to stay.

HEADLINE: Warm Month Damaged Part of New York's Maple Syrup Crop

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 13

 BODY:
New York farmers' maple syrup season ended this week, with reports of the 1990 crop ranging from ''dreadful'' to ''the best in the last five years.''
Although the official summary of the season will not be ready for a month, individual farmers throughout the state reported that the quantity and quality of their syrup was affected by an unseasonably warm March.
Normally, the maple syrup season in New York State starts in early March and ends in mid-April, with the maple sap flowing best when warm sunny days follow freezing nights. But this year, the sequence of cold nights followed by warm days was broken by the unusual March weather. 
In commercial operations, sap is no longer collected by metal taps emptying into buckets hanging from trees. Instead, the sap flows from the taps into plastic vacuum lines that carry it to central collecting vats, where the sap is boiled down. About 39 gallons of sap produces a gallon of syrup.
 
'Too Cold or Too Hot'
''It's been rather a poor year,'' said Arthur Merle, a producer in Attica in the western part of the state. ''The weather has been either too cold or too hot.''
Mr. Merle, who finished his production this week, said that he had a normal crop in quantity, but that much of it was dark in color rather than the light or medium amber that maple syrup users prefer.
''The economic difference is that I can sell the light amber grade for $35 a gallon to the public, but the dark commercial grade goes for $8 a gallon,'' he said.
Two other farmers, one near the Canadian border and the other in the Catskill Mountains, each reported a good year both in quantity and quality.
''Up here in the northern part of the state, we've made more syrup this year than in any of the past four or five years,'' said Earl Parker, a producer in Chazy in Clinton County.
 
'The Best Year'
Early this week, Lee and Marilyn Cole in Ferndale, in Sullivan County, ended their annual task of boiling down the sap into syrup.
''In volume, it's the best year in the last five years,'' Mr. Cole said. ''And the quality is good, too.''
Mr. Cole sells syrup at his farm for $32 a gallon, the same price as last year.
But a different production picture was reported by Sandra Putnam, who operates a grove of sugar maples with her husband, Raymond, at Richmondville in Schoharie County.
''It's been a dreadful year, the worst year we ever had,'' she said. ''Warm days at the end of March killed the season.''
She said that the heat apparently affected the chemistry of the trees, so the syrup late in the season had an off flavor.
 
Second Only to Vermont
''In quantity, we had about a third of a crop,'' she said.
Over the years, New York has been second only to Vermont in the production of maple syryp in the United States. Last year, New York produced 325,000 gallons of syrup, while Vermont produced 400,000 gallons. Together, the two states produce more than two-thirds of the maple syrup in the nation.
In Quebec, which supplies about 70 percent of the world market, production apparently was not affected by the warm March weather. Much Canadian syrup is trucked into Vermont and packaged there in cans or bottles for retail sale.
In Vermont this year, production varied according to geography, with a good crop in the colder northern part of the state and a lesser one in the south, said Robert Coombs, a producer and processor in Jacksonville. As in New York, production was affected by a warm spell in mid-March, he said.
Mr. Coombs said he had about 65 per cent of a normal crop from his own trees. He said the retail price there was $39.50 a gallon, down from $42 last year, when there was a very short crop in the area.
''All in all, it was not a very good year, not a disaster, but not a good year,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in Switch, Urges Landlord Cost Index

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
In an apparent reversal of the position he took three years ago when he was Manhattan Borough President, Mayor David N. Dinkins is now pressing the Board of Estimate to approve a city contract for an annual cost survey that is an important feature of the rent-stabilization system. The board is scheduled to vote on the issue at a special meeting on Wednesday.
Tenant groups and other critics have long charged that the survey, as carried out, is one-sided because it looks only at the estimated operating costs of landlords and not at their rental income and profits.
The survey is intended to provide an index of the costs of supplies and services, like fuel, insurance and labor, needed to operate a building. It will be one factor the city's Rent Guidelines Board will use to set rent increases for about 600,000 rent-stabilized apartments where leases will be renewed this year. There are about 950,000 rent-stabilized apartments in the city. 
In 1987 Mr. Dinkins joined other members of the Board of Estimate to block the award of a city contract for such a survey, saying that it was ''merely a perpetuation of a flawed system using a flawed index.''
Only Mayor Edward I. Koch voted for the award of the contract at that time. The Comptroller, then Harrison J. Goldin; the City Council president, Andrew J. Stein, and the five borough presidents all voted against it, and for the first time in 17 years, the city failed to award the survey contract.
The 1987 survey was ultimately made, largely without cost to the city, by the consulting company that had done it the five previous years. In 1988 and 1989, Mayor Koch circumvented the usual contract approval process by a budgetary maneuver that gave the Board of Estimate no voice in the matter.
Mayor Dinkins, who took office on Jan. 1, put this year's contract on the agenda of the Board of Estimate, which will go out of existence this summer. Under the new City Charter, most of its duties will be transferred to the City Council. And this time Mr. Dinkins has indicated he supports the award of the contract, which is for $174,858 and would go to Speedwell Inc., an economic consultant based in Duxbury, Mass.
In a letter last month urging board members to vote for the contract, Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, recalled Mr. Dinkins's 1987 vote and said he was aware of the index's shortcomings. But, she said, in the absence of legislation that would give the rent board the power to see the books and records of building owners, ''the price index is unfortunately the only gauge of operating costs currently available to the Rent Guidelines Board.''
Mrs. Fife also said ''steps have been taken to compensate somewhat for the shortcomings of the price index.''
When the matter came before the board on April 5, a parade of speakers, many of them tenants, opposed the contract and the board decided to lay the item over until Wednesday.
 
Index Said to Exaggerate Costs
Michael McKee and other representatives from the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition said at the April 5 session that rents should be adjusted according to the needs of individual buildings rather than on the basis of an index that ''makes it appear the landlords need rent increases when in fact they do not.''
They said that from 1969 to 1982 the index had overestimated increases in the actual costs of building owners by 15 percent. And they called for a moratorium on future rent increases until owners could demonstrate a need for more rent, based on actual increases in operation and maintenance costs.
At the April 5 hearing Timothy L. Collins, executive director of the Rent Guidelines Board, acknowledged that the price index ''is just that - it measures changes in prices'' and not changes in actual operating costs. But, he added, the information was still valuable when taken into consideration with other facts.
If the contract were not approved, he said, there would still have to be some kind of index, but it would have to be produced by the rent board's staff, which would take people away from other matters.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Bowdoin;
Students Angered By Vote to Change Grading System

DATELINE: BRUNSWICK, Me.

 BODY:
The Bowdoin College faculty voted last week to change the distinctive four-level grading system it instituted in 1967 to the traditional A, B, C, D and F system. The action met with immediate protest from students.
Bowdoin's present system, consisting of high honors, honors, pass and fail, was devised primarily to de-emphasize the importance of grades and to reduce competition.
Student reaction to the change, which will take effect in the fall of 1991, has been swift: a petition protesting the decision and calling for a student referendum on the issue began circulating immediately after the faculty meeting, and by Thursday it had accumulated more than 500 signatures from among the 1,350 undergraduates. A vote will be held tomorrow. 
The issue of changing the system had been raised by the faculty several months ago and was referred to the recording committee, which recommended that the present system remain in place. But at a faculty meeting March 12 an unspecified five-point system was voted in. On Monday, the traditional system was passed by a 49-to-31 vote of the faculty.
Dana W. Mayo, a professor of chemistry and a principal proponent of the change, centered his argument on the wide range that the pass grade encompasses. He told The Bowdoin Orient, the campus newspaper, that students who received a high P in the current system were being penalized because they received the same grade as students who had given up and were barely passing the course.
 
A 60's Leftover
David S. Page, another chemistry professor favoring the change, said: ''The four-point system was an artifact from the 60's when people were trying out new things. Bowdoin is the only institution that continues that system. The reason most people use A, B, C, D, F is that it has been shown to work well.''
David Shorrock, a senior from Shaker Heights, Ohio, majoring in economics and Asian studies who was one of the three student representatives along with four faculty members and three administrators on the recording committee, labeled the faculty action ''exasperating.''
''During our three months of discussion,'' he said, ''we brought up every possible idea and weighed them all before giving our recommendation to the faculty.''
The heart of the issue, he said, was inflation of grades. ''The faculty wants to attack it. In their minds this will solve the problem.'' But, he added, the research of the committee indicated otherwise.
Mr. Shorrock also said that the new system would bring back grade-point averages and class ranks. These figures will not be calculated under the new system, but Mr. Shorrock said that students would begin considering them anyway.
 
A Selling Point
Meredith Sumner, a junior English major from Boscawen, N.H., and a leader in the petition drive, said, ''I don't think the present grading system is perfect, but I think students should have a role in any change.''
One of the major points raised in the debate has been the effect the change will have on attracting students to Bowdoin. William R. Mason, the director of admissions, considers the grading system to be ''a part of Bowdoin's singularity and character.''
''I've seen kids pick Bowdoin because its grade system puts the responsibility of learning on the student,'' he said. ''They like the intellectual ambiance that system promotes.''
Marshall Carter, a junior from Cos Cob, Conn., majoring in history and English, who was a campus tour guide last summer, agreed. ''People are really attracted to Bowdoin by the grading system and the philosophy behind it,'' he said.
Tomorrow's vote is intended to ''allow the faculty to know how the students feel and convince them to reconsider the issue,'' said the vice chairman of the student executive board, Daniel Brakewood, a senior economics major from Lincolnville, Me. A similar decision made by the faculty in 1983 was overturned when student protests succeeded in reopening the issue. ''We are using that as inspiration as we fight,'' Mr. Carter said.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An Unpredictable Playwright Reverses Himself

BYLINE: By ROSEMARY L. BRAY; Rosemary L. Bray is an editor of The New York Times Book Review.

 BODY:
George C. Wolfe is a man in the midst of transition. A playwright (''The Colored Museum,'' his 1986 satire of black American life) and director of the forthcoming ''Spunk,'' Mr. Wolfe says he's been feeling different lately. At first he thought it had to do with turning 35 last September. But he's more inclined to pin his current state of mind on New Year's Day 1990 and his annual gumbo party.
''I throw this big, open extravaganza,'' Mr. Wolfe said last week in a local coffee shop, his hands a constant blur as he spoke. ''Every year it's gotten bigger and bigger. And this year I was so aware of my responsibility.'' Careful with words, he uttered this last not with distaste so much as fascination. ''Other years the party was a kind of purge, a way to begin this other energy. But somehow, this time was all about, 'O.K., now, peel the shrimp; do we have enough cups?' I felt like I was doing this adult thing.''
Now that responsibility has set in, his task, he has decided, is to figure out how to maintain a sense of freedom - in his life as well as his work. ''I'm no longer a part of some form; it's up to me to define it.'' 
As an example, he compares his two roles these days: ''When you're writing, in theory, everybody is serving you. When you're directing, you're serving everybody - in the guise of acting like everybody's serving you. But you're really serving the materials. You're serving the actors. You're in charge, but it's not free.''
Mr. Wolfe may have retained the unconventionality he prizes. The plain-spoken people of ''Spunk'' seem worlds away from the wacky, often embittered, satiric characters who inhabit ''The Colored Museum.'' Reviewing the latter, Frank Rich said in The Times in 1986 that the author is the kind of satirist ''who takes no prisoners.'' Mr. Wolfe says the unthinkable, Mr. Rich said, with uncompromising wit.
But that is not the playwright's aim in ''Spunk,'' which opens Wednesday at the Public Theater. The work is made up of vignettes with dance and music, all inspired by three Zora Neale Hurston short stories about blacks in the urban and rural America of the 1920's. Even when Hurston, a Harlem Renaissance writer, playwright and folklorist, first published these tales, a certain segment of the black community resented her use of dialect and the ''common people'' who were her focus. And since one of the most famous scenes in Mr. Wolfe's ''Colored Museum'' is ''The Last-Mama-on-the-Couch Play,'' a sharp-edged satirization of black maternal stereotypes, it might seem strange that Mr. Wolfe feels so strongly about working with Hurston's material.
He's quick to remind, though, that what he ridiculed in his previous play was the ''reprocessing of those old, stereotypical images,'' not the real people on whom they were based. Hurston's characters, he says, are complex and genuine, and their language is what he likes to call ''Southern colored classical.''
''I think she was an extraordinary writer,'' he said. ''Her characters - as she did - have an outrageous sense of self, which I feel a certain kinship to. I found these stories incredibly theatrical. And there were qualities in them that as a writer I would not naturally write, textures I wouldn't naturally go toward. There's a gentleness in her characters that I'm in awe of in her writing.''
He has retained much of Hurston's narrative because, ''I didn't want to surrender it. Her dialogue is dazzling and smart, but her truths exist inside her narrative.'' Hurston, who is having a renaissance herself, was the co-author with Langston Hughes of ''Mule Bone,'' scheduled for a Lincoln Center production this summer. A play by Laurence Holder based on her life was performed at the American Place Theater in February.
Connecting the three ''Spunk'' stories, Mr. Wolfe says, is Hurston's view of what makes survival possible. Despite the human tendency to construct defenses against life's troubles, those defenses are inevitably swept away. ''When her characters survive, it's because of that grit, that sense of self that is hidden or gets misplaced along the way.'' It is a theme mirrored in the musical prologue, ''How Do I Git to the Git?'':
 
I git to the git
With some blues and some grit
And some paint and some spit
And some spunk.
The cast members, including Danitra Vance and Reggie Montgomery, who appeared in ''The Colored Museum,'' play not only the characters in each Hurston story, but additional roles written by Mr. Wolfe, including Blues Speak Woman, Guitar Man and The Folk. These figures appear during the action to reveal the characters' inner feelings; they act as ''the voices that know the truth,'' he says. Mr. Wolfe found his inspiration for them in Japanese theater. ''I wanted to incorporate certain principles of Noh that translated into Southern black culture,'' he said.
''Story in Harlem Slang'' is his favorite of the three. ''It's such a celebration of language, a celebration of the rituals of colored folks that is so exquisite!'' he said with obvious delight. Two unemployed men, out and about on Harlem's Lenox Avenue, set their sights on the same young domestic worker on payday. Their ostensible object is to attract the woman and get a free meal.
''These characters may not have any money, they may not have anywhere to live, but they know how to talk!'' he said. ''If they could translate the brilliance of their language into other things, into work - they could transform the world. To have nothing, yet to have such a tremendous sense of self is an extraordinary act.''
In ''Sweat,'' Delia is a married woman with only her job as a laundress and her love of God to sustain her in the face of a straying husband and his growing public humiliation of her.
''The Gilded Six Bits,'' is based on ''what I think is one of the most flawlessly written short stories ever,'' Mr. Wolfe said. ''There is a phenomenon that exists within the story that I just think is a phenomenon in the canon of literature about black Americans - a masculine, gentle black man is at the center of this story.'' He is fascinated at Hurston's twist on the standard tale of love betrayed. ''It's always the woman who's betrayed, and the woman who's expected to endure, and get over it.''
''Spunk'' began in Los Angeles in 1989 as a cabaret piece presented by the Mark Taper Forum. Then, after a development workshop, Mr. Wolfe, and the composer Chic Street Man (who wrote much of the music for the production and is also in the cast) moved east to the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick, N.J., where ''Spunk'' opened for a six-week run in November of last year. Joseph Papp subsequently offered it a new home at the Public Theater.
Along with ''Spunk,'' Mr. Wolfe has been at work for several years on a musical, ''Mr. Jelly Lord,'' about Jelly Roll Morton, the pioneering jazz pianist and composer. ''It's a thrilling project,'' he said, speaking of his collaboration with Susan Birkenhead, the lyricist, and Luther Henderson, who is acting as a musical supervisor for Morton's music. Before that, Mr. Wolfe had been devoting time to another production, ''Queenie Pie,'' about a Harlem hairdresser, but said he has ''suspended my involvement with 'Queenie Pie' to complete work on 'Mr. Jelly Lord.' '' A production date for ''Mr. Jelly Lord'' will be announced soon, he said. But in any case, he is determined that the musical will be his last foray into the 1920's. He had intended to leave the decade a lot sooner, but something kept pulling him to the characters he found there and that something most recently has been ''Spunk.''
''Sometimes we're in rehearsal and a moment's not right and something's not working or I'm arguing about a costume - anything. And then an actor executes something that embodies the celebration of a culture, that has the delicacy of being a human being, that has this theatrical elegance to it. And I think 'Oh, that's why we're trying to pull all these disparate rhythms together.' '' They're very disarming stories, if we can get it right. That's what we're working toward - getting it right.''

Wolfe. (Martha Swope) (pg. 14)
