HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
COMPOSERS WHO HAD TO TRIUMPH OVER PREJUDICE

BYLINE: By K. ROBERT SCHWARZ; K. Robert Schwarz is a research assistant at the Institute for Studies in American Music at Brooklyn College.

 BODY:
Mention black American music, and most people will probably think of Ella Fitzgerald or Duke Ellington, of James Brown or Public Enemy. But few will think of William Grant Still, or of a host of black American classical composers. Their achievements are an integral part of the black musical heritage, however, and they have played a significant role in American music - even if they have been relegated to footnote status by the history books.
Of course, it is not difficult to ascertain the reason for this neglect. Racism on the part of the white musical establishment worked to deny blacks entry into the European-oriented world of American concert music. Publishers closed their doors to black musicians; conservatories turned away black students; orchestras refused to consider scores by black composers. When the black bandleader and composer Francis Johnson played in Pittsburgh in 1843, a contemporary report said that a ''mob followed Mr. Johnson and his company . . . hurling brickbats, stones and rotten eggs in great profusion.'' 
Even today, while blacks enjoy international acclaim for their popular music, a black presence in the classical-music world seems as tenuous as ever. Schools of music have few black students and professors; orchestras have few black players and conductors; black composers of concert music seem no more common now than in the 1930's. It is apparently a subtler sort of racism at play today, an economic one, which denies public arts education and career opportunities to young musicians who might most flourish if given the chance.
What is so remarkable is that in every generation of American history there have been black composers able to surmount the odds and establish professional careers. We hear far too little today about these men and women, but several recent recordings and reissues allow us to experience their music first-hand.
No one better demonstrates a composer's triumph over racism than Francis Johnson (1792-1844). Johnson, whose career was centered in Philadelphia, was internationally renowned as a bugle virtuoso and bandleader. His own music, mostly marches and formal dance numbers, occupies the bulk of Musicmasters MMD6 10236F (CD only). Of the 22 pieces recorded here, none survive in their original orchestrations, but their modern reconstructions reveal a composer of toe-tapping music who was endlessly inventive within the confines of small, rigid forms. The Chestnut Brass Company and Friends perform with rousing spirit, even if the recalcitrant original instruments do not always cooperate in matters of intonation.
By the end of the 19th century, mainstream American concert music consisted primarily of an imitation of European styles and forms. Dvorak, who lived here in the 1890's, could not understand why American composers did not embrace our native folk music, especially that of blacks. ''In the Negro melodies of America, I discover all that is needed for a great and noble school of music,'' he wrote. And a whole generation of American composers heeded his call, incorporating black spirituals and dances into their concert music.
Among these composers was R. Nathaniel Dett (1882-1943), whose piano music is recorded on New World NW-367-2 (CD and LP) in performances by Dennis Oldham. Over and over again, especially in Dett's early ''Magnolia Suite'' (1912) and ''In the Bottoms'' (1913), spirituallike modal or pentatonic melodies emerge from the late-Romantic mists. Sometimes these folk tunes are used overtly, as in the infectiously rhythmic ''Juba Dance.'' But more often Dett's fragile folklike sources seem overwhelmed, drowned within the European chromatic harmonies and dense late-Romantic textures.
If the piano music of Florence Price (1888-1953) is more successful than Dett's, it is, I suspect, because she set out to be a composer, and only secondarily one who would make reference to folk materials. Price earned trailblazer status when her Symphony in E minor, performed in 1933 by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, became the first work by a black woman to be played by an American orchestra. In 1932, Price composed a Piano Sonata in E minor, which remained unpublished and unrecorded until a 1987 release by the pianist Althea Waites (Cambria CT-1027; cassette and LP). Price's sonata is filled with poignant pentatonic melodies of obviously black derivation. But these melodies un-self-consciously arise out of her own compositional voice; they are not artificially planted within some foreign turf. And Price's fine control over large formal structures makes the sonata's turbulent late Romanticism a pleasure to follow.
By the 1930's, a black Renaissance was well underway in all the arts, embracing the poet Langston Hughes, the composer William Grant Still and the tenor Roland Hayes. Hayes (1887-1976), the first notable black concert singer, set the stage for better-known performers such as Paul Robeson and Marian Anderson. But he was a fine singer on his own terms, as is demonstrated by ''The Art of Roland Hayes'' (Smithsonian RD-041; CD only). This collection of 11 art songs and 12 spirituals consists primarily of recordings made in the 1950's, when the tenor was well past his prime. But the spirituals, delivered in a richly emotive, gorgeously shaded manner, stand as a lasting monument to the vitality of the black folk tradition.
Among composers, the 1930's saw a reinvigorated desire to turn to black-American forms as the basis for a distinctive classical music. This nationalism was, of course, only a part of the general mood of the era, which affected white composers like Copland and Thomson no less than blacks. But Still's ''Afro-American Symphony'' (1930) predated the nationalism of his white contemporaries, and made history as the first work by a black composer to be played by a major orchestra.
Still, who had experience in popular as well as classical music, used modern blues and jazz idioms in his symphony, rather than the more acceptable spirituals. It is the blues, especially, that permeates the ''Afro-American Symphony'' (reissued on Library of Congress OMP-105 [CD and cassette], in a 1965 performance by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra under Karl Krueger). Inventive in its orchestration and lively in its rhythms, Still's work can't help but impress with its sincerity of purpose. But its poor control over form and development make it more a pastiche of seductive tunes than a real symphony.
William Grant Still, however, had the good sense to keep his harmonic language simple, so as not to violate the spirit of his sources. Not so with William Levi Dawson, whose ''Negro Folk Symphony'' (1934) has been reissued in a ragged 1964 performance by the American Symphony Orchestra under Leopold Stokowski (MCA Classics MCAD2-9826A; CD only). Dawson (born in 1899) prefers spirituals to the less reputable blues, and he incorporates both newly composed and genuine folk material. Yet all is cast within a grandiose, hyper-emotive context, replete with slinky chromatic harmonies and bombastic climaxes. Even though Dawson's handling of symphonic form seems more astute than Still's, the alien garb ends up nearly obliterating the once-eloquent sources.
The problem with the large works of Still and Dawson - and to a lesser extent with the miniatures of Dett - is the disparity between the simple, self-contained black-American material and the extended European forms. It is a disparity rooted in the composer's own attitude toward the folk traditions. Dett wrote in 1918 that those traditions ''will be of no value unless our musical architects take the rough timber of Negro themes and fashion from it music which will prove that we, too, have national feelings. . . .'' Many years later, Still wrote that he ''wanted to demonstrate how the blues, so often considered a lowly expression, could be elevated to the highest musical level.''
The undercurrent is all too clear: the spirituals dances, and blues were not worthy enough in their unadorned state; they supposedly needed to be elevated so that they could compete with the achievements of European art music. Today, such an attitude seems naive, and it may account for the fact that this music - along with so much of American nationalism - went out of fashion after World War II. But for a composer like Still, who wanted to be judged by European standards, the path to success lay in couching black traditions in terms acceptable to white audiences.
The result is not the greatest music America has produced. And it is far from the greatest black music, for Bessie Smith's ''Lost Your Head Blues'' (1926), Duke Ellington's ''Ko-Ko'' (1940) - or Anthony Davis's opera ''X'' (1986) - are all more vital in their cultural stance than the ''Afro-American Symphony.'' Nevertheless, when viewed from today's perspective, composers like Dett, Price, Still and Dawson cannot help but appear heroic. They fought back against the racism of their country and of their chosen profession, and time has been their vindication.

HEADLINE: Protecting the Environment: How Much Can Tax Policy

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Since the start of the year, American producers of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, and other chemicals that deplete the atmosphere's ozone have been paying an excise tax expected to raise $4.3 billion over the next five years. Accounting firms have been warning business clients that the tax, termed a user fee by the Bush Administration, could be the first of a host of new environmentally related levies. Environmental tax credits and incentives are also being proposed, like tax breaks for waste incineration systems. What are the prospects for these proposals? How will they affect businesses and American competitivness? Nicholas Ashford, an associate professor of technology and policy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Paul Huard, vice president in charge of tax policy at the National Association of Manufacturers, and Bill Walsh of Greenpeace Action, a Washington-based environmental group, recently met to discuss these issues. Barnaby J. Feder of The New York Times moderated.
 
Question: Why use taxation in addition to regulation to address environmental problems?
 
Nicholas Ashford: I can see three reasons: to raise revenue, change incentives or out of moral concerns. You might want to make polluters pay without regard to how much revenue you raise. 
 
Paul Huard: We must look at tax policy, including incentives, rather than just taxes. Our members tend to break down the universe into carrots and sticks. By and large, we prefer the carrots, largely for economic reasons. Though the sticks may achieve the same results, in many cases, they don't work very well in the context of the global economy. You may make manufacturers less competitive; that reduces employment, G.N.P., and ultimately the revenue you pick up from the environmental taxes.
 
Bill Walsh: Also, taxes are a good way to get at small businesses, which are often among the worst polluters but outside the scope of regulation.
 
Q. What is likely to emerge from Congress this year?
 
Mr. Huard: The best result would be no bill at all. But I would not be surprised to see some environmental penalty taxes because they are convenient sources of quick revenue.
There are so many floating around, like taxes on harvesting virgin redwoods. I wouldn't rule out taxes on sulfur and nitrogen oxides, even though there are going to be emissions limits in the Clean Air Bill.
 
Q. Are you saying that environmental taxes are simply an ''in'' method on Capitol Hill for raising revenue?
 
Mr. Huard: Most of them are for the revenue. I don't think many would pass otherwise because of the demonstrable impact in lost jobs or the G.N.P. But yes, the Federal budget process has made quick, short-term sources of revenue the be-all and end-all of getting out and going home.
 
Mr. Walsh: I agree that some taxes are likely because they are quick hits. Some kind of tax on acid rain is most likely. I don't know what else will move out of the starting gate, but there are an awful lot of horses lined up. What's not going to happen is what needs to happen: - a fundamental thinking about the environmental impact of the tax laws.
 
Q. Are you saying that policy questions are getting ignored in the rush for revenue?
 
Mr. Ashford: We will disagree on specifics, but there are win-win situations we cannot fashion because of the quick-fix mentality of the Congress.
 
Mr. Walsh: You could reap huge revenues from emission or input taxes, or by cutting depletion allowances. But that doesn't make sense when other aspects of the tax code are pushing industry in the wrong direction, away from an environmental perspective - and an economic one.
 
Q. Can't these taxes be seen simply as a way to force markets to take into account the true costs of pollution?
 
Mr. Ashford: But it's not just a matter of internalizing social costs. The current tax structure distorts the investment picture. For example, you get accelerated depreciation for pollution-control equipment. But if, God forbid, an industrialist says I want to change my process to improve productivity and, by the way, it will cut my sulfur dioxide emissions to zero, he won't get favored tax treatment.
 
Mr. Huard: Yes, it's crazy. You get better results if you look for the win-win situation: better productivity and better products at lower cost, and a cleaner environment. But you can only do that with well thought out, very targeted incentives.
 
Q. Are there other environmental problems in the tax code beyond sending the wrong investment cues?
 
Mr. Ashford: Through standard deductions we subsidize improper behavior. People can deduct what they pay to transport hazardous waste to an illegal dump. Punitive damages when people lose environmental liability suits are deductible.
 
Mr. Walsh: That's not all. If you are engaged in illegal dumping, whether through pipes or trucks, you can still deduct all your expenses, even if a court has found your activity illegal.
 
Q. Is concern about global competitiveness holding back environmental tax reform, or is that a straw man?
 
Mr. Ashford: A straw man. There's a world trend toward these policies and any differences will be short-lived.
 
Mr. Huard: I'm not so sanguine. A company won't pick up a plant and move it to Belgium, but if you unilaterally impose penalties on multinationals, they will stop or reduce production here and increase it in a country that doesn't beat them over the head.
 
Mr. Walsh: International trade concerns don't need to be a barrier. This could be an opportunity for the big multinationals - the DuPonts of the world - to support similar policies in various countries and build a business constituency for rational change. But, at least from what I have seen with CFC's, the multinationals tend to play countries against each other.
 
Q. So environmental tax policy can be a way of improving competitiveness?
 
Mr. Ashford: It's a world market we could exploit, one that the Japanese and Europeans are not exploiting. We are at the cutting edge in these new, environmentally safe technologies. I think the real tension is within the industrial sector, not between industrialists and environmentalists. How do you shift from old technologies to new and safer one and make it palatable politically?
 
Q. Are any other countries taking a better approach?
 
Mr. Huard: Several have special accelerated provisions for pollution abatement facilities. But I don't know of any that has a well thought out policy of incentives for conversion to desirable processes.
 
Q. Are there problems squaring environmental taxes or incentives with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade or our other international trade treaties?
 
Mr. Huard: Most arise on the tax side, like proposals taxing the use of virgin materials. Opponents say that puts American producers at a disadvantage; so the proponents say, fine, we'll put an equivalent tariff on imports. That's a problem under G.A.T.T.
 
Mr. Walsh: You can avoid some problems by how you interpret G.A.T.T. I believe it has provisions for protection of natural resources. We also need an environmental perspective in the current G.A.T.T. negotiations.
 
Q. Should revenues from environmental taxes be dedicated to solving environmental problems?
 
Mr. Ashford: I think we have to earmark some of them to help industry develop cleaner technology.
 
Mr. Huard: The problem with dedicated trust funds is that the money gets collected and spent even when the need has dissipated or, even worse, it's allowed to pile up to make the deficit look smaller. There's a lot to be said for collecting general revenues and letting various social demands compete. Make Congress set priorities; that's what it's elected for.
 
Mr. Walsh: Clearly, reducing the deficit also benefits everybody. But there's a need to turn back some funds into environmental R. & D.
 
Q. What about dedicated taxes to compensate people injured by pollution?
 
Mr. Ashford: Tax policy ought to be used to make polluting industries pay up front for the damage they do. We are not doing that. Just look at the social costs of the Johns Manville bankruptcy and the people going uncompensated for asbestos injuries.
 
Mr. Walsh: The incredible example is the Lead Institute's rejection of any kind of tax to establish a fund to remove lead paint from inner-city buildings even though a study by the Environmental Defense Fund demonstrated that we have three million children suffering from lead poisoning. It's an immoral cost imposed on the neediest in society.
 
Mr. Huard: But a lot of these things are very hard to quantify, particularly if you are guessing up front, as would have been the case with asbestos, where it takes decades for the injuries to become apparent. We prefer to rely on general revenues to cover societal costs.
 
Q. How important is the problem of quantifying environmental costs in setting tax policy?
 
Mr. Walsh: We are at the point where we can no longer wait to tally up the costs. By the time everyone is convinced that global warming has bad consequences and we have the data to back that up, it will be too late.
 
Mr. Huard: I think we will have more areas of agreement if we stick to clean vs. dirty, as opposed to warm vs. warmer.
 
Mr. Ashford: It's a question of which mistake you want to avoid. On global warming, you can start now and have a relatively painless transition. If you wait until all the evidence comes in, it will be painful. There's no reason not to start demanding much more energy efficiency now.
 
Q. Is anyone in the business community trying to put forth a sound environmental tax policy? Or is business in a strictly reactive stance?
 
Mr. Huard: For the short term anyway; we spend all of our times putting out fires and it's hard to change that. Our membership may be too broad for something like that.
 
Mr. Walsh: Trade groups shouldn't have to do this. It's the job of the Ways and Means Committee and the President. Someone has to sort through the competing interests, shine a light toward the goal and carve out a path. Then you can bring the diverse interests to the table for debates about time and specifics.
 
Q. Should environmental taxes be put on hold until a sound policy is worked out?
 
Mr. Walsh: No, we shouldn't wait for Congress to do the right thing. Taxes on things like acid rain or the cutting of virgin timber at least express an interest and there would be some benefits.
 
Mr. Ashford: We are not even paying for the occupational environmental diseases we are causing, so you if you tax polluting industries, you can't be doing the wrong thing - even though you have to do much more than that.
 
Mr. Huard: When you talk about acid rain, smog or failure to meet ozone standards, there are definite problems that need to be dealt with. But other problems are more long range. Taxes on virgin timber or other materials to encourage recycling, for example, are particularly wrongheaded. If you look at the major industries involved, such as paper or plastic producers, the people using the virgin materials are also the leading recyclers.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bill Walsh of Greenpeace; Paul Huard of N.A.M.; Nicholas Ashford of M.I.T.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Cleaning Up Penny-Stock Fraud

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
A new bill that would strengthen Federal oversight of the nation's ''penny stock'' market could be the acid test of just how serious the securities industry and Federal regulators are about tackling the widespread and chronic fraud that characterizes that marketplace.
Penny stocks are low-priced securities that trade over the counter but are not listed on Nasdaq. They trade chiefly in the ''pink sheets,'' printed listings of brokers' offers to buy and sell that are distributed daily among market makers.
The proposed legislation takes aim squarely at that primitive marketplace, and would require that it be replaced with a computerized price-quote network under the auspices of a self-regulatory group like the National Association of Securities Dealers. It also would give regulators at the Securities and Exchange Commission new powers to sanction the promoters and consultants involved. 
One thing the bill cannot do, of course, is dictate that regulators, despite their expressions of concern about fraud in the penny-stock market, be enthusiastic. And neither organization, so far, has shown much support for the measure. Joseph Hardiman, president of the N.A.S.D., has said that he sees no need for Federal legislation in the penny-stock arena, and Richard C. Breeden, the S.E.C. chairman, has told Congress that, while some additional rules might be needed, he did not favor any sweeping changes in legislation.
The proposed legislation was introduced April 4 by Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommitteee on finance. There seems to be some some bipartisan energy behind the proposal: it was co-sponsored by both Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and the influential chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and Representative Matthew Rinaldi, Republican of New Jersey. And the bill has won an emphatic endorsement from the North American Securities Admininstrators Association, which represents state securities regulators and their counterparts in Canada and Mexico.
Susan E. Bryant, president of N.A.S.A.A. and the top securities regulator in Oklahoma, said last week that she plans to testify in favor of the bill at a subcommittee hearing scheduled for April 25 in Washington. Ms. Bryant, whose office has been aggressive in its policing of penny-stock sales in Oklahoma, is particularly pleased with the bill's call for an automated trading system. As it is, she said, investors find it almost impossible to get accurate information about the trading volume in a stock or the range of prices dealers are quoting.
Equally important, she said, is the bill's focus on the shadowy promoters and penny-stock consultants who are currently beyond the reach of regulators because they are not licensed brokers or underwriters. The involvement of ''repeat offenders of state and Federal securities laws and other felons'' has come to be one of the ''dominant characteristics'' of the penny-stock market, she said.
Mr. Markey, in introducing the bill, also noted that his subcommittee has found that ''even the most recidivist criminals imaginable, having been barred from acting as brokers or dealers, wind up as manipulative promoters in the penny-stock business.''
But less sensational provisions of the Markey bill also deserve attention, especially the proposed restrictions on stock offerings known as ''blank checks'' and ''blind pools.''
Boiled down from the prospectus boilerplate, a ''blank check'' company simply proposes to sell stock to the public and use the investors' money to shop around for some other business to buy. No business plans or details are provided. A ''blind pool'' offering is slightly more forthcoming: it indicates the general sector of the economy in which the shopping spree would occur - oil, perhaps, or technology.
The problems with these ''trust-me'' stocks is that once a blank-check venture has been registered with the S.E.C., it is a public company - and whatever it decides to buy becomes a public company, without the formal fuss and additional disclosure involved in an official public offering. These transactions are called ''reverse mergers,'' because the acquired company is the surviving entity. And they have been the rage among fraudulent penny-stock dealers and promoters for years, as any review of recent penny-stock fraud cases will show.
The Markey bill would simply prohibit blank-check and blind-pool companies from registering with the S.E.C., and would prevent them from selling their shares publicly. Even more importantly, it would require that some self-regulatory organization, like the N.A.S.D., review penny-stock offerings to assure that they are not used for fraudulent purposes and are consistent with ''just and equitable principles of trade,'' as required by Federal law.
Since 1934, regulation of the securities markets in the United States has been grounded on the notion that adequate, truthful disclosure is a sufficient antidote to stock fraud. That is why blank-check companies have been free to register with the S.E.C. in the past, so long as they candidly disclosed that they had no idea what they would do with investors' money.
The Markey bill envisions a tougher standard for registration and trading. It suggests that there are some companies that simply should not be permitted to register with the S.E.C. and sell shares to the public, no matter how candid their paperwork may be. And it puts the responsibility for screening out those companies squarely on the shoulders of the regulators at the S.E.C. and the N.A.S.D.
Both organizations have made many pronouncements over the past year about their determination to move against penny-stock fraud in the marketplace. The Markey bill seems to offer them a chance to tackle the problem before it reaches the marketplace - and before the public's money is at risk.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Susan E. Bryant

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 15, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1675 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 8-13

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Soda for Ships
 
Now this is a floating exchange rate. American Pepsi for Soviet ships. In a $3 billion deal - the largest ever between an American company and the Soviet Union - Pepsico will vastly expand its sales there in return for a flood of Stolichnaya vodka and a fleet of freighters and tankers. Since the ruble cannot be converted into Western currencies, companies operating in the Soviet Union have to look for other ways to take out their profits. Pepsico has been a leader in penetrating Soviet markets. Donald M. Kendall, the chairman of the company's executive committee, is ''Mr. U.S.-Soviet trade,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. Now other Western companies will be watching to see how much Pepsi can profit from perestroika.
 
From Low-Tech to High-Tech
 
In Japan, even low-technology companies are going high-tech. The Mitsubishi Mining and Cement Company has closed its last coal mine, while the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation has closed its last Japanese mine of any sort. The two announced on Wednesday that they would merge to concentrate on developing sophisticated new materials for industries like computers and electronics. The new company will have annual sales of $5.7 billion. Impressive, but not enough to make the new company more than a supporting actor within the powerful Mitsubishi Group of allied companies. Annual sales for Mitsubishi Electric Corporation alone are more than $19 billion. 
 
Buying Safer Tankers
 
The American Petroleum Institute questions whether two hulls make an oil tanker less prone to oil spills than one. The issue needs more study, the trade group says. But Conoco Inc. has already reached its own conclusion. On Tuesday, the company, a subsidiary of Du Pont, broke with the industry by announcing an order for two new tankers with the extra hulls. ''We realize that double-hulled tankers are not the total solution, but they do offer an increased margin of protection against oil spills,'' said Constantine S. Nicandros, Conoco's president. ARCO appears to favor the double hulls as well. The extra protection raises the cost of a ship by 5 to 15 percent. A Coast Guard study cited by the Natural Resources Defense Council said that if the Exxon Valdez tanker had a double hull, it would have spilled 15 to 60 percent less oil onto Alaska's shores and seas last year. Congress is considering legislation to make double hulls mandatory.
 
 
Lockheed Wins - And Loses
 
The battle between Harold C. Simmons and Lockheed could be one that both sides lose. The Lockheed Corporation claimed victory on Tuesday in a proxy fight with Mr. Simmons for control of the company and its board. But Mr. Simmons won several shareholder rights measures, one calling for the abolition of a ''poison pill'' defense against a takeover and another for voluntary exemption from Delaware's anti-takeover laws. Mr. Simmons, who owns nearly 10 percent of Lockheed's shares, says he will continue pressing the company to improve shareholder value. But some analysts believe that Lockheed's value is more likely to go down. ''They're looking at a defense budget that's going to decline precipitously over the next three or four years,'' said Michael Rosen, an aeronautics analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Major programs in the aeronautical systems division are winding down.'' Whatever the company's fate, Mr. Simmons has had enough success in budging an obstinate board to encourage others to wage proxy fights for control of major companies.
 
 
M.C.I.'s Growth Spurt
 
The MCI Communications Corporation plans to pick up another 1.4 percent of the long-distance telephone market - through an expensive acquisition rather than discounted service. MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, announced an agreement on Monday to buy Telecom USA Inc., the fourth largest, for $1.25 billion. Analysts lauded the deal, saying it would combine MCI's residential and big-business customers with Telecom's medium-size accounts in medium-size cities. But the new company, with more than 13 percent of the long-distance market, would still be dwarfed by A.T.& T., with 71 percent. The deal is subject to review by the Justice Department.
 
 
Clearing the Air
 
Men in a shadowy, smoke-filled room are plotting to woo new smokers to replace those who quit or die. They cackle with laughter as one of them says, ''Gentlemen, we're not in this for our health.'' The scene is from a paid television commercial in a new anti-smoking campaign that California launched on Tuesday. The state will spend $26.8 million over the next 18 months, much of it to show tart, pointed advertisements during prime time. Gone are the sober public-service announcements that aired at odd hours to an audience of insomniacs and night watchmen. ''The objective is to change the image that the tobacco industry has created for smokers,'' said Kenneth W. Kizer, director of the California Department of Health Services.
 
 
Boeing's Japan Connection
 
The Boeing Company plans to rely on three Japanese corporations for major components needed to develop a new commercial jet, the 300-seat 767-X. Boeing abandoned earlier plans for giving the companies equity in the project, which raised fears about whether the Japanese would gain enough expertise in aerospace to challenge American manufacturers.
 
 
CBS Bets on Sports
 
CBS Inc. found that betting on sports can pay off. First-quarter earnings, reported on Wednesday, rose 52 percent from the year before to $85.3 million. CBS profited by adding the Super Bowl and two games from the NCAA basketball semifinals to its first-quarter schedule. But its prime-time ratings continue to disappoint. And it paid so much for sporting events later this year that analysts predict weak earnings - unless the World Series involves a couple big-city teams that battle to six or seven games.
 
 
 
ECONOMY
 
 
Incompetence or Greed?
 
Last week's savings and loan horror story: William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said on Wednesday that the institutions seized by the Government are shot through with fraud. His said his agency will have to spend years hiring and training investigators familiar with accounting, banking, real estate, energy and white-collar shenanigans; sorting through truckloads of documents, and then proving to juries that savings and loan executives lost billions not through incompetence alone, but also through thievery. The incompetence argument is strong, judging from the billions these units sank into ''junk bonds'' and even junkier real estate. The horror story from the week before, remember, was the General Accounting Office's estimate that the bailout would cost $325 billion to $500 billion..
 
 
More Bond Defaults
 
The darkest forecasts of corporate bond defaults soon come to seem far too optimistic. The Bond Investors Association predicted in January that defaults would rise to a record $15 billion this year from $11.9 billion in 1989. But bond issues totaling $5.7 billion defaulted in the first quarter alone, the association reported. Leave out the $3.5 billion Campeau default, and the total would still be 64 percent ahead of last year. Richard Lehmann, the association's president, lists Western Union, Southland and Ames Department Stores among the companies most likely to default.
 
 
Explaining the Drop in Prices
 
Cheaper clothing, vegetables and gasoline helped drive wholesale prices down two-tenths of 1 percent in March. Economists -surprised by Friday's report of the first drop in seven months - were all but consulting the Old Farmer's Almanac for explanations. A warm winter, said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia State University Economic Forecasting Center, meant ''tomatoes came on line more quickly than expected.'' The core rate of producer price inflation, excluding food and energy, rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Investing in Japan Inc.
 
The Japanese keep spending on their corporations, if not on themselves. Last year, they invested $750 billion, about 24 percent of gross national product, in plants, equipment, and research and development. The United States spent $500 billion, or 10 percent of gross national product. Analysts say Japanese companies have enough cash to sustain investment despite higher interest rates and a falling stock market. American negotiators urge the Japanese to consume more. The response, from a recent book co-written by Akio Morita, the Sony chairman: ''We are focusing on business 10 years in advance, while you seem to be concerned only with profits 10 minutes from now. At that rate, you may well never be able to compete with us.''
 
 
Soviets Short on Cash
 
Can the Soviet Union pay for its grain? Shippers are complaining of late Soviet payments, which might amount to almost a half-billion dollars. Some grain dealers have stopped selling there on credit. Soviet payment problems extend to other areas; the Soviet Union reportedly defaulted on late charges for tankers waiting in the Black Sea to load Soviet oil. But Soviet oil exports appear to be holding up even if production and domestic consumption are off. Some economists say the trouble is less a lack of hard currency than bureaucratic confusion. But Thane Gustafson, a Soviet specialist for Cambridge Energy Research Associates, wonders whether the country is dealing with ''a succession of micro-crises, or the beginning of a macro-crisis.''
 
 
Americans in Brazil
 
American companies face losses from Brazil's economic turmoil. Johnson & Johnson announced a $125 million write-off on Wednesday; one reason is Brazil's radical new program to fight inflation, which its Congress approved on Wednesday. Measures imposed by President Fernando Collor de Mello have already pitched Brazil into a recession.

HEADLINE: Looking Into Accounting's Heart of Darkness

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Chris Campos finds adventure in a retailer insisting he sells women's coats at full price in February. He can grow rhapsodic over learning of someone who can shamelessly bilk the boss's son. Somebody blows up a factory? Hold on, he'll be right there.
Mr. Campos sifts the fine grains of financial books and records. Calculator in hand, he attempts to gauge revenues that matter greatly for insurance claims or litigation. His job title is forensic accountant, a specialist sometimes known as an investigative auditor - Dick Tracy in a green eyeshade. He's the sort of person who, when a flood shutters an air-freshener factory for 17 days, can go in and deduce just how much air freshener business might have washed away.
To a growing extent, insurers and a wide assortment of companies are hiring accounting sleuths like the 60-year-old Mr. Campos, head of the New York-based firm of Campos & Stratis, to compute the probable magnitude of damages from a business loss or disruption. This dependance has transformed the specialty over the last two decades from a negligible and arcane art to a sizable and fast-growing field. Campos & Stratis, which does only forensic accounting (no tax returns, please) and is perhaps the largest practitioner, says its revenues have tripled in the last five years to about $15 million. 
There are no solid estimates of the total size of the forsenic accounting field, which is highly fragmented among innumerable local and regional practitioners and a sprinkling of national firms, though Mr. Campos figures it creeps into the hundreds of millions of dollars a year. ''Over the years, the insurance business has expanded and the litigation business has expanded,'' Mr. Campos said, ''and that has meant great growth in investigative accounting.''
Chris Campos, a florid man with a placatory and friendly way about him, describes the work as ''a lot of just plain old common sense.'' It also involves tedious paper shuffling and the habit of being vigilant about asking for every piece of paper that has numbers scribbled on it.
''We had a recent case of a fire at a retailer of women's coats,'' Mr. Campos said. ''It happened in February and the guy put in an insurance claim for the full value of the coats. He said they were all selling at list price. That was baloney. Here it is February, the coat season is almost over. Women are looking for clearance sales. You only needed common sense to get that claim down to a reasonable amount.''
Disasters inevitably bring a skein of work. Last year, Hurricane Hugo loaded up the office with a clutter of business interruption claims. Mr. Campos has recently been groping through the gritty details of a fire at a San Francisco hotel. Working on behalf of the hotel, he is seeking to quantify a damage claim against the makers of the carpeting, draperies and acoustical tile. The hotel contends that the fire spread more swiftly than it should have because the flammability of those products was far greater than the hotel had been led to believe.
The forensic firm was founded by Chris Campos in 1969 as a one-man operation. Soon after, Elia Stratis joined and the two presided over the company until Mr. Stratis was killed in the Pan Am plane that was blown up over Scotland in December 1988. Increased demand for the firm's services has led it to open other offices in 22 cities that employ 140 accountants. Its major national competitor is Matson, Driscoll & Damico, and it also comes up against Kinsell & Associates, Meaden & Moore and several local practitioners. The huge accounting firms like Arthur Andersen also do forensic work.
To do its snooping, Campos charges between $40 and $200 an hour, depending on the level of experience of the person handling the assignment. Some work is completed in days, while complex matters that go to court can plod on for years.
The cases that come cascading across the Campos desks bespeak the dark side of American life. ''We've got all sorts of stuff - blood, messy divorces, theft, you name it,'' said Mark Gallagher, the partner in charge of the Atlanta office. Blessed with a mind that makes connections, he likes to assign patterns to the behavior he notices, and he doesn't need very much behavior before he agrees on a pattern.
Leading up to the disclosure of one of his grand theories, Mr. Gallagher rattled off the case of the bumptious female thief. Hired to work in the payroll department of a Florida printing company run by the son of the owner, she started stealing by neglecting to pay employee withholding taxes to the Internal Revenue Service. She stole enough to buy a car. Then she began dating the owner's son. They decided to live together. She swiped her part of the downpayment on the condominium they bought. When the I.R.S. came looking for its money, the game was over. Mightily displeased, the father summarily dismissed the son, basing his action on the belief that anyone that idiotic was unsuited to run his business.
''This is all part of Gallagher's First Law of Evolutionary Development and the Effect of Ultraviolet Rays on the Sons of Owners of Businesses in Florida,'' Mr. Gallagher summed up. ''The law is that the sons of owners of businesses in Florida prove to be genetically deficient. It may apply elsewhere, too, but so far I've only spotted it in Florida.''
For whatever reason, Mr. Gallagher commonly finds himself steeped in compulsive theft. ''We had a run of people stealing from doctors,'' he said. ''Those doctors got banged pretty hard. Then there was a run on car dealerships. Then it was manufacturers. We have a rule of thumb. A woman usually steals from $25,000 to $125,000 before she's caught. A man usually steals $50,000 to in excess of $1 million before he's caught. I think this is because men tend to have access to more money. All this is the result of a totally unscientific survey made by me.'' When it comes to larceny, Campos & Stratis is hired by the company that got drained of its money or its insurer to determine the dimensions of the losses. This involves taxing one's eyesight by combing through a company's financial and bank records to penetrate the cover woven around the thief.
''The best case we had,'' Mr. Gallagher said, ''was this guy who worked in accounts payable at different manufacturing companies in Atlanta. He would set up a dummy company and send money to it. He got $15,000 to $30,000 from the first place he worked at. The second place he got $300,000 to $400,000. The third place he got like $300,000. When he went to a fourth place, that company actually called the third place for a reference on the guy. Unfortunately, it got his lover and, naturally, she gave him one whale of a reference. He got the fourth place for $600,000. But they also got him. His nickname, by the way, was Mack the Knife.''
Mr. Gallagher quivered with delight. ''Oh, everybody's getting ripped off,'' he said. ''Look at this message here. When I get off the phone, I've got to call a guy who got banged for $200,000.''
Law firms that work with forensic accountants say their contribution can be considerable. ''I've used Campos on some major cases, along with other firms, and in some matters what they come up with is the whole case,'' said Larry Zelle, a partner in the Minneapolis law firm of Zelle & Larson.
Nevertheless, the work, like most everything in the accounting world, tends to have subjective underpinnings. In many disputes, forensic accountants work both sides of a case. Even though he stares at the very same information, a forensic accountant hired by a plaintiff will invariably produce numbers starkly different from those compiled by a forensic accountant retained by the defendant, in the way that psychiatrists testifying in trials tend to dance nimbly apart when it comes to whether a defendant is mad. The reason is partly because the work is rooted in hypothetical projections but also because motivations can inflate or deflate numbers. ''You would hope that the measurements would be the same,'' Mr. Campos said. ''In the real world they aren't because one person is always a little more zealous than the other.''
He mentioned a current case involving a hotel fire in which Campos, working for the hotel, concluded that business during the time the hotel was shut down would have grown 4.5 percent. The forensic accountant hired by the insurer decided business would have dropped by 7.5 percent. ''So we're 12 percentage points apart,'' Mr. Campos said. ''These sort of differences are typical. Usually there's a settlement somewhere in between.''
Forensic accountants are also commonly used in contentious divorces to ferret out ''hidden assets'' of spouses. Campos & Stratis, though, pursues only a sprinkling of such cases, preferring to confine itself to business conflicts.
Various authors, actors and inventors retain Campos & Stratis when they suspect they have been shortchanged on their royalties. Judith Spry, based in the Chicago office, was recently hired by a woman who had devised a board game and felt her payments had been too low. Sure enough, it turned out she was being paid according to sales of the games when her contract called for her to be compensated according to the number of games produced. She picked up an additional $20,000.
Some matters that come before the Campos sleuths appear rudimentary once information is sifted through. Jeff Baliban, a partner in the Dallas office, recently was involved in the case of the aching pipe salesman. He drove around from account to account selling plastic pipe. When he slipped while shopping for groceries at a supermarket, he claimed he damaged his back so badly that he was unable to sit in his car as much as usual and thus his business diminished. He'd forget all that, though, with a $150,000 check from the supermarket.
Mr. Baliban plotted his sales alongside his gasoline receipts. Sure enough, his sales did drop appreciably within months of his accident. Nevertheless, his gasoline expenditures remained pretty much unchanged. Further inquiry found that not long before his fall one of his major pipe suppliers had cut him off. The case was thrown out.
''It was a nice try,'' Mr. Baliban said. ''But no dough.''
 
 
 
TERRORISTS OR ARSONISTS?
For Campos & Stratis, one of the most ambitious forensic investigations involved the Sponge Rubber Products plant in Shelton, Conn. In March 1975, the plant was blown up and turned into a fire-blackened ruin by armed men hinting a connection with the radical group the Weathermen.
Sponge Rubber filed a whopping $62.6 million insurance claim. After an investigation by the F.B.I. and the police, however, arson charges were lodged against the owner of the plant and a band of men said to have carried out the firebombing. The owner was accused of directing the others to burn the plant for the insurance.
To see if economics might have made arson a motive, the plant's insurer hired Campos to analyze the financial state of the rubber factory.
Campos also tried to trace any money to the accused arsonists and did link payments from the company to a self-described clairvoyant minister who served as a spiritual adviser to the plant's owner.
Though the owner was ultimately acquitted, the psychic minister and his team were convicted.

HEADLINE: All About/Texas Real Estate;
A Glut of Office Space Turns Enticing

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Texas real estate people, dazed after the debacle of the 1980's, are now daring to brag of a rebound. The office market in the Northeast came back, so why not Texas, they ask. ''I really believe that great fortunes will be made over the next decade in Texas real estate to rival when Olympia & York made their big hit in New York in the 1970's,'' said Charles G. Dannis, president of Crosson Dannis Inc., a Dallas real estate appraiser.
Many large investors are in fact betting on Texas as Dallas and Houston, its largest cities, begin to fill the acres of office space built in the early 80's. Only a few years ago, desperate developers offered months of free rent. Now, the freebies are gone, vacancies are down, rents are up and buyers want in while buildings are still relatively cheap.
Texas real estate sank so deep that bargain hunters plumbing the bottom still need long lines. ''There is talk, there is activity, but we're still in a misunderstood market,'' said Roger Staubach, the former football star whose Dallas-based leasing company bears his name. ''We're in a healthy economy, but it was just so overbuilt that now it'll take years to absorb it.'' 
 
 
Beyond the Binge
 
Institutional Investors Return to the Fold
Institutional investors like the Teachers Insurance Annuity Association, a New York pension fund, are gaining confidence that their returns will not be jeopardized by another binge of overbuilding. The collapse of many Texas banks and savings and loans has virtually cut off credit to speculative builders. The Chubb Corporation bought the First Interstate tower, one of Dallas's premiere office buildings, earlier this month. It intends to build another tower nearby.
Instead of being ashamed of their office gluts, Dallas and Houston boast of having some of the least expensive big-city buildings in the nation. ''The horrendous overbuilding is coming back to be more of a positive than a negative,'' said William Bugg, the South-Central director for Cushman & Wakefield, a national real estate brokerage. ''Now they can be more competitive in offering space than other cities.
A 1989 survey by Cushman & Wakefield indicates that chief executives around the country take these claims seriously. For the second consecutive year, the executives named the Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston areas as the most likely to show improving business conditions over the coming year. San Antonio came in third. Dallas has regained all the jobs it lost in the economic downturn and, according to a Salomon Brothers real estate report, could grow faster than the nation, adding as many as 35,000 to 40,000 jobs annually. Houston is also adding jobs as its petrochemical business booms.
 
 
Lone Star Attractions
 
The Corporate Yen for Wide Open Spaces
The Dallas area is no longer the domain of the wildcat developers who, with nearly unlimited financing from savings and loans, compounded the glut of office space as they spoke of how the local economy was too diversified to suffer. Now, says the Salomon Brothers report, Dallas is one of the nation's largest cities with no major speculative office buildings under construction.
Any projects underway in Dallas today are being built by their future users. Dallas's low costs have attracted major corporations trying to cut their own expenses. Large, readily available tracts of land, low living costs and building costs and modern infrastructure have drawn giants like J. C. Penney, GTE, MCI Communications and Exxon to move in their offices and even headquarters. Many are choosing the suburbs. Exxon is moving its headquarters and GTE is bringing about 4,000 employees to Las Colinas, a huge development between downtown Dallas and the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport.
The office vacancy rate has fallen steadily for three years, from about 33 percent to 26.9 percent, according to the Office Network, a real estate market research association. The cost of leasing prime space has been rising. Las Colinas now charges $13 to $16 a square foot per month, up 20 percent from only two years ago. In Plano, a northern suburb, the best office space costs $11 to $13 per square foot. In midtown Manhattan, which Exxon is leaving, office leases run about $40. Buyers of Dallas buildings often come from other states, mainly New York, but also from Canada and Europe. Sales are rising. Marcus & Millichap, a regional real estate broker, found that investors purchased 209 office, retail, industrial and apartment properties in Dallas County in 1989, compared with 146 in 1988 and 142 in 1987.
Still, Mr. Staubach warns that Dallas can't count on the same good fortune as New York. ''There are a lot of great opportunities here, but we have a lot of land here and if you get supply and demand out of whack you can get into trouble,'' he said. ''I don't think its going to be as dramatic as New York's turnaround in the late 1970's, but you will find a lot of great opportunities to invest.''
 
 
Houston's Rebound
 
The Best Little Mergers in Texas
Houston became the nationally recognized home of the empty, unfinished, see-through office building after oil prices plunged and its economy collapsed. Now, as the energy companies recover, the city is adding jobs and filling some of its excess office space.
Even though Houston stopped building offices about five years ago, it had more space available at the end of 1989 than any cities except Los Angeles and New York. With a vacancy rate of 27.5 percent, Houston has 39.8 million square feet empty, the equivalent of almost 18 Empire State Buildings. But there were 42.9 million square feet vacant in 1988 and 47.1 million in 1987.
The improving market has been aided by the recent consolidation of the oil and gas companies concentrated in the city. International engineering companies, like Bechtel Group Inc. and the Fluor Corporation, also are expanding into Houston. Over the past two years, according to the Houston Chamber of Commerce, the area gained 110,000 jobs.
Institutional investors and foreigners are expected to keep pouring money into Houston because it still costs less to buy office space there than to build it. Last year, according to Coldwell Banker, the real estate brokerage, about ten percent of the city's 1,300 office buildings changed hands. Buyers, mostly from New York, Chicago and overseas, put up $1.37 billion for 129 Houston office buildings with 21.7 million square feet. Pension funds have been the biggest buyers. But the largest single deal was the $400 million purchase of the Houston Center office project by the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago. Said Neil G. Bluhm, the president of JMB, ''The Houston market has turned around.''
 
 
 
THE TALLEST STORIES IN TEXAS
In Texas, the building boom may be dormant, but the announcement boom is roaring again. In Dallas and Houston, builders are buying land and proposing projects that, so far, exist only as press releases and architect's models.
In Houston, some projects announced years ago are going through a new stage of promotional recycling. Last month, the wealthy oilman George Mitchell announced plans for Texas's tallest building, on a block downtown now used for parking. The Woodlands Corporation, a unit of his Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, bought the block for about $25 million. Mr. Mitchell wants to build as high as 82 stories, taking the state's high-rise title from the 75-story Texas Commerce tower down the street.
In the early 1980's, the Century Development Corporation also planned to build the state's tallest building, also 82 stories high, on the site. But Century's other investments included a Texas savings and loan that went into receivership. Century ended up in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Mr. Mitchell, it appears, is undeterred. His company is willing to spend as much as $300 million to prove that Texas-sized building can again match Texas-sized boasts.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Little Help From the Group of Seven

 BODY:
After the meeting in Paris a week ago of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, central banks in Japan, the United States and Europe sold dollars to support the weak Japanese yen. But the intervention had little impact because the Group of Seven seemed only lukewarm in its concern. By week's end, the dollar had risen against the yen and fallen against the West German mark.
It was thin trading before the Passover and Easter holidays and unfounded rumors that the credit rating of a money-center bank in New York would be lowered that helped pull the dollar down against the mark. If the dollar does not rally in trading this week, it could be pushed toward its lows of the year, just below 1.66 marks to the dollar.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Europe's Hot Place to Bet on Stocks

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
First it was Austria and then West Germany. Norway got some notice. Now it's springtime in Paris.
The Paris Bourse is the hot market of the moment, lifted to record highs by foreign investors looking for a new place to bet their money. In the last six trading days the CAC-40 has set five new highs, ending the shortened Easter Week Thursday at 2116.66, up 17 percent since its 1990 low on Feb. 23. 
Japanese fleeing a devastated Tokyo market have been picking up CGE, Lafarge, Saint Gobain, Suez and other stocks in the CAC-40, one of the markets two main indexes. Investors who have taken profits in West Germany, as its market slipped in the last two weeks from its record highs, have also been buying up the French blue chips.
But the runup has been so quick that the caution light is flashing. Investors with nice gains should be looking for profits. So those who missed the rally should wait until the market consolidates and retreats.
''I would tend to think it went too quickly,'' said Pascal Viorery of Bertrand Michel Securities Inc. in New York, a firm specializing in French equities.
''We think the potential is for another 5 percent from the present level,'' added Ricaldo Zavala, president of the international department at Magnin S.A. in Paris. ''But people with no position should wait for a setback.''
The French market had been poised for a rally, although it was down as much 10 percent for the year in February. A successful economic program, including lower wage settlements and a tough interest-rate policy, has been holding inflation at around 3 percent. More important, it has all but eliminated the inflation differential between France and West Germany, which had been as high as 4 percentage points. Economic growth this year is expected to be in the 3-percent range, and the franc, recently one of Europe's soft currencies, is challenging the mark in the European Monetary System.
But it was not until spring, when the West German and Austrian markets became too expensive, that investors began to take more notice of France's good economic numbers. The Bank of France also helped with a quarter-point cut in its key interest rate in the first week of April.
But this means the runup could be fragile, especially if there is another rush of euphoria when the two Germanys settle on the currency exchange rate for monetary union. Another rise in West German interest rates could also hurt because the French would likely follow to protect the franc.
''The reasons for the rise are O.K.,'' said Roelfien Kuypers of UBS Securities in New York. ''But they are not very strong. Many people are just tired of West Germany and wanted a new market.''
The CAC-40 blue chips get most of the attention from foreign investors, in part because they are the easiest to follow from afar. But because of that they are less of a bargain and harder to pick. Peugeot, for example, leaves analysts divided. Prudential-Bache has a ''buy'' recommendation on the stock, which closed at 919 francs Thursday, but said it would not chase it above the 830 level. UBS thinks it is still a good choice among European auto stocks, in part because the firm has downgraded Volkswagen to a ''sell'' due to its large exposure in Brazil. Economic reform there has brought the economy - and car sales - to a standstill, and should dent VW's earnings.
LVMH, the world's largest luxury-goods manufacturer that combines Luis Vuitton leather goods with Moet and Hennessey's wines and spirits, could be a high-priced bargain for a while, Mr. Zavala said. But Mr. Viorery thinks it is too speculative.
The company's earnings were up 46 percent in 1989, despite the bitter boardroom battle pitting Bernard Arnault, the chairman, against Henry Racamier, the head of the Louis Vuitton family. But that fight could reach a climax in two weeks, when a French court rules on contested 1987 warrants that helped Mr. Arnault gain control of LVMH.
A win for Mr. Arnault could lead to Mr. Racamier's removal. A loss could open another fight for control, pushing up the stock, which closed at 4,920 francs Thursday.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Free Markets Can't Control Pollution

BYLINE: By BARRY COMMONER; Barry Commoner, director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, is author of ''Making Peace With the Planet.''

 BODY:
Over the last 20 years, the managers of American industry have gradually become accustomed to the demands of environmental regulation.
Apart from paperwork, the chief requirement has been the installation, wherever possible, of control devices that trap or destroy pollutants that would otherwise enter the environment: the catalytic converters attached to vehicle exhaust systems to remove carbon monoxide, or the scrubbers installed in power plants to trap sulfur dioxide. The Environmental Protection Agency has relied on such devices to achieve the reduction in pollution mandated by law. 
It is now evident that this ''command and control'' strategy has failed. For example, the E.P.A. expected the prescribed automobile exhaust controls to reduce annual carbon monoxide emissions by 80 percent and nitrogen oxides by 70 percent between 1975 and 1985. But in that period carbon monoxide emissions fell only 19 percent and nitrogen oxides increased 4 percent. The trends in other standard air pollutants are similar.
Yet, annual emissions of lead into the air have fallen 94 percent since 1975, suggesting that there are right and wrong ways of reducing pollution. The very few succeses - lead, DDT, PCB's, strontium 90 are examples - tell us what works. In each case, substantial improvement was achieved not by tacking a control device onto the process that generates the pollutant, but by eliminating the pollutant from the production process itself.
Pollution prevention calls for replacing the production technologies that now assault the environment with processes that are inherently free of pollutants. Such technologies, which are both ecologically and - in the long term - economically sound, exist. If farmers would shift to organic agriculture, the rising tide of agricultural chemicals that now pollute water supplies would be reversed, and food would be freed of pesticide-derived carcinogens. If automobiles were powered by stratified-charge engines, which sharply reduce nitrogen oxide emissions, the urban pall of photochemical smog and ozone - which is triggered by nitrogen oxides - would be lifted. If electricity was produced by photovoltaic cells, directly from sunlight, the air could be freed of the noxious pollutants generated by conventional power plants. If brewers were forbidden to put plastic nooses on six-packs of beer; if McDonalds rediscovered the paper plate; if the use of plastics was limited to those products for which they are essential, we could push back the petrochemical industry's toxic invasion of the environment.
Pollution prevention has been adopted as E.P.A. policy. An announcement in the Jan. 19, 1989, Federal Register acknowledges that the control strategy has failed, and asserts that ''today's notice commits E.P.A. to a preventive program to reduce or eliminate the generation of potentially harmful pollutants.'' But, despite this ringing declaration, the Bush Administration's environmental strategy is a cartoon version of what pollution prevention is not. In the Clean Air bill, which just passed the Senate, Mr. Bush calls for a market in pollutants that will allow some companies to sell their right to pollute and others to buy it. But a market cannot operate unless provided with what it is supposed to exchange - in this case, pollutants. Mr. Bush's proposal not only fails to prevent pollution, but actually requires it.
The conflict between pollution prevention and the free market raises a basic, long-avoided question: To what extent should the choice of production technologies be governed - as it is now - by private, generally short-term, profit-maximizing responses to market forces, and to what extent by long-term social concerns like environmental quality? Our ability to resolve the environmental crisis depends on our willingness to debate and, before long, to answer this crucial question.

HEADLINE: REDOING EUROPE;
Part of the Problem Is Too Many Solutions

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THE end of the division of Europe and the waning of Soviet power have made the Western allies feel strangely insecure. Until a few months ago, the East-West confrontation insured order and stability. Now, with all the European pieces suddenly out of place, the allies are in a tizzy over how to reassemble them.
NATO is talking about assuming a new political role, the European Community is being invited to assume security responsibilities and the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe is being promoted as the embryo of a new pan-European organization. Washington, London, Paris and Bonn are all anxious for new structures. Yet to every new suggestion, there is also an objection.
Gradually, though, the right questions are being asked: What role will the United States play in Europe? Will NATO still be needed if the Soviet threat is perceived to disappear? Can the Warsaw Pact transform itself into a democratic alliance? Will the European Community become the new pillar of regional stability? 
The urgent need to shape the new Europe is also bringing a rush of high-level meetings. On Friday in Bermuda, President Bush met Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and this week he meets President Francois Mitterrand of France in Florida. NATO foreign ministers are to meet in Brussels after Easter, while European Community leaders plan a special summit meeting in Dublin on April 28.
Yet with so many premises of the old order no longer valid, ranging from the division of Germany and Soviet control over Eastern Europe to United States domination of NATO, the West is still struggling to find ways of filling the vacuum. Having been caught off guard by the collapse of the Soviet empire, it seems like a nervous trapeze artist, reluctant to let go of the past.
''Historical change is happening in a way it was not meant to happen,'' said an American defense expert at NATO headquarters in Brussels. ''Instead of a slow, drawn-out process, it has happened precipitously. It's natural for people to want a return to order and predictability.''
 
'An Archaic Anachronism'
The 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization is understandably wary of proclaiming the end of the cold war. To do so would be to encourage already-inevitable military cuts and to question its very reason for existence. It still talks of Soviet military superiority and it has yet to recognize that last year's dispute about the modernization of short-range nuclear missiles is now irrelevant: stationed in West Germany, they are pointed at East Germany.
''I can well understand the depression with which the civil and military alliance officials must contemplate the prospect of perestroika within NATO,'' Sir Michael Howard, president of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, noted last month. ''But the fact must be faced that a structure created to meet the dangers of the 1950's is in serious danger of becoming an archaic anachronism.''
NATO still retains two essential functions. First of all, it guarantees that United States troops remain in Europe. Even France, which does not belong to the alliance's integrated military command, thinks this is desirable. American troop strength and defense spending in Europe are expected to fall sharply in the coming years, but the Bush Administration's European policy still revolves around NATO.
The alliance also helps anchor Germany to the West and, in a sense, temper its new power. The allies rejected Moscow's earlier call for German neutrality and, last week, dismissed its new idea of German membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Today, many European countries see ''control'' of Germany as one of NATO's new functions. Britain even thinks German unification is reason enough for France to return to full membership in the alliance.
Aware that it must redefine itself, the alliance is already contemplating a new political role, not only in such logical areas as disarmament in the conventional arms talks in Vienna, but also on such broader questions as drugs, terrorism, economic stability and environmental protection. And when the terms of German unification are worked out in the so-called Two-Plus-Four talks, involving the two Germanys plus the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France, NATO wants the last word.
But while 11 of the 12 members of the European Community are also members of NATO, the two groups are quietly competing for leadership. Convinced that its economic success helped inspire the revolution in Eastern Europe, the community believes it should serve as the pivot of the new Europe. It has not, however, opened its doors to the emerging democracies, offering association agreements and economic assistance rather than the chance to join their exclusive club.
An old idea that the community assume a security role has also resurfaced here. President Mitterrand has spoken of the need for ''a European axis to defense.'' Lord Carrington of Britain, a former NATO secretary-general, has suggested the community look after its own defense. Several governments favor strengthening the Western European Union, a long-dormant nine-nation alliance. Others propose creation of a European caucus within NATO.
The unspoken focus of this debate is whether the United States should play a smaller - or at least a different - role in Europe. European governments still want the protection of Washington's defense shield. But while in the past, they accepted the United States as the dominant European power, today they want to be treated more as equals.
 
Shifting Loyalties
On political questions, major European governments no longer tolerate the notion of Washington and Moscow deciding their future without them. And in economic matters, the community, which is destined to become a single market of 320 million people with a $4.3 trillion gross product after 1992, no longer feels dominated by the United States and Japan. But the changing trans-Atlantic relationship is also bringing complications: London and Paris are none too pleased to see Washington treating Bonn (or soon Berlin) as its main European interlocutor.
Almost forgotten in recent weeks has been Eastern Europe. Because neither NATO nor the European Community has found a way of accommodating countries once held together by the Warsaw Pact and the economic pact known as Comecon, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe has emerged from anonymity. Moscow suddenly imagines it becoming a European umbrella organization, Paris sees it as a counterbalance to NATO, and London hopes it might slow the community's own march toward political union.
The United States, however, is skeptical. President Bush has agreed to attend a summit meeting of the security conference this fall if a conventional arms reduction treaty is ready for signature, but American officials believe the group is too large a forum to play a security role in Europe. And, while the organization has promoted human rights, it has neither a charter nor a headquarters. In its present form at least, it seems poorly equipped to deal with the problems that may emerge in the new Europe, above all borders and nationalities.
Having seen its principal strategic objectives achieved on the streets of Leipzig and Prague rather than in the negotiating rooms of Vienna and Geneva, the alliance is now swimming in plans and blueprints that promise stability. ''But the future still looks foggy,'' said an American defense expert at NATO headquarters in Brussels. ''There has been this tremendous historical earthquake and it still hasn't been absorbed properly.''
