PUB-DATE: April 15, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 4, Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1136 words

HEADLINE: For Youths On the Edge of Trouble

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

 BODY:
A GROUP of youngsters, from 16 to 21 years old, will take part in a weeklong job-training program this month that leads to a one-day job fair with potential employers. What is unusual about these youngsters is that they all have been involved with the juvenile-justice system.
''There have been signs of trouble with these kids,'' said Karen Bonaparte, executive director of the Yonkers Rehabilitation Center. ''Many of them never had jobs or even gave any thought to their employment options. We want to get these kids before what has happened to them in the past becomes a pattern or the only option for their future.'' 
The job training program, entitled Consortium for Youth, is one of 11 in Westchester being supported as state Special Delinquency Prevention Programs. Each of these private agency programs receives part of its financing from New York State. For the last eight years, New York State has set money aside for delinquency prevention efforts selected and administered by county Youth Bureaus in the state.
Westchester will receive $502,069 for these programs this year, a figure determined by the number of young people living in the county.
 
Demonstrated Risks
Of the 285,000 people in Westchester under the age of 21, the Special Delinquency Prevention Programs target 2,500 of them as possibly in need of help. They are not necessarily juvenile delinquents but ''are subject to variables that could lead to delinquency,'' said Dr. Toni Collarini, executive director of the Westchester County Youth Bureau.
''The targeted youngsters have either been involved with the juvenile or criminal justice systems, or the mental health or social service systems,'' she said. ''They have demonstrated a risk of dropping out of school, or being abused, neglected or unemployed.''
Dr. Collarini points out that at any given time about 100 minors are inmates at the county penitentiary. While noting that this is a narrow part of the county's youth population, she said ''it is going to cost more to incarcerate a youngster or provide residential care at a state-run facility after antisocial behavior than it is to try and prevent that behavior from ever happening.''
State guidelines specify that any program receiving funds must be a ''nonrecreational intervention'' effort, Dr. Collarini said. That means they must provide either counseling, tutorial help, remedial education, employment readiness, nonfinancial family support or parenting education.
 
'Kids Sometimes Get Lost'
One local program receiving $28,000 this year is Project Intercept, a Mount Vernon effort sponsored by the Westchester Jewish Community Services that has been part of the state program for six years.
Project Intercept tries to identify children between kindergarten and fifth grade who are having problems in school. About 60 children a year are referred to the program by the school, other participants or the Department of Social Services.
Program officials then meet with the child's family to ''focus on the learning problems and how they manifest themselves,'' said Dorothy Fox, the program's coordinator.
A tutor is then provided at the school to work with the child. That tutor also becomes a ''liaison,'' as Ms. Fox put it, between the school and Project Intercept. ''Kids sometimes get lost in the system,'' she explained.
''We have to help them obtain from the school system what they need in order to learn how to read,'' she said. ''Our goal is to get the family to respond to and understand what happens with their child.''
Another of the delinquency programs dealing with education is Challenge to Education, sponsored by Student Advocacy Inc., a countywide nonprofit agency that tries to insure that every child receives an education.
Failure and Anger
Kathleen Peters Durrigan, the executive director of Student Advocacy, said that half of the students suspended for disciplinary problems have undetected handicaps or learning disabilities.
''For a learning disabled child who can't read before going to school, the parents may think that child is not bright enough,'' she said. ''In school, the kid tries but still can't read and they then begin to internalize their anger. By the eighth or ninth grade, you get an angry kid who is going to strike out against the system and might end up suspended.''
Challenge to Education will receive $47,000 in state money this year. Program officials work with both the parents and schools and sometimes do a classroom observation of the child to get a ''better picture of the child's best interest and what they are entitled to by law,'' Ms. Durrigan said. ''We're an advocate on behalf of the student.''
The program might, for example, seek special education or alterntive programs for the student. If the youngster has already dropped out of school, it might try to help him re-enter the educational system, which one legally can do up until the age of 21.
 
Pooling Resources
The Consortium for Youth Program started in January of 1989 and was created as a direct result of the Special Delinquency Prevention Programs. In the process of applying for state aid, 11 agencies came together and decided to pool their resources in the job-training program coordinated by the Yonkers Rehabilitation Center, a private nonprofit corporation. The state is providing the consortium with $28,000 this year to help 40 youngsters a year from lower Westchester.
''Our primary goal is to take these kids, bring them into the mainstream and prepare them for the world of work,'' said Ms. Bonaparte, the center's executive director. ''The second goal is social. We want to improve the youngsters' self-esteem and make them look at themselves as participating members of the community. We want them to see what options are available to them.''
Participants who complete the job training cycle are then helped with job placement.
 
Hard to Measure
Among other agencies receiving the state funds are the Urban League of Westchester, Family Services of Westchester and the Youth Shelter Program of Westchester.
At the end of the year, the County Youth Bureau evaluates each program ''depending on what they're trying to accomplish,'' Dr. Collarini said. ''Because we're talking about prevention, that's a hard thing to measure.'' The evaluation determines eligibility for continued funding.
Dr. Collarini hopes that eventually the programs can be expanded to help young people as they are released from the county penitentiary.
''Every time we lose a young person, we lose a resource for the future,'' she said. ''In a time of stress for kids with problems like single-parent families and substance abuse, more pressure is put on the schools. But the schools can't do it all. These programs provide extra support to high-risk youngsters.''

 April 15, 1990, Sunday, National Edition

LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Developer's Collapse Shocks Florida Homeowners

BYLINE: By PAUL BLYTHE

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
The financial and legal problems of the General Development Corporation, one of Florida's largest home builders, have enveloped home owners in Florida and land purchasers across the country in uncertainty over the future of their investments.
The company filed for bankruptcy on April 6, a month after pleading guilty to charges of fraud in its sales practices.
Since 1955, General Development has built nine communities in the state, mostly through central Florida and bearing names such as Port St. Lucie and Port Charlotte. The developments, with a total of 220,000 residents in 38,000 dwellings, comprise town houses and single-family dwellings ranging in price from $40,000 to $128,000.
Company officials say the intent of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing is to give it time to reorganize and to find financing to meet its short-term cash needs so that it can continue its long-term operations. 
But lawyers for the customers who have legal claims against the company say the filing casts doubt about the company's ability to pay on those claims.
Last Monday, Judge A. Jay Cristol rejected a company proposal to leave 70,000 lot owners without recompense and called for a new hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court. Lawyers for litigants against the company expect a complicated legal wrangle to unfold.
''It's going to be utter chaos,'' said Richard Joel, an Oradell, N.J., lawyer who represents 4,000 home customers from the Northeast in a civil suit filed against the company in Federal Court in Newark. ''It's such a complicated picture because no one knows if G.D.C.'s liabilities exceed their assets. The only thing for sure is no money is safe money at this time.'' General Development officials declined to comment. Like other national land-sale and development companies, General Development used a two-stage sales operation. First it sold people undeveloped lots, paid for over a period of 10.5 years. The second step was to persuade those who completed the payments to use their vacant lots as down payments for building a home on a lot in the location where the company was building at the time.
Andres Rivero, the assistant United States Attorney handling the case, has said in court that G.D.C. targeted immigrants, minorities and blue-collar workers - mostly first-time buyers unfamiliar with such transactions. Potential buyers were offered a trip to Florida to visit G.D.C. communities but had no chance on tightly controlled visits to compare its sales offering with those of competitive home builders, court records indicate.
The crime in all this, Mr. Rivero said in court, was that the appraisals offered visitors were from people who worked under contract to G.D.C. and whose figures were up to 40 percent higher than those for similar houses sold by local competitors. Undeveloped lots also often sold at 10 times the fair market value of the land, Mr. Rivero said. And those contracts were such that G.D.C. retained control of the deeds until the final payment was made. Of the 15,000 customers who bought lots in 1988, about 60 percent canceled their contracts. And in most of those cases, a 1988 G.D.C. annual report said, the company was able to retain those properties and payments without foreclosure costs.
It usually was not until people tried to sell their homes or refinance their mortgages that they realized they had been cheated, said Doug Lyons, a Miami lawyer who represented 107 homeowners in lawsuits that G.D.C. settled in January. Such realizations led to civil suits and, ultimately, the two-year Federal investigation that resulted in an indictment on March 16 against the company on 16 counts of mail fraud and conspiracy to transport people over state lines for the purpose of fraud.
The same day the indictment was unsealed, the company agreed to a plea bargain in which it and its top two executives, David Brown, its chairman, and Robert Ehrling, its president, would plead guilty to one criminal charge, pay a $500,000 fine, set up a restitution plan and enact reforms outlined in a consent decree.
Among the reforms were promises to dismiss employees involved in the deceptive practices and to permit home buyers to cancel a deal within 10 days if an independent appraisal shows the home price to be more than 7.5 percent higher than the estimated market value. Since then, eight executives have left the company, including Mr. Brown and Mr. Ehrling, who could each be sentenced to five years in prison and fined $250,000 for their guilty pleas.
They were replaced by Charles Simons, who worked at Eastern Airlines for 41 years before he retired in 1981 as its chief financial officer and joined G.D.C.'s board of directors in 1985 when the company went public. He will serve as interim chairman.
The restitution plan calls for the company to repay 9,600 customers who bought homes between Jan. 1, 1983, and Dec. 31, 1989. The plan requires a minimum payment of $12.5 million over five years and as much as $100 million over 25 years.
How the bankruptcy filing will affect the restitution plan is yet unclear, but Federal Judge Lenore Nesbitt, who is presiding over the criminal case, has said she could order G.D.C. to sell its assets to pay claimants. She will decide whether to accept the plan and the guilty pleas at a May 22 sentencing.
Mr. Lyons, who represents the 107 homeowners who reached settlements with G.D.C., speculated that the 9,600 homeowners covered in the plea bargain restitution plan would be considered secured creditors, which would put them on an equal footing with banks and mortgage companies in collecting from G.D.C.
That's better than the status of perhaps as many as 70,000 lot buyers whom Mr. Lyons also represents in two class-action suits. In the first of these, filed in 1985, the plaintiffs contend they should be paid damages or given new lots because the lots they bought were delivered late due to unfinished roads and sewer systems.
The other suit, filed in 1987, claims lot buyers who cancel contracts should be refunded amounts over 15 percent of the principal instead of amounts over 52 percent of the principal, which G.D.C. is currently paying.
These plaintiffs and the homeowners represented by Mr. Joel in Newark could receive nothing for their claims as a result of G.D.C.'s bankruptcy filing, Mr. Lyons said. Because these suits have not been settled, the clients could become unsecured creditors who would be paid only after the lawyers and secured creditors were paid. The developer's financial problem, which the company claims is one of liquidity, has resulted partially from its legal problems. ''The fraud charges have made it increasingly more difficult to collect payments-receivable from customers,'' said Nelly Medel, the company spokesman.
But she said the company's financial crises also stem from a complex mixture of recent economic events, including the collapse of South Florida savings-and-loan institutions that G.D.C. dealt with and the collapse of the junk-bond market, where company bonds were traded.
''You get into trouble when you pledge the receivable money you expect from tomorrow's contracts to pay for yesterday's debts,'' Mr. Lyons said. ''It's a pretty tangled web, no question about it.''
On April 3, the developer, which has assets of $863 million and liabilities of $834 million, laid off 1,100 employees in a shutdown of its lot sales operations worldwide, according to its bankruptcy petition.
Last Monday, the company also laid off 239 construction workers and stopped all construction of new homes and all development of roads and sewers on home sites, Ms. Medel said.
The company is continuing operation of its community utilties, road repairs, home sales at community site offices, and time-share operations at resorts near Orlando and in east Tennessee. Ms. Medel said it also hopes to resume the selling of lots and the construction of new homes.
''The company has been around so long, we just can't accept ending like this,'' she said. ''Mr. Simons has pledged his all to make this work, and the intent of this filing is to reorganize so the company can continue its operations in the future.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13, Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: THE U.S: STILL ON ITS FEET

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. BESCHLOSS; Michael R. Beschloss is the author of ''Kennedy and Roosevelt: The Uneasy Alliance'' and ''Mayday: Eisenhower, Khrushchev and the U-2 Affair.''

 BODY:

BOUND TO LEAD
The Changing Nature of American Power.
By Joseph S. Nye Jr.
307 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.
No postwar Presidential candidate has ever been defeated for railing against the country's decline. In 1960, John F. Kennedy declared, ''This nation in 1965 will still be the greatest, but will it still be the most powerful? . . . We are falling behind - behind in our schedules, behind in our needs, behind the Russians in our rate of progress.'' In 1970, President Richard Nixon warned against America's becoming a ''pitiful, helpless giant'' and a ''second-rate power.'' In 1980, Ronald Reagan ran for President under the slogan ''Let's Make America Great Again.'' 
Each of these assertions turned out to have its irony. After campaigning on the need to restore United States nuclear superiority, Kennedy, as President, not only discovered that the nation had never lost its predominance, but moved toward the view that world peace would be better served by strategic parity with the Soviet Union. Mr. Nixon was the first postwar President to concede in public that the United States lived in a multipolar world. And the cost of Mr. Reagan's military buildup was the vast budget deficit that undermines American economic influence today.
The Harvard political scientist Samuel P. Huntington has observed that the public discussion of American decline often provides ''better indications of American psychology than of American power.'' Allowing this debate to be trivialized and distorted by emotion ill serves the nation's leaders, especially those who are the gravest offenders. This is why Joseph S. Nye Jr.'s corrective, ''Bound to Lead,'' is welcome.
Mr. Nye, the Ford Foundation Professor of International Security at Harvard, differs with Paul Kennedy's contention in ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' that the United States shows the symptoms of imperial exhaustion, like Philip II's Spain and Nicholas II's Russia. Mr. Nye allows that since the end of World War II, the American share of global product has slipped from roughly one-third to roughly one-fifth. But he calls this a ''return to normal'' from an artificial dominance over countries that had been invaded and bombed and needed to rebuild. He adds that the figure has remained stable since the early 1970's. Arguing against the thesis of military overcommitment, he notes that the ratio of the United States' defense burden to its share of world product is actually lower now than in the 1950's.
Among the countries of the world, he writes, only the United States is predominant in all of the traditional arsenals of power - territory and population, military might, economic vitality, technology. The country profits as well from less tangible resources, such as the international appeal of its culture and language; its attractiveness and openness to immigrants, foreign students and investors; its influence as a part of multinational institutions and alliances.
Are there any immediate challengers? Not the Soviet Union, with its economic, technological, political and ideological afflictions. Not China, with its unpredictable politics and still-backward economy. Not Japan, unless a very different political leadership is allowed to divert that country's immense technological and economic power into the building of a world-class military force. Not Europe, unless the one-market economic system that is to be established in 1992 leads to the much more difficult achievement of political integration. (Germany's movement toward reunification occurred too late for Mr. Nye to consider it as a separate case, but presumably that development has not caused him to alter his overall conclusions.) The end of the cold war, the spread of technology, rising nationalism in weak states and other fundamental changes are reshuffling the cards of world power. Not surprisingly, Mr. Nye proposes that the United States exercise leadership by restoring its domestic economic strength, preserving the ideal of an open world economy (without harming long-term American interests), helping to devise a new global balance of military power and making greater use of multinational organizations to overcome international problems like drugs, AIDS and global warming.
Displaying the sensible use of history that informs his book, Mr. Nye notes the cautionary lesson of the 19th century and the 1930's: ''If the strongest state does not lead, the prospects for instability increase.'' But the United States may be unable to mobilize its resources fully in order to provide that leadership. Mr. Nye cites the disappointing recent record of American productivity, savings, education, research and development. He also laments the diffusion of domestic political power - reflected in the weakness of political parties and the strength of interest groups, among other elements. Such factors make more difficult the coherent and expeditious decision making that would help to maximize the nation's influence in the world.
This places the burden on whoever is President to have the courage and political skill to lead - to warn Congress and the people against protectionism, sharp restrictions on immigration and foreign aid, and other measures that would reduce American global power.
Mr. Nye is not indifferent to who is President. He has in the past provided foreign policy advice to Democratic candidates, including Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 campaign. If a Democrat reaches the White House in the not-too-distant future, Mr. Nye may well be at his side, urging the prescriptions outlined in this volume.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Freeport, Me.;
House Prices Take a Tumble

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
WHEN a homeowner here decided to sell her waterfront house a year ago, two appraisers encouraged her to ask $269,500. Last month she accepted an offer based on her most recent asking price, $169,000.
Although the price reduction on most properties has not been as large as in her case, houses in today's sluggish market are being discounted throughout Maine. 
For example, a three-bedroom Cape Cod-style house with 200 feet of frontage on Quahog Bay in Harpswell that listed for $375,000 in June 1989 was reduced after six months to $339,000 and again recently to $299,000; a three-bedroom house in a small subdivision in Freeport was listed a year ago at $230,000 and recently was reduced to $219,000, and a four-bedroom farmhouse farther north, in Poland, was listed at $170,000 a year ago and is now $133,500.
''Three, four years ago people could put whatever price on it and get it,'' said Linda Coron, a broker in Brunswick who listed the Harpswell house. ''Now, houses are being more realistically priced.''
This town 20 miles north of Portland has so far been spared the worst of the decline in residential property values, but its commercial properties - despite a boom that began in 1980 - are starting to feel the pinch. Three commercial buildings will be going on the block this month.
Valerie Lamont, director of the Institute for Real Estate Research and Education at the University of Southern Maine in Portland, said the selling prices of houses in Maine appreciated 6 percent in 1989, compared with 11 and 12 percent in 1987 and 1988. In York County, however, which led the state in property appreciation from 1986 to 1988, the average selling price dropped by 2.5 percent in 1989.
The increases occurred as more and more people moved to Maine from southern New England and New York, where they sold houses for much more than they were going to pay for a new house in Maine. The newcomers came in with a lot of cash and often ended up bidding against one another, which sometimes resulted in houses' selling for more than the asking prices. But as the economy cooled and fewer newcomers came, the business slumped last year.
''People in Maine are not cash heavy,'' said Ms. Lamont. ''We can't sustain those high appreciations. We've burned ourselves out.''
Not only are people reducing their prices, Ms. Lamont said, but they are also paying closing costs and points. And Ms. Coron said she is seeing more sellers offering to finance at least part of the sale price.

HEADLINE: Retired Executives Return as Volunteers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
A FEW years ago, when Thomas R. Hodge retired from American Telephone and Telegraph, the former division manager was told that as a consultant his advice would be worth $1,000 a day plus expenses, to executives anxious to tap his experience.
Today, Mr. Hodge is making full use of his professional talents. But as a member of the Retired Executives and Professionals group, he receives no fee at all for his consulting.
The retired executives program was started two-and-a-half years ago by a half-dozen retired executives and professionals, who wanted to use their time constructively to help nonprofit agencies. It has grown into an organization of about 75 retired and semi-retired members, 60 to 85 years old, who serve 47 of Westchester's nonprofit and government agencies. 
Retired Executives and Professionals is a division of the Westchester Retired Senior Volunteer Program, and members provide their managerial know-how on a full-time or part-time basis to the organization without charge.
 
Diverse Projects Undertaken
''It's a win-win situation,'' emphasized Mr. Hodge, who is 64. ''There are a lot of people in Westchester who have made enough money in satisfying careers who are now willing to use their skills and experience to give a hand to the agencies that can't afford all the managerial assistance they need.''
The group's volunteers, who work either alone or in teams, have taken on diverse projects, from an individual member developing a financial plan for a grass-roots agency, to monthly think-tank meetings that involve the entire membership in brainstorming sessions with specific agencies to come up with ideas for solving specific problems.
A few weeks ago, the members held a think-tank session that represented a departure for the group, said Mr. Hodge, who coordinates these sessions, because it was with a government agency.
 
How It Came About
''The way it came about was that the solid-waste division of the Westchester County Department of Public Works asked us to hold the meeting,'' he said. ''As far as I know, we are the first group of our kind to be working with a government agency. The solid waste division is doing work of real value to all of Westchester, so we were very glad to accommodate them.''
The first step involved the executive committee of the group listening to a presentation by James J. Hogan, the division's director of resources. ''The presentation was very informative and challenging,'' Mr. Hodge said. ''Since many of our own members have specifically expressed a desire to work with government, we were eager to see if we could be effective in this area.''
Mr. Hogan said he first heard about the volunteer program at a recycling exposition. ''Dick Schaab, of the Westchester County Association, mentioned the terrific job they were doing with the not-for-profits,'' he recalled. ''And it seemed to me that they might be good for us.
 
Tackling the Paper Waste
Mr. Hogan said it seemed logical that former busines executives could help his agency confront the problem of business and paper waste.
''The business community generates a tremendous amount of waste computer paper and corrugated paper,'' he explained. ''And even though the county has developed a recycling guide especially for waste office paper, we've been having difficulties in overcoming apathy on the part of business and getting companies to set up recycling programs. We came to the retired executives think-tank for suggestions.''
More recently, a group of the volunteers met with Mr. Hogan to go over the ideas that had been presented during the think-tank session. In addition to Mr. Hodge, there were Thomas Van Raalte, a retired chemical company executive; John Ware, a former industrial-sales manager for the John Wiley publishing company; Howard Cohn, a former editor with McGraw-Hill; and Letty G. Zander, a psychiatric social worker and the former program director of the psychiatric day hospital of White Plains Hospital. Phyllis Hersh, the professional coordinator of the retired executives group, also attended.
''Before I left for the think-tank meeting,'' Mr. Hogan said, ''my boss said, 'It's the Rosetta Stone, and here we have the opportunity to get some keys.' And, indeed, for us it was a fruitful encounter. I was astonished at not only the level of vitality the group exhibited, but of their grasp of recycling as a whole. Their ideas were much broader in scope and much more pragmatic than any we had had.''
 
One Idea Put Into Effect
One idea envisioned placing labeled recycling containers at strategic points around the county, like public parks and beaches. Mr. Hogan said this had already been put into effect. ''We've got in touch with manufacturers of the containers and hope to have them in various places where people congregate as soon as possible.''
The former business executives advised the agency to take tough measures when dealing with business. ''They suggested a carrot-and-stick approach, using more stick than carrot,'' Mr. Hogan said. ''For example, our profit-motive theory, that we could sell business on the idea of making money by recycling paper - especially computer waste paper, which has a high resale value - was immediately shot down.
''Instead, they advised we'd be better off to develop legislation that would mandate business to recycle waste paper. They were telling us that business would have to be forced to comply.'' The retired executives, he said, ''also suggested that we reward companies like the A.T.&T. and Reader's Digest that are already doing a terrific job recycling paper, with public recognition.''
 
Supplying the Know-How
Calling the volunteer group a ''real economic advantage for the county,'' Mr. Hogan said of the members: ''They can supply their know-how to other agencies. Their constructive ideas are already at the top of our priority list. And the price was right. We figured we saved thousand and thousands of dollars in consulting fees.''
Members of Retired Executives and Professionals say that it is the nonprofit agencies that always need more resources than they have access to.
''Although needs vary from agency to agency, they all go beyond money,'' Mr. Ware explained. ''Recently we were asked to set up the books and accounting procedures, starting from scratch, for a new agency of the United Way.'' He added that the volunteers' skills include ''everything from organizational development, financial-systems management through public relations.''
When the Mount Vernon United Tenants Organization received a grant from the county's Department of Social Services, it asked for assistance on how best to allocate the funds. This group began as a grassroots organization several years ago and has grown into a coalition that works to prevent homelessness and to promote tenants' rights.
''Naturally, they are anxious to get the biggest bang out of their bucks,'' Mr. Cohn said. ''They need help with such things as budget procedures, long-term planning and also in beefing up their board. One of our members is working with them to help put the organization on a businesslike basis.''
Mr. Van Raalte, whose job is interviewing prospective Retired Executives and Professionals volunteers, said: ''I'm always struck by the amount of talent lying fallow out there, especially now with more executives taking early retirement. In the retired executives program, they can use some of their time more constructively. What's more, they can avoid the query, 'What are you planning to do today, dear?' - which sent me right out of the door to R.E.P.''
Mrs. Zander is now monitoring assistance to six local health-care agencies.
''My job is interviewing volunteers and placing them in agencies that need them,'' she said. ''My former life included staff training and interviewing, which makes me very comfortable with my assignment.''
Although most of the group's members are male, Mrs. Zander said more retired female executives were surfacing. ''When faced with retirement, women face the same challenges men do,'' she said.
For information about joining Retired Executives and Professionals or about obtaining help from the group, call Sandra A. Rubio or Phyllis Hersh at 948-6069; or visit the group's offices at 470 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains.

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: Slow Growth in Grand Lists Signals Rise in Local Tax

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS Connecticut towns complete their budget preparations, municipal officials say they are facing some of the largest property-tax increases in years. With inflation running at 4 to 5 percent and state aid receding, municipal budgets will have to increase 15 to 25 percent just to maintain existing services, the officials say.
Normally, some of that increase would be taken up by an expansion of the tax base. But grand lists, which include each town's taxable property, have increased an average of only 3.1 percent, and in some towns they have gone down.
''All towns are looking at a combination of tax hikes and spending cuts,'' said the secretary of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, George E. Hill, the Mayor of Mansfield, where the proposed budget would raise taxes 18 percent. ''I've heard of more than 25 municipalities that are already talking about layoffs.'' 
Of 37 towns that responded to a survey by the conference, 9 have budget proposals that would raise taxes 20 percent or more; only three would raise taxes less than 6 percent.
 
Affluent Towns Are Hard Hit
The grand list reflects of the wealth of a town. It includes houses, cars, business equipment, even horses. And because towns rely so heavily on the property tax to pay for local services, the list affects the tax rate. If a town's grand list increases 10 percent in one year, it will bring in 10 percent more revenue without raising the tax rate.
Figures submitted by towns to the State Office of Policy and Management show that grand lists in Connecticut increased an average of 6.1 percent in the 1989 fiscal year and 4.3 percent in fiscal 1990. But for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins July 1, grand lists are up only 3.1 percent.
Some of the more affluent towns are seeing the smallest increases. Redding's grand list is up only 1.6 percent, Norwalk's only 1.4 percent, New Canaan's and Westport's only 0.8 percent each.
Officials say the problem is that people are not building new homes or buying new cars and that businesses are afraid to invest in new equipment because of the uncertain economic climate. The research supervisor for the State Department of Housing, Sandy Bergin, said towns issued 12,607 permits for new housing in 1989, down 35.5 percent from 1988's 19,547, and down almost 60 percent from the 1986 peak of 30,163. ''We're projecting this year will be almost the same as 1989, pretty flat,'' Ms. Bergin said.''And I hope we're wrong.''
An economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, Richard H. Matoon, said his group's quarterly survey has shown declining business confidence.
Business personal property - everything a business owns that is not land or buildings - made up only 11 percent of the property tax base in Connecticut in 1988, $310 million, but that was up 123 percent from five years earlier, and most towns were getting used to significant increases.
Last year at this time, the association's survey showed that 38 percent of Connecticut businesses said they were planning to increase their capital investment in the next 90 days, and 15 percent planned to decrease their spending. In the most recent survey, 26 percent said they planned an increase in capital spending, and 28 percent planned a decrease.
''Over the short term, it doesn't look particularly strong,'' Mr. Matoon said.
Gov. William A. O'Neill has proposed incentives to boost spending on manufacturing equipment, but Mr. Matoon said that might not be enough.
''Companies are not investing because of uncertainty about Connecticut's fiscal situation,'' Mr. Matoon said. ''No one is sure whether Connecticut is the place to be investing.''
But there are other problems facing grand lists. Litchfield's assessor, A. Walter Parsons, said the town is still feeling the effects of a tornado last summer. ''We had some people in town who lost some buildings, and we had to lower their assessments,'' Mr. Parsons said.
 
Lower Assessments Sought
In addition, so many people took advantage of the town's open-space ordinance, which allows tax bills on large tracts of land to be reduced by almost 85 percent, the town lost $5 million in real-estate assessment, he said.
The result has been that Litchfield's grand list declined by 0.2 percent.
The manager of assessment and taxation for the State Office of Policy and Management, Donald W. Zimbowski, said another problem is that as people realize the real-estate market is slowing down, they are going to the local tax-review boards to seek lower assessments.
The problem is so bad, Mr. Zimbowski said, that he had to give Greenwich and Naugatuck an extra year to complete their decennial revaluations, because so many property owners were filing appeals.
''Greenwich had more than 1,600 appeals, and Naugatuck had more than 1,000,'' Mr. Zimbowski said. ''That's a lot more than they could have expected, and there's no way they could get them done in time.''
 
Checking Every Corner
Naugatuck, though, had the largest increase in the state in its grand list, almost 10 percent, thanks in large part to a $13 million investment by Hershey-Peter Paul Inc. in the candy factory it bought in town a couple of years ago from Cadbury Schweppes, said the assessor, Wayne A. McAllister, who was appointed less than a year ago.
''Because I'm new to the job, I've been poking into every corner possible,'' Mr. McAllister said, which has helped turn up some new tax revenues.
''We're trying to be as thorough as possible,'' he said. Next year the town will start a business audit program, he said, to make sure corporations are declaring the full value of personal property.
But most towns are struggling with much smaller increases in their tax base, which means they will face large tax increases, particularly to cover shortfalls in state funding.
Mayor Hill said Mansfield's education budget will go up $1.3 million next year, in large part because of higher teacher salaries that state aid was supposed to help pay for. But the state initially offered only $15,000 more in aid for next year, and after intensive lobbying, it raised that to $118,000, still less than one-tenth what the town needs to cover the increase, Mr. Hill said.
 
Layoffs Ahead
For the last few years, most towns have delayed buying new police cars or fire engines and have put off major repairs, because money has been so tight. But for the fiscal year beginning on July 1, the problem will be even worse, he said.
''Once you've already made those cuts, the only thing you can do is cut programs,'' Mr. Hill said. ''And that means laying off people.''
He said most town officials he has talked with have told him they intend to eliminate one-third of their 1991 budget shortfall with spending cuts and make up the rest with tax hikes.
That has resulted in proposed tax increases like 26 percent in Sprague, 25 percent in Westbrook and Coventry, 24 percent in Bristol and 22 percent in Canton and Clinton.
''I don't know how many of those towns are going to get tax increases like that past their town council or town meeting,'' when the final budgets are adopted next month, Mr. Hill said. ''But towns are in a real bind this year. If they cut services, there's and outcry; and if they raise taxes, there's an outcry.''
''This year, though,it's going to have to be one or the other,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1089 words

HEADLINE: THE CHURCH IS STILL RESTLESS

BYLINE: By MIRIAM DAVIDSON; Miriam Davidson, the author of ''Convictions of the Heart: Jim Corbett and the Sanctuary Movement,'' teaches journalism at the University of Arizona.

 BODY:

LIBERATION THEOLOGY AT THE CROSSROADS
Democracy or Revolution?
By Paul E. Sigmund.
257 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $29.95.
One of the liberation theologians quoted in this book, Father Ignacio Ellacuria, was among the six Jesuit priests massacred by a paramilitary death squad in El Salvador on Nov. 16. ''Liberation Theology at the Crossroads'' is dedicated to Ellacuria, whose death is but one in a long line of political murders of priests and nuns in Latin America over the past 20 years. These deaths make clear the price that church men and women pay when they decide to throw in their lot with the poor and oppressed. 
Liberation theology is a school of Roman Catholic thought that emerged in Latin America in the late 1960's. It teaches that a primary duty of the church must be to promote social and economic justice. In the beginning, writes Paul E. Sigmund, most prominent liberation theologians were overtly Marxist in their beliefs. They saw that the capitalist system had not caused Latin America to develop out of its dependence and poverty. Development had benefited only foreign business interests and the wealthy elites in Central and South America, not the poor majority. For that reason, they believed, revolutionary struggle to overthrow the capitalist system was the only way the suffering people of Latin America could improve their lot.
Twenty years later, after much turmoil and bloodshed, Latin America's poor are no better off. Mr. Sigmund writes that liberation theologians today retain anticapitalism as one of their themes, but increasingly reject armed revolution as the way to change things. He welcomes this move away from Marxism, but he cautions that many liberation theologians seem excessively enamored of the Cuban and Nicaraguan models. Mr. Sigmund, a professor of politics at Princeton University, argues that, through the democratic process, Latin American countries can have a well-fed, healthy and educated population, as well as political freedom and human rights. He seems to believe that a third way - between capitalist exploitation and Marxist totalitarianism - is possible. Yet it is that same ''third way'' that the liberation theologians previously rejected as a lie.
The situation in El Salvador is instructive. For 10 years the United States Government has called the Salvadoran Government a ''fledgling democracy.'' Yet none of the conditions that gave rise to the Marxist insurgency there - the starvation, landlessness and inequality - have been meaningfully addressed, and there has been no fundamental structural change in the rule of a bloodthirsty military dictatorship. Given this, it is not surprising that liberation theologians do not have much faith in the ability of capitalist democracy to reform itself. Father Ellacuria was one of several Central American liberation theologians who advocated revolutionary counterviolence to the poor and oppressed of El Salvador. Although this stance gave the Salvadoran military the excuse they needed to kill him, it is questionable whether he still would be alive had he advocated nonviolence - the Salvadoran Government brooks little dissent, nonviolent or otherwise.
Students of liberation theology will appreciate Mr. Sigmund's evenhanded exposition of the ideas of the liberation theologians, their disagreements with the Vatican and their responses to their North American critics. The general reader, however, will find this book extremely dry and theoretical. It contains little description of the social and political situation in Latin America that gave rise to liberation theology. Mr. Sigmund may also be guilty of one thing for which he criticizes the liberation theologians: not being sufficiently concrete in providing a prescription for a better society. He does admire the Basic Christian Communities movement. He views these small groups of peasants and church workers who discuss the meaning of the Bible in their daily lives as one way the liberation theologians have made specific improvements in the lives of their parishioners.
According to Mr. Sigmund, liberation theologians like Gustavo Gutierrez of Peru have in recent years come to recognize that there are other sources of oppression besides economics - race and sex, to name two. Yet the Latin American liberation theologians have not harshly criticized the Vatican for its stand on birth control and the status of women in the church. It appears that reproductive self-determination would go a long way toward real liberation (especially given the problems of overpopulation in the third world), but this issue has not been addressed by the liberation theologians. The liberation theologians of Latin America, for the most part, do not seem as bent on challenging the Vatican as do some priests from the developed North. As Leonardo Boff of Brazil wrote, ''The church is a reality of Faith that I assume. Theology is a product of reason that I discuss.''
At the end of ''Liberation Theology at the Crossroads,'' Mr. Sigmund ponders the future of liberation theology and argues again for dialogue and democracy. He poses some provocative questions for the liberation theologians. Although it is too late for Father Ellacuria, other liberation theologians will have to consider whether advocating violence begets democracy or only more violence.
 
IS CAPITALISM A SIN?
 The liberation theologians never did spell out in detail the mechanisms through which capitalism causes poverty. They did not resort directly to Marx's explanation - namely the alienation by the capitalist of surplus value. . . . More often the mere existence of large-scale poverty in Latin America was taken to prove that the system is unjust. There must be something wrong with a system that allows the majority of the people to live in squalor and poverty while a small minority enjoys all the luxuries of the modern world. . . .
Instead of directing their wrath at capitalism, the liberation theologians should - and are now beginning to - direct more attention to promoting a genuine participatory democracy that will work to restrain the excesses of economic power, whether capitalist or socialist. They should work to expose the behind-the-scenes manipulation and corruption that characterize both capitalist and socialist governments, and to assure that the voice of the poor is heard . . . rather than simply writing off all existing capitalist systems as structures of sin.
 
From ''Liberation Theology at the Crossroads.''

HEADLINE: Health Insurers Increase Rates For the Elderly

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The cost of private health insurance for the elderly is rising sharply, straining the budgets of millions of people who live on Social Security checks and fueling demands in Congress and the states for tighter regulation of this insurance.
The monthly cost rose at least 20 percent this year for many types of insurance intended to cover the gap between what the Federal Medicare program pays for medical services and what doctors and hospitals actually charge. Some premiums for such ''medigap'' insurance increased more than 50 percent, according to industry surveys and the General Accounting Office.
Critics of the insurance industry in Congress and spokesmen for consumer advocacy groups say many of the increases in medigap rates were exorbitant. But private insurers say they had to raise the rates, in part to pay for catastrophic illnesses that would have been covered under a 1988 law that was repealed in December. 
 
Surge in Spending
The increased costs are also a result of the continuing surge in spending on health care, and in some cases, the failure of insurers to raise rates enough in 1989 to cover higher medical costs, industry spokesmen say.
But many of the elderly, a majority of whom depend primarily on Social Security, say they are hard pressed to pay the extra costs.
''It's outrageous,'' said Mary Enos, a 79-year-old widow in New Bedford, Mass., who lives on ''a little over $500 a month.'' Her Blue Cross premium increased 84 percent to $71.30 a month, from $38.83. The $32.47 medigap increase buried the $18 cost-of-living increase in her Social Security check.
Medigap insurance is currently purchased by about 22 million of the 29 million Americans aged 65 or older.
Among the costs that medigap covers and Medicare does not are the first day in a hospital and all or part of the ''deductible'' that patients pay to doctors before Medicare insurance begins paying. Some medigap policies also cover prescription drugs, added charges by doctors and the cost of a hospital stay that extends beyond the Medicare limit.
 
People Without Coverage
Of the seven million elderly people who do not have medigap insurance, about 3.2 million of them with low incomes are eligible for state Medicaid benefits, but nearly four million rely on Medicare alone.
Because the 1988 law covering catastrophic illnesses was repealed, at least 17 million elderly ''will be doing worse,'' said Thomas Rice, a health economist at the University of North Carolina. They will have to pay higher premiums for medigap insurance, if they can afford it, or go without coverage for catastrophic illnesses and prescription drugs.
On the other hand, about 1.7 million elderly Americans with incomes of $37,000 or more, who would have had to pay an extra $800 each with their Federal taxes under the catastrophic-care law, are faring better now that the law has been repealed. Many of them are fully covered for such illnesses by former employers and do not need such coverage; others among them were reluctant to drop their own insurance when the law took effect, and were essentially paying twice for the same benefits.
 
Increasing Costs
But even people with medigap policies must often pay part of their doctor, hospital and prescription-drug charges, which have been increasing faster than the overall inflation rate.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, a group of 70 mainly nonprofit plans with 8.5 million medigap policyholders, said premiums were up 24 percent on average for 1990 after increasing 8 percent in 1989. The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which sells medigap insurance to three million members of the American Association of Retired Persons, raised its medigap rates by 40 percent on average in 1989 and plans a 17 percent increase in July. Blue Cross-Blue Shield and Prudential are by far the largest medigap insurers.
The General Accounting Office, a research arm of Congress, said the average monthly cost to elderly policyholders is now $69.96, or about $840 a year, compared with $58.52, or $702, in 1989, an increase of 20 percent.
One of the steepest increases was in Massachusetts, where Blue Cross-Blue Shield raised monthly premiums 67 percent to $85.87 for its most widely purchased medigap policy. (Mrs. Enos's $71.30 policy provides fewer benefits.) 'I Was Very Shocked'
In Wisconsin, Frances Hels, 74, a retired executive secretary in Waterford, is also struggling with a medigap increase. ''I was very shocked at the first of the year to get a raise of about $20 a month to $90.33,'' she said. Mrs. Hels, a widow, lives on ''a very small pension and mainly Social Security.''
The G.A.O. said about half the added medigap charges could be attributed to the repeal of the catastrophic-care law.
In Massachusetts, Blue Cross attributed 38 to 41 percent of its increases to the Medicare pullback. Thirty-two percent was for higher health-care costs, especially for prescription drugs, and increased use of health services, said Susan M. Leahy, a Blue Cross spokeswoman. The insurer said it also had to make up for medigap losses in 1989.
In New York, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has just raised monthly medigap rates 29 percent, to $45.15, after two years at $35. John Kelly, a spokesman for Empire Blue Cross, said two-thirds of the increase was to replace benefits in the repealed law.
 
Increases Criticized
Advocates for the elderly and consumers and their supporters in Congress criticized the increases.
''In many instances the increases are far in excess of what can be justified,'' said Representive Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon.
Gail Shearer, manager of policy analysis for Consumers Union, a group that advocates more Federal regulation, said: ''Medigap prices seem to go up whether Medicare benefits expand or contract. Consumers are confused.''
Most states are already revising laws and procedures regulating medigap insurance. Congress is expected to take up several bills this session that would increase Federal supervision of medigap insurance, a $16 billion business. Most states require that insurers must pay out 60 percent of medical-insurance premiums for individual medigap policyholders and 75 percent of the premiums for group medigap policyholders. The remainder may go to marketing and administrative costs, profits and to make up for past losses, commercial insurers say.
Among the bills being prepared or already introduced in Congress are ones that would require public hearings and a review before states approve medigap increases. The bills would also raise the percentages of revenues that must be paid out in benefits and standardize descriptions of competing medigap policies so purchasers can better compare them.
 
Insurance Counseling
A bill sponsored by Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, would help states to establish insurance counseling for the elderly in programs like those operating in California and North Carolina. Other proposals would prohibit selling medigap policies that duplicate each other or overlap. Insurers could be punished if their agents did not check on the existing coverage of elderly consumers and sold them unneeded policies.
''Our feeling is that Congress is going to do something this year,'' said Alan K. Richards, a Washington lawyer with the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurer group, which wants the states to remain in control of insurance regulation.
A stronger Federal regulatory role is supported by both the American Association of Retired Persons, which fought unsuccessfully to preserve the catastrophic-care law last year, and the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare, which helped defeat it.
 
State Requirements
Only a handful of states review requests for medigap rate increases; most rely on the standard requirements governing how much of the premiums must be eventually paid out for medical care. Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, said the payout minimums should be raised to 70 percent and 85 percent.
But Alan P. Spielman, a government-relations director with Blue Cross, said many plans were already paying out 90 percent of medigap premiums.
Earl R. Pomeroy, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, said his group would meet Tuesday to consider changes to make it easier to compare competing medigap policies. Massachusetts, Wisconsin and Minnesota already require standard language and formats.
Seven states have adopted other consumer protection recommendations approved last year by the state commissioners group. Similar rules are under consideration in 30 states.

HEADLINE: Poverty Rate Is Up for the Very Young

BYLINE: By J. C. BARDEN

 BODY:
At a time when poverty is on the decline among all other age groups in the United States, the poverty rate for children under 6 years of age is rising, an analysis of Federal population figures shows.
Nearly one of every four children under 6 in the nation is poor, says a report being released today by a research center at Columbia University. The report cites these reasons: a growing number of single teen-age mothers; a surprising number of young, two-parent families; a growing number of jobs for which the young parents are not qualified, and a shortage of affordable day care for young parents who could get low-paying jobs.
Starting life poor often relegates a child to a lifetime of struggle and poverty, the report said, adding, ''Early childhood experiences contribute to poor children's high rates of school failures, dropout, delinquency, early childbearing and adult poverty.'' 
The research group, the National Center for Children in Poverty, is affiliated with Columbia University's School of Public Health. Its analysis is the first statistical profile devoted exclusively to children under 6 who are living in poverty.
 
Income Support Urged
To break the poverty cycle, the report recommended government income support for all employed parents and assured child support payments for single parents; community child care centers; the expansion of Head Start and other preschool programs to serve all children of low-income families, and the expansion of them to full-day, year-round programs; health insurance coverage for all poor families, and the preparation of poor young adults for employment in more technically demanding jobs.
The report did not suggest where the money for these programs would come from.
Judith E. Jones, director of the center, said in the report that part of the fault was the nation's policy of responding to crises rather than preventing them. ''The concept of a social insurance system for all families and children, which is the foundation of national policy in many industrialized nations, does not guide our thinking or our actions,'' she said.
''We pay welfare costs for teen-age mothers rather than the costs of preventive services, education and decent jobs and wages for them and their partners,'' Ms. Jones said. ''We pay the high costs of neonatal intensive care for infants rather than offering quality low-cost prenatal care for their mothers. It is this crisis orientation that is costly, and while many of our social initiatives do work, only a portion of the families eligible for some services actually receive them.''
 
Report Called a Crucial Step
Paul Smith, director of research for the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group based in Washington, called the report a crucial step in the effort to stem poverty among the nation's youngest poor.
''This takes us beyond the point of knowing we've got a problem, which the Census Bureau told us,'' Mr. Smith said, ''and added information never available that lets us begin to ask what kind of problem it is and what we might consider doing about it.''
In a look at poverty over the last two decades among the very young, the center found that the rate of children under 6 who live under the poverty line grew by about a third, to 23 percent in 1987 from 17 percent in 1968.
The figures were based on unpublished data from the Census Bureau and other sources; 1987 was the last year for which figures were available when the data in the report were analyzed. In 1987 the poverty line was $11,611 for a family of four.
 
Growth Continued in 1988
In interviews, officials at the center said an examination of statistics available since the report was completed shows that this growth continued in 1988, with 5.03 million children under 6 living in poverty as against 4.98 million in 1987, an increase of 1 percent.
Over the last 20 years, the poverty growth rate for children under 6 has been several percentage points higher than that of any other age group, said William Scarbrough, associate director of the center, and dramatically higher than the overall poverty rate.
In the same period, from 1968 to 1987, the overall rate increased by 5.5 percent, to 13.5 percent in 1987, when 32.5 million people lived in poverty.
The breakdown on other age groups living in poverty in 1987 was 19 percent for those 6 through 17, 11 percent for those 18 through 64 and 12 percent for those 65 and over, the report said.
Mr. Scarbrough said census data for 1988 put the number of older children living in poverty, those 6 through 17, at 7.6 million, a drop of 7 percent from the year before.
 
Decline in Poverty Since 1983
Since 1983, when the rate of poor people reached a high level because of a recession and changes in government policies, poverty among all groups has declined, but the drop has been less for children under 6, the report said.
Other major findings in the report, ''A Statistical Profile of Our Poorest Young Citizens,'' include these:
* Only 28 percent of the children lived in families that relied solely on public assistance.
* Thirty-eight percent of the children lived in families with two married adults, and most of these children had at least one parent who was employed full or part time.
* Minority children living with two parents were more than twice as likely to be poor as white children living with two parents.
 
Single Teen-Age Parents
The report said, ''Children born outside of marriage who grow up with single mothers are likely to be poor for most or all of their childhood.'' And it said that even though the teen-age birthrate had declined from 1960 through 1986, the proportion of unmarried teen-agers who have children rose sharply. In 1960, 15 percent of all teen-agers giving birth were unmarried; in 1986, the figure was 61 percent.
When a single teen-ager has a baby, it usually means an end to the mother's formal education, the study said, limiting her ability to find a job that will pay enough to support her family.
A minimum-wage job paid only 60 percent of what it would take to break the poverty line in 1987, the report said. It added that although the minimum wage rose in April to $3.80 an hour from $3.35, the difference ''is not enough to have a significant impact on poverty rates.''
Living nearly in poverty can sometimes be just as difficult for some families as well, the report said, because such families are ineligible for various forms of noncash assistance, or sometimes are unaware such assistance is available. The report said 2.7 million children under 6 live nearly in poverty.
The center was assisted in the study by Child Trends Inc., a nonprofit research group in Washington. The purpose of the center, which was established a little more than a year ago with the aid of grants from the Ford Foundation and the Carnegie Corporation, is to report on issues important to groups working for the welfare of children.
Copies of the report are available from the center at 154 Haven Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10032, for $12.95 ($9.95 plus postage and handling).

HEADLINE: Special Schools Proposed Where Teachers Could Learn by Teaching

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Administrators of America's leading education schools are proposing a radical redesign of teacher education, in which universities and public schools would join forces to train teachers the way medical schools use hospitals to train doctors.
In a report issued yesterday, the group envisioned a national network of ''professional development schools.'' These would be public elementary and high schools, where university professors and education students would work with teachers and administrators to design curriculums, conduct research projects, train new teachers and rejuvenate experienced teachers.
While the group expects many versions of these schools, the report says all should share several principles: teaching methods that go beyond rote memorization to promote critical thinking; helping students of all ethnic and economic backgrounds to succeed; flexible organizational structures that involve parents, social service agencies and local communities; lifelong learning for teachers as well as students, and research that draws on the needs of the public school and may improve conditions there. 
The proposals were made in a report, ''Tomorrow's Schools: Principles for the Design of Professional Development Schools,'' by a coalition of nearly 100 universities interested in improving teacher education. The group's first report, in 1986, rocked education circles by calling for tough new certification tests for teachers and an end to undergraduate degrees in education.
 
Relating Theory to Practice
Some other teacher education experts said that the idea of professional development schools was not new and that several variants already existed. The report's contribution, they said, was to define common principles for such schools, pledge to establish them in major research universities and establish a nationwide network. These experts added that the group had set itself a formidable task.
The model for a professional development school would be a teaching hospital, where there would be a longterm institutional relationship between a university and a public school that allowed both sides to make changes in curriculum and practices to train teachers better. The idea is to integrate theory and practice. In the current student teacher system, a future teacher's brief stint in a classroom may bear little resemblance to what he or she has been learning in college.
The report ''is a very valuable contribution to redefining the relationship between universities and schools,'' said David G. Imig, executive director of the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education, which includes many of the universities that produced the report. ''I think it's going to be enormously difficult to do. In effect, you're bringing together two very different kinds of cultures: the culture of the university and of schools. Can you in fact create virtually new kinds of institutions in a society that's accustomed to seeing teacher education done one way and teaching in schools another?''
 
'Laboratory Schools' Declined
Many graduate schools of education now have few links with public schools and have trouble placing their graduates as student teachers, said Judith E. Lanier, dean of education at Michigan State University and president of the group that produced the report. At one time, many ran ''laboratory schools,'' usually private elementary and high schools on university campuses. Although some of these schools still thrive, many declined in the face of complaints that they were too elitist and detached from the real world of public schools. Professional development schools would be different, Professor Lanier said, because they would be in public schools and would combine education and research.
Professor Lanier has a grant to establish professional development schools in Michigan. He said a similar effort was under way in Louisville, Ky., and programs were beginning at the University of Missouri and the University of Albuquerque, N.M., among others.
Making professional development schools work, said the report and several professors who have tried to establish such schools, means completely changing the way most traditional graduate schools of education operate: granting professors tenure for practical work in the classroom as well as research, and using the knowledge gained in the public schools to change courses not only in education departments, but also in academic departments that have traditionally looked down on education schools. For example, to better train elementary school teachers in science, universities could develop courses on the undergraduate level that can reach nonscientists.
The most difficult task is forging a relationship of equality between public schools and universities, so that decision making is shared, said Philip Schlechty, who has established public school-university partnerships in Louisville, and Kenneth Palmer, who is coordinating similar efforts in San Luis Obispo, Calif.
 
Research Emphasis Disputed
''We're engaged in politics,'' said Mr. Palmer, who is a professor at California State Polytechnic University. He disputes the report's emphasis on including research on professional development schools. ''I don't say research is not important, but it's different from a bunch of deans at research institutions talking about how teacher education ought to be done. That's interesting, but I don't really have time. I've got to move this university to address putting teachers in schools.''
Mr. Schlechty said that for the professional development schools to be more successful than laboratory schools, they need to be in the poorest communities. ''They need to be ordinary schools that take on extraordinary qualities,'' he said. ''Training hospitals were quite often located in places where there were a lot of indigents.''
The report endorsed that idea. The point of establishing professional development schools, it said, is to insure that education improvements spread beyond a few model schools.

HEADLINE: How to End Tax Welfare for the Wealthy;
Social Security Juggling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is unfortunate that just when there seemed to be agreement that Social Security should be removed from deficit calculations, Representative Dan Rostenkowski's proposal puts Social Security back on the table for cuts. Even those who disagreed with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Federal Insurance Contributions Act taxes conceded that the Social Security trust funds are being used to mask, but not reduce, the deficit.
Nevertheless, Representative Rostenkowski has suggested a one-year elimination of the Social Security inflation adjustment, and a number of leaders and institutions have lauded him for courage. But, as was made clear in the debate over the Moynihan proposal, the billions ''borrowed'' from the trust funds now and secured with Government bonds must be repaid to the fund later by the Government and represent a growing debt -even though that ''loan'' is not reflected as part of the deficit. 
While issuing bonds (promises to pay later) has been used to finance Social Security in the past, there is a well-founded concern that the amounts borrowed from the trust funds are becoming so large as to make tax increases on future generations almost inevitable. Cutting the Social Security inflation adjustment, therefore, simply means there is more money in the fund to be borrowed for the short-term illusion of reducing the deficit and exacerbates the long-term problem.
For the illusion of reducing the deficit through an inflation adjustment cut, more than 500,000 low-income elderly people will fall below the poverty line next year.
The elderly have already seen cuts of billions of dollars to Medicare. That's a sacrifice in money and -even more precious - in health. The elderly, therefore, are as motivated as anyone to see a reduction in the deficit - but let's leave Social Security alone.
 
LAWRENCE T. SMEDLEY
Executive Director
National Council of Senior Citizens
 Washington, March 26, 1990

HEADLINE: How to End Tax Welfare for the Wealthy;
Return to Old I.R.A.'s

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In 1980 our net national savings rate was 6.1 percent of gross domestic product, whereas in 1986 it was only 2.4 percent. In contrast, the corresponding rates from Japan were 11.3 percent in 1980 and 12.9 percent in 1986. (Note, however, that the concept of ''savings'' is not precise and can differ between countries.) As bad as our savings rate was, it would have been worse if not for tax-deductible individual retirement accounts, which in 1986 accounted for $38.2 billion (38 percent of our total national savings).
Notwithstanding public opinion and the advice of pundits, Congress in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 drastically changed the ground rules for I.R.A.'s. The net result has been that only some $13.5 billion went into tax-deductible I.R.A.'s in 1987.
President Bush's suggested remedy is no remedy at all. Both the ''family savings account'' and the ''restructuring of I.R.A.'s'' will merely result in transferring assets from non-tax-deferred investments to tax-deferred ones.
What is clearly needed is a return to the immensely popular pre-1986 I.R.A., which created new savings by allowing tax deductions for money put into I.R.A.'s. I.R.A.'s are a near-perfect tool for a free-enterprise society, because they create self-reliance by encouraging people to provide for their financial future, while at the same time providing desperately needed capital to the free-enterprise system.
 
ROBERT MYERS
THOMAS WOLFF
Vernon, Conn., March 26, 1990
 The writers are, respectively, former chief actuary, Social Security Administration (1947-70), and past president, National Association of Life Underwriters.

HEADLINE: Soviet Anti-Semitism Survey Shows Bias

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Survey in Moscow Sees a High Level of Anti-Jewish Feeling'' (news article, March 30) shows the disturbing prejudices not only of Muscovites but also of the survey's designers.
The survey seems to validate prejudices as it seeks to quantify them. For example, by asking whether a respondent agrees that ''More than any other group in society, it is the Jews who are responsible for the problems the Soviet Union is experiencing today,'' the survey validates the idea that distinct religious, ethnic or racial groups bear responsibility for the economic and sociopolitical problems of a multiethnic nation. 
When the survey asks if a respondent agrees that ''when it comes to choosing between people and money, Jews will choose money,'' it validates the notion that all Jews act one way or another, that there is something inherent about Jewishness that determines behavior.
I wonder, also, whether by offering respondents, among other choices, the chance to agree that, in the Soviet population, ''only some are anti-Jewish,'' the word ''only'' makes a certain amount of anti-Semitism acceptable, offering the assessment as a compromise more flattering than the reported Soviet opinion of 17 percent that ''most people are anti-Jewish.''
I am troubled that the survey did not give Muscovites the chance to agree that Jews are neither more nor less responsible for Soviet problems than any other group. I would have also been pleased to see Muscovites asked if it was right to divide their nation into ethnic and religious groups when seeking to cast blame for the country's worries.
Even if only a tiny minority had shown themselves to be tolerant in their response to these statements, to include such statements would have at least given Muscovites the chance to prove themselves more broad-minded than they are perhaps expected to be; and in the bargain, the citizens of Moscow would have been offered a model of real tolerance to think about.
 
PETER S. TEMES
New York, April 1, 1990
 The writer is an instructor in logic and rhetoric at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Earth Day's 'Planetism'

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: HARPERS FERRY, W. Va

 BODY:
In celebration of the 20th recycling of Earth Day, the folk musician Glen McClure will perform a concert in Rochester on an instrument made entirely of garbage.
He won't be alone. Around the world, ecological activists will join publicity-hungry celebrities and tie-in-conscious corporations to whoop it up for the salvation of the planet. In Germany, 10,000 trees will be planted along the site of the Berlin wall; in Japan, a campaign will be launched against the use of wooden chopsticks. 
In 1969, when this environmental brainchild of Wisconsin Senator Gaylord Nelson's hove into view, the Nixon White House embraced it. Why not? Conservation, as the organized love of nature was previously called, was a Teddy Roosevelt crusade, and besides, it was good to have the fierce energy of young, white, elitist demonstrators channeled into other than anti-war protests.
Now the day has become a week (Tuesday is Recycling Day, Friday Toxics Information Day), and morning-show hosts are poised to deluge their audiences with guests fluent in tech-bashing greenspeak.
Politicians mired in peace and prosperity are seeking a new source of voter interest aboard this new Motherhood Express. Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, who has genuine anti-pollution credentials, dropped by a few months ago to deliver an impressive briefing on the danger of carbon dioxide; Jesse Jackson is now trying to steal the issue from him, on the dubious theory that poor neighborhoods become waste disposal dumps.
For Republicans, George Bush has nicely split the political difference between concern and cost: we are for clean air and water, but not against necessary industries that pollute a little and employ a lot. ''Think globally and act locally,'' he advises; better to clean up a single eyesore than to curse the dark forces of pollution.
We are all environmentalists now, but we are not all planetists. I sit here in West Virginia on weekends watching the white-water rafters shoot the rapids on the Shenandoah River, and I haul my garbage back to Washington, where it seems to belong; my mountain retreat is no Walden, but nature has its pleasures and deserves respect.
A planetist, on the other hand, puts the Earth ahead of the earthlings -places society's responsibility for the individual ahead of the individual's responsibility for himself.
The planetist sees the world whole, as if from space; this ultimate outsider discerns global danger with great certainty and demands supranational solutions at any cost to avert nothing less than extinction.
Just in time for Earth Day's publicity extravaganza, I submit this guide for pro-earthling non-planetism: 1. First, do no harm. When planetism takes global warming as an article of faith, but NASA's latest scientific study refutes it, the layman should err on the side of caution. If it doesn't trigger a depression, ease up on the carbon dioxide. 2. Demand to see the whole agenda. Before joining the Greens or making ecology your switcher issue, call for truth in activism: are we all supposed to return to a simpler life? What of those who like crowded cities, or dig glitz? Is the third world to be denied development or be subsidized to stay backward and pure? 3. Love the activist, hate the power-grabber. The Earth Day organizers have done much good, and saw a legitimate health concern before most of us did. But watch out for the bureaucratization of the goo-goos, in the form of a ''Green Seal'' of approval, to force companies to obey standards set by unelected overseers. 4. Press the ''eco-eco effect.'' Ecology and economics go hand in hand; instead of railing against greedy corporations or too-protective unions, or complaining about a ''license to pollute,'' use economic incentives to clean the air and water. People pollute because it is cheap and easy; by using tax policy to make it expensive and hard, we will change behavior the productive way. 5. Put a higher value on growth than on limitation. Malthus was mistaken; the world can produce and then feed and shelter billions of human beings.
We are not a race blindly bent on suicide by mindless self-strangulation; on this peculiarly blessed planet, we are among the sperm cells and ova of the universe - and in a century or two, our descendants will be coordinating our celebration with the colonists whooping it up for Mars Day and Venus Day.

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 19, Column 5; Editorial Desk
