HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush and the Blacks

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Commenting on the strange popularity of President Bush among blacks, Prof. Lawrence Bobo of the University of Wisconsin argued that Mr. Bush ''hasn't done anything seriously damaging of the sort that seemed to happen repeatedly'' under Ronald Reagan.
Ruby Tilghman, an unemployed home health care worker in West Philadelphia, takes a more critical attitude toward the President. In her view, on ''the real big important issues where it affects the minorities, he's doing it in a roundabout way where it doesn't look like he's against us, but he is.''
Wicker's Keen Political Insight Award goes to Ms. Tilghman. Both she and Mr. Bobo were interviewed for a New York Times/CBS News Poll that found a remarkable 56 percent of 403 black respondents approving Mr. Bush's performance in office. That makes him the first Republican President since Dwight Eisenhower to score above 50 percent among blacks; their approval may be tentative and lukewarm but they've given black-majority approval to Mr. Bush in four consecutive Times/CBS Polls. 
These scores baffle conventional political wisdom. Not only have blacks for years been the most reliable element of the Democratic Party; not only does Mr. Bush give his highest priority to retaining the support of the Republican right wing that spurns minorities and shaped the Reagan Administration; the President also allowed himself to benefit, in his 1988 campaign, from the Willie Horton ad that evoked white racial fears.
On minority issues, moreover, as on education, Ruby Tilghman has Mr. Bush pegged: he is trying to have it both ways. He proclaims himself ''the education President'' but reduces Federal money for education, not a small matter for minorities. He tells a mostly black audience he'll welcome the first black President -while his Attorney General says Mr. Bush will veto this year's most needed civil rights bill.
It's addressed to the Rehnquist Court's radical Ward's Cove decision overturning established law dating to 1971 and an opinion written by Warren Burger. Ward's Cove assigned the burden of proof to an employee who charged an employer with discriminatory hiring and employment practices. Chief Justice Burger, in keeping with overall legal custom, had placed the burden on the party best able to show that the procedures at issue were fair and necessary -obviously, the employer.
The Democratic Congress is now considering a bill to overrule Ward's Cove and return civil rights law to the 1971 standard. But Mr. Bush threatens to veto the bill if it passes. In non-legal terms, he threatens to make it easier for employers to discriminate and harder for employees (often members of minority groups) to get relief in court.
Meanwhile, quietly but steadily, the President follows the Reagan path in naming ideological Federal judges. The President's aim, his legal counsel told Neil Lewis of The Times, is ''very much the same'' as Mr. Reagan's -''to shift the courts in a more conservative direction.''
Conservative and liberal court watchers agree that Mr. Bush's 46 appointments so far have fulfilled that aim, with dozens more to come. The appointees' records suggest that most - like the Rehnquist Court -will require civil rights and minority-group plaintiffs to meet tough standards, and will take a more punitive attitude toward criminal defendants (who are, again, often members of minority groups).
Three Rehnquist Court Justices, all more liberal than the majority, are over 80; so Mr. Bush may well be able to shape that Court even further in the Reagan mold. If he replaces Thurgood Marshall, the Court's only black, he's expected to name Clarence Thomas, a black foe of affirmative action, whom he's already put on the important D.C. Court of Appeals.
Such specific issues are not always the prime influence on political views, white or black. The Times/CBS News Poll found, for instance, that blacks' approval of Mr. Bush was based partly on black resentment of a Democratic Party that they think takes them for granted. That's food for thought for Democrats who want to move the party rightward ''to the center.''
Blacks, significantly, seem to expect little of Mr. Bush; sadly, that may reflect a more general voters' attitude toward American politics. ''He hasn't gotten us into any major wars and the economy hasn't completely fallen through,'' Joanne Clark, a black schoolteacher from New Jersey, told the poll takers. ''He's O.K. as long as he doesn't do anything really negative.''
Or, as many Americans seem to think: ''He's O.K. as long as he doesn't do anything.''

HEADLINE: Falling Revenues and Rising Costs Force Counties to Trim More Services

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
Rockland County was surprised to discover recently that it was the only jurisdiction in the lower Hudson River Valley still operating patrol boats, at an annual cost of $300,000. Now the service is being ended, County Executive John Grant said, ''because we're looking everywhere to save money.''
In Suffolk County, bills are being paid every two weeks now, instead of twice a week, saving $300,000 a year. Likewise, Westchester County is studying whether to turn its modern medical center over to an authority, and Nassau County is thinking of consolidating its health services.
Atlantic County in New Jersey has started to use recycled asphalt and concrete to cut the costs of road programs. In Bergen County, its Executive, William McDowell, said, ''We've been talking to Essex and Hudson Counties about a regional solution to the garbage problem.'' 
In these days of rising costs, falling revenues and shrinking subsidies, no government service is seen as too small to escape the scrutiny of county officials. They are looking beyond traditional cost-cutting techniques, like layoffs and hiring freezes, to balance their budgets.
 
Duties Rise but Aid Falls
Ordered to operate welfare programs, jails, bus systems and scores of other services, the counties are facing difficult times as they seek to cope with services mandated in state capitals and in Washington.
County officials say their burdens are growing heavier faster because the Federal and state governments continue to add county obligations while reducing the subsidies that once covered their costs.
Federal and state officials say there is not enough money to continue their share of the services. The reductions, usually made without fanfare, must then be made up by the counties.
John P. Thomas, executive director of the National Association of Counties, said, ''Washington keeps calling for improvements but its policy is to have local and state governments pay for them.'' He said a new Bush Administration proposal to improve transportation systems was typical: ''They mandate the changes, but we end up paying for them.''
''We see it getting worse and worse,'' Mr. Thomas said. ''Any service you mention - health care, transportation, the environment - is constantly being improved, but they tell the counties to pay for the new standards.''
 
Babylon Sweeps County Roads
This, in turn, is forcing county officials to scrutinize spending with unusual care, while finding new ways to cut costs. Some methods represent greater scrutiny by desperate administrators; some seem quite innovative.
The Suffolk County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, said, ''We're entering arrangements with municipalities, such as the Town of Babylon, to have it sweep the 35 miles of county roads in its jurisdiction.'' He said it was a new source of income for the town, ''and the county doesn't have to go out and buy a $150,000 sweeper.''
He spoke of an education and transportation program for handicapped children, a mandated service that Mr. Halpin said ''has been rising at three times the rate of inflation.'' In Suffolk, he said, ''we were spending $80 million a year to educate 4,000 kids, about $20,000 a child.''
''In the past, the county just paid the bill, but last year we hired teams of professionals who audited every program,'' Mr. Halpin said, indicating that his office suspected fraud in some cases. ''Some were referred to the District Attorney's office; others were simply better controlled. We found that Family Court was rubber-stamping assignments made by the families, who were selecting schools of their choice.''
 
Westchester Looks at Workfare
In Westchester, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke described how a new look at an old program saved millions of dollars. ''Starting just over a year ago, we began examining our home relief recipients, who are single and childless, in terms of having them work for their benefits.'' The result, he said, was startling.
After four months, 3,000 of the county's 7,300 home-relief cases had been examined for ''workfare,'' as the program is known, and 1,000 recipients had been dropped from the rolls. Some never showed up; the majority of those were assumed by county officials to be illegally working while receiving benefits intended for the unemployed.
A total of 1,800 home relief cases in Westchester were eventually dropped, ''saving $10 million in direct costs,'' Mr. O'Rourke said, ''while another $7 million was saved indirectly in medical payments and food stamps.''
New cases of homelessness dropped by 30 percent after Westchester, whose 4,500 cases represent the largest per capita homeless population in the state, established an assessment center at Westchester County Airport, the site of a large county shelter.
Suffolk County saved $3 million last year, Mr. Halpin said, by transferring many home relief recipients, whose costs are shared by the counties and the state, to S.S.I., the federally financed supplemental security income program.
 
Guests in the County Jails
Linda Spalinski, executive director of the New Jersey Association of Counties, said jail overcrowding was particularly serious for county governments, in part because of a nine-year-old executive order that ''forces counties to house state prisoners.''
''We have a county jail in Camden County built three or four years ago to handle 500 prisoners, but is now holding a prison population of 1,200,'' she said. ''New Jersey is one of only nine states not currently under some Federal order to reduce overcrowding, because it is using county jails as stopgaps.''
Counties, she said, ''look to property taxes to pay for government services, and this has a terrible effect on the elderly and young people trying to raise families.''
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, earlier this year drew attention to school costs, which represent at least half of most homeowners' property tax bills. He said rising property taxes were the greatest threat to the county's quality of life.
 
L.I. Commission To Study Cuts
Mr. Gulotta proposed a two-year moratorium on additional tax assessments for homeowners who make home improvements, and he joined Mr. Halpin, his Suffolk County counterpart, in forming a two-county commission, whose task is to propose tax-cutting measures for advisory referendums in November.
The commission could recommend changes that elected officials might fear to propose, like consolidating school districts or combining police and emergency services. It is headed by John V. N. Klein, a lawyer and former Suffolk County Executive, and Dr. James Shuart, president of Hofstra University.
Dr. Shuart said: ''We are going to have to face facts by answering the question: What does this or that service really provide, and can we afford it? The people being served would argue that the services are 100 percent necessary,'' but the commission is charged with finding tax relief.
State governments, said Ms. Spalinski, who represents New Jersey counties, ''have not only failed to replace Federal revenue sharing, which ended in 1986, but in New Jersey siphoned away from counties and municipalities revenues that have traditionally gone to them, such as our share of financial and corporate business taxes.''
 
Regionalizing Garbage Costs
''When the state took it away in 1981 it was worth $9 million,'' she said. ''Today it would be worth $20 million, and we used to get 25 percent of those taxes.'' Mandated costs, like paying for the court system, can increase by as much as 15 percent in a year, while New Jersey county budgets are usually not allowed to rise by more than five percent a year.
Some county administrators are looking to regional solutions for rising costs. Mr. McDowell, the Bergen County Executive, said that ''the solid waste crisis - getting rid of garbage -has become a big bill locally, with costs of dumping five times higher today than it was four years ago.''
''The answer may be regionalization, or the marrying of two or three counties,'' the Bergen official said, describing his talks with Essex and Hudson Counties over construction of a resource recovery plant.

HEADLINE: Renovation Program Is Running Out of Abandoned Housing

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Four years after deciding to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to build affordable housing, New York City finds itself at a surprising pass: it is running out of abandoned buildings to renovate.
This shortage is both a measure of New York's success and a predicament for the future. After it depletes its portfolio of 5,000 vacant, burned-out buildings - probably by 1992 or 1993 - will the fiscally strapped city be able to meet the continuing need for new housing? And what is the best, and most economical, way to do so?
This is undoubtedly the most difficult housing issue facing the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. It is being debated now by housing experts and planners, who say it must be resolved this year if the city is to be ready with new programs when the renovation of the last large vacant structures is finished in the next two or three years. Determining government housing initiatives and awarding sites and financing to developers and community groups takes at least two years. 
 
A Major Reversal
No other American city had as many abandoned buildings, and none have mounted a comparable effort to produce new affordable housing. New York's record also represents a major reversal. As recently as 1983, the city, unwilling to spend its own money on housing, papered over the windows of some abandoned buildings with painted decals showing shutters and potted plants.
Some experts say completion of the renovations will mark the end of the city's ambitious effort. They say there will not be enough money to undertake the more costly task of building brand-new housing for the poor and working poor. Though the city is creating tens of thousands of new apartments, the need continues: a recent study estimated that New York city needed 231,000 more apartments and houses.
''Every war is fought with the weapons and concepts of its predecessors, so we are now fully equipped with a magnificent armament for the basic rehab of shattered structures,'' said George Sternlieb, University Professor of Urban Studies at Rutgers University.
''But now the better buildings have either been rebuilt or are in development, and some of the rest may not be worth renovating,'' he continued. ''Nobody has figured out what happens tomorrow. You have to place this in the context of the city's fiscal problems. It's a very tough one.'' Others argue that the city may have no choice. ''The city is going to have to switch from rehab to new construction,'' said Abraham Biderman, the last Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development in the Koch administration. ''To say that we simply can't afford it, that means we won't produce any more affordable housing in New York City. What are the consequences of not providing any more affordable housing?''
 
A Valued Commodity
Once the bane of hard-pressed neighborhoods, the shells of apartment buildings became a valued commodity when the city decided to spend several billion dollars to produce new housing for a population desperately short of living accommodations.
It costs less to rebuild an abandoned structure, even one that has only its foundation and outer walls intact, than to construct a new one. Renovations can also be completed more quickly because they require fewer approvals from government agencies and elected officials than does new construction.
But the city's unusual resource of vacant ruins, with 50,000 apartments, is being used up rapidly. Besides the 3,500 apartments that have been completed and the 14,700 that are under construction, most of the 18,000 apartments that are in development have city money committed for them, said Felice Michetti, who was appointed Housing Commissioner last month.
Most of the remaining abandoned buildings have fewer than 15 apartments each, and new programs will probably have to be devised to make it feasible for developers or nonprofit groups to rebuild them, she said.
 
A Shrinking Inventory
While some experts fear that New York's declining housing market may cause a new round of abandonment, most think the city is unlikely to add many newly abandoned structures to its shrinking inventory. In recent years, the city has been seizing occupied and vacant buildings containing about 2,000 apartments annually, a fifth of the total taken each year in the 1970's and early 1980's, when landlords and tenants walked away from huge swaths of New York's poorest sections.
In many of those neighborhoods, including most parts of the South Bronx, virtually every remaining city-owned abandoned shell is spoken for, say leaders of local nonprofit housing groups. That is putting pressure on the city to create new programs, both to keep housing producers busy and to provide new housing for New Yorkers not served by the private market.
Most experts said that the city must continue to create housing for low- and moderate-income households and that new construction would be the only alternative once the abandoned stock was depleted. But they differed significantly on what kind of housing should be built and whom it should serve.
The city now helps finance construction of new two- and three-story town houses that are sold to middle-income families, defined as those with incomes between $32,000 and $53,000 a year. Some experts said the city should expand this program to include new low-rise housing for those less affluent.
 
Cost of Renovation
If prefabricated housing was used, the city could produce new buildings, three to five stories tall, for about $80,000 an apartment, said Willa Appel, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit group. The complete renovation of abandoned shells has cost an average of $60,000 to $70,000 a unit, although some have cost up to $94,000 each.
The Nehemiah housing plan, which builds inexpensive, single-family row houses in the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn, has proposed a new type of garden apartment, which it said could be built for less than $60,000 a unit.
Ms. Appel argued that low-rise construction would be politically appealing because it would not cost much more than the renovations. By using small sites - vacant land held by the city and by private owners - the city government could also complete the renewal of many neighborhoods, she said.
The hard part would be obtaining private land, Ms. Appel said. That now takes as long as three years, but could be speeded up with some changes in city procedures, she said.
Mr. Biderman, who is now working for an investment firm, said taller structures should be built, so that the city's last remaining housing resource - land - could be used most efficiently. He argued that low-rise construction would not produce enough apartments. While he was Commissioner, Mr. Biderman refused several times to grant more land for Nehemiah housing.
Constructing buildings from 6 to 12 stories tall could cost as much as $130,000 to $150,000 an apartment, he said. To make a $130,000 apartment affordable to a family with a $30,000 annual income, the city would have to pay a direct subsidy of $100,000. City subsidies for the renovation of abandoned buildings range from a low of about $40,000 per apartment to the complete development cost.
 
New Techniques
New construction techniques, including prefabrication, might bring down the cost, said Paul A. Crotty, another former Housing Commissioner. Mr. Crotty suggested that new construction should be primarily for people with incomes above $19,000 a year and that existing older housing should be upgraded and preserved for the poor.
Others urged that future city programs be more flexible than existing ones. Rather than setting broad citywide standards and rules, the government should tailor initiatives to the differing needs of communities. Low-rise housing might be more appropriate in some areas, and high-rise more appropriate in others, they said.
Ms. Michetti, the new Housing Commissioner, said she too would like to create flexible programs. ''I really think you have to do it on a community-by-community basis,'' she said.
Among the possibilities, she said, is developing a new four-story apartment house, with units to be sold both to middle-income and low-income New Yorkers. Apartments could be made affordable to the poor by requiring very small down payments and then limiting the profit that could be made upon resale. The apartments then could remain a low-income resource.
''New construction presents a unique challenge,'' Ms. Michetti said. ''Rehab itself is pretty straightforward. The footprint, the building, is already there. In new construction we have the opportunity to become much more involved with communities in the planning. It's a much broader kind of initiative.''

HEADLINE: Team of Scientists Sees Substantial Warming of Earth

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Assembled by the United Nations in an attempt to arrive at an international consensus on global warming, a team of scientists says it is a ''virtual certainty'' that the temperature of the earth's surface will rise substantially in the next century.
The scientists generally agree with the theory that has been largely accepted by other national and international panels: that energy trapped in a greenhouse effect by industrial gases will warm the earth by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit within the next 60 years.
A number of scientists, though, have raised doubts about the theory and about models of climatic change on which it is based. Skeptics call the model inaccurate or incomplete. 
The stakes are huge: Backers of the greenhouse theory say it will lead to worldwide flooding, climatic change and social disruption, #3 Groups Examine Theory Three United Nations teams are examining the theory and its policy implications. A team led by Britain is assessing the state of scientific knowledge about climate change. The conclusions that support the greenhouse theory are in this team's draft report. A group headed by the Soviet Union is looking into how such changes would affect social and economic systems. The third group, led by the United States, is preparing suggested policy responses to such changes. Final reports from all three groups are to be issued this year.
Although still in draft form, the report generally supporting the greenhouse theory is likely to play a role in a White House conference on the changes in global climate. President Bush, who will open the meeting Tuesday, has invited 17 nations plus the European Community and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to participate.
Michael R. Deland, the chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, said the conference was intended to ''integrate the scientific and economic research challenges posed by the climate change issue.''
Mr. Deland, who is co-chairman of the conference, said in an interview that the White House called the conference to accelerate United Nations efforts to collect information needed for policy decisions about the greenhouse effect. He denied the contention of some Democrats and environmentalists that the Bush Administration had organized the forum to justify delaying national and international efforts to cope with global warming.
 
Many Unanswered Questions
In February, the President spoke to the international group assembled by the United National to study the greenhouse theory and emphasized the many unanswered questions about the evidence supporting the theory and the uncertainity about the economic consequences of reducing the use of fossil fuels and taking other steps to lower emissions of industrial gases.
Mr. Bush's remarks appeared to reflect the skepticism of those scientists who questioned whether the available evidence was sufficient to predict that the earth will warm substantially in the next century.
As Mr. Deland noted, however, the President has offered to serve as host of a conference to begin work on international climate change treaty. Mr. Bush has also proposed that $1 billion be budgeted for research into global warming issues.
Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat who is an advocate of a strong international response to the threat of global warming, has questioned the motives of the Administration in calling the conference on climate change.
He said in a telephone interview that it was ironic that the findings of the international panel supporting the greenhouse theory would be made public on the eve ''of a conference that was designed to highlight scientific uncertainty,'' and added, ''The report confounds the skeptics.''
 
Substantial Modifications Likely
D. Allan Bromley, Assistant to the President for Science and Technology, said he had had only a ''cursory look'' at the draft report. But he said scientists on the panel had told him the draft was likely to be modified substantially before it is issued in final form.
Asked about the report's predictions of global warming, Dr. Bromley, also a co-chairman of the upcoming conference, said: ''There are still large uncertainties with any of the models. There is a consensus that if we continue to put greenhouse gases into the atmosphere at the rate of this century, we eventually will get global warming. But we don't know the exact time and magnitude, and some gaping uncertainties that underly these models have not yet been resolved.''
The draft report found that emissions of carbon dioxide, methane, chlorofluorocarbons and nitrous oxides, gases that retain radiation from sunlight and thus contribute to a warming of the earth, are continuing to build up in the atmosphere.
To stabilize concentrations of carbon dioxide at present levels, it said, ''an immediate reduction in global man-made emissions by 60 to 80 percent would be necessary.'' Such emissions come chiefly from the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil.
 
Analysis of Geologic Records
The authors of the report said they had a high degree of confidence that the earth's surface and the lower atmosphere would warm by 2.7 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit. While the models show there is likely to be increased drought at mid-latitudes in the Northern Hemisphere, the available data permit only relatively low confidence in this finding, the report said.
In the last 100 years, the temperature of the globe has gone up by three-tenths of a degree to 1.1 degrees Fahrenheit, a range consistent with the climate models, the report said. But it also said it cannot be determined at this point how much of that increase can be attributed to greenhouse gases.
The report noted, however, that an analysis of the geologic records of prehistoric epochs shows that the correlation of increases of carbon dioxide in the air with temperature changes is similar to the predictions of the computer models.
Richard S. Lindzen, a scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has been one of the most vocal critics of the conclusions of the climate models, said he had not seen the draft report. But when told of its findings, he said, ''The conclusions sound off the wall to me.''
Mr. Lindzen said there are still so many uncertainties in the models, including the role of increased cloud formation and water vapor as a result of warmer temperature, that they cannot accurately forecast what will happen in the next century.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bars Chinese Role At Talks on Air Pollution

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
To avoid violating sanctions imposed on China last year because of its crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, the Administration has excluded Beijing from an international conference on air pollution and climatic change, even though the Chinese burn more industrial coal than any other country, officials said today.
The conference, to be held here on Tuesday and Wednesday, will include the rest of the world's most industrialized or populous nations, and White House officials said they normally would have considered Chinese participation an important element of such a meeting.
The White House Conference on Scientific and Economic Research Related to Global Change is part of President Bush's effort to spur research into the way pollution may be changing the global climate and to allay criticism of his environmental policies. Mr. Bush will address the gathering on Tuesday morning and Wednesday afternoon.
The conference is to focus on the kind of research the industrialized and developing nations should conduct on the theory of global warming, which postulates that certain kinds of pollutants are causing the Earth's temperature to rise. The burning of coal is the primary source of carbon dioxide, a chemical that is believed to be a major cause of this phenomenon. 
 
Criteria Explained
In drawing up the guest list for the conference, the White House selected countries ''that have substantial populations, large land masses, industrial economies or heavy future energy needs,'' said Stephen Hart, a White House spokesman.
China, which has the world's largest population, about 1 billion people, burns more coal than any other country and is expected to increase its consumption dramatically in an industrialization drive. At present, it is the third largest producer of carbon dioxide in the world, after the United States and the Soviet Union, according to United Nations statistics.
''China has the potential to emit a lot of carbon dioxide as they continue to develop, as well as chlorofluorocarbons, and under different circumstances they probably would have been invited to this meeting,'' Mr. Hart said.
Scientists say chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals used for such purposes as propellants in aerosol sprays and coolants in refrigerators and air conditioners, damage the ozone layer, increasing the amount of harmful radiation reaching the earth's surface.
 
High-Level Exchanges Banned
But Mr. Hart said China was excluded from the list because of the sanctions Mr. Bush imposed against the Beijing Government last year after its nationwide crackdown on political dissent, which culminated in the violence in Tiananmen Square last June.
Among those measures was a ban on high-level exchanges between the two nations. Mr. Hart said the White House determined that the rule would apply to the conference since the invitations went out to government officials of ministerial level.
Officials said that even if China's participation might have been useful, the Administration wanted to avoid the kind of severe criticism it drew last year after it was disclosed that Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, had made two trips to China after the sanctions were imposed. The White House took the position at the time that the Scowcroft-Eagleburger mission was not an exchange.
The United States signed the 1987 Montreal Protocol, which called for a reduction of 50 percent in the production of chlorofluorocarbons. The 80 nations that signed the document are now negotiating a deadline for a complete ban on the chemicals. China has not ratified the protocol.
Sending delegations to the conference besides the United States are Australia, Brazil, Canada, West Germany, France, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Mexico, the Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Poland, the Soviet Union, Britain and Zaire, as well as the European Community and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

HEADLINE: Rain Alone Won't Ease Latest Drought in West

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 15

 BODY:
The plentiful and cheap water that made much of the West rich, powerful and populous has now turned scarce and ever more costly to find.
A fourth straight year of drought has descended on California and the Southwest. It has brought not only painful shortages and restrictions on water use but also profound questions about the region's capacity to grow the way it has and preserve its comfortable style of life without devastating environmental consequences and bitter divisions.
But by contrast with previous droughts, shortages will endure even if rain and snowfall return to normal next winter, officials say. Enormous population growth, environmental concerns, contamination of underground water and court rulings have all combined to make it harder and harder to keep up with demand. 
''In the past, we went out and built another dam or aqueduct,'' said Carl Boronkay, general manager of the Metropolitan Water District, the powerful agency that supplies 62 percent of the water used by 15 million residents of Southern California. ''That's more and more difficult now.'' Action Likely This Week This week, officials of the San Francisco Water Department are expected to recommend mandatory rationing for that city, whose sole source of water, the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir on the Tuolumne River in the Sierra Nevada, was down to 27 percent of capacity as of April 3. Since most reservoir water accumulates between November and April, there is little chance the situation will improve soon.
Also This week, the board of the Metropolitan Water District is expected to issue drought rules that could result in cutbacks of 10 to 20 percent or more to the 300 cities and towns it serves in six counties from Oxnard to the Mexican border. Two weeks ago, Mayor Tom Bradley said was ''very likely'' in Los Angeles.
Rationing has been a fact of life for some time on the central coast of California. In Monterey, each household must cut back by 20 percent or face stiff fines. Farther south, in the seaside city of Santa Barbara, where residents voted 11 years ago not to built an aqueduct to the State Water Project for fear it would bring unbridled growth, people water lawns with buckets.
 
Nevada and Arizona Affected
In Nevada, the fastest-growing state, rural interests are mounting a political and legal assault on a $1.5 billion plan by the parched city of Las Vegas to pump water from remote, sparsely populated counties to the north. And in Phoenix, the City Council recently considered restrictions on lawns.
The water for these areas comes mainly from snows melting off the Sierra and channeled to the farms of the Central Valley of California and to cities along the coast, as well as from the Colorado River.
This year, precipitation in California has been 60 percent of normal and snow runoff is 40 percent of normal. Some reservoirs, like the Gibraltar near Santa Barbara, are empty. Gibraltar's caretaker, Dennis Ward, recently stood on the cracked sand that in other times has been under many feet of water.
Meanwhile, the Colorado River is flowing at less than 50 percent of normal volume.
As a result, the California Department of Water Resources is expected to order urban users of the State Water Project to cut back by 5 to 10 percent. It has aleady imposed a 28 percent cut on agricultural users in the San Joaquin and Sacramento Valleys.
 
Effects of Court Ruling
The drought also means that California for the first time will feel the effects of a 1964 Supreme Court decision that limited the state's rights to Colorado River water in dry years. California officials say increased demand by Arizona will likely mean that the water diverted by the Metropolitan Water District and fed into a 242-mile aqueduct to Southern California will be cut by a quarter.
California grew by about 5.2 million people during the 1980's. The Department of Finance projects that the population will grow from 28.8 million this year to 32.9 million in 2000.
In the past, the water barons of the West easily and eagerly coped with such demand. With what many historians now believe was arrogance and blind contempt for the environment, they built aqueducts, dams and reservoirs that brought water to the growing cities and farms.
 
Fish Are a Factor
But such projects are not so easily built today. Major elements of the State Water Project, which diverts water from the Sacramento River delta, remain unfinished, bogged down in environmental and legal battles. Concerns about harm to San Francisco Bay, into which the delta empties, have caused long delays in diverting more water to Southern California.
Legal sanctions against taking endangered winter-run Chinook salmon have complicated efforts to divert more water from the Sacramento River.
But given economic and political forces, few doubt that urban needs will be met. The question is how, and at what cost to the environment and agriculture. Farming still consumes 80 percent of California water.
''Over all, the state has enough water to meet even the tremendous growth we are seeing,'' said David Kennedy, director of the California Department of Water Resources. But he said a shift from ''absolutes'' to ''reasonable protection'' on environmental issues is necessary. A Lesson From Nature? Environmentalists say the drought underscores the need for wiser use of resources. Some environmentalists see water as a possible tool in the battle to limit growth. Developers, though, have not yet been squeezed hard except in areas like Santa Barbara.
In the meantime, political accommodations and conservation continue. San Francisco, long a center of opposition to the State Water Project because of environmental damage to the bay, recently agreed to spend $700,000 to build a 30-inch pipeline to allow it to tap into the pipeline in emergencies.
But many say even more sweeping changes can be expected. ''One in 10 Americans lives in California,'' said Jason E. Peltier, director of the Central Valley Project Association, which represents water districts that buy water from that Federal project. ''When they get thirsty, we'll see changes.''

LENGTH: 1819 words

HEADLINE: Tides of Change Lap at Soviet Sports

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Amid the economic crisis and political reforms in the Soviet Union, sports authorities are straining to preserve a costly system that has made the Soviet Union the leading country in the Olympics for almost 20 years.
While a comparable situation forced sports leaders in East Germany to scrap a system that lifted their Olympic athletes to second place, Soviet officials contend that success at the international level is too important to the Soviet people to allow the apparatus to degenerate.
As a result, they defend the system against an increasing number of critics who say elite sports are being maintained at the expense of sports programs for ordinary citizens. Officials are also facing an assault from within: the expanding capitalist tendencies of elite athletes, who want to be treated the same as their counterparts in Western countries.
''We are looking for the correct ways to develop sports for all and, at the same time, maintain our high performance sports,'' Nikolai I. Rusak, the chairman of the State Committee for Physical Education and Sports, said in a recent interview. ''But we're working hard so that changes in our country do not affect elite sports. It is very easy to destroy a system created over many years and very difficult to reconstruct.'' 
The vast system of sports clubs, schools and colleges, run by the national sports committee, is supported by revenues generated from a national lottery, the sale of daily sports newspapers and of tickets to events, plus the sponsorship of enterprises and trade unions affiliated with various clubs. The Government makes an annual contribution, but officials say the sports committee returns all of it and more in the form of taxes.
In its ideal form, the system blends mass sports and elite programs, producing Olympic champions as a result of exposing all citizens to all sports. As the more skilled athletes emerge, currently some 23,000, they move along an assembly line through any of 40 sports schools, in which they learn from coaches who trained at one of the country's 50 sports colleges.
Meanwhile, citizens interested in sports for fitness and fun can partcipate as they wish.
 
Only Partial Success
But while the Soviet economy has deteriorated in recent years, creating severe shortages of food and consumer goods, only the elite half of the equation seems to be working. In all except 2 of the 10 Olympic Games staged since 1972, Soviet athletes have won the most medals. The exceptions were the 1980 Lake Placid Winter Games, in which East Germany won one more, and the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Games, which the Soviet Union did not attend for political reasons.
At the same time, opportunities for the masses have withered as public demands for more venues, adequate athletic equipment and new clothing go unanswered. Rusak's deputy, Aleksandr Koslovsky, said that his daughter, an avid tennis player, grew so frustrated trying to find an open court that she gave up the sport and turned to table tennis.
''We have only 30 percent of the gymnastics halls we need and only 10 percent of the swimming pools,'' Rusak said. ''The biggest problem is a shortage of equipment and clothing. All of our factories can produce only 7 million pairs of shoes when we need at least 70 million.''
 
Small Turnouts
Interest in watching sports may also be declining. At a recent game to determine the national club championship in basketball, fewer than 1,000 people attended. Rusak said low attendance was more characteristic of competitions staged in Moscow, where the Central Army Club dominates most competition.
But the phenomenon is worrisome to those who view spectator sports as part of the mass programs, which serve as the foundation of the Olympic factory.
''This is a problem that concerns us,'' Rusak said. ''Frankly speaking, I cannot answer the question why Soviet people don't want to attend sports competition. The skill level is quite high. The cost of the tickets is moderately low. We think what influences this are society factors, the way of life, problems with the food supply. Most people, after finishing work, have to run around to shops to look for food and other different goods. This takes a lot of time.''
Frequent critics of the system, like Yuri Vlasov, the 1960 Olympic gold medalist in weight lifting and a member of the Congress of People's Deputies from Moscow, cite the widespread shortages of food and other goods and argue that, for now, Government expenditures for elite sports are entirely inappropriate.
''I represent 300,000 people in the dirtiest, most industrialized district in Moscow,'' he said during an interview in his home. ''The mood among the workers is very gloomy, indeed, and the situation among poor people is worsening increasingly.''
Vlasov charged that the national sports committee was less concerned about developing sports in the Soviet Union than in maintaining the system for personal status and gain.
He said the entire apparatus should be overhauled, with a state committee to run mass sports programs and individual federations to govern each sport living off their own marketing and commercial efforts. In the process, layers of bureaucracy would be eliminated.
The failure to restructure the current system, he contended, could lead to the end of mass sports progams.
''Officials at the sports ministry are completely out of touch with reality,'' Vlasov said. ''The entire country is sitting on a volcano. It is quite possible that all finances from the Government will be withdrawn from sports within the next two or three years. The economic situation of the country is much more serious than ever before. Sports will be impinged; I have not the slightest doubt about that.''
 
Agreement on Need for Change
Rusak and other senior sports officials agree with Vlasov that the system should be restructured. They favor independent federations. They also feel that the sports committee should be responsible for setting up mass programs, overseeing the construction of new venues, scheduling events, running the schools and colleges, publishing sports newspapers and directing scientific research.
But other Government agencies, they say, should pay for it.
''The health of the nation is an affair of the state,' said Marat Gramov, the president of the national Olympic committee and a member of the International Olympic Committee. ''The state has not taken the responsibility for the health of the nation through sports and physical culture. They have not given big money, just kopeks. That's not enough.''
Changes are being planned. Koslovsky, Rusak's deputy, said the national sports committee recently proposed laws to the national Parliament that would lead to the kind of reorganization Vlasov suggested and are similar to those recently adopted by sports leaders in East Germany. Further, the committee has negotiated several joint-venture deals with Western firms, including adidas of West Germany, for plants to produce equipment and clothing.
But change on a grand scale in a country of nearly 290 million is usually painfully slow.
Koslovsky said the changes would take three to five years to go into effect, and the more popular sports, like track and field, basketball and gymnastics, he predicted, would have no trouble finding sponsors. He wonders about the others, leaving him somewhat pessimistic that the changes would do much good over all.
 
'Forced to Change'
''There will definitely be changes,'' he said. ''We are forced to change our type of operation because of the situation in the country. But it's our intention to keep everything good we developed before. When I see the destructive character of change in some of our neighboring countries, I feel our main obligation is to try to preserve what we have managed.''
Change in one area has come faster, much to the dismay of Vlasov and others. Soviet officials have acted with uncommon speed to reward athletes who have performed well in major international competitions.
The practice has been in effect for more than 40 years though not widely known until recently, when the sums awarded have soared. Vladimir Artemov, who won three gold medals at the 1988 Seoul Olympics in gymnastics, said he had received 32,000 rubles, $5,333 at the official exchange rate of 6 rubles to the dollar, plus $1,280 in hard currency - unfathomable amounts to the average Soviet citizen. Champion athletes also wait far less time to get cars and larger apartments.
Koslovsky defended the bonuses, above the athlete's usual salary of 400 rubles a month. He argued that Soviet athletes who train as hard as Western athletes were entitled to equal rewards. Further, athletes can earn such amounts for only a limited number of years, after which many face late entry into the mainstream for which they are not necessarily prepared.
''Without the money, an athlete gets a gold medal and two stories about him in the newspaper,'' Koslovsky said. ''An actor has to receive his flowers on the stage.''
 
Keeping More Money
The committee has also relaxed rules that govern prize money. For years, Soviet athletes competing outside the country were given little more than pocket change while the bulk of their winnings was claimed by the state. Now, they can keep as much as half, with 20 percent of the remainder going to the state as taxes and 30 percent to the national sports committee for use in mass sports programs through payments to clubs and trade unions.
Athletes now are also allowed to retain an agent, although in that case, their tax bite is higher, 69 percent.
Koslovsky contended he had misgivings about capitulating to such changes, saying, ''We feel we have to do it, so we do it.'' But Vlasov contended that Koslovsky and his colleagues were actually eager to satisfy the athletes' demands, as a way of eliminating them as potential threats to their positions.
''Athletes have become more malleable and sheepish, the only way they can survive,'' Vlasov said, adding that he believed none of the country's current sports leaders had the vision to lead the system into the future.
Those leaders, however, seem unfazed by his or anyone else's points of view and undeterred in their resolve to make sure the Soviet Union remains the world's leading Olympic nation.
''I once took a friend to Leningrad to see the summer gardens, planted by Peter the Great,'' Koslovsky said. ''The trees there were planted in 1720 and weren't destroyed by the revolution of 1917 like so many other things. My friend asked me why. 'Because they are part of our culture,' I told him. Elite sports are also part of our culture. We simply have to understand that. I don't know of a single country that would even consider the question, whether or not to develop elite sports. We would be foolish idiots if we made any steps backward. The nation would never forgive us.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 16, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 6, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: A Champion-Turned-Critic

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
The signposts of his life were strewn all about in the old flat he and his wife moved into just days before. Along one wall were scores of unopened cartons, filled with books and papers, the necessities of almost two decades of writing. In a far corner sat a gleaming barbell, the kind he lifted to win an Olympic gold medal in 1960 and set four world records during an eight-year period in which he was known as ''the world's strongest man.''
It is only when Yuri Vlasov starts talking that other evidence of his life's work begins to emerge: the harsh words he uses to criticize sports authorities in the Soviet Union for the way he feels they have sanctified elite sports when the country suffers from so many deficiencies. 
Once an insider, as Olympic champion and later the president of the national weight-lifting federation and, until three years ago, the chairman of the national body-building federation, Vlasov has railed against officials for years, accusing them of corrupt practices and charging that some have even encouraged athletes to use drugs as a way to continue the stream of Olympic medals.
 
Campaign Expands
But during the current economic crisis in the Soviet Union, Vlasov has expanded his campaign, warning that a prolonged emphasis on elite sports will ultimately bankrupt the system, bringing an end to programs for everyday citizens.
''How long the system lasts depends upon the general crisis in the country,'' he said in a recent interview. ''When the general crisis gets really bad, all money will be taken away from the national sports committee. If people stay hungry, there will be an explosion in the near future.''
Vlasov's skepticism toward the sports establishment began early in his career as a competitor, in the late 1950's.
During his training as a student in the Soviet air force academy, he was taught ''hatred toward America,'' an attitude conveniently applied to competition. When he defeated an American, he said, he received larger bonuses than usual.
Sports officials also drummed into him that by establishing athletic superiority, Soviet athletes were demonstrating the superiority of socialism.
 
'Ideological Warfare'
''When I became an athlete, I was told I was waging ideological warfare against the West,'' he said. ''I was told: 'You are the shock force. You have been taken from a vast army of ordinary citizens, handpicked, to fight for our selfless ideals.' The pitch acquired special intensity when we competed against Americans. In weight lifting, Americans were our main enemy. Winning against Americans always had a special priority.
''The paradox was, my hatred for America was combined with a natural sympathy for American people. I had no difficulty combining my ambivalence because we were training for all-out war with America, and we were quite prepared for that event.''
 
Highest Honor
In 1960, he won the gold medal at the Rome Olympics, setting two Olympic and two world records, and for that, he received the Order of Lenin, the highest honor awarded by the state. In 1967 he retired from competition to write books, and has published seven of them. Three others are completed; he is working on another.
Vlasov's open attacks on Soviet sports officials began around the time he retired from competition, when the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes was becoming popular and officials did little to discourage it. While the use of the substances was not banned by international sports organizations until the early 1970's, he said he watched generations of athletes use them, win medals, then suffer adverse side effects. Not much has changed, he said. ''The whole system was designed to squeeze out their last ounce of juice to produce the best results,'' he said. ''We once took random tests of 13- and 14-year-old boys competing in weight lifting. Ninety percent of them tested positive for steroids. This poison seeps down from elite sports, and now the poison has permeated into the masses of coaches and athletes, themselves.''
In separate interviews, several senior sports officials denied that the state had ever sanctioned drug use. Vlasov finds the denials almost amusing.
''If we really discontinued drug use, all of our teams would start losing,'' he said. ''The sports officials would be made the scapegoats, and that's not going to happen. They are simply playing for public sympathies. You cannot be declared a thief unless you get caught red-handed.''
 
Wins Seat in Congress
Vlasov has gained a more formal setting for his outspoken comments. At the urging of friends last spring, he ran for a seat in the Congress of People's Deputies and won when his opponent, fearing defeat, dropped out of the race and moved to a different district, a practice not uncommon in Soviet politics. In one of his first speeches, he stunned the nation by excoriating the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police, the first time such an attack had been mounted from the Parliament podium.
Despite his views on those who run elite sports in the Soviet Union, he said he still loved elite sports and they were necessary. It is the system, he said, that is ''totally rotten.''
''It would be a real crime to conform them to oblivion,'' he said. ''They are part of our human culture. To renounce them completely would be silly.''
